00:02:43.141 --> 00:02:48.590
by 400,000 Hiroshima-class
atomic bombs exploding

00:02:48.614 --> 00:02:51.627
every 24 hours, 365 days a year.

00:02:52.452 --> 00:02:54.270
Fact-checked over and over again,

00:02:54.294 --> 00:02:56.491
conservative, it's the truth.

00:02:56.515 --> 00:02:58.611
Now it's a big planet, but --

00:02:59.089 --> 00:03:01.090
(Explosion sound)

00:03:01.114 --> 00:03:02.737
that is a lot of energy,

00:03:02.761 --> 00:03:08.164
particularly when you multiply it
400,000 times per day.

00:03:08.839 --> 00:03:10.348
And all that extra heat energy

00:03:10.372 --> 00:03:13.348
is heating up the atmosphere,
the whole earth system.

00:03:13.372 --> 00:03:15.322
Let's look at the atmosphere.

00:03:15.346 --> 00:03:16.636
This is a depiction

00:03:16.660 --> 00:03:22.125
of what we used to think of as
the normal distribution of temperatures.

00:03:22.149 --> 00:03:25.236
The white represents
normal temperature days;

00:03:25.260 --> 00:03:28.301
1951-1980 are arbitrarily chosen.

00:03:28.325 --> 00:03:30.205
The blue are cooler than average days,

00:03:30.229 --> 00:03:32.480
the red are warmer than average days.

00:03:32.504 --> 00:03:36.662
But the entire curve has moved
to the right in the 1980s.

00:03:36.686 --> 00:03:38.837
And you'll see
in the lower right-hand corner

00:03:38.861 --> 00:03:41.304
the appearance of statistically
significant numbers

00:03:41.328 --> 00:03:42.906
of extremely hot days.

00:03:42.930 --> 00:03:44.903
In the 90s, the curve shifted further.

00:03:44.927 --> 00:03:48.618
And in the last 10 years,
you see the extremely hot days

00:03:48.642 --> 00:03:52.309
are now more numerous
than the cooler than average days.

00:03:52.333 --> 00:03:57.789
In fact, they are 150 times more common
on the surface of the earth

00:03:57.813 --> 00:04:01.194
than they were just 30 years ago.

00:04:01.671 --> 00:04:04.741
So we're having
record-breaking temperatures.

00:04:04.765 --> 00:04:08.088
Fourteen of the 15 of the hottest years
ever measured with instruments

00:04:08.112 --> 00:04:09.651
have been in this young century.

00:04:09.675 --> 00:04:12.208
The hottest of all was last year.

00:04:12.232 --> 00:04:15.729
Last month was the 371st month in a row

00:04:15.753 --> 00:04:17.920
warmer than the 20th-century average.

00:04:17.944 --> 00:04:21.124
And for the first time,
not only the warmest January,

00:04:21.148 --> 00:04:26.209
but for the first time, it was more
than two degrees Fahrenheit warmer

00:04:26.233 --> 00:04:28.315
than the average.

00:04:28.339 --> 00:04:32.243
These higher temperatures
are having an effect on animals,

00:04:32.267 --> 00:04:35.330
plants, people, ecosystems.

00:04:35.354 --> 00:04:40.276
But on a global basis, 93 percent
of all the extra heat energy

00:04:40.300 --> 00:04:41.716
is trapped in the oceans.

00:04:42.074 --> 00:04:44.281
And the scientists can measure
the heat buildup

00:04:44.305 --> 00:04:45.574
much more precisely now

00:04:45.598 --> 00:04:47.829
at all depths: deep, mid-ocean,

00:04:47.853 --> 00:04:49.893
the first few hundred meters.

00:04:49.917 --> 00:04:52.512
And this, too, is accelerating.

00:04:52.536 --> 00:04:54.165
It goes back more than a century.

00:04:54.189 --> 00:04:58.576
And more than half of the increase
has been in the last 19 years.

00:04:58.600 --> 00:04:59.923
This has consequences.

00:04:59.947 --> 00:05:01.490
The first order of consequence:

00:05:01.514 --> 00:05:03.468
the ocean-based storms get stronger.

00:05:03.492 --> 00:05:05.944
Super Typhoon Haiyan
went over areas of the Pacific

00:05:05.968 --> 00:05:09.287
five and a half degrees Fahrenheit
warmer than normal

00:05:09.311 --> 00:05:11.804
before it slammed into Tacloban,

00:05:11.828 --> 00:05:15.851
as the most destructive storm
ever to make landfall.

00:05:15.875 --> 00:05:20.495
Pope Francis, who has made
such a difference to this whole issue,

00:05:20.519 --> 00:05:22.824
visited Tacloban right after that.

00:05:22.848 --> 00:05:25.427
Superstorm Sandy went over
areas of the Atlantic

00:05:25.451 --> 00:05:27.809
nine degrees warmer than normal

00:05:27.833 --> 00:05:30.720
before slamming into
New York and New Jersey.

00:05:31.912 --> 00:05:35.080
The second order of consequences
are affecting all of us right now.

00:05:35.104 --> 00:05:40.835
The warmer oceans are evaporating
much more water vapor into the skies.

00:05:40.859 --> 00:05:44.689
Average humidity worldwide
has gone up four percent.

00:05:44.713 --> 00:05:47.406
And it creates these atmospheric rivers.

00:05:47.430 --> 00:05:50.448
The Brazilian scientists
call them "flying rivers."

00:05:50.472 --> 00:05:55.215
And they funnel all of that
extra water vapor over the land

00:05:55.239 --> 00:06:00.501
where storm conditions trigger
these massive record-breaking downpours.

00:06:00.525 --> 00:06:03.265
This is from Montana.

00:06:03.289 --> 00:06:05.612
Take a look at this storm last August.

00:06:05.636 --> 00:06:07.955
As it moves over Tucson, Arizona.

00:06:07.979 --> 00:06:11.763
It literally splashes off the city.

00:06:11.787 --> 00:06:14.990
These downpours are really unusual.

00:06:15.014 --> 00:06:18.165
Last July in Houston, Texas,

00:06:18.189 --> 00:06:21.143
it rained for two days,
162 billion gallons.

00:06:21.167 --> 00:06:25.230
That represents more than two days
of the full flow of Niagara Falls

00:06:25.254 --> 00:06:26.499
in the middle of the city,

00:06:26.523 --> 00:06:28.426
which was, of course, paralyzed.

00:06:28.450 --> 00:06:32.798
These record downpours are creating
historic floods and mudslides.

00:06:32.822 --> 00:06:36.236
This one is from Chile last year.

00:06:37.133 --> 00:06:40.276
And you'll see that warehouse going by.

00:06:40.300 --> 00:06:42.904
There are oil tankers cars going by.

00:06:42.928 --> 00:06:44.864
This is from Spain last September,

00:06:44.888 --> 00:06:48.982
you could call this the running
of the cars and trucks, I guess.

00:06:49.823 --> 00:06:52.651
Every night on the TV news now
is like a nature hike

00:06:52.675 --> 00:06:54.206
through the Book of Revelation.

00:06:54.533 --> 00:06:56.924
(Laughter)

00:06:56.948 --> 00:06:58.309
I mean, really.

00:06:59.014 --> 00:07:01.660
The insurance industry
has certainly noticed,

00:07:01.684 --> 00:07:03.904
the losses have been mounting up.

00:07:03.928 --> 00:07:07.526
They're not under any illusions
about what's happening.

00:07:07.930 --> 00:07:13.200
And the causality requires
a moment of discussion.

00:07:13.224 --> 00:07:16.538
We're used to thinking of linear cause
and linear effect --

00:07:16.562 --> 00:07:17.713
one cause, one effect.

00:07:17.737 --> 00:07:20.539
This is systemic causation.

00:07:20.967 --> 00:07:23.206
As the great Kevin Trenberth says,

00:07:23.230 --> 00:07:24.690
"All storms are different now.

00:07:24.714 --> 00:07:26.953
There's so much extra energy
in the atmosphere,

00:07:26.977 --> 00:07:28.642
there's so much extra water vapor.

00:07:28.666 --> 00:07:31.659
Every storm is different now."

00:07:31.683 --> 00:07:36.024
So, the same extra heat pulls
the soil moisture out of the ground

00:07:36.048 --> 00:07:40.458
and causes these deeper, longer,
more pervasive droughts

00:07:40.482 --> 00:07:42.572
and many of them are underway right now.

00:07:42.596 --> 00:07:44.110
It dries out the vegetation

00:07:44.134 --> 00:07:47.796
and causes more fires
in the western part of North America.

00:07:47.820 --> 00:07:51.279
There's certainly been evidence
of that, a lot of them.

00:07:51.303 --> 00:07:52.454
More lightning,

00:07:52.478 --> 00:07:55.260
as the heat energy builds up,
there's a considerable amount

00:07:55.284 --> 00:07:58.104
of additional lightning also.

00:07:58.668 --> 00:08:05.536
These climate-related disasters also have
geopolitical consequences

00:08:05.560 --> 00:08:07.370
and create instability.

00:08:07.394 --> 00:08:12.670
The climate-related historic drought
that started in Syria in 2006

00:08:12.694 --> 00:08:15.646
destroyed 60 percent
of the farms in Syria,

00:08:15.670 --> 00:08:18.011
killed 80 percent of the livestock,

00:08:18.035 --> 00:08:22.254
and drove 1.5 million climate refugees
into the cities of Syria,

00:08:22.278 --> 00:08:25.507
where they collided with another
1.5 million refugees

00:08:25.531 --> 00:08:27.547
from the Iraq War.

00:08:27.943 --> 00:08:32.168
And along with other factors,
that opened the gates of Hell

00:08:32.192 --> 00:08:35.372
that people are trying to close now.

00:08:35.396 --> 00:08:37.810
The US Defense Department has long warned

00:08:37.834 --> 00:08:40.132
of consequences from the climate crisis,

00:08:40.156 --> 00:08:44.683
including refugees,
food and water shortages

00:08:44.707 --> 00:08:46.587
and pandemic disease.

00:08:46.611 --> 00:08:51.340
Right now we're seeing microbial diseases
from the tropics spread

00:08:51.364 --> 00:08:52.624
to the higher latitudes;

00:08:52.648 --> 00:08:56.266
the transportation revolution has had
a lot to do with this.

00:08:56.290 --> 00:08:59.955
But the changing conditions
change the latitudes and the areas

00:08:59.979 --> 00:09:03.812
where these microbial diseases
can become endemic

00:09:03.836 --> 00:09:08.575
and change the range of the vectors,
like mosquitoes and ticks that carry them.

00:09:08.599 --> 00:09:12.067
The Zika epidemic now --

00:09:12.091 --> 00:09:14.008
we're better positioned in North America

00:09:14.032 --> 00:09:18.722
because it's still a little too cool
and we have a better public health system.

00:09:18.746 --> 00:09:23.046
But when women in some regions
of South and Central America

00:09:23.070 --> 00:09:25.781
are advised not to get pregnant
for two years --

00:09:25.805 --> 00:09:29.078
that's something new,
that ought to get our attention.

00:09:29.919 --> 00:09:33.067
The Lancet, one of the two greatest
medical journals in the world,

00:09:33.091 --> 00:09:37.321
last summer labeled this
a medical emergency now.

00:09:37.345 --> 00:09:40.007
And there are many factors because of it.

00:09:40.031 --> 00:09:42.828
This is also connected
to the extinction crisis.

00:09:42.852 --> 00:09:46.399
We're in danger of losing 50 percent
of all the living species on earth

00:09:46.423 --> 00:09:47.746
by the end of this century.

00:09:47.770 --> 00:09:50.532
And already, land-based plants and animals

00:09:50.556 --> 00:09:52.204
are now moving towards the poles

00:09:52.228 --> 00:09:55.611
at an average rate of 15 feet per day.

00:09:56.619 --> 00:09:57.929
Speaking of the North Pole,

00:09:57.953 --> 00:10:03.223
last December 29, the same storm
that caused historic flooding

00:10:03.247 --> 00:10:04.896
in the American Midwest,

00:10:04.920 --> 00:10:07.103
raised temperatures at the North Pole

00:10:07.127 --> 00:10:09.757
50 degrees Fahrenheit warmer than normal,

00:10:09.781 --> 00:10:12.219
causing the thawing of the North Pole

00:10:12.243 --> 00:10:16.855
in the middle of the long,
dark, winter, polar night.

00:10:16.879 --> 00:10:20.461
And when the land-based ice
of the Arctic melts,

00:10:20.485 --> 00:10:22.203
it raises sea level.

00:10:22.227 --> 00:10:25.972
Paul Nicklen's beautiful photograph
from Svalbard illustrates this.

00:10:26.432 --> 00:10:28.392
It's more dangerous coming off Greenland

00:10:28.416 --> 00:10:30.422
and particularly, Antarctica.

00:10:30.446 --> 00:10:35.136
The 10 largest risk cities
for sea-level rise by population

00:10:35.160 --> 00:10:37.899
are mostly in South and Southeast Asia.

00:10:37.923 --> 00:10:42.032
When you measure it by assets at risk,
number one is Miami:

00:10:42.056 --> 00:10:44.679
three and a half trillion dollars at risk.

00:10:44.703 --> 00:10:46.374
Number three: New York and Newark.

00:10:46.398 --> 00:10:49.694
I was in Miami last fall
during the supermoon,

00:10:49.718 --> 00:10:52.829
one of the highest high-tide days.

00:10:52.853 --> 00:10:55.985
And there were fish from the ocean
swimming in some of the streets

00:10:56.009 --> 00:10:58.160
of Miami Beach and Fort Lauderdale

00:10:58.184 --> 00:10:59.358
and Del Rey.

00:10:59.382 --> 00:11:02.356
And this happens regularly
during the highest-tide tides now.

00:11:02.380 --> 00:11:04.995
Not with rain -- they call it
"sunny-day flooding."

00:11:05.019 --> 00:11:09.570
It comes up through the storm sewers.

00:11:09.594 --> 00:11:13.958
And the Mayor of Miami
speaks for many when he says

00:11:13.982 --> 00:11:18.205
it is long past time this can be viewed
through a partisan lens.

00:11:18.229 --> 00:11:21.365
This is a crisis
that's getting worse day by day.

00:11:21.389 --> 00:11:23.710
We have to move beyond partisanship.

00:11:23.734 --> 00:11:26.996
And I want to take a moment
to honor these House Republicans --

00:11:27.020 --> 00:11:28.074
(Applause)

00:11:28.098 --> 00:11:30.931
who had the courage last fall

00:11:30.955 --> 00:11:35.389
to step out and take a political risk,

00:11:35.413 --> 00:11:38.152
by telling the truth
about the climate crisis.

00:11:38.176 --> 00:11:41.333
So the cost of the climate
crisis is mounting up,

00:11:41.357 --> 00:11:45.025
there are many of these aspects
I haven't even mentioned.

00:11:45.049 --> 00:11:47.022
It's an enormous burden.

00:11:47.046 --> 00:11:48.610
I'll mention just one more,

00:11:48.634 --> 00:11:53.361
because the World Economic Forum
last month in Davos,

00:11:53.385 --> 00:11:56.402
after their annual survey
of 750 economists,

00:11:56.426 --> 00:11:59.286
said the climate crisis is now
the number one risk

00:11:59.310 --> 00:12:01.139
to the global economy.

00:12:01.163 --> 00:12:02.481
So you get central bankers

00:12:02.505 --> 00:12:05.275
like Mark Carney, the head
of the UK Central Bank,

00:12:05.299 --> 00:12:09.335
saying the vast majority
of the carbon reserves are unburnable.

00:12:09.359 --> 00:12:11.105
Subprime carbon.

00:12:11.129 --> 00:12:14.420
I'm not going to remind you what happened
with subprime mortgages,

00:12:14.444 --> 00:12:16.046
but it's the same thing.

00:12:16.070 --> 00:12:18.785
If you look at all of the carbon fuels
that were burned

00:12:18.809 --> 00:12:21.479
since the beginning
of the industrial revolution,

00:12:21.503 --> 00:12:25.019
this is the quantity burned
in the last 16 years.

00:12:25.043 --> 00:12:28.622
Here are all the ones that are proven
and left on the books,

00:12:28.646 --> 00:12:30.434
28 trillion dollars.

00:12:30.458 --> 00:12:34.667
The International Energy Agency
says only this amount can be burned.

00:12:34.691 --> 00:12:37.580
So the rest, 22 trillion dollars --

00:12:37.604 --> 00:12:38.801
unburnable.

00:12:39.261 --> 00:12:41.494
Risk to the global economy.

00:12:41.518 --> 00:12:44.555
That's why divestment movement
makes practical sense

00:12:44.579 --> 00:12:47.159
and is not just a moral imperative.

00:12:47.183 --> 00:12:51.353
So the answer to the first question,
"Must we change?"

00:12:51.377 --> 00:12:53.301
is yes, we have to change.

00:12:53.325 --> 00:12:55.077
Second question, "Can we change?"

00:12:55.101 --> 00:12:57.422
This is the exciting news!

00:12:57.446 --> 00:13:00.951
The best projections
in the world 16 years ago

00:13:00.975 --> 00:13:05.006
were that by 2010, the world
would be able to install

00:13:05.030 --> 00:13:07.197
30 gigawatts of wind capacity.

00:13:07.221 --> 00:13:12.212
We beat that mark
by 14 and a half times over.

00:13:12.236 --> 00:13:16.020
We see an exponential curve
for wind installations now.

00:13:16.044 --> 00:13:19.619
We see the cost coming down dramatically.

00:13:19.643 --> 00:13:22.893
Some countries -- take Germany,
an industrial powerhouse

00:13:22.917 --> 00:13:26.285
with a climate not that different
from Vancouver's, by the way --

00:13:26.309 --> 00:13:27.944
one day last December,

00:13:27.968 --> 00:13:31.406
got 81 percent of all its energy
from renewable resources,

00:13:31.430 --> 00:13:33.063
mainly solar and wind.

00:13:33.087 --> 00:13:36.388
A lot of countries are getting
more than half on an average basis.

00:13:36.412 --> 00:13:37.570
More good news:

00:13:37.594 --> 00:13:40.617
energy storage,
from batteries particularly,

00:13:40.641 --> 00:13:42.235
is now beginning to take off

00:13:42.259 --> 00:13:46.052
because the cost has been
coming down very dramatically

00:13:46.076 --> 00:13:47.849
to solve the intermittency problem.

00:13:47.873 --> 00:13:50.384
With solar, the news is even
more exciting!

00:13:50.408 --> 00:13:53.757
The best projections 14 years ago
were that we would install

00:13:53.781 --> 00:13:56.328
one gigawatt per year by 2010.

00:13:56.352 --> 00:14:00.972
When 2010 came around,
we beat that mark by 17 times over.

00:14:00.996 --> 00:14:04.581
Last year, we beat it by 58 times over.

00:14:04.605 --> 00:14:07.845
This year, we're on track
to beat it 68 times over.

00:14:07.869 --> 00:14:09.059
We're going to win this.

00:14:09.083 --> 00:14:10.817
We are going to prevail.

00:14:10.841 --> 00:14:14.924
The exponential curve on solar
is even steeper and more dramatic.

00:14:14.948 --> 00:14:16.877
When I came to this stage 10 years ago,

00:14:16.901 --> 00:14:18.296
this is where it was.

00:14:18.852 --> 00:14:22.406
We have seen a revolutionary breakthrough

00:14:22.430 --> 00:14:25.619
in the emergence
of these exponential curves.

00:14:25.643 --> 00:14:28.867
(Applause)

00:14:28.891 --> 00:14:32.388
And the cost has come down
10 percent per year

00:14:32.412 --> 00:14:33.711
for 30 years.

00:14:33.735 --> 00:14:36.033
And it's continuing to come down.

00:14:36.057 --> 00:14:38.703
Now, the business community
has certainly noticed this,

00:14:38.727 --> 00:14:41.536
because it's crossing
the grid parity point.

00:14:41.560 --> 00:14:44.812
Cheaper solar penetration rates
are beginning to rise.

00:14:44.836 --> 00:14:48.352
Grid parity is understood
as that line, that threshold,

00:14:48.376 --> 00:14:52.250
below which renewable electricity
is cheaper than electricity

00:14:52.274 --> 00:14:54.492
from burning fossil fuels.

00:14:54.516 --> 00:14:57.209
That threshold is a little bit
like the difference

00:14:57.233 --> 00:15:01.343
between 32 degrees Fahrenheit
and 33 degrees Fahrenheit,

00:15:01.367 --> 00:15:02.953
or zero and one Celsius.

00:15:02.977 --> 00:15:05.001
It's a difference of more than one degree,

00:15:05.025 --> 00:15:07.726
it's the difference between ice and water.

00:15:07.750 --> 00:15:11.694
And it's the difference between markets
that are frozen up,

00:15:11.718 --> 00:15:16.250
and liquid flows of capital
into new opportunities for investment.

00:15:16.274 --> 00:15:19.879
This is the biggest
new business opportunity

00:15:19.903 --> 00:15:21.435
in the history of the world,

00:15:21.459 --> 00:15:24.607
and two-thirds of it
is in the private sector.

00:15:24.631 --> 00:15:28.067
We are seeing an explosion
of new investment.

00:15:28.091 --> 00:15:33.659
Starting in 2010, investments globally
in renewable electricity generation

00:15:33.683 --> 00:15:35.216
surpassed fossils.

00:15:35.240 --> 00:15:37.656
The gap has been growing ever since.

00:15:37.680 --> 00:15:40.628
The projections for the future
are even more dramatic,

00:15:40.652 --> 00:15:44.251
even though fossil energy
is now still subsidized

00:15:44.275 --> 00:15:47.502
at a rate 40 times larger than renewables.

00:15:47.526 --> 00:15:51.616
And by the way, if you add
the projections for nuclear on here,

00:15:51.640 --> 00:15:54.261
particularly if you assume
that the work many are doing

00:15:54.285 --> 00:15:56.999
to try to break through to safer
and more acceptable,

00:15:57.023 --> 00:15:58.862
more affordable forms of nuclear,

00:15:58.886 --> 00:16:01.329
this could change even more dramatically.

00:16:01.892 --> 00:16:04.848
So is there any precedent
for such a rapid adoption

00:16:04.872 --> 00:16:06.601
of a new technology?

00:16:06.625 --> 00:16:09.085
Well, there are many,
but let's look at cell phones.

00:16:09.109 --> 00:16:12.482
In 1980, AT&T, then Ma Bell,

00:16:12.506 --> 00:16:14.899
commissioned McKinsey to do
a global market survey

00:16:14.923 --> 00:16:18.539
of those clunky new mobile phones
that appeared then.

00:16:18.563 --> 00:16:21.726
"How many can we sell
by the year 2000?" they asked.

00:16:21.750 --> 00:16:24.318
McKinsey came back and said, "900,000."

00:16:24.342 --> 00:16:26.414
And sure enough,
when the year 2000 arrived,

00:16:26.438 --> 00:16:29.016
they did sell 900,000 --
in the first three days.

00:16:29.040 --> 00:16:32.952
And for the balance of the year,
they sold 120 times more.

00:16:32.976 --> 00:16:37.352
And now there are more cell connections
than there are people in the world.

00:16:37.376 --> 00:16:41.845
So, why were they not only wrong,
but way wrong?

00:16:41.869 --> 00:16:44.269
I've asked that question myself, "Why?"

00:16:44.293 --> 00:16:45.296
(Laughter)

00:16:45.320 --> 00:16:47.553
And I think the answer is in three parts.

00:16:48.080 --> 00:16:51.469
First, the cost came down much faster
than anybody expected,

00:16:51.493 --> 00:16:54.000
even as the quality went up.

00:16:54.024 --> 00:16:58.296
And low-income countries, places
that did not have a landline grid --

00:16:58.320 --> 00:17:00.548
they leap-frogged to the new technology.

00:17:00.572 --> 00:17:03.636
The big expansion has been
in the developing counties.

00:17:03.660 --> 00:17:07.408
So what about the electricity grids
in the developing world?

00:17:07.432 --> 00:17:09.162
Well, not so hot.

00:17:09.186 --> 00:17:11.484
And in many areas, they don't exist.

00:17:11.508 --> 00:17:14.654
There are more people
without any electricity at all in India

00:17:14.678 --> 00:17:17.800
than the entire population
of the United States of America.

00:17:17.824 --> 00:17:19.328
So now we're getting this:

00:17:19.352 --> 00:17:21.190
solar panels on grass huts

00:17:21.214 --> 00:17:24.152
and new business models
that make it affordable.

00:17:24.176 --> 00:17:29.061
Muhammad Yunus financed
this one in Bangladesh with micro-credit.

00:17:29.085 --> 00:17:30.793
This is a village market.

00:17:30.817 --> 00:17:33.707
Bangladesh is now the fastest-deploying
country in the world:

00:17:33.731 --> 00:17:36.143
two systems per minute
on average, night and day.

00:17:36.167 --> 00:17:37.356
And we have all we need:

00:17:37.380 --> 00:17:39.672
enough energy from the Sun
comes to the earth

00:17:39.696 --> 00:17:45.059
every hour to supply the full world's
energy needs for an entire year.

00:17:45.083 --> 00:17:47.256
It's actually a little bit
less than an hour.

00:17:47.280 --> 00:17:50.612
So the answer to the second question,
"Can we change?"

00:17:50.636 --> 00:17:52.559
is clearly "Yes."

00:17:52.583 --> 00:17:55.355
And it's an ever-firmer "yes."

00:17:55.379 --> 00:17:57.987
Last question, "Will we change?"

00:17:58.011 --> 00:18:00.003
Paris really was a breakthrough,

00:18:00.027 --> 00:18:01.690
some of the provisions are binding

00:18:01.714 --> 00:18:03.752
and the regular reviews will matter a lot.

00:18:03.776 --> 00:18:06.027
But nations aren't waiting,
they're going ahead.

00:18:06.051 --> 00:18:08.566
China has already announced
that starting next year,

00:18:08.590 --> 00:18:11.573
they're adopting a nationwide
cap and trade system.

00:18:11.597 --> 00:18:14.740
They will likely link up
with the European Union.

00:18:14.764 --> 00:18:17.256
The United States
has already been changing.

00:18:17.280 --> 00:18:19.330
All of these coal plants were proposed

00:18:19.354 --> 00:18:21.884
in the next 10 years and canceled.

00:18:21.908 --> 00:18:24.827
All of these existing
coal plants were retired.

00:18:24.851 --> 00:18:27.868
All of these coal plants have had
their retirement announced.

00:18:27.892 --> 00:18:30.220
All of them -- canceled.

00:18:30.244 --> 00:18:31.734
We are moving forward.

00:18:31.758 --> 00:18:34.226
Last year -- if you look at
all of the investment

00:18:34.250 --> 00:18:37.193
in new electricity generation
in the United States,

00:18:37.217 --> 00:18:39.883
almost three-quarters
was from renewable energy,

00:18:39.907 --> 00:18:42.419
mostly wind and solar.

00:18:42.443 --> 00:18:45.590
We are solving this crisis.

00:18:45.614 --> 00:18:50.513
The only question is:
how long will it take to get there?

00:18:50.537 --> 00:18:55.154
So, it matters that a lot
of people are organizing

00:18:55.178 --> 00:18:57.316
to insist on this change.

00:18:57.340 --> 00:19:01.124
Almost 400,000 people
marched in New York City

00:19:01.148 --> 00:19:03.995
before the UN special session on this.

00:19:04.019 --> 00:19:06.023
Many thousands, tens of thousands,

00:19:06.047 --> 00:19:08.920
marched in cities around the world.

00:19:08.944 --> 00:19:13.087
And so, I am extremely optimistic.

00:19:13.111 --> 00:19:15.666
As I said before,
we are going to win this.

00:19:15.690 --> 00:19:17.657
I'll finish with this story.

00:19:18.176 --> 00:19:20.768
When I was 13 years old,

00:19:20.792 --> 00:19:24.223
I heard that proposal by President Kennedy

00:19:24.247 --> 00:19:26.798
to land a person on the Moon
and bring him back safely

00:19:26.822 --> 00:19:27.987
in 10 years.

00:19:28.011 --> 00:19:30.995
And I heard adults
of that day and time say,

00:19:31.019 --> 00:19:34.536
"That's reckless, expensive,
may well fail."

00:19:34.560 --> 00:19:36.737
But eight years and two months later,

00:19:36.761 --> 00:19:40.023
in the moment that Neil Armstrong
set foot on the Moon,

00:19:40.047 --> 00:19:44.637
there was great cheer that went up
in NASA's mission control in Houston.

00:19:44.661 --> 00:19:47.121
Here's a little-known fact about that:

00:19:47.145 --> 00:19:49.350
the average age of the systems engineers,

00:19:49.374 --> 00:19:52.550
the controllers in the room
that day, was 26,

00:19:52.574 --> 00:19:54.133
which means, among other things,

00:19:54.157 --> 00:19:57.407
their age, when they heard
that challenge, was 18.

00:19:57.431 --> 00:20:00.633
We now have a moral challenge

00:20:00.657 --> 00:20:04.187
that is in the tradition of others
that we have faced.

00:20:04.211 --> 00:20:07.865
One of the greatest poets
of the last century in the US,

00:20:07.889 --> 00:20:09.238
Wallace Stevens,

00:20:09.262 --> 00:20:11.080
wrote a line that has stayed with me:

00:20:11.104 --> 00:20:13.587
"After the final 'no,'
there comes a 'yes,'

00:20:13.611 --> 00:20:16.592
and on that 'yes',
the future world depends."

00:20:16.616 --> 00:20:18.901
When the abolitionists
started their movement,

00:20:18.925 --> 00:20:21.132
they met with no after no after no.

00:20:21.156 --> 00:20:22.432
And then came a yes.

00:20:22.456 --> 00:20:24.845
The Women's Suffrage
and Women's Rights Movement

00:20:24.869 --> 00:20:28.464
met endless no's, until finally,
there was a yes.

00:20:28.488 --> 00:20:31.259
The Civil Rights Movement,
the movement against apartheid,

00:20:31.283 --> 00:20:34.874
and more recently, the movement
for gay and lesbian rights

00:20:34.898 --> 00:20:37.303
here in the United States and elsewhere.

00:20:37.327 --> 00:20:39.503
After the final "no" comes a "yes."

00:20:39.527 --> 00:20:44.660
When any great moral challenge
is ultimately resolved

00:20:44.684 --> 00:20:48.539
into a binary choice
between what is right and what is wrong,

00:20:48.563 --> 00:20:52.692
the outcome is fore-ordained
because of who we are as human beings.

00:20:52.716 --> 00:20:56.569
Ninety-nine percent of us,
that is where we are now

00:20:56.593 --> 00:20:59.085
and it is why we're going to win this.

00:20:59.109 --> 00:21:01.047
We have everything we need.

00:21:01.071 --> 00:21:04.486
Some still doubt that we have
the will to act,

00:21:04.510 --> 00:21:09.200
but I say the will to act is itself
a renewable resource.

00:21:09.224 --> 00:21:10.431
Thank you very much.

00:21:10.455 --> 00:21:13.926
(Applause)

00:21:47.277 --> 00:21:50.460
Chris Anderson: You've got this incredible
combination of skills.

00:21:50.484 --> 00:21:53.445
You've got this scientist mind
that can understand

00:21:53.469 --> 00:21:55.770
the full range of issues,

00:21:55.794 --> 00:21:59.446
and the ability to turn it
into the most vivid language.

00:21:59.470 --> 00:22:02.353
No one else can do that,
that's why you led this thing.

00:22:02.377 --> 00:22:05.788
It was amazing to see it 10 years ago,
it was amazing to see it now.

00:22:05.812 --> 00:22:07.987
Al Gore: Well, you're nice
to say that, Chris.

00:22:08.011 --> 00:22:11.172
But honestly, I have a lot
of really good friends

00:22:11.196 --> 00:22:14.915
in the scientific community
who are incredibly patient

00:22:14.939 --> 00:22:17.710
and who will sit there
and explain this stuff to me

00:22:17.734 --> 00:22:19.068
over and over and over again

00:22:19.092 --> 00:22:22.688
until I can get it
into simple enough language

00:22:22.712 --> 00:22:23.924
that I can understand it.

00:22:23.948 --> 00:22:26.876
And that's the key to trying
to communicate.

00:22:27.455 --> 00:22:31.140
CA: So, your talk. First part: terrifying,

00:22:31.164 --> 00:22:33.101
second part: incredibly hopeful.

00:22:33.768 --> 00:22:39.069
How do we know that all those graphs,
all that progress, is enough

00:22:39.093 --> 00:22:41.821
to solve what you showed
in the first part?

00:22:41.845 --> 00:22:45.373
AG: I think that the crossing --

00:22:45.397 --> 00:22:48.410
you know, I've only been
in the business world for 15 years.

00:22:48.434 --> 00:22:51.712
But one of the things I've learned
is that apparently it matters

00:22:51.736 --> 00:22:54.900
if a new product or service
is more expensive

00:22:54.924 --> 00:22:57.078
than the incumbent, or cheaper than.

00:22:57.102 --> 00:22:59.657
Turns out, it makes a difference
if it's cheaper than.

00:22:59.681 --> 00:23:00.776
(Laughter)

00:23:00.800 --> 00:23:03.494
And when it crosses that line,

00:23:03.518 --> 00:23:05.414
then a lot of things really change.

00:23:05.438 --> 00:23:08.383
We are regularly surprised
by these developments.

00:23:08.407 --> 00:23:10.954
The late Rudi Dornbusch,
the great economist said,

00:23:10.978 --> 00:23:13.774
"Things take longer to happen
then you think they will,

00:23:13.798 --> 00:23:16.756
and then they happen much faster
than you thought they could."

00:23:16.780 --> 00:23:18.478
I really think that's where we are.

00:23:18.502 --> 00:23:22.179
Some people are using the phrase
"The Solar Singularity" now,

00:23:22.203 --> 00:23:25.496
meaning when it gets
below the grid parity,

00:23:25.520 --> 00:23:27.568
unsubsidized in most places,

00:23:27.592 --> 00:23:29.234
then it's the default choice.

00:23:29.258 --> 00:23:35.248
Now, in one of the presentations
yesterday, the jitney thing,

00:23:35.272 --> 00:23:40.379
there is an effort to use
regulations to slow this down.

00:23:40.403 --> 00:23:43.542
And I just don't think it's going to work.

00:23:44.566 --> 00:23:46.962
There's a woman in Atlanta, Debbie Dooley,

00:23:46.986 --> 00:23:49.067
who's the Chairman
of the Atlanta Tea Party.

00:23:49.091 --> 00:23:51.268
They enlisted her
in this effort to put a tax

00:23:51.292 --> 00:23:53.415
on solar panels and regulations.

00:23:53.439 --> 00:23:55.558
And she had just put
solar panels on her roof

00:23:55.582 --> 00:23:57.448
and she didn't understand the request.

00:23:57.472 --> 00:23:59.237
(Laughter)

00:23:59.261 --> 00:24:02.739
And so she went and formed
an alliance with the Sierra Club

00:24:02.763 --> 00:24:06.816
and they formed a new organization
called the Green Tea Party.

00:24:06.840 --> 00:24:07.842
(Laughter)

00:24:07.866 --> 00:24:08.867
(Applause)

00:24:08.891 --> 00:24:10.379
And they defeated the proposal.

00:24:10.403 --> 00:24:13.629
So, finally, the answer
to your question is,

00:24:13.653 --> 00:24:16.686
this sounds a little corny
and maybe it's a cliché,

00:24:16.710 --> 00:24:20.226
but 10 years ago -- and Christiana
referred to this --

00:24:20.250 --> 00:24:26.157
there are people in this audience
who played an incredibly significant role

00:24:26.181 --> 00:24:28.982
in generating those exponential curves.

00:24:29.006 --> 00:24:31.530
And it didn't work out economically
for some of them,

00:24:31.554 --> 00:24:34.608
but it kick-started
this global revolution.

00:24:34.632 --> 00:24:38.411
And what people in this audience do now

00:24:38.435 --> 00:24:40.940
with the knowledge
that we are going to win this.

00:24:40.964 --> 00:24:45.194
But it matters a lot how fast we win it.

00:24:45.218 --> 00:24:47.575
CA: Al Gore, that was incredibly powerful.

00:24:47.599 --> 00:24:49.274
If this turns out to be the year,

00:24:49.298 --> 00:24:52.126
that the partisan thing changes,

00:24:52.150 --> 00:24:55.528
as you said, it's no longer
a partisan issue,

00:24:55.552 --> 00:24:59.718
but you bring along people
from the other side together,

00:24:59.742 --> 00:25:03.027
backed by science, backed by these kinds
of investment opportunities,

00:25:03.051 --> 00:25:05.159
backed by reason that you win the day --

00:25:05.183 --> 00:25:07.542
boy, that's really exciting.

00:25:07.566 --> 00:25:08.734
Thank you so much.

00:25:08.758 --> 00:25:11.265
AG: Thank you so much
for bringing me back to TED.

00:25:11.289 --> 00:25:12.440
Thank you!

00:25:12.464 --> 00:25:15.070
(Applause)

title: What it's like to be Muslim in America
transcript: What do you think when you look at me? A woman of faith? An expert? Maybe even a sister. Or oppressed, brainwashed, a terrorist. Or just an airport security line delay. That one's actually true.(Laughter)If some of your perceptions were negative, I don't really blame you. That's just how the media has been portraying people who look like me. One study found that 80 percent of news coverage about Islam and Muslims is negative. And studies show that Americans say that most don't know a Muslim. I guess people don't talk to their Uber drivers.(Laughter)Well, for those of you who have never met a Muslim, it's great to meet you. Let me tell you who I am. I'm a mom, a coffee lover — double espresso, cream on the side. I'm an introvert. I'm a wannabe fitness fanatic. And I'm a practicing, spiritual Muslim. But not like Lady Gaga says, because baby, I wasn't born this way. It was a choice.When I was 17, I decided to come out. No, not as a gay person like some of my friends, but as a Muslim, and decided to start wearing the hijab, my head covering. My feminist friends were aghast: "Why are you oppressing yourself?" The funny thing was, it was actually at that time a feminist declaration of independence from the pressure I felt as a 17-year-old, to conform to a perfect and unattainable standard of beauty. I didn't just passively accept the faith of my parents. I wrestled with the Quran. I read and reflected and questioned and doubted and, ultimately, believed. My relationship with God — it was not love at first sight. It was a trust and a slow surrender that deepened with every reading of the Quran. Its rhythmic beauty sometimes moves me to tears. I see myself in it. I feel that God knows me. Have you ever felt like someone sees you, completely understands you and yet loves you anyway? That's how it feels.And so later, I got married, and like all good Egyptians, started my career as an engineer.(Laughter)I later had a child, after getting married, and I was living essentially the Egyptian-American dream.And then that terrible morning of September, 2001. I think a lot of you probably remember exactly where you were that morning. I was sitting in my kitchen finishing breakfast, and I look up on the screen and see the words "Breaking News." There was smoke, airplanes flying into buildings, people jumping out of buildings. What was this? An accident? A malfunction? My shock quickly turned to outrage. Who would do this? And I switch the channel and I hear,"... Muslim terrorist ...," "... in the name of Islam ...," "... Middle-Eastern descent ...," "... jihad ...," "... we should bomb Mecca." Oh my God.Not only had my country been attacked, but in a flash, somebody else's actions had turned me from a citizen to a suspect.That same day, we had to drive across Middle America to move to a new city to start grad school. And I remember sitting in the passenger seat as we drove in silence, crouched as low as I could go in my seat, for the first time in my life, afraid for anyone to know I was a Muslim.We moved into our apartment that night in a new town in what felt like a completely different world. And then I was hearing and seeing and reading warnings from national Muslim organizations saying things like, "Be alert," "Be aware," "Stay in well-lit areas," "Don't congregate."I stayed inside all week. And then it was Friday that same week, the day that Muslims congregate for worship. And again the warnings were, "Don't go that first Friday, it could be a target." And I was watching the news, wall-to-wall coverage. Emotions were so raw, understandably, and I was also hearing about attacks on Muslims, or people who were perceived to be Muslim, being pulled out and beaten in the street. Mosques were actually firebombed. And I thought, we should just stay home.And yet, something didn't feel right. Because those people who attacked our country attacked our country. I get it that people were angry at the terrorists. Guess what? So was I. And so to have to explain yourself all the time isn't easy. I don't mind questions. I love questions. It's the accusations that are tough.Today we hear people actually saying things like, "There's a problem in this country, and it's called Muslims. When are we going to get rid of them?" So, some people want to ban Muslims and close down mosques. They talk about my community kind of like we're a tumor in the body of America. And the only question is, are we malignant or benign? You know, a malignant tumor you extract altogether, and a benign tumor you just keep under surveillance.The choices don't make sense, because it's the wrong question. Muslims, like all other Americans, aren't a tumor in the body of America, we're a vital organ.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)Muslims are inventors and teachers, first responders and Olympic athletes.Now, is closing down mosques going to make America safer? It might free up some parking spots, but it will not end terrorism. Going to a mosque regularly is actually linked to having more tolerant views of people of other faiths and greater civic engagement. And as one police chief in the Washington, DC area recently told me, people don't actually get radicalized at mosques. They get radicalized in their basement or bedroom, in front of a computer. And what you find about the radicalization process is it starts online, but the first thing that happens is the person gets cut off from their community, from even their family, so that the extremist group can brainwash them into believing that they, the terrorists, are the true Muslims, and everyone else who abhors their behavior and ideology are sellouts or apostates. So if we want to prevent radicalization, we have to keep people going to the mosque.Now, some will still argue Islam is a violent religion. After all, a group like ISIS bases its brutality on the Quran. Now, as a Muslim, as a mother, as a human being, I think we need to do everything we can to stop a group like ISIS. But we would be giving in to their narrative if we cast them as representatives of a faith of 1.6 billion people.(Applause)Thank you.ISIS has as much to do with Islam as the Ku Klux Klan has to do with Christianity.(Applause)Both groups claim to base their ideology on their holy book. But when you look at them, they're not motivated by what they read in their holy book. It's their brutality that makes them read these things into the scripture.Recently, a prominent imam told me a story that really took me aback. He said that a girl came to him because she was thinking of going to join ISIS. And I was really surprised and asked him, had she been in contact with a radical religious leader? And he said the problem was quite the opposite, that every cleric that she had talked to had shut her down and said that her rage, her sense of injustice in the world, was just going to get her in trouble. And so with nowhere to channel and make sense of this anger, she was a prime target to be exploited by extremists promising her a solution. What this imam did was to connect her back to God and to her community. He didn't shame her for her rage — instead, he gave her constructive ways to make real change in the world. What she learned at that mosque prevented her from going to join ISIS.I've told you a little bit about how Islamophobia affects me and my family. But how does it impact ordinary Americans? How does it impact everyone else? How does consuming fear 24 hours a day affect the health of our democracy, the health of our free thought?Well, one study — actually, several studies in neuroscience — show that when we're afraid, at least three things happen. We become more accepting of authoritarianism, conformity and prejudice. One study showed that when subjects were exposed to news stories that were negative about Muslims, they became more accepting of military attacks on Muslim countries and policies that curtail the rights of American Muslims.Now, this isn't just academic. When you look at when anti-Muslim sentiment spiked between 2001 and 2013, it happened three times, but it wasn't around terrorist attacks. It was in the run up to the Iraq War and during two election cycles. So Islamophobia isn't just the natural response to Muslim terrorism as I would have expected. It can actually be a tool of public manipulation, eroding the very foundation of a free society, which is rational and well-informed citizens. Muslims are like canaries in the coal mine. We might be the first to feel it, but the toxic air of fear is harming us all.(Applause)And assigning collective guilt isn't just about having to explain yourself all the time. Deah and his wife Yusor were a young married couple living in Chapel Hill, North Carolina, where they both went to school. Deah was an athlete. He was in dental school, talented, promising ... And his sister would tell me that he was the sweetest, most generous human being she knew. She was visiting him there and he showed her his resume, and she was amazed. She said, "When did my baby brother become such an accomplished young man?" Just a few weeks after Suzanne's visit to her brother and his new wife, their neighbor, Craig Stephen Hicks, murdered them, as well as Yusor's sister, Razan, who was visiting for the afternoon, in their apartment, execution style, after posting anti-Muslim statements on his Facebook page. He shot Deah eight times. So bigotry isn't just immoral, it can even be lethal.So, back to my story. What happened after 9/11? Did we go to the mosque or did we play it safe and stay home? Well, we talked it over, and it might seem like a small decision, but to us, it was about what kind of America we wanted to leave for our kids: one that would control us by fear or one where we were practicing our religion freely. So we decided to go to the mosque. And we put my son in his car seat, buckled him in, and we drove silently, intensely, to the mosque. I took him out, I took off my shoes, I walked into the prayer hall and what I saw made me stop. The place was completely full. And then the imam made an announcement, thanking and welcoming our guests, because half the congregation were Christians, Jews, Buddhists, atheists, people of faith and no faith, who had come not to attack us, but to stand in solidarity with us.(Applause)I just break down at this time. These people were there because they chose courage and compassion over panic and prejudice.What will you choose? What will you choose at this time of fear and bigotry? Will you play it safe? Or will you join those who say we are better than that?Thank you.(Applause)Thank you so much.Helen Walters: So Dalia, you seem to have struck a chord. But I wonder, what would you say to those who might argue that you're giving a TED Talk, you're clearly a deep thinker, you work at a fancy think tank, you're an exception, you're not the rule. What would you say to those people?Dalia Mogahed: I would say, don't let this stage distract you, I'm completely ordinary. I'm not an exception. My story is not unusual. I am as ordinary as they come. When you look at Muslims around the world — and I've done this, I've done the largest study ever done on Muslims around the world — people want ordinary things. They want prosperity for their family, they want jobs and they want to live in peace. So I am not in any way an exception. When you meet people who seem like an exception to the rule, oftentimes it's that the rule is broken, not that they're an exception to it.HW: Thank you so much. Dalia Mogahed.(Applause)

00:00:28.019 --> 00:00:31.565
Or just an airport security line delay.

00:00:32.529 --> 00:00:34.038
That one's actually true.

00:00:34.062 --> 00:00:35.618
(Laughter)

00:00:35.642 --> 00:00:38.865
If some of your perceptions were negative,
I don't really blame you.

00:00:38.889 --> 00:00:41.009
That's just how the media
has been portraying

00:00:41.033 --> 00:00:42.563
people who look like me.

00:00:42.587 --> 00:00:43.993
One study found

00:00:44.017 --> 00:00:48.762
that 80 percent of news coverage
about Islam and Muslims is negative.

00:00:48.786 --> 00:00:53.022
And studies show that Americans
say that most don't know a Muslim.

00:00:53.046 --> 00:00:55.902
I guess people don't talk
to their Uber drivers.

00:00:55.926 --> 00:00:57.844
(Laughter)

00:00:59.323 --> 00:01:02.922
Well, for those of you
who have never met a Muslim,

00:01:02.946 --> 00:01:04.791
it's great to meet you.

00:01:05.696 --> 00:01:07.646
Let me tell you who I am.

00:01:08.689 --> 00:01:11.792
I'm a mom, a coffee lover --

00:01:11.816 --> 00:01:13.644
double espresso, cream on the side.

00:01:14.061 --> 00:01:15.400
I'm an introvert.

00:01:16.047 --> 00:01:18.054
I'm a wannabe fitness fanatic.

00:01:18.078 --> 00:01:22.420
And I'm a practicing, spiritual Muslim.

00:01:23.746 --> 00:01:28.095
But not like Lady Gaga says,
because baby, I wasn't born this way.

00:01:28.889 --> 00:01:30.445
It was a choice.

00:01:31.598 --> 00:01:34.943
When I was 17, I decided to come out.

00:01:35.637 --> 00:01:38.798
No, not as a gay person
like some of my friends,

00:01:38.822 --> 00:01:40.322
but as a Muslim,

00:01:40.346 --> 00:01:43.417
and decided to start wearing
the hijab, my head covering.

00:01:44.174 --> 00:01:47.194
My feminist friends were aghast:

00:01:47.729 --> 00:01:50.450
"Why are you oppressing yourself?"

00:01:51.394 --> 00:01:52.926
The funny thing was,

00:01:52.950 --> 00:01:57.918
it was actually at that time
a feminist declaration of independence

00:01:58.856 --> 00:02:02.814
from the pressure I felt as a 17-year-old,

00:02:02.838 --> 00:02:06.484
to conform to a perfect
and unattainable standard of beauty.

00:02:07.540 --> 00:02:12.062
I didn't just passively accept
the faith of my parents.

00:02:12.616 --> 00:02:14.822
I wrestled with the Quran.

00:02:14.846 --> 00:02:19.774
I read and reflected
and questioned and doubted

00:02:20.386 --> 00:02:22.007
and, ultimately, believed.

00:02:23.579 --> 00:02:27.826
My relationship with God --
it was not love at first sight.

00:02:29.572 --> 00:02:32.446
It was a trust and a slow surrender

00:02:32.470 --> 00:02:35.483
that deepened with every
reading of the Quran.

00:02:36.091 --> 00:02:39.893
Its rhythmic beauty
sometimes moves me to tears.

00:02:40.867 --> 00:02:44.062
I see myself in it.
I feel that God knows me.

00:02:45.027 --> 00:02:50.619
Have you ever felt like someone sees you,
completely understands you

00:02:50.643 --> 00:02:52.294
and yet loves you anyway?

00:02:52.881 --> 00:02:54.511
That's how it feels.

00:02:55.731 --> 00:02:58.411
And so later, I got married,

00:02:58.435 --> 00:03:00.299
and like all good Egyptians,

00:03:00.323 --> 00:03:02.782
started my career as an engineer.

00:03:02.806 --> 00:03:04.806
(Laughter)

00:03:06.560 --> 00:03:10.402
I later had a child,
after getting married,

00:03:11.561 --> 00:03:15.139
and I was living essentially
the Egyptian-American dream.

00:03:18.406 --> 00:03:22.839
And then that terrible morning
of September, 2001.

00:03:24.375 --> 00:03:29.321
I think a lot of you probably remember
exactly where you were that morning.

00:03:31.139 --> 00:03:34.846
I was sitting in my kitchen
finishing breakfast,

00:03:34.870 --> 00:03:38.499
and I look up on the screen
and see the words "Breaking News."

00:03:39.033 --> 00:03:42.424
There was smoke,
airplanes flying into buildings,

00:03:42.448 --> 00:03:45.211
people jumping out of buildings.

00:03:45.235 --> 00:03:46.898
What was this?

00:03:47.414 --> 00:03:48.768
An accident?

00:03:49.744 --> 00:03:51.605
A malfunction?

00:03:53.042 --> 00:03:56.129
My shock quickly turned to outrage.

00:03:56.508 --> 00:03:58.753
Who would do this?

00:03:59.343 --> 00:04:01.789
And I switch the channel and I hear,

00:04:02.069 --> 00:04:03.740
"... Muslim terrorist ...,"

00:04:04.149 --> 00:04:06.146
"... in the name of Islam ...,"

00:04:06.170 --> 00:04:08.519
"... Middle-Eastern descent ...,"

00:04:08.543 --> 00:04:10.354
"... jihad ...,"

00:04:10.378 --> 00:04:11.829
"... we should bomb Mecca."

00:04:12.252 --> 00:04:13.408
Oh my God.

00:04:15.190 --> 00:04:19.014
Not only had my country been attacked,

00:04:19.038 --> 00:04:20.380
but in a flash,

00:04:20.404 --> 00:04:24.310
somebody else's actions
had turned me from a citizen

00:04:24.334 --> 00:04:25.756
to a suspect.

00:04:26.979 --> 00:04:31.916
That same day, we had to drive
across Middle America

00:04:31.940 --> 00:04:35.347
to move to a new city
to start grad school.

00:04:36.866 --> 00:04:38.949
And I remember sitting
in the passenger seat

00:04:38.973 --> 00:04:40.948
as we drove in silence,

00:04:41.829 --> 00:04:44.415
crouched as low as I could go in my seat,

00:04:44.439 --> 00:04:49.957
for the first time in my life,
afraid for anyone to know I was a Muslim.

00:04:50.901 --> 00:04:54.044
We moved into our apartment
that night in a new town

00:04:54.068 --> 00:04:56.837
in what felt like
a completely different world.

00:04:57.886 --> 00:05:01.840
And then I was hearing
and seeing and reading

00:05:01.864 --> 00:05:04.561
warnings from national
Muslim organizations

00:05:04.585 --> 00:05:07.516
saying things like,
"Be alert," "Be aware,"

00:05:08.270 --> 00:05:11.386
"Stay in well-lit areas,"
"Don't congregate."

00:05:12.138 --> 00:05:14.029
I stayed inside all week.

00:05:14.946 --> 00:05:17.690
And then it was Friday that same week,

00:05:17.714 --> 00:05:21.110
the day that Muslims
congregate for worship.

00:05:21.993 --> 00:05:26.559
And again the warnings were,
"Don't go that first Friday,

00:05:26.583 --> 00:05:28.305
it could be a target."

00:05:29.470 --> 00:05:32.121
And I was watching the news,
wall-to-wall coverage.

00:05:32.145 --> 00:05:35.010
Emotions were so raw, understandably,

00:05:35.034 --> 00:05:38.152
and I was also hearing
about attacks on Muslims,

00:05:38.736 --> 00:05:41.554
or people who were perceived
to be Muslim, being pulled out

00:05:41.578 --> 00:05:42.800
and beaten in the street.

00:05:42.824 --> 00:05:44.938
Mosques were actually firebombed.

00:05:44.962 --> 00:05:46.950
And I thought, we should just stay home.

00:05:47.735 --> 00:05:50.483
And yet, something didn't feel right.

00:05:51.293 --> 00:05:53.726
Because those people
who attacked our country

00:05:53.750 --> 00:05:56.067
attacked our country.

00:05:58.569 --> 00:06:01.375
I get it that people were angry
at the terrorists.

00:06:01.399 --> 00:06:03.520
Guess what? So was I.

00:06:04.855 --> 00:06:07.992
And so to have to explain yourself
all the time isn't easy.

00:06:10.151 --> 00:06:13.031
I don't mind questions. I love questions.

00:06:13.540 --> 00:06:15.729
It's the accusations that are tough.

00:06:16.541 --> 00:06:19.188
Today we hear people actually
saying things like,

00:06:20.236 --> 00:06:23.042
"There's a problem in this country,
and it's called Muslims.

00:06:23.066 --> 00:06:24.904
When are we going to get rid of them?"

00:06:25.462 --> 00:06:28.674
So, some people want to ban Muslims
and close down mosques.

00:06:29.155 --> 00:06:32.213
They talk about my community
kind of like we're a tumor

00:06:32.237 --> 00:06:33.878
in the body of America.

00:06:33.902 --> 00:06:37.163
And the only question is,
are we malignant or benign?

00:06:37.824 --> 00:06:40.805
You know, a malignant tumor
you extract altogether,

00:06:40.829 --> 00:06:46.006
and a benign tumor
you just keep under surveillance.

00:06:47.425 --> 00:06:51.290
The choices don't make sense,
because it's the wrong question.

00:06:51.851 --> 00:06:55.752
Muslims, like all other Americans,
aren't a tumor in the body of America,

00:06:55.776 --> 00:06:57.251
we're a vital organ.

00:06:58.067 --> 00:06:59.068
(Applause)

00:06:59.092 --> 00:07:00.251
Thank you.

00:07:00.275 --> 00:07:03.495
(Applause)

00:07:05.895 --> 00:07:08.461
Muslims are inventors and teachers,

00:07:08.485 --> 00:07:11.523
first responders and Olympic athletes.

00:07:12.299 --> 00:07:15.699
Now, is closing down mosques
going to make America safer?

00:07:16.152 --> 00:07:19.228
It might free up some parking spots,

00:07:19.252 --> 00:07:20.895
but it will not end terrorism.

00:07:22.092 --> 00:07:24.545
Going to a mosque regularly
is actually linked

00:07:24.569 --> 00:07:28.475
to having more tolerant views
of people of other faiths

00:07:28.499 --> 00:07:30.521
and greater civic engagement.

00:07:31.519 --> 00:07:34.800
And as one police chief
in the Washington, DC area

00:07:34.824 --> 00:07:35.975
recently told me,

00:07:35.999 --> 00:07:38.859
people don't actually
get radicalized at mosques.

00:07:38.883 --> 00:07:42.975
They get radicalized in their basement
or bedroom, in front of a computer.

00:07:44.484 --> 00:07:47.314
And what you find
about the radicalization process

00:07:47.338 --> 00:07:48.961
is it starts online,

00:07:48.985 --> 00:07:50.556
but the first thing that happens

00:07:50.580 --> 00:07:53.574
is the person gets cut off
from their community,

00:07:53.598 --> 00:07:55.240
from even their family,

00:07:55.264 --> 00:07:58.032
so that the extremist group
can brainwash them

00:07:58.056 --> 00:08:02.354
into believing that they,
the terrorists, are the true Muslims,

00:08:02.378 --> 00:08:06.394
and everyone else who abhors
their behavior and ideology

00:08:06.418 --> 00:08:09.089
are sellouts or apostates.

00:08:09.565 --> 00:08:11.820
So if we want to prevent radicalization,

00:08:11.844 --> 00:08:15.242
we have to keep people
going to the mosque.

00:08:16.723 --> 00:08:20.451
Now, some will still argue
Islam is a violent religion.

00:08:20.475 --> 00:08:25.424
After all, a group like ISIS
bases its brutality on the Quran.

00:08:26.276 --> 00:08:29.610
Now, as a Muslim, as a mother,
as a human being,

00:08:29.634 --> 00:08:34.355
I think we need to do everything we can
to stop a group like ISIS.

00:08:35.678 --> 00:08:40.558
But we would be giving in
to their narrative

00:08:40.582 --> 00:08:45.714
if we cast them as representatives
of a faith of 1.6 billion people.

00:08:46.331 --> 00:08:49.824
(Applause)

00:08:49.848 --> 00:08:51.284
Thank you.

00:08:53.767 --> 00:08:57.051
ISIS has as much to do with Islam

00:08:57.075 --> 00:09:00.126
as the Ku Klux Klan has to do
with Christianity.

00:09:00.449 --> 00:09:05.116
(Applause)

00:09:06.753 --> 00:09:11.789
Both groups claim to base
their ideology on their holy book.

00:09:12.307 --> 00:09:15.331
But when you look at them,
they're not motivated

00:09:15.355 --> 00:09:17.639
by what they read in their holy book.

00:09:17.663 --> 00:09:22.810
It's their brutality that makes them
read these things into the scripture.

00:09:24.056 --> 00:09:27.706
Recently, a prominent imam
told me a story that really took me aback.

00:09:27.730 --> 00:09:29.469
He said that a girl came to him

00:09:29.493 --> 00:09:31.882
because she was thinking
of going to join ISIS.

00:09:32.514 --> 00:09:34.562
And I was really surprised and asked him,

00:09:34.586 --> 00:09:37.832
had she been in contact
with a radical religious leader?

00:09:37.856 --> 00:09:40.151
And he said the problem
was quite the opposite,

00:09:40.175 --> 00:09:43.902
that every cleric that she had
talked to had shut her down

00:09:43.926 --> 00:09:47.523
and said that her rage,
her sense of injustice in the world,

00:09:47.547 --> 00:09:49.632
was just going to get her in trouble.

00:09:49.656 --> 00:09:53.337
And so with nowhere to channel
and make sense of this anger,

00:09:53.361 --> 00:09:55.376
she was a prime target to be exploited

00:09:55.400 --> 00:09:58.049
by extremists promising her a solution.

00:09:58.563 --> 00:10:02.829
What this imam did was to connect her
back to God and to her community.

00:10:03.277 --> 00:10:08.124
He didn't shame her for her rage --
instead, he gave her constructive ways

00:10:08.148 --> 00:10:10.685
to make real change in the world.

00:10:10.709 --> 00:10:15.401
What she learned at that mosque
prevented her from going to join ISIS.

00:10:16.941 --> 00:10:18.196
I've told you a little bit

00:10:18.220 --> 00:10:21.010
about how Islamophobia
affects me and my family.

00:10:21.034 --> 00:10:23.574
But how does it impact ordinary Americans?

00:10:23.598 --> 00:10:25.503
How does it impact everyone else?

00:10:25.527 --> 00:10:31.293
How does consuming fear 24 hours a day
affect the health of our democracy,

00:10:31.317 --> 00:10:32.965
the health of our free thought?

00:10:33.485 --> 00:10:37.356
Well, one study -- actually,
several studies in neuroscience --

00:10:37.380 --> 00:10:41.241
show that when we're afraid,
at least three things happen.

00:10:41.815 --> 00:10:45.936
We become more accepting
of authoritarianism,

00:10:45.960 --> 00:10:48.408
conformity and prejudice.

00:10:49.152 --> 00:10:54.939
One study showed that when subjects
were exposed to news stories

00:10:54.963 --> 00:10:57.947
that were negative about Muslims,

00:10:57.971 --> 00:11:02.086
they became more accepting
of military attacks on Muslim countries

00:11:02.110 --> 00:11:06.126
and policies that curtail the rights
of American Muslims.

00:11:06.150 --> 00:11:08.307
Now, this isn't just academic.

00:11:08.331 --> 00:11:12.723
When you look at when
anti-Muslim sentiment spiked

00:11:13.513 --> 00:11:17.061
between 2001 and 2013,

00:11:17.085 --> 00:11:18.652
it happened three times,

00:11:18.676 --> 00:11:20.901
but it wasn't around terrorist attacks.

00:11:21.252 --> 00:11:25.645
It was in the run up to the Iraq War
and during two election cycles.

00:11:26.113 --> 00:11:30.657
So Islamophobia isn't just
the natural response to Muslim terrorism

00:11:30.681 --> 00:11:32.680
as I would have expected.

00:11:33.176 --> 00:11:37.654
It can actually be a tool
of public manipulation,

00:11:37.678 --> 00:11:41.661
eroding the very foundation
of a free society,

00:11:41.685 --> 00:11:45.809
which is rational
and well-informed citizens.

00:11:46.563 --> 00:11:49.094
Muslims are like canaries
in the coal mine.

00:11:49.613 --> 00:11:51.304
We might be the first to feel it,

00:11:51.328 --> 00:11:55.365
but the toxic air of fear
is harming us all.

00:11:56.209 --> 00:12:01.762
(Applause)

00:12:03.538 --> 00:12:05.937
And assigning collective guilt

00:12:05.961 --> 00:12:08.799
isn't just about having
to explain yourself all the time.

00:12:09.735 --> 00:12:13.383
Deah and his wife Yusor
were a young married couple

00:12:13.407 --> 00:12:15.406
living in Chapel Hill, North Carolina,

00:12:15.430 --> 00:12:17.029
where they both went to school.

00:12:17.644 --> 00:12:20.059
Deah was an athlete.

00:12:20.083 --> 00:12:23.615
He was in dental school,
talented, promising ...

00:12:24.218 --> 00:12:28.436
And his sister would tell me
that he was the sweetest,

00:12:28.460 --> 00:12:30.495
most generous human being she knew.

00:12:30.519 --> 00:12:34.373
She was visiting him there
and he showed her his resume,

00:12:34.397 --> 00:12:35.659
and she was amazed.

00:12:35.683 --> 00:12:39.913
She said, "When did my baby brother
become such an accomplished young man?"

00:12:41.077 --> 00:12:45.642
Just a few weeks after Suzanne's visit
to her brother and his new wife,

00:12:46.195 --> 00:12:47.472
their neighbor,

00:12:48.690 --> 00:12:50.831
Craig Stephen Hicks,

00:12:50.855 --> 00:12:52.600
murdered them,

00:12:52.624 --> 00:12:57.405
as well as Yusor's sister, Razan,
who was visiting for the afternoon,

00:12:57.429 --> 00:12:59.188
in their apartment,

00:12:59.712 --> 00:13:01.467
execution style,

00:13:01.491 --> 00:13:05.447
after posting anti-Muslim statements
on his Facebook page.

00:13:06.016 --> 00:13:07.760
He shot Deah eight times.

00:13:09.212 --> 00:13:13.247
So bigotry isn't just immoral,
it can even be lethal.

00:13:14.313 --> 00:13:15.634
So, back to my story.

00:13:15.658 --> 00:13:17.358
What happened after 9/11?

00:13:17.382 --> 00:13:20.510
Did we go to the mosque
or did we play it safe and stay home?

00:13:21.348 --> 00:13:23.230
Well, we talked it over,

00:13:23.254 --> 00:13:25.943
and it might seem like
a small decision, but to us,

00:13:25.967 --> 00:13:29.823
it was about what kind of America
we wanted to leave for our kids:

00:13:29.847 --> 00:13:33.227
one that would control us by fear

00:13:33.251 --> 00:13:36.745
or one where we were practicing
our religion freely.

00:13:36.769 --> 00:13:38.617
So we decided to go to the mosque.

00:13:39.781 --> 00:13:41.524
And we put my son in his car seat,

00:13:41.548 --> 00:13:45.239
buckled him in, and we drove silently,
intensely, to the mosque.

00:13:45.263 --> 00:13:49.140
I took him out, I took off my shoes,
I walked into the prayer hall

00:13:50.567 --> 00:13:52.137
and what I saw made me stop.

00:13:53.229 --> 00:13:54.857
The place was completely full.

00:13:55.450 --> 00:13:57.638
And then the imam made an announcement,

00:13:57.662 --> 00:14:01.928
thanking and welcoming our guests,

00:14:02.522 --> 00:14:04.736
because half the congregation

00:14:05.791 --> 00:14:08.519
were Christians, Jews,
Buddhists, atheists,

00:14:08.543 --> 00:14:10.963
people of faith and no faith,

00:14:10.987 --> 00:14:15.888
who had come not to attack us,
but to stand in solidarity with us.

00:14:16.377 --> 00:14:23.348
(Applause)

00:14:25.557 --> 00:14:27.680
I just break down at this time.

00:14:28.632 --> 00:14:33.176
These people were there because they chose
courage and compassion

00:14:33.200 --> 00:14:35.298
over panic and prejudice.

00:14:36.689 --> 00:14:38.356
What will you choose?

00:14:39.080 --> 00:14:44.101
What will you choose
at this time of fear and bigotry?

00:14:45.355 --> 00:14:47.066
Will you play it safe?

00:14:47.872 --> 00:14:50.171
Or will you join those who say

00:14:50.195 --> 00:14:52.183
we are better than that?

00:14:52.207 --> 00:14:53.358
Thank you.

00:14:53.382 --> 00:14:57.706
(Applause)

00:15:07.868 --> 00:15:09.232
Thank you so much.

00:15:12.455 --> 00:15:16.799
Helen Walters: So Dalia,
you seem to have struck a chord.

00:15:16.823 --> 00:15:18.360
But I wonder,

00:15:18.384 --> 00:15:20.843
what would you say to those
who might argue

00:15:20.867 --> 00:15:22.624
that you're giving a TED Talk,

00:15:22.648 --> 00:15:24.203
you're clearly a deep thinker,

00:15:24.227 --> 00:15:26.234
you work at a fancy think tank,

00:15:26.258 --> 00:15:28.371
you're an exception, you're not the rule.

00:15:28.395 --> 00:15:30.167
What would you say to those people?

00:15:30.799 --> 00:15:33.721
Dalia Mogahed: I would say,
don't let this stage distract you,

00:15:33.745 --> 00:15:34.950
I'm completely ordinary.

00:15:35.779 --> 00:15:37.024
I'm not an exception.

00:15:37.405 --> 00:15:39.425
My story is not unusual.

00:15:39.449 --> 00:15:42.432
I am as ordinary as they come.

00:15:42.456 --> 00:15:46.654
When you look at Muslims
around the world --

00:15:46.678 --> 00:15:49.509
and I've done this, I've done
the largest study ever done

00:15:49.533 --> 00:15:51.075
on Muslims around the world --

00:15:51.099 --> 00:15:52.549
people want ordinary things.

00:15:52.573 --> 00:15:54.398
They want prosperity for their family,

00:15:54.422 --> 00:15:55.573
they want jobs

00:15:55.597 --> 00:15:57.203
and they want to live in peace.

00:15:57.227 --> 00:16:00.273
So I am not in any way an exception.

00:16:00.297 --> 00:16:03.148

transcript: I believe big institutions have unique potential to create change, and I believe that we as individuals have unique power to influence the direction that those institutions take.Now, these beliefs did not come naturally to me, because trusting big institutions, not really part of my family legacy. Later, when she decided she wanted to emigrate to the United States, she had to defy an entire culture that said the girls would never be the best and brightest. Only because her name happens to sound like a boy's was she able to finagle her way into the government immigration exam to come to the United States.Because of her bravery and passion, I've had all the opportunities that she never did, and that has made my story so different. Instead of running away from big institutions, I've actually run toward them. I've had the chance over the course of my career to work for The Wall Street Journal, the White House and now one of the largest financial institutions in the world, where I lead sustainable investing.Now, these institutions are like tankers, and working inside of them, I've come to appreciate what large wakes they can leave, and I've become convinced that the institution of the global capital markets, the nearly 290 trillion dollars of stocks and bonds in the world, that that may be one of our most powerful forces for positive social change at our disposal, if we ask it to be.Now, I know some of you are thinking, global capital markets, positive social change, not usually in the same sentence or even the same paragraph. I think many people think of the capital markets kind of like an ocean. It's a vast, impersonal, uncaring force of nature that is not affected by our wishes or desires. So the best that our little savings accounts or retirement accounts can do is to try to catch some waves in the good cycles and hope that we don't get inundated in the turbulent ones, but certainly our decisions on how to steer our little retirement accounts don't affect the tides, don't change the shape or size or direction of the waves.But why is that? Because actually, one third of this ocean of capital actually belongs to individuals like us, and most of the rest of the capital markets is controlled by the institutions that get their power and authority and their capital from us, as members, participants, beneficiaries, shareholders or citizens. So if we are the ultimate owners of the capital markets, why aren't we able to make our voices heard? Why can't we make some waves?So let me ask you a different question: did any of you buy fair trade coffee the last time you were at a supermarket or at Starbucks? OK. Do any of you go to the restaurant and order the sustainably farmed trout instead of the miso-glazed Chilean sea bass that you really wish you could have? Do any of you drive hybrid cars or even electric cars?So why do we do these things? Right? One electric car doesn't amount to much in a fleet of 1.2 billion combustion engine vehicles. One fish is just one fish in the sea. And one cup of coffee doesn't amount to a hill of beans in this crazy world. But we do these things because we believe they matter, that our actions add up, that our choices might influence others and collectively, what an impact we can have.So, in my bag I have a coffee mug that I bought a couple of years ago.
