00:06:04.667 --> 00:06:06.094
In a series of bad decisions,

00:06:06.118 --> 00:06:09.723
he stole 30 laptops from a store
and sold them on the Internet.

00:06:10.382 --> 00:06:11.871
This led to his arrest

00:06:11.895 --> 00:06:16.151
and a criminal complaint
of 30 felony charges.

00:06:17.635 --> 00:06:21.183
The potential jail time he faced is what
stressed Christopher out the most.

00:06:21.207 --> 00:06:23.301
But what he had little understanding of

00:06:23.325 --> 00:06:26.635
was the impact a criminal record
would have on his future.

00:06:28.269 --> 00:06:30.162
I was standing in arraignments that day

00:06:30.186 --> 00:06:32.282
when Christopher's case
came across my desk.

00:06:32.306 --> 00:06:34.822
And at the risk of sounding
dramatic, in that moment,

00:06:34.846 --> 00:06:36.797
I had Christopher's life in my hands.

00:06:37.463 --> 00:06:39.714
I was 29 years old,
a brand-new prosecutor,

00:06:39.738 --> 00:06:42.834
and I had little appreciation
for how the decisions I would make

00:06:42.858 --> 00:06:45.444
would impact Christopher's life.

00:06:46.864 --> 00:06:48.680
Christopher's case was a serious one

00:06:48.704 --> 00:06:50.585
and it needed to be dealt with as such,

00:06:50.609 --> 00:06:53.648
but I didn't think branding him
a felon for the rest of his life

00:06:53.672 --> 00:06:54.830
was the right answer.

00:06:56.358 --> 00:06:58.621
For the most part,
prosecutors step onto the job

00:06:58.645 --> 00:07:01.296
with little appreciation
of the impact of our decisions,

00:07:01.320 --> 00:07:02.629
regardless of our intent.

00:07:02.653 --> 00:07:04.168
Despite our broad discretion,

00:07:04.192 --> 00:07:07.364
we learn to avoid risk at all cost,

00:07:07.388 --> 00:07:09.126
rendering our discretion

00:07:09.150 --> 00:07:10.434
basically useless.

00:07:11.929 --> 00:07:14.321
History has conditioned us
to believe that somehow,

00:07:14.345 --> 00:07:17.132
the criminal justice system
brings about accountability

00:07:17.156 --> 00:07:18.486
and improves public safety,

00:07:18.510 --> 00:07:20.217
despite evidence to the contrary.

00:07:21.058 --> 00:07:24.702
We're judged internally and externally
by our convictions and our trial wins,

00:07:24.726 --> 00:07:28.224
so prosecutors aren't really
incentivized to be creative

00:07:28.248 --> 00:07:30.355
at our case dispositions,

00:07:30.379 --> 00:07:33.526
or to take risks on people
we might not otherwise.

00:07:34.624 --> 00:07:36.121
We stick to an outdated method,

00:07:36.145 --> 00:07:39.276
counterproductive to achieving
the very goal that we all want,

00:07:39.300 --> 00:07:41.255
and that's safer communities.

00:07:41.962 --> 00:07:45.773
Yet most prosecutors standing in my space
would have arraigned Christopher.

00:07:46.855 --> 00:07:50.233
They have little appreciation
for what we can do.

00:07:50.257 --> 00:07:53.367
Arraigning Christopher
would give him a criminal record,

00:07:54.384 --> 00:07:56.494
making it harder for him to get a job,

00:07:56.978 --> 00:07:58.667
setting in motion a cycle

00:07:58.691 --> 00:08:01.547
that defines the failing
criminal justice system today.

00:08:04.031 --> 00:08:06.016
With a criminal record and without a job,

00:08:06.040 --> 00:08:10.561
Christopher would be unable to find
employment, education or stable housing.

00:08:10.585 --> 00:08:12.704
Without those protective
factors in his life,

00:08:12.728 --> 00:08:16.098
Christopher would be more likely
to commit further, more serious crime.

00:08:16.122 --> 00:08:19.247
The more contact Christopher had
with the criminal justice system,

00:08:19.271 --> 00:08:21.815
the more likely it would be
that he would return again

00:08:21.839 --> 00:08:23.808
and again and again --

00:08:23.832 --> 00:08:27.636
all at tremendous social cost
to his children, to his family

00:08:27.660 --> 00:08:28.811
and to his peers.

00:08:28.835 --> 00:08:30.140
And, ladies and gentlemen,

00:08:30.164 --> 00:08:33.639
it is a terrible public safety
outcome for the rest of us.

00:08:36.467 --> 00:08:38.742
When I came out of law school,

00:08:38.766 --> 00:08:40.972
I did the same thing as everybody else.

00:08:41.504 --> 00:08:43.960
I came out as a prosecutor
expected to do justice,

00:08:43.984 --> 00:08:46.487
but I never learned what
justice was in my classes --

00:08:46.511 --> 00:08:47.661
none of us do.

00:08:48.161 --> 00:08:49.311
None of us do.

00:08:50.918 --> 00:08:53.405
And yet, prosecutors
are the most powerful actors

00:08:53.429 --> 00:08:55.039
in the criminal justice system.

00:08:56.187 --> 00:08:57.880
Our power is virtually boundless.

00:08:57.904 --> 00:08:59.357
In most cases, not the judge,

00:08:59.381 --> 00:09:01.111
not the police, not the legislature,

00:09:01.135 --> 00:09:03.508
not the mayor, not the governor,
not the President

00:09:03.532 --> 00:09:05.468
can tell us how to prosecute our cases.

00:09:06.964 --> 00:09:10.080
The decision to arraign Christopher
and give him a criminal record

00:09:10.104 --> 00:09:11.333
was exclusively mine.

00:09:12.301 --> 00:09:15.787
I would choose whether to prosecute
him for 30 felonies, for one felony,

00:09:15.811 --> 00:09:16.962
for a misdemeanor,

00:09:16.986 --> 00:09:18.163
or at all.

00:09:18.187 --> 00:09:21.163
I would choose whether to leverage
Christopher into a plea deal

00:09:21.187 --> 00:09:23.216
or take the case to trial, and ultimately,

00:09:23.240 --> 00:09:26.231
I would be in a position to ask
for Christopher to go to jail.

00:09:27.878 --> 00:09:31.547
These are decisions that prosecutors
make every day unfettered,

00:09:32.571 --> 00:09:35.380
and we are unaware and untrained

00:09:35.404 --> 00:09:38.318
of the grave consequences
of those decisions.

00:09:40.456 --> 00:09:41.778
One night this past summer,

00:09:41.802 --> 00:09:45.704
I was at a small gathering
of professional men of color

00:09:45.728 --> 00:09:47.315
from around the city.

00:09:47.339 --> 00:09:50.296
As I stood there stuffing
free finger sandwiches into my mouth,

00:09:50.320 --> 00:09:51.803
as you do as public servant --

00:09:51.827 --> 00:09:52.843
(Laughter)

00:09:52.867 --> 00:09:54.430
I noticed across the room,

00:09:54.454 --> 00:09:58.253
a young man waving and smiling
at me and approaching me.

00:09:59.485 --> 00:10:02.509
And I recognized him,
but I couldn't place from where,

00:10:02.533 --> 00:10:06.121
and before I knew it,
this young man was hugging me.

00:10:07.092 --> 00:10:08.479
And thanking me.

00:10:09.724 --> 00:10:12.025
"You cared about me,
and you changed my life."

00:10:13.297 --> 00:10:14.787
It was Christopher.

00:10:15.794 --> 00:10:17.480
See, I never arraigned Christopher.

00:10:17.504 --> 00:10:19.104
He never faced a judge or a jail,

00:10:19.128 --> 00:10:20.707
he never had a criminal record.

00:10:21.091 --> 00:10:22.849
Instead, I worked with Christopher;

00:10:22.873 --> 00:10:25.592
first on being accountable
for his actions,

00:10:25.616 --> 00:10:28.705
and then, putting him in a position
where he wouldn't re-offend.

00:10:29.623 --> 00:10:32.576
We recovered 75 percent
of the computers that he sold

00:10:32.600 --> 00:10:34.103
and gave them back to Best Buy,

00:10:34.127 --> 00:10:35.731
and came up with a financial plan

00:10:35.755 --> 00:10:37.970
to repay for the computers
we couldn't recover.

00:10:37.994 --> 00:10:39.709
Christopher did community service.

00:10:39.733 --> 00:10:43.012
He wrote an essay reflecting on how
this case could impact his future

00:10:43.036 --> 00:10:44.387
and that of the community.

00:10:44.411 --> 00:10:45.618
He applied to college,

00:10:45.642 --> 00:10:46.902
he obtained financial aid,

00:10:46.926 --> 00:10:49.487
and he went on to graduate
from a four-year school.

00:10:50.481 --> 00:10:56.965
(Applause)

00:10:57.532 --> 00:10:59.972
After we finished hugging,
I looked at his name tag,

00:10:59.996 --> 00:11:03.245
to learn that Christopher was the manager
of a large bank in Boston.

00:11:03.269 --> 00:11:06.569
Christopher had accomplished --
and making a lot more money than me --

00:11:06.593 --> 00:11:07.594
(Laughter)

00:11:07.618 --> 00:11:09.124
He had accomplished all of this

00:11:09.148 --> 00:11:12.243
in the six years since I had first
seen him in Roxbury Court.

00:11:12.867 --> 00:11:15.934
I can't take credit for Christopher's
journey to success,

00:11:16.689 --> 00:11:19.847
but I certainly did my part
to keep him on the path.

00:11:20.950 --> 00:11:24.029
There are thousands
of Christophers out there,

00:11:24.551 --> 00:11:26.332
some locked in our jails and prisons.

00:11:26.356 --> 00:11:28.221
We need thousands of prosecutors

00:11:28.245 --> 00:11:31.069
to recognize that and to protect them.

00:11:32.466 --> 00:11:35.982
An employed Christopher is better
for public safety than a condemned one.

00:11:36.420 --> 00:11:39.063
It's a bigger win for all of us.

00:11:40.396 --> 00:11:43.477
In retrospect, the decision not
to throw the book at Christopher

00:11:43.501 --> 00:11:44.652
makes perfect sense.

00:11:44.676 --> 00:11:46.888
When I saw him that first day
in Roxbury Court,

00:11:46.912 --> 00:11:48.784
I didn't see a criminal standing there.

00:11:48.808 --> 00:11:51.603
I saw myself -- a young person
in need of intervention.

00:11:51.627 --> 00:11:55.940
As an individual caught selling a large
quantity of drugs in my late teens,

00:11:55.964 --> 00:11:58.889
I knew firsthand the power of opportunity

00:11:58.913 --> 00:12:01.799
as opposed to the wrath
of the criminal justice system.

00:12:04.299 --> 00:12:08.210
Along the way, with the help
and guidance of my district attorney,

00:12:08.234 --> 00:12:11.207
my supervisor and judges,

00:12:11.231 --> 00:12:13.758
I learned the power of the prosecutor

00:12:13.782 --> 00:12:16.504
to change lives instead of ruining them.

00:12:18.500 --> 00:12:20.137
And that's how we do it in Boston.

00:12:21.164 --> 00:12:24.709
We helped a woman who was arrested
for stealing groceries to feed her kids

00:12:24.733 --> 00:12:25.883
get a job.

00:12:26.359 --> 00:12:29.507
Instead of putting an abused
teenager in adult jail

00:12:29.531 --> 00:12:30.984
for punching another teenager,

00:12:31.008 --> 00:12:33.898
we secured mental health treatment
and community supervision.

00:12:34.246 --> 00:12:35.893
A runaway girl who was arrested

00:12:35.917 --> 00:12:38.020
for prostituting, to survive
on the streets,

00:12:38.044 --> 00:12:40.785
needed a safe place to live and grow --

00:12:40.809 --> 00:12:42.812
something we could help her with.

00:12:42.836 --> 00:12:44.312
I even helped a young man

00:12:44.336 --> 00:12:47.439
who was so afraid of the older gang kids
showing up after school,

00:12:47.463 --> 00:12:50.138
that one morning instead
of a lunchbox into his backpack,

00:12:50.162 --> 00:12:51.787
he put a loaded 9-millimeter.

00:12:53.425 --> 00:12:57.461
We would spend our time that we'd
normally take prepping our cases

00:12:57.485 --> 00:12:59.652
for months and months
for trial down the road

00:12:59.676 --> 00:13:03.577
by coming up with real solutions
to the problems as they presented.

00:13:04.657 --> 00:13:06.943
Which is the better way to spend our time?

00:13:07.927 --> 00:13:10.661
How would you prefer
your prosecutors to spend theirs?

00:13:11.859 --> 00:13:14.227
Why are we spending 80 billion dollars

00:13:14.251 --> 00:13:16.693
on a prison industry
that we know is failing,

00:13:16.717 --> 00:13:20.281
when we could take that money
and reallocate it into education,

00:13:20.305 --> 00:13:21.714
into mental health treatment,

00:13:21.738 --> 00:13:23.235
into substance abuse treatment

00:13:23.259 --> 00:13:26.317
and to community investment
so we can develop our neighborhoods?

00:13:26.341 --> 00:13:32.857
(Applause)

00:13:33.574 --> 00:13:35.178
So why should this matter to you?

00:13:35.202 --> 00:13:38.320
Well, one, we're spending a lot of money.

00:13:39.252 --> 00:13:40.489
Our money.

00:13:41.021 --> 00:13:43.427
It costs 109,000 dollars in some states

00:13:43.451 --> 00:13:45.041
to lock up a teenager for a year,

00:13:45.065 --> 00:13:49.517
with a 60 percent chance that that person
will return to the very same system.

00:13:49.541 --> 00:13:52.964
That is a terrible return on investment.

00:13:54.664 --> 00:13:56.938
Number two: it's the right thing to do.

00:13:56.962 --> 00:13:59.917
If prosecutors were a part
of creating the problem,

00:13:59.941 --> 00:14:02.170
it's incumbent on us to create a solution

00:14:02.194 --> 00:14:04.241
and we can do that using other disciplines

00:14:04.265 --> 00:14:06.781
that have already done the data
and research for us.

00:14:06.805 --> 00:14:07.974
And number three:

00:14:07.998 --> 00:14:10.599
your voice and your vote
can make that happen.

00:14:10.623 --> 00:14:13.303
The next time there's a local
district attorney's election

00:14:13.327 --> 00:14:14.479
in your jurisdiction,

00:14:14.503 --> 00:14:15.997
ask candidates these questions.

00:14:16.021 --> 00:14:19.208
One: What are you doing to make
me and my neighbors safer?

00:14:19.232 --> 00:14:21.612
Two: What data are you collecting,

00:14:21.636 --> 00:14:23.857
and how are you training your prosecutors

00:14:23.881 --> 00:14:25.552
to make sure that it's working?

00:14:25.576 --> 00:14:26.741
And number three:

00:14:26.765 --> 00:14:28.621
If it's not working for everybody,

00:14:28.645 --> 00:14:30.199
what are you doing to fix it?

00:14:30.520 --> 00:14:32.232
If they can't answer the questions,

00:14:32.256 --> 00:14:34.143
they shouldn't be doing the job.

00:14:35.438 --> 00:14:38.655
Each one of you that raised your hand
at the beginning of this talk

00:14:38.679 --> 00:14:42.117
is a living, breathing example
of the power of opportunity,

00:14:42.141 --> 00:14:43.292
of intervention,

00:14:43.316 --> 00:14:44.467
of support

00:14:44.491 --> 00:14:45.772
and of love.

00:14:45.796 --> 00:14:48.697
While each of you may have faced
your own brand of discipline

00:14:48.721 --> 00:14:50.834
for whatever malfeasances you committed,

00:14:50.858 --> 00:14:52.723
barely any of you needed a day in jail

00:14:52.747 --> 00:14:54.826
to make you the people
that you are today --

00:14:54.850 --> 00:14:56.912
some of the greatest minds on the planet.

00:14:57.706 --> 00:14:59.585
Every day, thousands of times a day,

00:14:59.609 --> 00:15:02.555
prosecutors around the United States
wield power so great

00:15:02.579 --> 00:15:04.319
that it can bring about catastrophe

00:15:04.343 --> 00:15:06.921
as quickly as it can
bring about opportunity,

00:15:06.945 --> 00:15:08.177
intervention,

00:15:08.201 --> 00:15:09.360
support

00:15:09.384 --> 00:15:11.502
and yes, even love.

00:15:12.716 --> 00:15:15.622
Those qualities are the hallmarks
of a strong community,

00:15:15.646 --> 00:15:17.440
and a strong community is a safe one.

00:15:17.464 --> 00:15:18.920
If our communities are broken,

00:15:18.944 --> 00:15:21.041
don't let the lawyers
that you elect fix them

00:15:21.065 --> 00:15:23.248
with outdated, inefficient,
expensive methods.

00:15:23.272 --> 00:15:26.915
Demand more; vote for the prosecutor
who's helping people stay out of jail,

00:15:26.939 --> 00:15:28.091
not putting them in.

00:15:28.115 --> 00:15:29.266
Demand better.

00:15:29.290 --> 00:15:31.296
You deserve it, your children deserve it,

00:15:31.320 --> 00:15:33.758
the people who are tied up
in the system deserve it,

00:15:33.782 --> 00:15:34.934
but most of all,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:38.205
the people that we are sworn to protect
and do justice for demand it.

00:15:38.229 --> 00:15:39.380
We must,

00:15:39.404 --> 00:15:40.786
we must do better.

00:15:40.810 --> 00:15:41.967
Thank you.

00:15:41.991 --> 00:15:43.968
(Applause)

00:15:46.507 --> 00:15:47.946
Thank you.

00:15:47.970 --> 00:15:50.176
(Applause)

00:15:51.171 --> 00:15:53.447
Thank you very much.

title: How to get back to work after a career break
transcript: People returning to work after a career break: I call them relaunchers. These are people who have taken career breaks for elder care, for childcare reasons, pursuing a personal interest or a personal health issue. Closely related are career transitioners of all kinds: veterans, military spouses, retirees coming out of retirement or repatriating expats. Returning to work after a career break is hard because of a disconnect between the employers and the relaunchers. Employers can view hiring people with a gap on their resume as a high-risk proposition, and individuals on career break can have doubts about their abilities to relaunch their careers, especially if they've been out for a long time. This disconnect is a problem that I'm trying to help solve.Now, successful relaunchers are everywhere and in every field. This is Sami Kafala. He's a nuclear physicist in the UK who took a five-year career break to be home with his five children. The Singapore press recently wrote about nurses returning to work after long career breaks. And speaking of long career breaks, this is Mimi Kahn. She's a social worker in Orange County, California, who returned to work in a social services organization after a 25-year career break. That's the longest career break that I'm aware of. Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor took a five-year career break early in her career.And this is Tracy Shapiro, who took a 13-year career break. Tracy answered a call for essays by the Today Show from people who were trying to return to work but having a difficult time of it. Tracy wrote in that she was a mom of five who loved her time at home, but she had gone through a divorce and needed to return to work, plus she really wanted to bring work back into her life because she loved working. Tracy was doing what so many of us do when we feel like we've put in a good day in the job search. She was looking for a finance or accounting role, and she had just spent the last nine months very diligently researching companies online and applying for jobs with no results.I met Tracy in June of 2011, when the Today Show asked me if I could work with her to see if I could help her turn things around. The first thing I told Tracy was she had to get out of the house. I told her she had to go public with her job search and tell everyone she knew about her interest in returning to work. I also told her, "You are going to have a lot of conversations that don't go anywhere. Expect that, and don't be discouraged by it. There will be a handful that ultimately lead to a job opportunity."I'll tell you what happened with Tracy in a little bit, but I want to share with you a discovery that I made when I was returning to work after my own career break of 11 years out of the full-time workforce. And that is, that people's view of you is frozen in time. What I mean by this is, when you start to get in touch with people and you get back in touch with those people from the past, the people with whom you worked or went to school, they are going to remember you as you were before your career break. And that's even if your sense of self has diminished over time, as happens with so many of us the farther removed we are from our professional identities. So for example, you might think of yourself as someone who looks like this. This is me, crazy after a day of driving around in my minivan. Or here I am in the kitchen. But those people from the past, they don't know about any of this. They only remember you as you were, and it's a great confidence boost to be back in touch with these people and hear their enthusiasm about your interest in returning to work.There's one more thing I remember vividly from my own career break. And that was that I hardly kept up with the business news. My background is in finance, and I hardly kept up with any news when I was home caring for my four young children. So I was afraid I'd go into an interview and start talking about a company that didn't exist anymore. So I had to resubscribe to the Wall Street Journal and read it for a good six months cover to cover before I felt like I had a handle on what was going on in the business world again.I believe relaunchers are a gem of the workforce, and here's why. Think about our life stage: for those of us who took career breaks for childcare reasons, we have fewer or no maternity leaves. We did that already. We have fewer spousal or partner job relocations. We're in a more settled time of life. We have great work experience. We have a more mature perspective. We're not trying to find ourselves at an employer's expense. Plus we have an energy, an enthusiasm about returning to work precisely because we've been away from it for a while.On the flip side, I speak with employers, and here are two concerns that employers have about hiring relaunchers.The first one is, employers are worried that relaunchers are technologically obsolete. Now, I can tell you, having been technologically obsolete myself at one point, that it's a temporary condition. I had done my financial analysis so long ago that I used Lotus 1-2-3. I don't know if anyone can even remember back that far, but I had to relearn it on Excel. It actually wasn't that hard. A lot of the commands are the same. I found PowerPoint much more challenging, but now I use PowerPoint all the time. I tell relaunchers that employers expect them to come to the table with a working knowledge of basic office management software. And if they're not up to speed, then it's their responsibility to get there. And they do.The second area of concern that employers have about relaunchers is they're worried that relaunchers don't know what they want to do. I tell relaunchers that they need to do the hard work to figure out whether their interests and skills have changed or have not changed while they have been on career break. That's not the employer's job. It's the relauncher's responsibility to demonstrate to the employer where they can add the most value.Back in 2010 I started noticing something. I had been tracking return to work programs since 2008, and in 2010, I started noticing the use of a short-term paid work opportunity, whether it was called an internship or not, but an internship-like experience, as a way for professionals to return to work. I saw Goldman Sachs and Sara Lee start corporate reentry internship programs. I saw a returning engineer, a nontraditional reentry candidate, apply for an entry-level internship program in the military, and then get a permanent job afterward. I saw two universities integrate internships into mid-career executive education programs.So I wrote a report about what I was seeing, and it became this article for Harvard Business Review called "The 40-Year-Old Intern." I have to thank the editors there for that title, and also for this artwork where you can see the 40-year-old intern in the midst of all the college interns. And then, courtesy of Fox Business News, they called the concept "The 50-Year-Old Intern."(Laughter)So five of the biggest financial services companies have reentry internship programs for returning finance professionals. And at this point, hundreds of people have participated. These internships are paid, and the people who move on to permanent roles are commanding competitive salaries. And now, seven of the biggest engineering companies are piloting reentry internship programs for returning engineers as part of an initiative with the Society of Women Engineers. Now, why are companies embracing the reentry internship? Because the internship allows the employer to base their hiring decision on an actual work sample instead of a series of interviews, and the employer does not have to make that permanent hiring decision until the internship period is over. This testing out period removes the perceived risk that some managers attach to hiring relaunchers, and they are attracting excellent candidates who are turning into great hires.Think about how far we have come. Before this, most employers were not interested in engaging with relaunchers at all. But now, not only are programs being developed specifically with relaunchers in mind, but you can't even apply for these programs unless you have a gap on your résumé.This is the mark of real change, of true institutional shift, because if we can solve this problem for relaunchers, we can solve it for other career transitioners too. In fact, an employer just told me that their veterans return to work program is based on their reentry internship program. And there's no reason why there can't be a retiree internship program. Different pool, same concept.So let me tell you what happened with Tracy Shapiro. Remember that she had to tell everyone she knew about her interest in returning to work. Well, one critical conversation with another parent in her community led to a job offer for Tracy, and it was an accounting job in a finance department. But it was a temp job. The company told her there was a possibility it could turn into something more, but no guarantees. This was in the fall of 2011. Tracy loved this company, and she loved the people and the office was less than 10 minutes from her house. So even though she had a second job offer at another company for a permanent full-time role, she decided to take her chances with this internship and hope for the best. Well, she ended up blowing away all of their expectations, and the company not only made her a permanent offer at the beginning of 2012, but they made it even more interesting and challenging, because they knew what Tracy could handle.Fast forward to 2015, Tracy's been promoted. They've paid for her to get her MBA at night. She's even hired another relauncher to work for her. Tracy's temp job was a tryout, just like an internship, and it ended up being a win for both Tracy and her employer.Now, my goal is to bring the reentry internship concept to more and more employers. But in the meantime, if you are returning to work after a career break, don't hesitate to suggest an internship or an internship-like arrangement to an employer that does not have a formal reentry internship program. Be their first success story, and you can be the example for more relaunchers to come.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:14.238 --> 00:00:17.774
People returning to work
after a career break:

00:00:17.798 --> 00:00:19.974
I call them relaunchers.

00:00:19.997 --> 00:00:23.854
These are people who have taken
career breaks for elder care,

00:00:23.878 --> 00:00:25.694
for childcare reasons,

00:00:25.718 --> 00:00:27.414
pursuing a personal interest

00:00:27.438 --> 00:00:29.638
or a personal health issue.

00:00:30.118 --> 00:00:33.494
Closely related are
career transitioners of all kinds:

00:00:33.518 --> 00:00:35.854
veterans, military spouses,

00:00:35.878 --> 00:00:38.294
retirees coming out of retirement

00:00:38.318 --> 00:00:40.038
or repatriating expats.

00:00:41.718 --> 00:00:44.653
Returning to work
after a career break is hard

00:00:44.678 --> 00:00:47.694
because of a disconnect
between the employers

00:00:47.718 --> 00:00:49.614
and the relaunchers.

00:00:49.638 --> 00:00:53.614
Employers can view hiring people
with a gap on their resume

00:00:53.638 --> 00:00:55.734
as a high-risk proposition,

00:00:55.758 --> 00:00:59.614
and individuals on career break
can have doubts about their abilities

00:00:59.638 --> 00:01:01.214
to relaunch their careers,

00:01:01.238 --> 00:01:03.558
especially if they've been out
for a long time.

00:01:04.278 --> 00:01:09.038
This disconnect is a problem
that I'm trying to help solve.

00:01:09.598 --> 00:01:14.118
Now, successful relaunchers
are everywhere and in every field.

00:01:14.638 --> 00:01:16.374
This is Sami Kafala.

00:01:16.398 --> 00:01:19.134
He's a nuclear physicist in the UK

00:01:19.158 --> 00:01:23.078
who took a five-year career break
to be home with his five children.

00:01:24.118 --> 00:01:28.054
The Singapore press recently wrote
about nurses returning to work

00:01:28.078 --> 00:01:30.134
after long career breaks.

00:01:30.158 --> 00:01:32.174
And speaking of long career breaks,

00:01:32.198 --> 00:01:33.478
this is Mimi Kahn.

00:01:34.078 --> 00:01:37.254
She's a social worker
in Orange County, California,

00:01:37.278 --> 00:01:40.614
who returned to work
in a social services organization

00:01:40.638 --> 00:01:43.414
after a 25-year career break.

00:01:43.438 --> 00:01:45.798
That's the longest career break
that I'm aware of.

00:01:46.238 --> 00:01:48.774
Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor

00:01:48.798 --> 00:01:51.638
took a five-year career break
early in her career.

00:01:52.678 --> 00:01:56.878
And this is Tracy Shapiro,
who took a 13-year career break.

00:01:57.358 --> 00:02:01.294
Tracy answered a call for essays
by the Today Show

00:02:01.318 --> 00:02:03.734
from people who were trying
to return to work

00:02:03.758 --> 00:02:05.598
but having a difficult time of it.

00:02:06.118 --> 00:02:10.574
Tracy wrote in that she was a mom of five
who loved her time at home,

00:02:10.598 --> 00:02:14.134
but she had gone through a divorce
and needed to return to work,

00:02:14.158 --> 00:02:17.094
plus she really wanted
to bring work back into her life

00:02:17.118 --> 00:02:18.758
because she loved working.

00:02:19.478 --> 00:02:22.054
Tracy was doing what so many of us do

00:02:22.078 --> 00:02:25.814
when we feel like we've put in
a good day in the job search.

00:02:25.838 --> 00:02:28.814
She was looking for a finance
or accounting role,

00:02:28.838 --> 00:02:31.534
and she had just spent
the last nine months

00:02:31.558 --> 00:02:34.854
very diligently researching
companies online

00:02:34.878 --> 00:02:37.638
and applying for jobs with no results.

00:02:38.078 --> 00:02:41.814
I met Tracy in June of 2011,

00:02:41.838 --> 00:02:45.374
when the Today Show asked me
if I could work with her

00:02:45.398 --> 00:02:47.558
to see if I could help her
turn things around.

00:02:48.118 --> 00:02:51.574
The first thing I told Tracy
was she had to get out of the house.

00:02:51.598 --> 00:02:54.334
I told her she had to go public
with her job search

00:02:54.358 --> 00:02:58.198
and tell everyone she knew
about her interest in returning to work.

00:02:58.638 --> 00:03:02.414
I also told her, "You are going
to have a lot of conversations

00:03:02.438 --> 00:03:04.014
that don't go anywhere.

00:03:04.038 --> 00:03:07.294
Expect that, and don't
be discouraged by it.

00:03:07.318 --> 00:03:08.894
There will be a handful

00:03:08.918 --> 00:03:11.758
that ultimately lead
to a job opportunity."

00:03:12.638 --> 00:03:15.254
I'll tell you what happened
with Tracy in a little bit,

00:03:15.278 --> 00:03:17.707
but I want to share with you
a discovery that I made

00:03:17.731 --> 00:03:19.454
when I was returning to work

00:03:19.478 --> 00:03:23.574
after my own career break of 11 years
out of the full-time workforce.

00:03:23.598 --> 00:03:28.838
And that is, that people's view of you
is frozen in time.

00:03:29.278 --> 00:03:32.934
What I mean by this is,
when you start to get in touch with people

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.694
and you get back in touch
with those people from the past,

00:03:35.718 --> 00:03:38.974
the people with whom you worked
or went to school,

00:03:38.998 --> 00:03:41.734
they are going to remember you as you were

00:03:41.758 --> 00:03:43.574
before your career break.

00:03:43.598 --> 00:03:47.094
And that's even if your sense of self
has diminished over time,

00:03:47.118 --> 00:03:49.214
as happens with so many of us

00:03:49.238 --> 00:03:53.134
the farther removed we are
from our professional identities.

00:03:53.158 --> 00:03:55.854
So for example,
you might think of yourself

00:03:55.878 --> 00:03:57.358
as someone who looks like this.

00:03:57.758 --> 00:04:02.054
This is me, crazy after a day
of driving around in my minivan.

00:04:02.078 --> 00:04:04.278
Or here I am in the kitchen.

00:04:04.718 --> 00:04:07.254
But those people from the past,

00:04:07.278 --> 00:04:09.494
they don't know about any of this.

00:04:09.518 --> 00:04:12.054
They only remember you as you were,

00:04:12.078 --> 00:04:16.254
and it's a great confidence boost
to be back in touch with these people

00:04:16.278 --> 00:04:19.918
and hear their enthusiasm
about your interest in returning to work.

00:04:21.398 --> 00:04:25.494
There's one more thing I remember vividly
from my own career break.

00:04:25.518 --> 00:04:28.893
And that was that I hardly kept up
with the business news.

00:04:28.917 --> 00:04:30.534
My background is in finance,

00:04:30.558 --> 00:04:32.974
and I hardly kept up with any news

00:04:32.998 --> 00:04:35.934
when I was home caring
for my four young children.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:39.334
So I was afraid I'd go into an interview

00:04:39.358 --> 00:04:42.718
and start talking about a company
that didn't exist anymore.

00:04:43.158 --> 00:04:46.694
So I had to resubscribe
to the Wall Street Journal

00:04:46.718 --> 00:04:50.174
and read it for a good six months
cover to cover before I felt

00:04:50.198 --> 00:04:54.118
like I had a handle on what was going on
in the business world again.

00:04:55.838 --> 00:04:59.494
I believe relaunchers
are a gem of the workforce,

00:04:59.518 --> 00:05:01.254
and here's why.

00:05:01.278 --> 00:05:03.094
Think about our life stage:

00:05:03.118 --> 00:05:06.774
for those of us who took career breaks
for childcare reasons,

00:05:06.798 --> 00:05:08.774
we have fewer or no maternity leaves.

00:05:08.798 --> 00:05:10.294
We did that already.

00:05:10.318 --> 00:05:13.654
We have fewer spousal
or partner job relocations.

00:05:13.678 --> 00:05:16.134
We're in a more settled time of life.

00:05:16.158 --> 00:05:17.974
We have great work experience.

00:05:17.998 --> 00:05:20.014
We have a more mature perspective.

00:05:20.038 --> 00:05:23.614
We're not trying to find ourselves
at an employer's expense.

00:05:23.638 --> 00:05:27.854
Plus we have an energy,
an enthusiasm about returning to work

00:05:27.878 --> 00:05:30.798
precisely because we've been
away from it for a while.

00:05:31.558 --> 00:05:34.174
On the flip side, I speak with employers,

00:05:34.198 --> 00:05:36.734
and here are two concerns
that employers have

00:05:36.758 --> 00:05:38.654
about hiring relaunchers.

00:05:38.678 --> 00:05:41.734
The first one is, employers
are worried that relaunchers

00:05:41.758 --> 00:05:43.798
are technologically obsolete.

00:05:44.358 --> 00:05:45.614
Now, I can tell you,

00:05:45.638 --> 00:05:49.214
having been technologically
obsolete myself at one point,

00:05:49.238 --> 00:05:50.918
that it's a temporary condition.

00:05:51.478 --> 00:05:57.614
I had done my financial analysis
so long ago that I used Lotus 1-2-3.

00:05:57.638 --> 00:06:00.574
I don't know if anyone
can even remember back that far,

00:06:00.598 --> 00:06:02.814
but I had to relearn it on Excel.

00:06:02.838 --> 00:06:05.918
It actually wasn't that hard.
A lot of the commands are the same.

00:06:06.558 --> 00:06:08.774
I found PowerPoint much more challenging,

00:06:08.798 --> 00:06:10.958
but now I use PowerPoint all the time.

00:06:11.918 --> 00:06:16.574
I tell relaunchers that employers
expect them to come to the table

00:06:16.598 --> 00:06:20.094
with a working knowledge
of basic office management software.

00:06:20.118 --> 00:06:21.854
And if they're not up to speed,

00:06:21.878 --> 00:06:24.254
then it's their
responsibility to get there.

00:06:24.278 --> 00:06:25.478
And they do.

00:06:25.918 --> 00:06:29.534
The second area of concern
that employers have about relaunchers

00:06:29.558 --> 00:06:32.758
is they're worried that relaunchers
don't know what they want to do.

00:06:33.398 --> 00:06:36.614
I tell relaunchers that they need
to do the hard work

00:06:36.638 --> 00:06:40.134
to figure out whether their interests
and skills have changed

00:06:40.158 --> 00:06:41.734
or have not changed

00:06:41.758 --> 00:06:43.574
while they have been on career break.

00:06:43.598 --> 00:06:45.854
That's not the employer's job.

00:06:45.878 --> 00:06:50.454
It's the relauncher's responsibility
to demonstrate to the employer

00:06:50.478 --> 00:06:52.398
where they can add the most value.

00:06:54.518 --> 00:06:57.798
Back in 2010 I started noticing something.

00:06:58.358 --> 00:07:02.494
I had been tracking
return to work programs since 2008,

00:07:02.518 --> 00:07:05.814
and in 2010, I started noticing

00:07:05.838 --> 00:07:09.734
the use of a short-term
paid work opportunity,

00:07:09.758 --> 00:07:12.214
whether it was called
an internship or not,

00:07:12.238 --> 00:07:14.574
but an internship-like experience,

00:07:14.598 --> 00:07:17.734
as a way for professionals
to return to work.

00:07:17.758 --> 00:07:20.534
I saw Goldman Sachs and Sara Lee

00:07:20.558 --> 00:07:23.854
start corporate reentry
internship programs.

00:07:23.878 --> 00:07:28.318
I saw a returning engineer,
a nontraditional reentry candidate,

00:07:29.078 --> 00:07:32.894
apply for an entry-level
internship program in the military,

00:07:32.918 --> 00:07:35.278
and then get a permanent job afterward.

00:07:35.838 --> 00:07:39.534
I saw two universities
integrate internships

00:07:39.558 --> 00:07:42.598
into mid-career executive
education programs.

00:07:43.158 --> 00:07:45.974
So I wrote a report
about what I was seeing,

00:07:45.998 --> 00:07:48.974
and it became this article
for Harvard Business Review

00:07:48.998 --> 00:07:50.894
called "The 40-Year-Old Intern."

00:07:50.918 --> 00:07:53.534
I have to thank the editors
there for that title,

00:07:53.558 --> 00:07:54.934
and also for this artwork

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:59.294
where you can see the 40-year-old intern
in the midst of all the college interns.

00:07:59.318 --> 00:08:02.494
And then, courtesy of Fox Business News,

00:08:02.518 --> 00:08:05.694
they called the concept
"The 50-Year-Old Intern."

00:08:05.718 --> 00:08:09.534
(Laughter)

00:08:09.558 --> 00:08:13.414
So five of the biggest
financial services companies

00:08:13.438 --> 00:08:17.574
have reentry internship programs
for returning finance professionals.

00:08:17.598 --> 00:08:20.894
And at this point,
hundreds of people have participated.

00:08:20.918 --> 00:08:22.694
These internships are paid,

00:08:22.718 --> 00:08:25.454
and the people who move on
to permanent roles

00:08:25.478 --> 00:08:28.158
are commanding competitive salaries.

00:08:28.638 --> 00:08:32.094
And now, seven of the biggest
engineering companies

00:08:32.118 --> 00:08:36.414
are piloting reentry internship programs
for returning engineers

00:08:36.438 --> 00:08:40.158
as part of an initiative
with the Society of Women Engineers.

00:08:41.518 --> 00:08:45.358
Now, why are companies embracing
the reentry internship?

00:08:46.398 --> 00:08:49.374
Because the internship allows the employer

00:08:49.398 --> 00:08:53.414
to base their hiring decision
on an actual work sample

00:08:53.438 --> 00:08:55.493
instead of a series of interviews,

00:08:55.517 --> 00:08:59.254
and the employer does not have to make
that permanent hiring decision

00:08:59.278 --> 00:09:02.078
until the internship period is over.

00:09:02.598 --> 00:09:06.494
This testing out period
removes the perceived risk

00:09:06.518 --> 00:09:10.094
that some managers attach
to hiring relaunchers,

00:09:10.118 --> 00:09:12.774
and they are attracting
excellent candidates

00:09:12.798 --> 00:09:14.638
who are turning into great hires.

00:09:15.198 --> 00:09:17.158
Think about how far we have come.

00:09:17.518 --> 00:09:20.494
Before this, most employers
were not interested

00:09:20.518 --> 00:09:22.854
in engaging with relaunchers at all.

00:09:22.878 --> 00:09:26.374
But now, not only
are programs being developed

00:09:26.398 --> 00:09:28.934
specifically with relaunchers in mind,

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.454
but you can't even apply
for these programs

00:09:31.478 --> 00:09:34.158
unless you have a gap on your résumé.

00:09:34.798 --> 00:09:36.894
This is the mark of real change,

00:09:36.918 --> 00:09:39.174
of true institutional shift,

00:09:39.198 --> 00:09:42.734
because if we can solve
this problem for relaunchers,

00:09:42.758 --> 00:09:46.054
we can solve it for other
career transitioners too.

00:09:46.078 --> 00:09:48.014
In fact, an employer just told me

00:09:48.038 --> 00:09:50.534
that their veterans return to work program

00:09:50.558 --> 00:09:53.934
is based on their reentry
internship program.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:58.974
And there's no reason why there can't be
a retiree internship program.

00:09:58.998 --> 00:10:01.478
Different pool, same concept.

00:10:02.358 --> 00:10:04.814
So let me tell you
what happened with Tracy Shapiro.

00:10:04.838 --> 00:10:07.414
Remember that she had to tell
everyone she knew

00:10:07.438 --> 00:10:09.438
about her interest in returning to work.

00:10:09.758 --> 00:10:13.934
Well, one critical conversation
with another parent in her community

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.054
led to a job offer for Tracy,

00:10:16.078 --> 00:10:18.854
and it was an accounting job
in a finance department.

00:10:18.878 --> 00:10:20.198
But it was a temp job.

00:10:20.758 --> 00:10:23.214
The company told her
there was a possibility

00:10:23.238 --> 00:10:26.774
it could turn into something more,
but no guarantees.

00:10:26.798 --> 00:10:29.158
This was in the fall of 2011.

00:10:29.678 --> 00:10:32.694
Tracy loved this company,
and she loved the people

00:10:32.718 --> 00:10:35.774
and the office was less
than 10 minutes from her house.

00:10:35.798 --> 00:10:38.014
So even though she had a second job offer

00:10:38.038 --> 00:10:40.934
at another company
for a permanent full-time role,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:44.174
she decided to take her chances
with this internship

00:10:44.198 --> 00:10:45.958
and hope for the best.

00:10:47.278 --> 00:10:50.334
Well, she ended up blowing away
all of their expectations,

00:10:50.358 --> 00:10:52.854
and the company not only
made her a permanent offer

00:10:52.878 --> 00:10:54.974
at the beginning of 2012,

00:10:54.998 --> 00:10:57.614
but they made it even more
interesting and challenging,

00:10:57.638 --> 00:10:59.758
because they knew what Tracy could handle.

00:11:00.358 --> 00:11:02.814
Fast forward to 2015,

00:11:02.838 --> 00:11:04.414
Tracy's been promoted.

00:11:04.438 --> 00:11:06.854
They've paid for her
to get her MBA at night.

00:11:06.878 --> 00:11:10.198
She's even hired another relauncher
to work for her.

00:11:11.798 --> 00:11:15.174
Tracy's temp job was a tryout,

00:11:15.198 --> 00:11:16.854
just like an internship,

00:11:16.878 --> 00:11:22.118
and it ended up being a win
for both Tracy and her employer.

00:11:23.558 --> 00:11:27.934
Now, my goal is to bring
the reentry internship concept

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.694
to more and more employers.

00:11:30.718 --> 00:11:32.534
But in the meantime,

00:11:32.558 --> 00:11:35.774
if you are returning to work
after a career break,

00:11:35.798 --> 00:11:41.814
don't hesitate to suggest an internship
or an internship-like arrangement

00:11:41.838 --> 00:11:47.454
to an employer that does not have
a formal reentry internship program.

00:11:47.478 --> 00:11:49.774
Be their first success story,

00:11:49.798 --> 00:11:53.438
and you can be the example
for more relaunchers to come.

00:11:53.878 --> 00:11:55.094
Thank you.

00:11:55.118 --> 00:12:00.283
(Applause)

title: You have no idea where camels really come from
transcript: So, this is a story about how we know what we know.It's a story about this woman, Natalia Rybczynski. She's a paleobiologist, which means she specializes in digging up really old dead stuff.(Audio) Natalia Rybczynski: Yeah, I had someone call me "Dr. Dead Things."Latif Nasser: And I think she's particularly interesting because of where she digs that stuff up, way above the Arctic Circle in the remote Canadian tundra.Now, one summer day in 2006, she was at a dig site called the Fyles Leaf Bed, which is less than 10 degrees latitude away from the magnetic north pole.(Audio) NR: Really, it's not going to sound very exciting, because it was a day of walking with your backpack and your GPS and notebook and just picking up anything that might be a fossil.LN: And at some point, she noticed something.(Audio) NR: Rusty, kind of rust-colored, about the size of the palm of my hand. It was just lying on the surface.LN: And at first she thought it was just a splinter of wood, because that's the sort of thing people had found at the Fyles Leaf Bed before — prehistoric plant parts. But that night, back at camp ...(Audio) NR: ... I get out the hand lens, I'm looking a little bit more closely and realizing it doesn't quite look like this has tree rings. Maybe it's a preservation thing, but it looks really like ... bone.LN: Huh. So over the next four years, she went to that spot over and over, and eventually collected 30 fragments of that exact same bone, most of them really tiny.(Audio) NR: It's not a whole lot. It fits in a small Ziploc bag.LN: And she tried to piece them together like a jigsaw puzzle. But it was challenging.(Audio) NR: It's broken up into so many little tiny pieces, I'm trying to use sand and putty, and it's not looking good. So finally, we used a 3D surface scanner.LN: Ooh! NR: Yeah, right?(Laughter)LN: It turns out it was way easier to do it virtually.(Audio) NR: It's kind of magical when it all fits together.LN: How certain were you that you had it right, that you had put it together in the right way? 00:00:32.321 --> 00:00:34.950

00:00:44.938 --> 00:00:48.129

title: How young Africans found a voice on Twitter
transcript: It began with one question: If Africa was a bar, what would your country be drinking or doing? I kicked it off with a guess about South Africa, which wasn't exactly according to the rules because South Africa's not my country. But alluding to the country's continual attempts to build a postracial society after being ravaged for decades by apartheid, I tweeted, #ifafricawasabar South Africa would be drinking all kinds of alcohol and begging them to get along in its stomach.And then I waited. And then I had that funny feeling where I wondered if I crossed the line. So, I sent out a few other tweets about my own country and a few other African countries I'm familiar with. And then I waited again, but this time I read through almost every tweet I had ever tweeted to convince myself, no, to remind myself that I'm really funny and that if nobody gets it, that's fine.But luckily, I didn't have to do that for very long. Very soon, people were participating. In fact, by the end of that week in July, the hashtag #ifafricawasabar would have garnered around 60,000 tweets, lit up the continent and made its way to publications all over the world.People were using the hashtag to do many different things. To poke fun at their stereotypes: [#IfAfricaWasABar Nigeria would be outside explaining that he will pay the entrance fee, all he needs is the bouncer's account details.](Laughter)To criticize government spending: [#ifafricawasabar South Africa would be ordering bottles it can't pronounce running a tab it won't be able to pay]To make light of geopolitical tensions: [#IfAfricaWasABar South Sudan would be the new guy with serious anger management issues.]To remind us that even in Africa there are some countries we don't know exist: [#IfAfricaWasABar Lesotho would be that person who nobody really knows but is always in the pictures.]And also to make fun of the countries that don't think that they're in Africa: [#IfAfricaWasABar Egypt, Libya, Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco be like "What the hell are we doing here?!!"](Laughter)And to note the countries that had made a big turnaround: [#ifAfricawasabar Rwanda would be that girl that comes with no money and no transport but leaves drunk, happy and rich]But most importantly, people were using the hashtag to connect. People were connecting over their Africanness. So for one week in July, Twitter became a real African bar. And I was really thrilled, mainly because I realized that Pan-Africanism could work, that we had before us, between us, at our fingertips a platform that just needed a small spark to light in us a hunger for each other.My name is Siyanda Mohutsiwa, I'm 22 years old and I am Pan-Africanist by birth. Now, I say I'm Pan-Africanist by birth because my parents are from two different African countries. My father's from a country called Botswana in southern Africa. It's only slightly bigger than Germany. This year we celebrate our 50th year of stable democracy. And it has some very progressive social policies. My mother's country is the Kingdom of Swaziland. It's a very, very small country, also in southern Africa. It is Africa's last complete monarchy. So it's been ruled by a king and a royal family in line with their tradition, for a very long time.On paper, these countries seem very different. And when I was a kid, I could see the difference. It rained a lot in one country, it didn't rain quite as much in the other. But outside of that, I didn't really realize why it mattered that my parents were from two different places. But it would go on to have a very peculiar effect on me. You see, I was born in one country and raised in the other.When we moved to Botswana, I was a toddler who spoke fluent SiSwati and nothing else. So I was being introduced to my new home, my new cultural identity, as a complete outsider, incapable of comprehending anything that was being said to me by the family and country whose traditions I was meant to move forward. But very soon, I would shed SiSwati. And when I would go back to Swaziland, I would be constantly confronted by how very non-Swazi I was becoming.Add to that my entry into Africa's private school system, whose entire purpose is to beat the Africanness out of you, and I would have a very peculiar adolescence. But I think that my interest in ideas of identity was born here, in the strange intersection of belonging to two places at once but not really belonging to either one very well and belonging to this vast space in between and around simultaneously. I became obsessed with the idea of a shared African identity.Since then, I have continued to read about politics and geography and identity and what all those things mean. I've also held on to a deep curiosity about African philosophies. When I began to read, I gravitated towards the works of black intellectuals like Steve Biko and Frantz Fanon, who tackled complex ideas like decolonization and black consciousness. And when I thought, at 14, that I had digested these grand ideas, I moved on to the speeches of iconic African statesmen like Burkina Faso's Thomas Sankara and Congo's Patrice Lumumba. I read every piece of African fiction that I could get my hands on.So when Twitter came, I hopped on with the enthusiasm of a teenage girl whose friends are super, super bored of hearing about all this random stuff.The year was 2011 and all over southern Africa and the whole continent, affordable data packages for smartphones and Internet surfing became much easier to get. So my generation, we were sending messages to each other on this platform that just needed 140 characters and a little bit of creativity. On long commutes to work, in lectures that some of us should have been paying attention to, on our lunch breaks, we would communicate as much as we could about the everyday realities of being young and African.But of course, this luxury was not available to everybody. So this meant that if you were a teenage girl in Botswana and you wanted to have fun on the Internet, one, you had to tweet in English. Two, you had to follow more than just the three other people you knew online. You had to follow South Africans, Zimbabweans, Ghanaians, Nigerians. And suddenly, your whole world opened up. And my whole world did open up.I followed vibrant Africans who were travelling around the continent, taking pictures of themselves and posting them under the hashtag #myafrica. Because at that time, if you were to search Africa on Twitter or on Google or any kind of social media, you would think that the entire continent was just pictures of animals and white guys drinking cocktails in hotel resorts.(Laughter)But Africans were using this platform to take some kind of ownership of the tourism sectors. It was Africans taking selfies on the beaches of Nigeria. It was Africans in cocktail bars in Nairobi.And these were the same Africans that I began to meet in my own travels around the continent. We would discuss African literature, politics, economic policy. But almost invariably, every single time, we would end up discussing Twitter. And that's when I realized what this was. We were standing in the middle of something amazing, because for the first time ever young Africans could discuss the future of our continent in real time, without the restriction of borders, finances and watchful governments.Because the little known truth is many Africans know a lot less about other African countries than some Westerners might know about Africa as a whole. This is by accident, but sometimes, it's by design. For example, in apartheid South Africa, black South Africans were constantly being bombarded with this message that any country ruled by black people was destined for failure. And this was done to convince them that they were much better off under crushing white rule than they were living in a black and free nation. Add to that Africa's colonial, archaic education system, which has been unthinkingly carried over from the 1920s — and at the age of 15, I could name all the various causes of the wars that had happened in Europe in the past 200 years, but I couldn't name the president of my neighboring country. And to me, this doesn't make any sense because whether we like it or not, the fates of African people are deeply intertwined.When disaster hits, when turmoil hits, we share the consequences. When Burundians flee political turmoil, they go to us, to other African countries. Africa has six of the world's largest refugee centers. What was once a Burundian problem becomes an African problem. So to me, there are no Sudanese problems or South African problems or Kenyan problems, only African problems because eventually, we share the turmoil.So if we share the problems, why aren't we doing a better job of sharing the successes? How can we do that? Well, in the long term, we can shoot towards increasing inter-African trade, removing borders and putting pressure on leaders to fulfill regional agreements they've already signed. But I think that the biggest way for Africa to share its successes is to foster something I like to call social Pan-Africanism.Now, political Pan-Africanism already exists, so I'm not inventing anything totally new here. But political Pan-Africanism is usually the African unity of the political elite. And who does that benefit? Well, African leaders, almost exclusively. No, what I'm talking about is the Pan-Africanism of the ordinary African. Young Africans like me, we are bursting with creative energy, with innovative ideas. But with bad governance and shaky institutions, all of this potential could go to waste. On a continent where more than a handful of leaders have been in power longer than the majority of the populations has been alive, we are in desperate need of something new, something that works. And I think that thing is social Pan-Africanism.My dream is that young Africans stop allowing borders and circumstance to suffocate our innovation. My dream is that when a young African comes up with something brilliant, they don't say, "Well, this wouldn't work in my country," and then give up. My dream is that young Africans begin to realize that the entire continent is our canvas, is our home. Using the Internet, we can begin to think collaboratively, we can begin to innovate together. In Africa, we say, "If you want to go fast, you go alone, but if you want to go far, you go together." And I believe that social Pan-Africanism is how we can go far together.And this is already happening. Access to these online networks has given young Africans something we've always had to violently take: a voice. We now have a platform. Before now, if you wanted to hear from the youth in Africa, you waited for the 65-year-old minister of youth —(Laughter)to wake up in the morning, take his heartburn medication and then tell you the plans he has for your generation in 20 years time. Before now, if you wanted to be heard by your possibly tyrannical government, you were pushed to protest, suffer the consequences and have your fingers crossed that some Western paper somewhere might make someone care. But now we have opportunities to back each other up in ways we never could before.We support South African students who are marching against ridiculously high tertiary fees. We support Zimbabwean women who are marching to parliament. We support Angolan journalists who are being illegally detained. For the first time ever, African pain and African aspiration has the ability to be witnessed by those who can empathize with it the most: other Africans.I believe that with a social Pan-Africanist thinking and using the Internet as a tool, we can begin to rescue each other, and ultimately, to rescue ourselves.Thank you.(Applause)
