and we rely on them to feed
all the mouths of human civilization.

00:06:28.118 --> 00:06:31.534
Nature does stuff like this already,

00:06:31.558 --> 00:06:33.094
without our help.

00:06:33.118 --> 00:06:36.198
We have simply found
more precise ways to do it.

00:06:37.438 --> 00:06:40.918
So why would we want to change
the genetic makeup of plants for space?

00:06:42.078 --> 00:06:45.654
Well, to not do so
would mean needing to engineer

00:06:45.678 --> 00:06:49.094
endless acres of land
on an entirely new planet

00:06:49.118 --> 00:06:52.614
by releasing trillions of gallons
of atmospheric gasses

00:06:52.638 --> 00:06:55.678
and then constructing
a giant glass dome to contain it all.

00:06:56.438 --> 00:06:58.494
It's an unrealistic engineering enterprise

00:06:58.518 --> 00:07:02.038
that quickly becomes
a high-cost cargo transport mission.

00:07:03.198 --> 00:07:04.654
One of the best ways to ensure

00:07:04.678 --> 00:07:07.774
that we will have the food supplies
and the air that we need

00:07:07.798 --> 00:07:10.894
is to bring with us organisms
that have been engineered

00:07:10.918 --> 00:07:13.478
to adapt to new and harsh environments.

00:07:14.718 --> 00:07:18.694
In essence, using engineered organisms
to help us terraform a planet

00:07:18.718 --> 00:07:20.758
both in the short and long term.

00:07:22.358 --> 00:07:26.358
These organisms can then also
be engineered to make medicine or fuel.

00:07:27.878 --> 00:07:31.614
So we can use synthetic biology
to bring highly engineered plants with us,

00:07:31.638 --> 00:07:32.878
but what else can we do?

00:07:33.838 --> 00:07:36.694
Well, I mentioned earlier
that we, as a species,

00:07:36.718 --> 00:07:39.038
were evolved uniquely for planet Earth.

00:07:39.758 --> 00:07:42.374
That fact has not changed much
in the last five minutes

00:07:42.398 --> 00:07:44.838
that you were sitting here
and I was standing there.

00:07:45.438 --> 00:07:49.134
And so, if we were to dump
any of us on Mars right this minute,

00:07:49.158 --> 00:07:52.654
even given ample food, water, air

00:07:52.678 --> 00:07:53.894
and a suit,

00:07:53.918 --> 00:07:57.294
we are likely to experience
very unpleasant health problems

00:07:57.318 --> 00:08:00.614
from the amount of ionizing radiation
that bombards the surface

00:08:00.638 --> 00:08:04.478
of planets like Mars that have little
or nonexistent atmosphere.

00:08:05.238 --> 00:08:07.254
Unless we plan
to stay holed up underground

00:08:07.278 --> 00:08:09.918
for the duration of our stay
on every new planet,

00:08:10.438 --> 00:08:13.014
we must find better ways
of protecting ourselves

00:08:13.038 --> 00:08:15.694
without needing to resort
to wearing a suit of armor

00:08:15.718 --> 00:08:18.174
that weighs something
equal to your own body weight,

00:08:18.198 --> 00:08:20.478
or needing to hide behind a wall of lead.

00:08:22.198 --> 00:08:24.798
So let us appeal
to nature for inspiration.

00:08:26.158 --> 00:08:28.254
Among the plethora of life here on Earth,

00:08:28.278 --> 00:08:31.134
there's a subset of organisms
known as extremophiles,

00:08:31.158 --> 00:08:33.134
or lovers of extreme living conditions,

00:08:33.158 --> 00:08:35.614
if you'll remember
from high school biology.

00:08:35.638 --> 00:08:40.118
And among these organisms is a bacterium
by the name of Deinococcus radiodurans.

00:08:40.998 --> 00:08:46.374
It is known to be able to withstand cold,
dehydration, vacuum, acid,

00:08:46.398 --> 00:08:48.598
and, most notably, radiation.

00:08:49.398 --> 00:08:52.093
While its radiation
tolerance mechanisms are known,

00:08:52.117 --> 00:08:54.517
we have yet to adapt
the relevant genes to mammals.

00:08:55.478 --> 00:08:58.094
To do so is not particularly easy.

00:08:58.118 --> 00:09:00.934
There are many facets
that go into its radiation tolerance,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.198
and it's not as simple
as transferring one gene.

00:09:03.918 --> 00:09:07.174
But given a little bit of human ingenuity

00:09:07.198 --> 00:09:08.454
and a little bit of time,

00:09:08.478 --> 00:09:10.918
I think to do so is not very hard either.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:17.718
Even if we borrow just a fraction
of its ability to tolerate radiation,

00:09:18.358 --> 00:09:21.374
it would be infinitely better
than what we already have,

00:09:21.398 --> 00:09:23.358
which is just the melanin in our skin.

00:09:24.518 --> 00:09:26.534
Using the tools of synthetic biology,

00:09:26.558 --> 00:09:29.574
we can harness Deinococcus
radiodurans' ability

00:09:29.598 --> 00:09:33.318
to thrive under otherwise
very lethal doses of radiation.

00:09:35.718 --> 00:09:37.198
As difficult as it is to see,

00:09:37.878 --> 00:09:40.198
homo sapiens, that is humans,

00:09:41.158 --> 00:09:43.454
evolves every day,

00:09:43.478 --> 00:09:45.398
and still continues to evolve.

00:09:46.318 --> 00:09:48.094
Thousands of years of human evolution

00:09:48.118 --> 00:09:51.094
has not only given us
humans like Tibetans,

00:09:51.118 --> 00:09:53.694
who can thrive in low-oxygen conditions,

00:09:53.718 --> 00:09:58.654
but also Argentinians,
who can ingest and metabolize arsenic,

00:09:58.678 --> 00:10:01.478
the chemical element
that can kill the average human being.

00:10:02.318 --> 00:10:06.014
Every day, the human body evolves
by accidental mutations

00:10:06.038 --> 00:10:08.894
that equally accidentally
allow certain humans

00:10:08.918 --> 00:10:11.158
to persevere in dismal situations.

00:10:12.118 --> 00:10:13.998
But, and this is a big but,

00:10:15.438 --> 00:10:19.614
such evolution requires two things
that we may not always have,

00:10:19.638 --> 00:10:21.078
or be able to afford,

00:10:22.078 --> 00:10:24.318
and they are death and time.

00:10:25.518 --> 00:10:28.534
In our species' struggle
to find our place in the universe,

00:10:28.558 --> 00:10:31.014
we may not always have the time necessary

00:10:31.038 --> 00:10:33.574
for the natural evolution
of extra functions

00:10:33.598 --> 00:10:35.598
for survival on non-Earth planets.

00:10:36.318 --> 00:10:40.814
We're living in what E.O. Wilson
has termed the age of gene circumvention,

00:10:40.838 --> 00:10:46.214
during which we remedy our genetic defects
like cystic fibrosis or muscular dystrophy

00:10:46.238 --> 00:10:48.838
with temporary external supplements.

00:10:49.918 --> 00:10:51.454
But with every passing day,

00:10:51.478 --> 00:10:54.654
we approach the age
of volitional evolution,

00:10:54.678 --> 00:10:56.654
a time during which we as a species

00:10:56.678 --> 00:11:01.558
will have the capacity to decide
for ourselves our own genetic destiny.

00:11:02.678 --> 00:11:05.014
Augmenting the human body
with new abilities

00:11:05.038 --> 00:11:07.118
is no longer a question of how,

00:11:07.878 --> 00:11:09.078
but of when.

00:11:10.198 --> 00:11:11.454
Using synthetic biology

00:11:11.478 --> 00:11:14.574
to change the genetic makeup
of any living organisms,

00:11:14.598 --> 00:11:15.814
especially our own,

00:11:15.838 --> 00:11:18.158
is not without its moral
and ethical quandaries.

00:11:19.238 --> 00:11:21.758
Will engineering ourselves
make us less human?

00:11:22.918 --> 00:11:25.174
But then again, what is humanity

00:11:25.198 --> 00:11:27.718
but star stuff
that happens to be conscious?

00:11:29.158 --> 00:11:31.598
Where should human genius direct itself?

00:11:32.598 --> 00:11:36.518
Surely it is a bit of a waste
to sit back and marvel at it.

00:11:37.758 --> 00:11:39.094
How do we use our knowledge

00:11:39.118 --> 00:11:42.374
to protect ourselves
from the external dangers

00:11:42.398 --> 00:11:45.038
and then protect ourselves from ourselves?

00:11:46.358 --> 00:11:47.774
I pose these questions

00:11:47.798 --> 00:11:49.974
not to engender the fear of science

00:11:49.998 --> 00:11:52.374
but to bring to light
the many possibilities

00:11:52.398 --> 00:11:55.798
that science has afforded
and continues to afford us.

00:11:56.718 --> 00:12:00.694
We must coalesce as humans
to discuss and embrace the solutions

00:12:00.718 --> 00:12:01.918
not only with caution

00:12:02.598 --> 00:12:04.558
but also with courage.

00:12:06.158 --> 00:12:09.758
Mars is a destination,

00:12:10.398 --> 00:12:11.998
but it will not be our last.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.814
Our true final frontier
is the line we must cross

00:12:15.838 --> 00:12:20.558
in deciding what we can and should make
of our species' improbable intelligence.

00:12:21.838 --> 00:12:26.078
Space is cold, brutal and unforgiving.

00:12:27.078 --> 00:12:29.494
Our path to the stars
will be rife with trials

00:12:29.518 --> 00:12:32.494
that will bring us to question
not only who we are

00:12:32.518 --> 00:12:34.278
but where we will be going.

00:12:35.118 --> 00:12:38.694
The answers will lie in our choice
to use or abandon the technology

00:12:38.718 --> 00:12:40.814
that we have gleaned from life itself,

00:12:40.838 --> 00:12:44.694
and it will define us for the remainder
of our term in this universe.

00:12:44.718 --> 00:12:45.934
Thank you.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:50.577
(Applause)

title: Two reasons companies fail -- and how to avoid them
transcript: Here are two reasons companies fail: they only do more of the same, or they only do what's new.To me the real, real solution to quality growth is figuring out the balance between two activities: exploration and exploitation. Both are necessary, but it can be too much of a good thing.Consider Facit. I'm actually old enough to remember them. Facit was a fantastic company. They were born deep in the Swedish forest, and they made the best mechanical calculators in the world. Everybody used them. And what did Facit do when the electronic calculator came along? They continued doing exactly the same. In six months, they went from maximum revenue ... and they were gone. Gone.To me, the irony about the Facit story is hearing about the Facit engineers, who had bought cheap, small electronic calculators in Japan that they used to double-check their calculators.(Laughter)Facit did too much exploitation. But exploration can go wild, too.A few years back, I worked closely alongside a European biotech company. Let's call them OncoSearch. The company was brilliant. They had applications that promised to diagnose, even cure, certain forms of blood cancer. Every day was about creating something new. They were extremely innovative, and the mantra was, "When we only get it right," or even, "We want it perfect." The sad thing is, before they became perfect — even good enough — they became obsolete. OncoSearch did too much exploration.I first heard about exploration and exploitation about 15 years ago, when I worked as a visiting scholar at Stanford University. The founder of the idea is Jim March. And to me the power of the idea is its practicality.Exploration. Exploration is about coming up with what's new. It's about search, it's about discovery, it's about new products, it's about new innovations. It's about changing our frontiers. Our heroes are people who have done exploration: Madame Curie, Picasso, Neil Armstrong, Sir Edmund Hillary, etc. I come from Norway; all our heroes are explorers, and they deserve to be. We all know that exploration is risky. We don't know the answers, we don't know if we're going to find them, and we know that the risks are high.Exploitation is the opposite. Exploitation is taking the knowledge we have and making good, better. Exploitation is about making our trains run on time. It's about making good products faster and cheaper. Exploitation is not risky — in the short term. But if we only exploit, it's very risky in the long term. And I think we all have memories of the famous pop groups who keep singing the same songs again and again, until they become obsolete or even pathetic. That's the risk of exploitation.So if we take a long-term perspective, we explore. If we take a short-term perspective, we exploit. Small children, they explore all day. All day it's about exploration. As we grow older, we explore less because we have more knowledge to exploit on. The same goes for companies. Companies become, by nature, less innovative as they become more competent.And this is, of course, a big worry to CEOs. And I hear very often questions phrased in different ways. For example, "How can I both effectively run and reinvent my company?" Or, "How can I make sure that our company changes before we become obsolete or are hit by a crisis?" So, doing one well is difficult. Doing both well as the same time is art — pushing both exploration and exploitation.So one thing we've found is only about two percent of companies are able to effectively explore and exploit at the same time, in parallel. But when they do, the payoffs are huge. So we have lots of great examples. We have Nestlé creating Nespresso, we have Lego going into animated films, Toyota creating the hybrids, Unilever pushing into sustainability — there are lots of examples, and the benefits are huge.Why is balancing so difficult? I think it's difficult because there are so many traps that keep us where we are. So I'll talk about two, but there are many.So let's talk about the perpetual search trap. We discover something, but we don't have the patience or the persistence to get at it and make it work. So instead of staying with it, we create something new. But the same goes for that, then we're in the vicious circle of actually coming up with ideas but being frustrated. OncoSearch was a good example. A famous example is, of course, Xerox. But we don't only see this in companies. We see this in the public sector as well. We all know that any kind of effective reform of education, research, health care, even defense, takes 10, 15, maybe 20 years to work. But still, we change much more often. We really don't give them the chance.Another trap is the success trap. Facit fell into the success trap. They literally held the future in their hands, but they couldn't see it. They were simply so good at making what they loved doing, that they wouldn't change. We are like that, too. When we know something well, it's difficult to change. Bill Gates has said: "Success is a lousy teacher. It seduces us into thinking we cannot fail." That's the challenge with success.So I think there are some lessons, and I think they apply to us. And they apply to our companies. The first lesson is: get ahead of the crisis. And any company that's able to innovate is actually able to also buy an insurance in the future. Netflix — they could so easily have been content with earlier generations of distribution, but they always — and I think they will always — keep pushing for the next battle. I see other companies that say, "I'll win the next innovation cycle, whatever it takes."Second one: think in multiple time scales. I'll share a chart with you, and I think it's a wonderful one. Any company we look at, taking a one-year perspective and looking at the valuation of the company, innovation typically accounts for only about 30 percent. So when we think one year, innovation isn't really that important. Move ahead, take a 10-year perspective on the same company — suddenly, innovation and ability to renew account for 70 percent. But companies can't choose. They need to fund the journey and lead the long term.Third: invite talent. I don't think it's possible for any of us to be able to balance exploration and exploitation by ourselves. I think it's a team sport. I think we need to allow challenging. I think the mark of a great company is being open to be challenged, and the mark of a good corporate board is to constructively challenge. I think that's also what good parenting is about.Last one: be skeptical of success. Maybe it's useful to think back at the old triumph marches in Rome, when the generals, after a big victory, were given their celebration. Riding into Rome on the carriage, they always had a companion whispering in their ear, "Remember, you're only human."So I hope I made the point: balancing exploration and exploitation has a huge payoff. But it's difficult, and we need to be conscious.I want to just point out two questions that I think are useful. First question is, looking at your own company: In which areas do you see that the company is at the risk of falling into success traps, of just going on autopilot? And what can you do to challenge?Second question is: When did I explore something new last, and what kind of effect did it have on me? Is that something I should do more of? In my case, yes.So let me leave you with this. Whether you're an explorer by nature or whether you tend to exploit what you already know, don't forget: the beauty is in the balance.Thank you.(Applause)

00:05:22.295 --> 00:05:24.684
So we have lots of great examples.

00:05:24.708 --> 00:05:27.424
We have Nestlé creating Nespresso,

00:05:27.448 --> 00:05:30.470
we have Lego going into animated films,

00:05:30.494 --> 00:05:32.900
Toyota creating the hybrids,

00:05:32.924 --> 00:05:35.395
Unilever pushing into sustainability --

00:05:35.419 --> 00:05:38.600
there are lots of examples,
and the benefits are huge.

00:05:39.770 --> 00:05:42.306
Why is balancing so difficult?

00:05:42.804 --> 00:05:45.434
I think it's difficult
because there are so many traps

00:05:45.458 --> 00:05:47.108
that keep us where we are.

00:05:47.933 --> 00:05:50.296
So I'll talk about two,
but there are many.

00:05:51.056 --> 00:05:54.044
So let's talk about
the perpetual search trap.

00:05:54.574 --> 00:05:56.386
We discover something,

00:05:56.410 --> 00:05:59.265
but we don't have the patience
or the persistence

00:05:59.289 --> 00:06:01.617
to get at it and make it work.

00:06:01.641 --> 00:06:04.786
So instead of staying with it,
we create something new.

00:06:04.810 --> 00:06:06.110
But the same goes for that,

00:06:06.134 --> 00:06:07.885
then we're in the vicious circle

00:06:07.909 --> 00:06:11.221
of actually coming up with ideas
but being frustrated.

00:06:12.339 --> 00:06:14.659
OncoSearch was a good example.

00:06:14.683 --> 00:06:17.506
A famous example is, of course, Xerox.

00:06:18.565 --> 00:06:20.665
But we don't only see this in companies.

00:06:20.689 --> 00:06:23.203
We see this in the public sector as well.

00:06:23.684 --> 00:06:29.406
We all know that any kind
of effective reform of education,

00:06:29.430 --> 00:06:31.857
research, health care, even defense,

00:06:31.881 --> 00:06:35.284
takes 10, 15, maybe 20 years to work.

00:06:35.724 --> 00:06:38.536
But still, we change much more often.

00:06:39.048 --> 00:06:40.933
We really don't give them the chance.

00:06:42.382 --> 00:06:45.402
Another trap is the success trap.

00:06:46.766 --> 00:06:49.513
Facit fell into the success trap.

00:06:50.233 --> 00:06:53.483
They literally held
the future in their hands,

00:06:53.507 --> 00:06:54.721
but they couldn't see it.

00:06:54.745 --> 00:06:58.500
They were simply so good
at making what they loved doing,

00:06:58.524 --> 00:07:00.190
that they wouldn't change.

00:07:01.145 --> 00:07:02.438
We are like that, too.

00:07:02.462 --> 00:07:05.209
When we know something well,
it's difficult to change.

00:07:06.830 --> 00:07:08.128
Bill Gates has said:

00:07:08.974 --> 00:07:11.974
"Success is a lousy teacher.

00:07:11.998 --> 00:07:15.572
It seduces us into thinking
we cannot fail."

00:07:16.415 --> 00:07:18.325
That's the challenge with success.

00:07:19.844 --> 00:07:23.298
So I think there are some lessons,
and I think they apply to us.

00:07:23.322 --> 00:07:25.063
And they apply to our companies.

00:07:25.528 --> 00:07:28.918
The first lesson is:
get ahead of the crisis.

00:07:29.907 --> 00:07:32.476
And any company that's able to innovate

00:07:32.500 --> 00:07:36.296
is actually able to also buy
an insurance in the future.

00:07:36.667 --> 00:07:39.530
Netflix -- they could so easily
have been content

00:07:39.554 --> 00:07:42.418
with earlier generations of distribution,

00:07:42.442 --> 00:07:44.999
but they always -- and I think
they will always --

00:07:45.023 --> 00:07:46.998
keep pushing for the next battle.

00:07:47.530 --> 00:07:49.895
I see other companies that say,

00:07:49.919 --> 00:07:54.360
"I'll win the next innovation cycle,
whatever it takes."

00:07:55.593 --> 00:07:58.475
Second one: think in multiple time scales.

00:07:58.876 --> 00:08:00.214
I'll share a chart with you,

00:08:00.238 --> 00:08:02.096
and I think it's a wonderful one.

00:08:02.419 --> 00:08:04.132
Any company we look at,

00:08:04.156 --> 00:08:05.955
taking a one-year perspective

00:08:05.979 --> 00:08:08.256
and looking at the valuation
of the company,

00:08:08.280 --> 00:08:11.659
innovation typically accounts
for only about 30 percent.

00:08:12.145 --> 00:08:13.532
So when we think one year,

00:08:13.556 --> 00:08:15.838
innovation isn't really that important.

00:08:16.448 --> 00:08:20.016
Move ahead, take a 10-year perspective
on the same company --

00:08:20.040 --> 00:08:25.218
suddenly, innovation and ability
to renew account for 70 percent.

00:08:26.211 --> 00:08:27.688
But companies can't choose.

00:08:27.712 --> 00:08:31.618
They need to fund the journey
and lead the long term.

00:08:32.704 --> 00:08:33.880
Third:

00:08:34.262 --> 00:08:35.499
invite talent.

00:08:35.932 --> 00:08:38.480
I don't think it's possible for any of us

00:08:38.504 --> 00:08:43.034
to be able to balance exploration
and exploitation by ourselves.

00:08:43.058 --> 00:08:44.764
I think it's a team sport.

00:08:44.788 --> 00:08:47.177
I think we need to allow challenging.

00:08:48.231 --> 00:08:53.121
I think the mark of a great company
is being open to be challenged,

00:08:53.145 --> 00:08:57.368
and the mark of a good corporate board
is to constructively challenge.

00:08:58.222 --> 00:09:01.828
I think that's also what
good parenting is about.

00:09:02.816 --> 00:09:05.297
Last one: be skeptical of success.

00:09:06.091 --> 00:09:12.424
Maybe it's useful to think back
at the old triumph marches in Rome,

00:09:12.448 --> 00:09:15.944
when the generals, after a big victory,

00:09:15.968 --> 00:09:18.319
were given their celebration.

00:09:18.712 --> 00:09:21.447
Riding into Rome on the carriage,

00:09:21.471 --> 00:09:25.693
they always had a companion
whispering in their ear,

00:09:25.717 --> 00:09:28.203
"Remember, you're only human."

00:09:29.881 --> 00:09:32.635
So I hope I made the point:

00:09:32.659 --> 00:09:35.681
balancing exploration and exploitation

00:09:35.705 --> 00:09:37.152
has a huge payoff.

00:09:37.176 --> 00:09:39.737
But it's difficult,
and we need to be conscious.

00:09:40.296 --> 00:09:44.741
I want to just point out two questions
that I think are useful.

00:09:45.355 --> 00:09:48.759
First question is,
looking at your own company:

00:09:49.404 --> 00:09:53.714
In which areas do you see
that the company is at the risk

00:09:53.738 --> 00:09:55.982
of falling into success traps,

00:09:56.006 --> 00:09:58.537
of just going on autopilot?

00:09:59.063 --> 00:10:02.244
And what can you do to challenge?

00:10:03.597 --> 00:10:05.200
Second question is:

00:10:06.488 --> 00:10:09.749
When did I explore something new last,

00:10:09.773 --> 00:10:12.026
and what kind of effect did it have on me?

00:10:12.772 --> 00:10:14.986
Is that something I should do more of?

00:10:15.554 --> 00:10:16.803
In my case, yes.

00:10:18.615 --> 00:10:20.626
So let me leave you with this.

00:10:20.650 --> 00:10:23.931
Whether you're an explorer by nature

00:10:23.955 --> 00:10:27.857
or whether you tend to exploit
what you already know,

00:10:27.881 --> 00:10:31.965
don't forget: the beauty
is in the balance.

00:10:33.350 --> 00:10:34.510
Thank you.

00:10:34.534 --> 00:10:37.155
(Applause)

title: The surprising habits of original thinkers
transcript: Seven years ago, a student came to me and asked me to invest in his company. He said, "I'm working with three friends, and we're going to try to disrupt an industry by selling stuff online." And I said, "OK, you guys spent the whole summer on this, right?" "No, we all took internships just in case it doesn't work out." "All right, but you're going to go in full time once you graduate." "Not exactly. We've all lined up backup jobs." Six months go by, it's the day before the company launches, and there is still not a functioning website. "You guys realize, the entire company is a website. That's literally all it is." So I obviously declined to invest.And they ended up naming the company Warby Parker.(Laughter) They sell glasses online. They were recently recognized as the world's most innovative company and valued at over a billion dollars. And now? My wife handles our investments. Why was I so wrong?To find out, I've been studying people that I come to call "originals." Originals are nonconformists, people who not only have new ideas but take action to champion them. They are people who stand out and speak up. Originals drive creativity and change in the world. They're the people you want to bet on. And they look nothing like I expected. I want to show you today three things I've learned about recognizing originals and becoming a little bit more like them.So the first reason that I passed on Warby Parker was they were really slow getting off the ground. Now, you are all intimately familiar with the mind of a procrastinator. Well, I have a confession for you. I'm the opposite. I'm a precrastinator. Yes, that's an actual term. You know that panic you feel a few hours before a big deadline when you haven't done anything yet. I just feel that a few months ahead of time.(Laughter)So this started early: when I was a kid, I took Nintendo games very seriously. I would wake up at 5am, start playing and not stop until I had mastered them. Eventually it got so out of hand that a local newspaper came and did a story on the dark side of Nintendo, starring me.(Laughter)(Applause)Since then, I have traded hair for teeth.(Laughter)But this served me well in college, because I finished my senior thesis four months before the deadline. And I was proud of that, until a few years ago. I had a student named Jihae, who came to me and said, "I have my most creative ideas when I'm procrastinating." And I was like, "That's cute, where are the four papers you owe me?"(Laughter)No, she was one of our most creative students, and as an organizational psychologist, this is the kind of idea that I test. So I challenged her to get some data. She goes into a bunch of companies. She has people fill out surveys about how often they procrastinate. Then she gets their bosses to rate how creative and innovative they are. And sure enough, the precrastinators like me, who rush in and do everything early are rated as less creative than people who procrastinate moderately. So I want to know what happens to the chronic procrastinators. She was like, "I don't know. They didn't fill out my survey."(Laughter)No, here are our results. You actually do see that the people who wait until the last minute are so busy goofing off that they don't have any new ideas. And on the flip side, the people who race in are in such a frenzy of anxiety that they don't have original thoughts either. There's a sweet spot where originals seem to live. Why is this? Maybe original people just have bad work habits. Maybe procrastinating does not cause creativity.To find out, we designed some experiments. We asked people to generate new business ideas, and then we get independent readers to evaluate how creative and useful they are. And some of them are asked to do the task right away. Others we randomly assign to procrastinate by dangling Minesweeper in front of them for either five or 10 minutes. And sure enough, the moderate procrastinators are 16 percent more creative than the other two groups. Now, Minesweeper is awesome, but it's not the driver of the effect, because if you play the game first before you learn about the task, there's no creativity boost. It's only when you're told that you're going to be working on this problem, and then you start procrastinating, but the task is still active in the back of your mind, that you start to incubate. Procrastination gives you time to consider divergent ideas, to think in nonlinear ways, to make unexpected leaps.So just as we were finishing these experiments, I was starting to write a book about originals, and I thought, "This is the perfect time to teach myself to procrastinate, while writing a chapter on procrastination." So I metaprocrastinated, and like any self-respecting precrastinator, I woke up early the next morning and I made a to-do list with steps on how to procrastinate.(Laughter)And then I worked diligently toward my goal of not making progress toward my goal. I started writing the procrastination chapter, and one day — I was halfway through — I literally put it away in mid-sentence for months. It was agony. But when I came back to it, I had all sorts of new ideas. As Aaron Sorkin put it, "You call it procrastinating. I call it thinking." And along the way I discovered that a lot of great originals in history were procrastinators. Take Leonardo da Vinci. He toiled on and off for 16 years on the Mona Lisa. He felt like a failure. He wrote as much in his journal. But some of the diversions he took in optics transformed the way that he modeled light and made him into a much better painter. What about Martin Luther King, Jr.? The night before the biggest speech of his life, the March on Washington, he was up past 3am, rewriting it. He's sitting in the audience waiting for his turn to go onstage, and he is still scribbling notes and crossing out lines. When he gets onstage, 11 minutes in, he leaves his prepared remarks to utter four words that changed the course of history: "I have a dream." That was not in the script. By delaying the task of finalizing the speech until the very last minute, he left himself open to the widest range of possible ideas. And because the text wasn't set in stone, he had freedom to improvise.Procrastinating is a vice when it comes to productivity, but it can be a virtue for creativity. What you see with a lot of great originals is that they are quick to start but they're slow to finish. And this is what I missed with Warby Parker. When they were dragging their heels for six months, I looked at them and said, "You know, a lot of other companies are starting to sell glasses online." They missed the first-mover advantage. But what I didn't realize was they were spending all that time trying to figure out how to get people to be comfortable ordering glasses online. And it turns out the first-mover advantage is mostly a myth. Look at a classic study of over 50 product categories, comparing the first movers who created the market with the improvers who introduced something different and better. What you see is that the first movers had a failure rate of 47 percent, compared with only 8 percent for the improvers. Look at Facebook, waiting to build a social network until after Myspace and Friendster. Look at Google, waiting for years after Altavista and Yahoo. It's much easier to improve on somebody else's idea than it is to create something new from scratch. So the lesson I learned is that to be original you don't have to be first. You just have to be different and better.But that wasn't the only reason I passed on Warby Parker. They were also full of doubts. They had backup plans lined up, and that made me doubt that they had the courage to be original, because I expected that originals would look something like this.(Laughter)Now, on the surface, a lot of original people look confident, but behind the scenes, they feel the same fear and doubt that the rest of us do. They just manage it differently. Let me show you: this is a depiction of how the creative process works for most of us.(Laughter)Now, in my research, I discovered there are two different kinds of doubt. There's self-doubt and idea doubt. Self-doubt is paralyzing. It leads you to freeze. But idea doubt is energizing. It motivates you to test, to experiment, to refine, just like MLK did. And so the key to being original is just a simple thing of avoiding the leap from step three to step four. Instead of saying, "I'm crap," you say, "The first few drafts are always crap, and I'm just not there yet." So how do you get there? Well, there's a clue, it turns out, in the Internet browser that you use. We can predict your job performance and your commitment just by knowing what web browser you use. Now, some of you are not going to like the results of this study —(Laughter)But there is good evidence that Firefox and Chrome users significantly outperform Internet Explorer and Safari users. Yes.(Applause)They also stay in their jobs 15 percent longer, by the way. Why? It's not a technical advantage. The four browser groups on average have similar typing speed and they also have similar levels of computer knowledge. It's about how you got the browser. Because if you use Internet Explorer or Safari, those came preinstalled on your computer, and you accepted the default option that was handed to you. If you wanted Firefox or Chrome, you had to doubt the default and ask, is there a different option out there, and then be a little resourceful and download a new browser. So people hear about this study and they're like, "Great, if I want to get better at my job, I just need to upgrade my browser?"(Laughter)No, it's about being the kind of person who takes the initiative to doubt the default and look for a better option. And if you do that well, you will open yourself up to the opposite of déjà vu. There's a name for it. It's called vuja de.(Laughter)Vuja de is when you look at something you've seen many times before and all of a sudden see it with fresh eyes. It's a screenwriter who looks at a movie script that can't get the green light for more than half a century. In every past version, the main character has been an evil queen. But Jennifer Lee starts to question whether that makes sense. She rewrites the first act, reinvents the villain as a tortured hero and Frozen becomes the most successful animated movie ever. So there's a simple message from this story. When you feel doubt, don't let it go.(Laughter)What about fear? Originals feel fear, too. They're afraid of failing, but what sets them apart from the rest of us is that they're even more afraid of failing to try. They know you can fail by starting a business that goes bankrupt or by failing to start a business at all. They know that in the long run, our biggest regrets are not our actions but our inactions. The things we wish we could redo, if you look at the science, are the chances not taken.Elon Musk told me recently, he didn't expect Tesla to succeed. He was sure the first few SpaceX launches would fail to make it to orbit, let alone get back, but it was too important not to try. And for so many of us, when we have an important idea, we don't bother to try. But I have some good news for you. You are not going to get judged on your bad ideas. A lot of people think they will. If you look across industries and ask people about their biggest idea, their most important suggestion, 85 percent of them stayed silent instead of speaking up. They were afraid of embarrassing themselves, of looking stupid. But guess what? Originals have lots and lots of bad ideas, tons of them, in fact. Take the guy who invented this. Do you care that he came up with a talking doll so creepy that it scared not only kids but adults, too? No. You celebrate Thomas Edison for pioneering the light bulb.(Laughter)If you look across fields, the greatest originals are the ones who fail the most, because they're the ones who try the most. Take classical composers, the best of the best. Why do some of them get more pages in encyclopedias than others and also have their compositions rerecorded more times? One of the best predictors is the sheer volume of compositions that they generate. The more output you churn out, the more variety you get and the better your chances of stumbling on something truly original. Even the three icons of classical music — Bach, Beethoven, Mozart — had to generate hundreds and hundreds of compositions to come up with a much smaller number of masterpieces. Now, you may be wondering, how did this guy become great without doing a whole lot? I don't know how Wagner pulled that off. But for most of us, if we want to be more original, we have to generate more ideas.The Warby Parker founders, when they were trying to name their company, they needed something sophisticated, unique, with no negative associations to build a retail brand, and they tested over 2,000 possibilities before they finally put together Warby and Parker. So if you put all this together, what you see is that originals are not that different from the rest of us. They feel fear and doubt. They procrastinate. They have bad ideas. And sometimes, it's not in spite of those qualities but because of them that they succeed.So when you see those things, don't make the same mistake I did. Don't write them off. And when that's you, don't count yourself out either. Know that being quick to start but slow to finish can boost your creativity, that you can motivate yourself by doubting your ideas and embracing the fear of failing to try, and that you need a lot of bad ideas in order to get a few good ones.Look, being original is not easy, but I have no doubt about this: it's the best way to improve the world around us.Thank you.(Applause)

Then she gets their bosses to rate

00:03:30.998 --> 00:03:33.854
And sure enough,
the precrastinators like me,

00:03:33.878 --> 00:03:35.814
who rush in and do everything early

00:03:35.838 --> 00:03:37.574
are rated as less creative

00:03:37.598 --> 00:03:39.558
than people who procrastinate moderately.

00:03:40.438 --> 00:03:43.614
So I want to know what happens
to the chronic procrastinators.

00:03:43.638 --> 00:03:46.534
She was like, "I don't know.
They didn't fill out my survey."

00:03:46.558 --> 00:03:49.054
(Laughter)

00:03:49.078 --> 00:03:51.038
No, here are our results.

00:03:51.838 --> 00:03:55.774
You actually do see that the people
who wait until the last minute

00:03:55.798 --> 00:03:59.518
are so busy goofing off
that they don't have any new ideas.

00:04:00.638 --> 00:04:03.854
And on the flip side,
the people who race in

00:04:03.878 --> 00:04:07.798
are in such a frenzy of anxiety that they
don't have original thoughts either.

00:04:09.358 --> 00:04:12.678
There's a sweet spot
where originals seem to live.

00:04:13.838 --> 00:04:15.038
Why is this?

00:04:15.478 --> 00:04:18.374
Maybe original people
just have bad work habits.

00:04:18.398 --> 00:04:21.518
Maybe procrastinating
does not cause creativity.

00:04:22.158 --> 00:04:25.374
To find out, we designed some experiments.

00:04:25.398 --> 00:04:28.213
We asked people
to generate new business ideas,

00:04:28.237 --> 00:04:29.934
and then we get independent readers

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:33.134
to evaluate how creative
and useful they are.

00:04:33.158 --> 00:04:36.574
And some of them are asked
to do the task right away.

00:04:36.598 --> 00:04:39.134
Others we randomly assign
to procrastinate

00:04:39.158 --> 00:04:41.158
by dangling Minesweeper in front of them

00:04:41.798 --> 00:04:43.854
for either five or 10 minutes.

00:04:43.878 --> 00:04:47.014
And sure enough,
the moderate procrastinators

00:04:47.038 --> 00:04:50.718
are 16 percent more creative
than the other two groups.

00:04:51.558 --> 00:04:54.734
Now, Minesweeper is awesome,
but it's not the driver of the effect,

00:04:54.758 --> 00:04:57.934
because if you play the game first
before you learn about the task,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.614
there's no creativity boost.

00:04:59.638 --> 00:05:03.174
It's only when you're told that you're
going to be working on this problem,

00:05:03.198 --> 00:05:04.894
and then you start procrastinating,

00:05:04.918 --> 00:05:07.454
but the task is still active
in the back of your mind,

00:05:07.478 --> 00:05:08.974
that you start to incubate.

00:05:08.998 --> 00:05:12.574
Procrastination gives you time
to consider divergent ideas,

00:05:12.598 --> 00:05:15.718
to think in nonlinear ways,
to make unexpected leaps.

00:05:16.678 --> 00:05:18.894
So just as we were finishing
these experiments,

00:05:18.918 --> 00:05:21.414
I was starting to write
a book about originals,

00:05:21.438 --> 00:05:25.974
and I thought, "This is the perfect time
to teach myself to procrastinate,

00:05:25.998 --> 00:05:28.078
while writing a chapter
on procrastination."

00:05:28.678 --> 00:05:30.078
So I metaprocrastinated,

00:05:32.078 --> 00:05:35.454
and like any self-respecting
precrastinator,

00:05:35.478 --> 00:05:37.054
I woke up early the next morning

00:05:37.078 --> 00:05:39.894
and I made a to-do list
with steps on how to procrastinate.

00:05:39.918 --> 00:05:42.438
(Laughter)

00:05:43.278 --> 00:05:47.014
And then I worked diligently

00:05:47.038 --> 00:05:50.678
toward my goal of not making
progress toward my goal.

00:05:52.118 --> 00:05:54.294
I started writing
the procrastination chapter,

00:05:54.318 --> 00:05:56.214
and one day -- I was halfway through --

00:05:56.238 --> 00:05:58.134
I literally put it away in mid-sentence

00:05:58.158 --> 00:05:59.494
for months.

00:05:59.518 --> 00:06:01.518
It was agony.

00:06:02.598 --> 00:06:05.558
But when I came back to it,
I had all sorts of new ideas.

00:06:06.518 --> 00:06:07.854
As Aaron Sorkin put it,

00:06:07.878 --> 00:06:10.838
"You call it procrastinating.
I call it thinking."

00:06:12.158 --> 00:06:13.614
And along the way I discovered

00:06:13.638 --> 00:06:16.918
that a lot of great originals
in history were procrastinators.

00:06:17.638 --> 00:06:19.414
Take Leonardo da Vinci.

00:06:19.438 --> 00:06:22.974
He toiled on and off for 16 years

00:06:22.998 --> 00:06:24.774
on the Mona Lisa.

00:06:24.798 --> 00:06:26.214
He felt like a failure.

00:06:26.238 --> 00:06:28.038
He wrote as much in his journal.

00:06:30.198 --> 00:06:32.774
But some of the diversions
he took in optics

00:06:32.798 --> 00:06:34.774
transformed the way that he modeled light

00:06:34.798 --> 00:06:36.718
and made him into a much better painter.

00:06:37.718 --> 00:06:39.478
What about Martin Luther King, Jr.?

00:06:40.438 --> 00:06:42.694
The night before
the biggest speech of his life,

00:06:42.718 --> 00:06:43.974
the March on Washington,

00:06:43.998 --> 00:06:46.118
he was up past 3am, rewriting it.

00:06:46.758 --> 00:06:50.174
He's sitting in the audience
waiting for his turn to go onstage,

00:06:50.198 --> 00:06:53.998
and he is still scribbling notes
and crossing out lines.

00:06:54.718 --> 00:06:56.774
When he gets onstage, 11 minutes in,

00:06:56.798 --> 00:06:58.734
he leaves his prepared remarks

00:06:58.758 --> 00:07:01.894
to utter four words
that changed the course of history:

00:07:01.918 --> 00:07:03.198
"I have a dream."

00:07:04.038 --> 00:07:06.118
That was not in the script.

00:07:07.038 --> 00:07:11.694
By delaying the task of finalizing
the speech until the very last minute,

00:07:11.718 --> 00:07:15.454
he left himself open
to the widest range of possible ideas.

00:07:15.478 --> 00:07:17.734
And because the text wasn't set in stone,

00:07:17.758 --> 00:07:19.798
he had freedom to improvise.

00:07:20.598 --> 00:07:23.774
Procrastinating is a vice
when it comes to productivity,

00:07:23.798 --> 00:07:26.638
but it can be a virtue for creativity.

00:07:27.358 --> 00:07:29.374
What you see with a lot of great originals

00:07:29.398 --> 00:07:33.014
is that they are quick to start
but they're slow to finish.

00:07:33.038 --> 00:07:35.118
And this is what I missed
with Warby Parker.

00:07:35.678 --> 00:07:38.334
When they were dragging
their heels for six months,

00:07:38.358 --> 00:07:39.974
I looked at them and said,

00:07:39.998 --> 00:07:43.454
"You know, a lot of other companies
are starting to sell glasses online."

00:07:43.478 --> 00:07:45.318
They missed the first-mover advantage.

00:07:46.158 --> 00:07:49.094
But what I didn't realize was
they were spending all that time

00:07:49.118 --> 00:07:50.974
trying to figure out how to get people

00:07:50.998 --> 00:07:52.998
to be comfortable ordering glasses online.

00:07:53.022 --> 00:07:56.014
And it turns out the first-mover
advantage is mostly a myth.

00:07:56.038 --> 00:07:59.854
Look at a classic study
of over 50 product categories,

00:07:59.878 --> 00:08:02.374
comparing the first movers
who created the market

00:08:02.398 --> 00:08:05.838
with the improvers who introduced
something different and better.

00:08:06.878 --> 00:08:10.854
What you see is that the first movers
had a failure rate of 47 percent,

00:08:10.878 --> 00:08:14.158
compared with only 8 percent
for the improvers.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.494
Look at Facebook,
waiting to build a social network

00:08:17.518 --> 00:08:20.974
until after Myspace and Friendster.

00:08:20.998 --> 00:08:24.774
Look at Google, waiting for years
after Altavista and Yahoo.

00:08:24.798 --> 00:08:27.894
It's much easier to improve
on somebody else's idea

00:08:27.918 --> 00:08:30.158
than it is to create
something new from scratch.

00:08:30.838 --> 00:08:34.934
So the lesson I learned is that
to be original you don't have to be first.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.158
You just have to be different and better.

00:08:38.318 --> 00:08:41.294
But that wasn't the only reason
I passed on Warby Parker.

00:08:41.318 --> 00:08:43.734
They were also full of doubts.

00:08:43.758 --> 00:08:45.574
They had backup plans lined up,

00:08:45.598 --> 00:08:49.014
and that made me doubt
that they had the courage to be original,

00:08:49.038 --> 00:08:53.718
because I expected that originals
would look something like this.

00:08:54.997 --> 00:08:57.318
(Laughter)

00:08:58.638 --> 00:09:00.254
Now, on the surface,

00:09:00.278 --> 00:09:02.254
a lot of original people look confident,

00:09:02.278 --> 00:09:03.534
but behind the scenes,

00:09:03.558 --> 00:09:06.574
they feel the same fear and doubt
that the rest of us do.

00:09:06.598 --> 00:09:08.158
They just manage it differently.

00:09:08.798 --> 00:09:10.534
Let me show you: this is a depiction

00:09:10.558 --> 00:09:12.878
of how the creative process
works for most of us.

00:09:16.078 --> 00:09:18.078
(Laughter)

00:09:20.118 --> 00:09:23.574
Now, in my research, I discovered
there are two different kinds of doubt.

00:09:23.598 --> 00:09:25.254
There's self-doubt and idea doubt.

00:09:25.278 --> 00:09:26.814
Self-doubt is paralyzing.

00:09:26.838 --> 00:09:28.454
It leads you to freeze.

00:09:28.478 --> 00:09:30.214
But idea doubt is energizing.

00:09:30.238 --> 00:09:33.014
It motivates you to test,
to experiment, to refine,

00:09:33.038 --> 00:09:35.094
just like MLK did.

00:09:35.118 --> 00:09:38.374
And so the key to being original

00:09:38.398 --> 00:09:40.134
is just a simple thing

00:09:40.158 --> 00:09:43.534
of avoiding the leap
from step three to step four.

00:09:43.558 --> 00:09:45.374
Instead of saying, "I'm crap,"

00:09:45.398 --> 00:09:47.878
you say, "The first few drafts
are always crap,

00:09:48.638 --> 00:09:50.038
and I'm just not there yet."

00:09:50.878 --> 00:09:52.494
So how do you get there?

00:09:52.518 --> 00:09:54.414
Well, there's a clue, it turns out,

00:09:54.438 --> 00:09:56.398
in the Internet browser that you use.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.574
We can predict your job performance
and your commitment

00:09:59.598 --> 00:10:02.438
just by knowing what web browser you use.

00:10:03.398 --> 00:10:06.574
Now, some of you are not
going to like the results of this study --

00:10:06.598 --> 00:10:07.934
(Laughter)

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:11.894
But there is good evidence
that Firefox and Chrome users

00:10:11.918 --> 00:10:15.278
significantly outperform
Internet Explorer and Safari users.

00:10:15.918 --> 00:10:17.254
Yes.

00:10:17.278 --> 00:10:19.134
(Applause)

00:10:19.158 --> 00:10:22.118
They also stay in their jobs
15 percent longer, by the way.

00:10:23.078 --> 00:10:25.254
Why? It's not a technical advantage.

00:10:25.278 --> 00:10:28.654
The four browser groups
on average have similar typing speed

00:10:28.678 --> 00:10:31.814
and they also have similar levels
of computer knowledge.

00:10:31.838 --> 00:10:33.934
It's about how you got the browser.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.414
Because if you use
Internet Explorer or Safari,

00:10:36.438 --> 00:10:38.974
those came preinstalled on your computer,

00:10:38.998 --> 00:10:41.798
and you accepted the default option
that was handed to you.

00:10:42.558 --> 00:10:45.574
If you wanted Firefox or Chrome,
you had to doubt the default

00:10:45.598 --> 00:10:47.854
and ask, is there
a different option out there,

00:10:47.878 --> 00:10:50.838
and then be a little resourceful
and download a new browser.

00:10:51.718 --> 00:10:54.054
So people hear about this study
and they're like,

00:10:54.078 --> 00:10:57.774
"Great, if I want to get better at my job,
I just need to upgrade my browser?"

00:10:57.798 --> 00:10:58.814
(Laughter)

00:10:58.838 --> 00:11:00.934
No, it's about being the kind of person

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.374
who takes the initiative
to doubt the default

00:11:03.398 --> 00:11:05.534
and look for a better option.

00:11:05.558 --> 00:11:07.054
And if you do that well,

00:11:07.078 --> 00:11:09.878
you will open yourself up
to the opposite of déjà vu.

00:11:10.558 --> 00:11:13.694
There's a name for it.
It's called vuja de.

00:11:13.718 --> 00:11:15.718
(Laughter)

00:11:16.758 --> 00:11:19.934
Vuja de is when you look at something
you've seen many times before

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.718
and all of a sudden
see it with fresh eyes.

00:11:23.878 --> 00:11:26.494
It's a screenwriter
who looks at a movie script

00:11:26.518 --> 00:11:29.494
that can't get the green light
for more than half a century.

00:11:29.518 --> 00:11:33.718
In every past version,
the main character has been an evil queen.

00:11:34.238 --> 00:11:37.374
But Jennifer Lee starts to question
whether that makes sense.

00:11:37.398 --> 00:11:38.854
She rewrites the first act,

00:11:38.878 --> 00:11:41.494
reinvents the villain as a tortured hero

00:11:41.518 --> 00:11:44.478
and Frozen becomes
the most successful animated movie ever.

00:11:45.558 --> 00:11:47.654
So there's a simple message
from this story.

00:11:47.678 --> 00:11:50.278
When you feel doubt, don't let it go.

00:11:50.638 --> 00:11:52.918
(Laughter)

00:11:53.598 --> 00:11:54.934
What about fear?

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.878
Originals feel fear, too.

00:11:57.558 --> 00:11:59.414
They're afraid of failing,

00:11:59.438 --> 00:12:01.534
but what sets them apart
from the rest of us

00:12:01.558 --> 00:12:04.174
is that they're even more
afraid of failing to try.

00:12:04.198 --> 00:12:07.294
They know you can fail
by starting a business that goes bankrupt

00:12:07.318 --> 00:12:09.758
or by failing to start a business at all.

00:12:10.438 --> 00:12:13.974
They know that in the long run,
our biggest regrets are not our actions

00:12:13.998 --> 00:12:15.654
but our inactions.

00:12:15.678 --> 00:12:18.536
The things we wish we could redo,
if you look at the science,

00:12:18.560 --> 00:12:20.760
are the chances not taken.

00:12:21.678 --> 00:12:25.334
Elon Musk told me recently,
he didn't expect Tesla to succeed.

00:12:25.358 --> 00:12:28.094
He was sure the first few SpaceX launches

00:12:28.118 --> 00:12:31.294
would fail to make it to orbit,
let alone get back,

00:12:31.318 --> 00:12:33.518
but it was too important not to try.

00:12:34.318 --> 00:12:36.854
And for so many of us,
when we have an important idea,

00:12:36.878 --> 00:12:38.118
we don't bother to try.

00:12:38.918 --> 00:12:40.974
But I have some good news for you.

00:12:40.998 --> 00:12:43.574
You are not going to get judged
on your bad ideas.

00:12:43.598 --> 00:12:45.214
A lot of people think they will.

00:12:45.238 --> 00:12:46.894
If you look across industries

00:12:46.918 --> 00:12:50.347
and ask people about their biggest idea,
their most important suggestion,

00:12:50.838 --> 00:12:54.678
85 percent of them stayed silent
instead of speaking up.

00:12:55.198 --> 00:12:58.614
They were afraid of embarrassing
themselves, of looking stupid.

00:12:58.638 --> 00:13:02.054
But guess what? Originals
have lots and lots of bad ideas,

00:13:02.078 --> 00:13:03.358
tons of them, in fact.

00:13:04.518 --> 00:13:06.518
Take the guy who invented this.

00:13:07.358 --> 00:13:10.054
Do you care that he came up
with a talking doll so creepy

00:13:10.078 --> 00:13:12.478
that it scared not only kids
but adults, too?

00:13:13.878 --> 00:13:18.214
No. You celebrate Thomas Edison
for pioneering the light bulb.

00:13:18.238 --> 00:13:19.878
(Laughter)

00:13:20.638 --> 00:13:23.054
If you look across fields,

00:13:23.078 --> 00:13:26.054
the greatest originals
are the ones who fail the most,

00:13:26.078 --> 00:13:28.374
because they're the ones who try the most.

00:13:28.398 --> 00:13:31.374
Take classical composers,
the best of the best.

00:13:31.398 --> 00:13:34.534
Why do some of them get more pages
in encyclopedias than others

00:13:34.558 --> 00:13:37.934
and also have their compositions
rerecorded more times?

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.254
One of the best predictors

00:13:39.278 --> 00:13:42.078
is the sheer volume
of compositions that they generate.

00:13:43.198 --> 00:13:46.294
The more output you churn out,
the more variety you get

00:13:46.318 --> 00:13:50.054
and the better your chances
of stumbling on something truly original.

00:13:50.078 --> 00:13:54.414
Even the three icons of classical music --
Bach, Beethoven, Mozart --

00:13:54.438 --> 00:13:57.454
had to generate hundreds
and hundreds of compositions

00:13:57.478 --> 00:14:00.718
to come up with a much smaller
number of masterpieces.

00:14:01.798 --> 00:14:03.334
Now, you may be wondering,

00:14:03.358 --> 00:14:06.838
how did this guy become great
without doing a whole lot?

00:14:07.478 --> 00:14:09.438
I don't know how Wagner pulled that off.

00:14:10.718 --> 00:14:13.334
But for most of us,
if we want to be more original,

00:14:13.358 --> 00:14:15.678
we have to generate more ideas.

00:14:16.478 --> 00:14:20.094
The Warby Parker founders, when they
were trying to name their company,

00:14:20.118 --> 00:14:23.614
they needed something sophisticated,
unique, with no negative associations

00:14:23.638 --> 00:14:25.094
to build a retail brand,

00:14:25.118 --> 00:14:27.574
and they tested over 2,000 possibilities

00:14:27.598 --> 00:14:29.254
before they finally put together

00:14:29.278 --> 00:14:30.678
Warby and Parker.

00:14:31.998 --> 00:14:34.974
So if you put all this together,
what you see is that originals

00:14:34.998 --> 00:14:37.038
are not that different
from the rest of us.

00:14:37.678 --> 00:14:40.814
They feel fear and doubt.
They procrastinate.

00:14:40.838 --> 00:14:42.854
They have bad ideas.

00:14:42.878 --> 00:14:46.214
And sometimes, it's not in spite
of those qualities but because of them

00:14:46.238 --> 00:14:47.478
that they succeed.

00:14:47.998 --> 00:14:51.054
So when you see those things,
don't make the same mistake I did.

00:14:51.078 --> 00:14:52.334
Don't write them off.

00:14:52.358 --> 00:14:55.334
And when that's you,
don't count yourself out either.

00:14:55.358 --> 00:14:57.814
Know that being quick to start
but slow to finish

00:14:57.838 --> 00:14:59.454
can boost your creativity,

00:14:59.478 --> 00:15:02.014
that you can motivate yourself
by doubting your ideas

00:15:02.038 --> 00:15:04.614
and embracing the fear of failing to try,

00:15:04.638 --> 00:15:08.198
and that you need a lot of bad ideas
in order to get a few good ones.

00:15:08.838 --> 00:15:11.294
Look, being original is not easy,

00:15:11.318 --> 00:15:13.254
but I have no doubt about this:

00:15:13.278 --> 00:15:16.094
it's the best way
to improve the world around us.

00:15:16.118 --> 00:15:17.334
Thank you.

00:15:17.358 --> 00:15:20.598
(Applause)

title: How a start-up in the White House is changing business as usual
transcript: I'm here to talk to you today about a story that we have all been conditioned to believe is not possible. It's a story about a living, breathing start-up flourishing in an unlikely environment: the United States government. Now, this start-up is fundamentally beginning to disrupt the way government does business from the inside out. But before I get there, let's start with the problem.For me, the problem begins with a number: 137. 137 is the average number of days a veteran has to wait to have benefits processed by the VA. 137 days. Now, in order to file that application in the first place, she has to navigate over 1,000 different websites and over 900 different call-in numbers, all owned and operated by the United States government.Now, we live in times of incredible change. The private sector is constantly changing and improving itself all the time. For that matter, it's removing every single inconvenience in my life that I could possibly think of. I could be sitting on my couch in my apartment, and from my phone, I can order a warm, gluten-free meal that can arrive at my door in less than 10 minutes. But meanwhile, a working mother who depends on food stamps to support her family has to complete an arduous, complicated application which she might not even be able to do online. And the inability of her to do that same work from her couch means that she might be having to take days or hours off of work that she can't spare. And this growing dichotomy between the beneficiaries of the tech revolution and those it's left behind is one of the greatest challenges of our time —(Applause)Because government's failure to deliver digital services that work is disproportionately impacting the very people who need it most. It's impacting the students trying to go to college, the single mothers trying to get health care, the veterans coming home from battle. They can't get what they need when they need it. And for these Americans, government is more than just a presidential election every four years. Government is a lifeline that provides services they need and depend on and deserve. Which is, quite frankly, why government needs to get its shit together and catch up. Just saying.(Applause)Now, this wasn't always a problem I was passionate about. When I joined President Obama's campaign in 2008, we brought the tech industry's best practices into politics. We earned more money, we engaged more volunteers and we earned more votes than any political campaign in history. We were a cutting-edge start-up that changed the game of politics forever. So when the President asked a small group of us to bring that very same disruption directly into government, I knew it wasn't going to be easy work, but I was eager and showed up ready to get to work.Now, on my first day in DC, my first day in government, I walked into the office and they handed me a laptop. And the laptop was running Windows 98.(Laughter)I mean, three entire presidential elections had come and gone since the government had updated the operating system on that computer. Three elections! Which is when we realized this problem was a whole lot bigger than we ever could have imagined. Let me paint the picture for you.The federal government is the largest institution in the world. It spends over 86 billion dollars a year — 86 billion — on federal IT projects. For context: that is more than the entire venture capital industry spends annually — on everything. Now, the problem here is that we the taxpayers are not getting what we pay for, because 94 percent of federal IT projects are over budget or behind schedule. 94 percent! For those of you keeping score, yes, the number 94 is very close to 100.(Laughter)There's another problem: 40 percent of those never end up seeing the light of day. They are completely scrapped or abandoned. Now, this is a very existentially painful moment for any organization, because it means as government continues to operate as it's programmed to do, failure is nearly inevitable. And when the status quo is the riskiest option, that means there is simply no other choice than radical disruption.So, what do we do about it? How do we fix this? Well, the irony of all of this is that we actually don't have to look any further than our backyard, because right here in America are the very ideas, the very people, who have swept our world into a radically different place than it was two decades ago. So what would it look like if it was actually as easy to get student loans or veterans' benefits as it is to order cat food to my house? What would it look like if there was an easy pathway for the very entrepreneurs and innovators who have disrupted our tech sector to come and disrupt their government?Well, my friends, here's where we get to talk about some of the exciting new formulas we've discovered for creating change in government. Enter the United States Digital Service. The United States Digital Service is a new network of start-ups, a team of teams, organizing themselves across government to create radical change. The mission of the United States Digital Service is to help government deliver world-class digital services for students, immigrants, children, the elderly — everybody — at dramatically lower costs. We are essentially trying to build a more awesome government, for the people, by the people, today. We don't care — (Applause) Thank you.(Applause)Who doesn't want a more awesome government, right?We don't care about politics. We care about making government work better, because it's the only one we've got.(Applause)Now, you can think of our team — well, it's pretty funny — you can think of our team a little bit like the Peace Corps meets DARPA meets SEAL Team 6. We're like the Peace Corps for nerds, but instead of traveling to crazy, interesting, far-off places, you spend a lot of time indoors, behind computers, helping restore the fabric of our democracy.(Laughter)Now, this team — our playbook for the United States Digital Service is pretty simple. The first play is we recruit the very best talent our country has to offer, and recruit them for short tours of duty inside government. These are the very people who have helped build the products and companies that have made our tech sector amongst the most innovative in the world. Second, we pair these incredible people from the tech core with the dedicated civil servants already inside government on the ground creating change. Third, we strategically deploy them in a targeted formation at the most mission-critical, life-changing, important services that government offers. And finally, we give them massive air cover, from the leadership inside the agencies all the way up to the President himself, to transform these services for the better.Now, this team is beginning to disrupt how government does business from the inside out. If you study classic patterns of disruption, one very common pattern is rather simple. It's to take something that has become routine and standard in one industry and apply it to another where it's a radical departure from the status quo. Think about what Airbnb took that was normal from hospitality and revolutionized my apartment. The United States Digital Service is doing exactly that. We are taking what Silicon Valley and the private sector has learned through a ton of hard work about how to build planetary-scale digital services that delight users at lower cost, and we're applying that to government, where it is a radical departure from the status quo.Now, the good news is: it's starting to work. We know this because we can already see the results from some of our early projects, like the rescue effort of Healthcare.gov, when that went off the rails. Fixing Healthcare.gov was the first place that we ran this play, and today we are taking that same play and scaling it across a large number of government's most important citizen-facing services. Now, if I can take a moment and brag about the team for a second — it is the highest concentration of badasses I could have ever dreamed of. We have top talent from Google, Facebook, Amazon, Twitter and the likes, all on staff today, all choosing to join their government. And what's incredible is, everybody is as eager and kind as they are intelligent. It's the classic JFK quote. It says, "No problem of human destiny is beyond human beings." It's true. We have the tools to solve these problems.
