it was when it was becoming little.

00:06:33.667 --> 00:06:37.184
The big point for me was not being alone

00:06:37.208 --> 00:06:40.925
and having 10, maybe 100
people being involved --

00:06:40.949 --> 00:06:42.428
that was a big point.

00:06:42.452 --> 00:06:45.491
Then everything else was very gradual.

00:06:45.515 --> 00:06:49.774
Going from 100 people to a million people
is not a big deal -- to me.

00:06:49.798 --> 00:06:51.631
Well, I mean, maybe it is if you're --

00:06:51.655 --> 00:06:52.656
(Laughter)

00:06:52.680 --> 00:06:55.398
If you want to sell your result
then it's a huge deal --

00:06:55.422 --> 00:06:56.573
don't get me wrong.

00:06:56.597 --> 00:06:58.724
But if you're interested in the technology

00:06:58.748 --> 00:07:00.603
and you're interested in the project,

00:07:00.627 --> 00:07:02.508
the big part was getting the community.

00:07:02.532 --> 00:07:04.156
Then the community grew gradually.

00:07:04.180 --> 00:07:07.528
And there's actually not
a single point where I went like,

00:07:08.124 --> 00:07:10.300
"Wow, that just took off!" because it --

00:07:10.324 --> 00:07:13.648
I mean -- it took a long time, relatively.

00:07:13.672 --> 00:07:16.648
CA: So all the technologists
that I talk to really credit you

00:07:16.672 --> 00:07:19.546
with massively changing their work.

00:07:19.570 --> 00:07:21.193
And it's not just Linux,

00:07:21.217 --> 00:07:22.663
it's this thing called Git,

00:07:22.687 --> 00:07:26.699
which is this management system
for software development.

00:07:26.723 --> 00:07:29.508
Tell us briefly about that
and your role in that.

00:07:30.439 --> 00:07:32.228
LT: So one of the issues we had,

00:07:32.252 --> 00:07:35.304
and this took a while to start to appear,

00:07:35.328 --> 00:07:36.483
is when you ...

00:07:37.666 --> 00:07:42.998
When you grow from having 10 people
or 100 people working on a project

00:07:43.022 --> 00:07:45.410
to having 10,000 people, which --

00:07:45.434 --> 00:07:48.900
I mean, right now we're in the situation
where just on the kernel,

00:07:48.924 --> 00:07:52.098
we have 1,000 people involved
in every single release

00:07:52.122 --> 00:07:55.708
and that's every two months,
roughly two or three months.

00:07:56.294 --> 00:07:58.715
Some of those people don't do a lot.

00:07:58.739 --> 00:08:01.322
There's a lot of people
who make small, small changes.

00:08:01.346 --> 00:08:03.592
But to maintain this,

00:08:03.616 --> 00:08:06.505
the scale changes how
you have to maintain it.

00:08:06.529 --> 00:08:08.927
And we went through a lot of pain.

00:08:10.671 --> 00:08:17.200
And there are whole projects
that do only source-code maintenance.

00:08:17.224 --> 00:08:20.516
CVS is the one that used to be
the most commonly used,

00:08:20.540 --> 00:08:24.437
and I hated CVS with a passion
and refused to touch it

00:08:24.461 --> 00:08:27.524
and tried something else
that was radical and interesting

00:08:27.548 --> 00:08:30.204
and everybody else hated.

00:08:30.962 --> 00:08:32.336
CA: (Laughs)

00:08:32.360 --> 00:08:34.448
LT: And we were in this bad spot,

00:08:34.472 --> 00:08:37.289
where we had thousands of people
who wanted to participate,

00:08:37.313 --> 00:08:42.354
but in many ways,
I was the kind of break point,

00:08:42.378 --> 00:08:44.902
where I could not scale to the point

00:08:44.926 --> 00:08:47.726
where I could work
with thousands of people.

00:08:47.750 --> 00:08:50.202
So Git is my second big project,

00:08:50.226 --> 00:08:54.764
which was only created for me
to maintain my first big project.

00:08:55.391 --> 00:08:57.638
And this is literally how I work.

00:08:57.662 --> 00:09:00.167
I don't code for --

00:09:00.191 --> 00:09:01.913
well, I do code for fun --

00:09:01.937 --> 00:09:04.318
but I want to code
for something meaningful

00:09:04.342 --> 00:09:08.389
so every single project I've ever done
has been something I needed

00:09:08.413 --> 00:09:09.789
and --

00:09:09.813 --> 00:09:13.246
CA: So really, both Linux
and Git kind of arose

00:09:13.270 --> 00:09:15.606
almost as an unintended consequence

00:09:15.630 --> 00:09:18.301
of your desire not to have
to work with too many people.

00:09:18.325 --> 00:09:19.476
LT: Absolutely. Yes.

00:09:19.500 --> 00:09:20.580
(Laughter)

00:09:20.604 --> 00:09:22.254
CA: That's amazing.
LT: Yeah.

00:09:22.278 --> 00:09:23.770
(Applause)

00:09:23.794 --> 00:09:27.185
And yet, you're the man
who's transformed technology

00:09:27.209 --> 00:09:28.526
not just once but twice,

00:09:28.550 --> 00:09:31.133
and we have to try
and understand why it is.

00:09:31.157 --> 00:09:32.841
You've given us some clues, but ...

00:09:32.865 --> 00:09:37.506
Here's a picture of you as a kid,
with a Rubik's Cube.

00:09:37.530 --> 00:09:41.650
You mentioned that you've been
programming since you were like 10 or 11,

00:09:41.674 --> 00:09:43.039
half your life.

00:09:43.063 --> 00:09:46.879
Were you this sort of computer
genius, you know, übernerd,

00:09:46.903 --> 00:09:49.388
were you the star at school
who could do everything?

00:09:49.412 --> 00:09:50.944
What were you like as a kid?

00:09:52.088 --> 00:09:54.581
LT: Yeah, I think I was
the prototypical nerd.

00:09:54.605 --> 00:09:55.874
I mean, I was ...

00:09:57.088 --> 00:09:59.050
I was not a people person back then.

00:09:59.074 --> 00:10:01.654
That's my younger brother.

00:10:01.678 --> 00:10:04.465
I was clearly more interested
in the Rubik's Cube

00:10:04.489 --> 00:10:06.014
than my younger brother.

00:10:06.038 --> 00:10:07.125
(Laughter)

00:10:07.149 --> 00:10:10.269
My younger sister,
who's not in the picture,

00:10:10.293 --> 00:10:12.707
when we had family meetings --

00:10:12.731 --> 00:10:16.523
and it's not a huge family, but I have,
like, a couple of cousins --

00:10:16.547 --> 00:10:19.411
she would prep me beforehand.

00:10:19.435 --> 00:10:22.001
Like, before I stepped
into the room she would say,

00:10:22.025 --> 00:10:24.568
"OK. That's so-and-so ..."

00:10:25.883 --> 00:10:28.212
Because I was not --

00:10:28.236 --> 00:10:29.451
I was a geek.

00:10:29.475 --> 00:10:30.641
I was into computers,

00:10:30.665 --> 00:10:31.824
I was into math,

00:10:31.848 --> 00:10:32.999
I was into physics.

00:10:33.023 --> 00:10:34.174
I was good at that.

00:10:34.198 --> 00:10:36.984
I don't think I was
particularly exceptional.

00:10:37.512 --> 00:10:39.903
Apparently, my sister said

00:10:39.927 --> 00:10:46.778
that my biggest exceptional quality
was that I would not let go.

00:10:47.576 --> 00:10:50.133
CA: OK, so let's go there,
because that's interesting.

00:10:50.157 --> 00:10:51.331
You would not let go.

00:10:51.355 --> 00:10:54.220
So that's not about being
a geek and being smart,

00:10:54.244 --> 00:10:57.349
that's about being ... stubborn?

00:10:57.373 --> 00:10:58.900
LT: That's about being stubborn.

00:10:58.924 --> 00:11:00.312
That's about, like,

00:11:01.051 --> 00:11:03.251
just starting something

00:11:03.275 --> 00:11:08.725
and not saying, "OK, I'm done,
let's do something else --

00:11:08.749 --> 00:11:09.936
Look: shiny!"

00:11:10.912 --> 00:11:14.293
And I notice that in many
other parts in my life, too.

00:11:15.428 --> 00:11:18.678
I lived in Silicon Valley for seven years.

00:11:18.702 --> 00:11:22.814
And I worked for the same
company, in Silicon Valley,

00:11:22.838 --> 00:11:24.552
for the whole time.

00:11:24.576 --> 00:11:26.114
That is unheard of.

00:11:27.162 --> 00:11:28.929
That's not how Silicon Valley works.

00:11:28.953 --> 00:11:32.532
The whole point of Silicon Valley
is that people jump between jobs

00:11:32.556 --> 00:11:35.183
to kind of mix up the pot.

00:11:35.207 --> 00:11:37.087
And that's not the kind of person I am.

00:11:37.111 --> 00:11:39.682
CA: But during the actual
development of Linux itself,

00:11:39.706 --> 00:11:44.002
that stubbornness sometimes brought
you in conflict with other people.

00:11:44.403 --> 00:11:46.057
Talk about that a bit.

00:11:46.081 --> 00:11:51.625
Was that essential to sort of maintain
the quality of what was being built?

00:11:51.649 --> 00:11:53.814
How would you describe what happened?

00:11:54.350 --> 00:11:56.433
LT: I don't know if it's essential.

00:11:57.197 --> 00:12:00.342
Going back to the "I'm not
a people person," --

00:12:00.366 --> 00:12:02.154
sometimes I'm also ...

00:12:04.058 --> 00:12:05.591
shall we say,

00:12:05.615 --> 00:12:09.035
"myopic" when it comes
to other people's feelings,

00:12:09.625 --> 00:12:14.903
and that sometimes makes you
say things that hurt other people.

00:12:14.927 --> 00:12:18.695
And I'm not proud of that.

00:12:18.719 --> 00:12:19.833
(Applause)

00:12:19.857 --> 00:12:21.655
But, at the same time, it's --

00:12:22.936 --> 00:12:26.012
I get people who tell me
that I should be nice.

00:12:26.754 --> 00:12:32.422
And then when I try to explain to them
that maybe you're nice,

00:12:32.446 --> 00:12:34.700
maybe you should be more aggressive,

00:12:34.724 --> 00:12:38.266
they see that as me being not nice.

00:12:38.290 --> 00:12:40.400
(Laughter)

00:12:40.424 --> 00:12:42.592
What I'm trying to say
is we are different.

00:12:42.616 --> 00:12:44.426
I'm not a people person;

00:12:44.450 --> 00:12:46.556
it's not something
I'm particularly proud of,

00:12:46.580 --> 00:12:48.120
but it's part of me.

00:12:48.144 --> 00:12:50.849
And one of the things
I really like about open source

00:12:50.873 --> 00:12:56.665
is it really allows different
people to work together.

00:12:56.689 --> 00:12:58.413
We don't have to like each other --

00:12:58.437 --> 00:13:00.640
and sometimes we really
don't like each other.

00:13:00.664 --> 00:13:04.151
Really -- I mean, there are very,
very heated arguments.

00:13:04.175 --> 00:13:07.167
But you can, actually,
you can find things that --

00:13:08.285 --> 00:13:10.512
you don't even agree to disagree,

00:13:10.536 --> 00:13:13.582
it's just that you're interested
in really different things.

00:13:13.606 --> 00:13:16.509
And coming back to the point
where I said earlier

00:13:16.533 --> 00:13:20.826
that I was afraid of commercial people
taking advantage of your work,

00:13:20.850 --> 00:13:23.449
it turned out, and very
quickly turned out,

00:13:23.473 --> 00:13:26.439
that those commercial people
were lovely, lovely people.

00:13:26.463 --> 00:13:30.169
And they did all the things that I was not
at all interested in doing,

00:13:30.193 --> 00:13:32.250
and they had completely different goals.

00:13:32.274 --> 00:13:37.597
And they used open source in ways
that I just did not want to go.

00:13:37.621 --> 00:13:39.883
But because it was open
source they could do it,

00:13:39.907 --> 00:13:42.259
and it actually works
really beautifully together.

00:13:42.283 --> 00:13:44.307
And I actually think
it works the same way.

00:13:44.331 --> 00:13:47.536
You need to have the people-people,
the communicators,

00:13:47.560 --> 00:13:48.987
the warm and friendly people

00:13:49.011 --> 00:13:50.733
who like --

00:13:50.757 --> 00:13:52.199
(Laughter)

00:13:52.223 --> 00:13:55.273
really want to hug you
and get you into the community.

00:13:55.297 --> 00:13:56.868
But that's not everybody.

00:13:56.892 --> 00:13:58.324
And that's not me.

00:13:58.348 --> 00:13:59.805
I care about the technology.

00:13:59.829 --> 00:14:01.710
There are people who care about the UI.

00:14:01.734 --> 00:14:04.804
I can't do UI to save my life.

00:14:04.828 --> 00:14:07.849
I mean, if I was stranded on an island

00:14:07.873 --> 00:14:11.273
and the only way to get off that island
was the make a pretty UI,

00:14:11.297 --> 00:14:12.460
I'd die there.

00:14:12.484 --> 00:14:13.635
(Laughter)

00:14:13.659 --> 00:14:15.798
So there's different kinds of people,

00:14:15.822 --> 00:14:18.687
and I'm not making excuses,
I'm trying to explain.

00:14:18.711 --> 00:14:20.377
CA: Now, when we talked last week,

00:14:20.401 --> 00:14:22.886
you talked about some
other trait that you have,

00:14:22.910 --> 00:14:24.501
which I found really interesting.

00:14:24.525 --> 00:14:25.908
It's this idea called taste.

00:14:25.932 --> 00:14:27.934
And I've just got a couple of images here.

00:14:28.312 --> 00:14:32.315
I think this is an example of not
particularly good taste in code,

00:14:32.339 --> 00:14:35.330
and this one is better taste,

00:14:35.354 --> 00:14:37.417
which one can immediately see.

00:14:37.441 --> 00:14:39.414
What is the difference between these two?

00:14:40.597 --> 00:14:41.779
LT: So this is --

00:14:41.803 --> 00:14:44.480
How many people here actually have coded?

00:14:45.629 --> 00:14:47.149
CA: Oh my goodness.

00:14:47.173 --> 00:14:48.328
LT: So I guarantee you,

00:14:48.352 --> 00:14:49.897
everybody who raised their hand,

00:14:49.921 --> 00:14:52.542
they have done what's called
a singly-linked list.

00:14:52.566 --> 00:14:54.575
And it's taught --

00:14:55.073 --> 00:14:58.664
This, the first not very
good taste approach,

00:14:58.688 --> 00:15:02.755
is basically how it's taught to be done
when you start out coding.

00:15:02.779 --> 00:15:04.823
And you don't have to understand the code.

00:15:04.847 --> 00:15:06.903
The most interesting part to me

00:15:06.927 --> 00:15:09.116
is the last if statement.

00:15:10.891 --> 00:15:13.151
Because what happens
in a singly-linked list --

00:15:13.175 --> 00:15:16.825
this is trying to remove
an existing entry from a list --

00:15:16.849 --> 00:15:20.691
and there's a difference
between if it's the first entry

00:15:20.715 --> 00:15:22.714
or whether it's an entry in the middle.

00:15:22.738 --> 00:15:24.343
Because if it's the first entry,

00:15:24.367 --> 00:15:27.383
you have to change
the pointer to the first entry.

00:15:27.407 --> 00:15:28.605
If it's in the middle,

00:15:28.629 --> 00:15:31.050
you have to change the pointer
of a previous entry.

00:15:31.074 --> 00:15:33.098
So they're two completely different cases.

00:15:33.122 --> 00:15:34.274
CA: And that's better.

00:15:34.298 --> 00:15:35.479
LT: And this is better.

00:15:35.898 --> 00:15:38.221
It does not have the if statement.

00:15:38.595 --> 00:15:40.808
And it doesn't really matter --

00:15:40.832 --> 00:15:44.033
I don't want you understand
why it doesn't have the if statement,

00:15:44.057 --> 00:15:45.399
but I want you to understand

00:15:45.423 --> 00:15:48.048
that sometimes you can see
a problem in a different way

00:15:48.072 --> 00:15:51.426
and rewrite it so that
a special case goes away

00:15:51.450 --> 00:15:53.327
and becomes the normal case.

00:15:53.351 --> 00:15:54.890
And that's good code.

00:15:55.286 --> 00:15:56.836
But this is simple code.

00:15:56.860 --> 00:15:58.209
This is CS 101.

00:15:58.233 --> 00:16:01.089
This is not important --
although, details are important.

00:16:01.756 --> 00:16:05.834
To me, the sign of people
I really want to work with

00:16:05.858 --> 00:16:08.531
is that they have good taste,
which is how ...

00:16:09.253 --> 00:16:10.850
I sent you this stupid example

00:16:10.874 --> 00:16:13.218
that is not relevant
because it's too small.

00:16:13.701 --> 00:16:15.843
Good taste is much bigger than this.

00:16:15.867 --> 00:16:19.888
Good taste is about really
seeing the big patterns

00:16:19.912 --> 00:16:24.370
and kind of instinctively knowing
what's the right way to do things.

00:16:24.394 --> 00:16:27.051
CA: OK, so we're putting
the pieces together here now.

00:16:27.694 --> 00:16:29.161
You have taste,

00:16:30.015 --> 00:16:32.352
in a way that's meaningful
to software people.

00:16:32.376 --> 00:16:33.527
You're --

00:16:33.551 --> 00:16:35.367
(Laughter)

00:16:35.391 --> 00:16:37.952
LT: I think it was meaningful
to some people here.

00:16:39.925 --> 00:16:42.842
CA: You're a very smart computer coder,

00:16:42.866 --> 00:16:44.563
and you're hellish stubborn.

00:16:45.580 --> 00:16:47.166
But there must be something else.

00:16:47.190 --> 00:16:48.813
I mean, you've changed the future.

00:16:48.837 --> 00:16:51.800
You must have the ability
of these grand visions of the future.

00:16:51.824 --> 00:16:53.085
You're a visionary, right?

00:16:53.109 --> 00:16:55.700
LT: I've actually felt slightly
uncomfortable at TED

00:16:55.724 --> 00:16:57.884
for the last two days,

00:16:57.908 --> 00:17:00.503
because there's a lot
of vision going on, right?

00:17:00.527 --> 00:17:02.224
And I am not a visionary.

00:17:02.248 --> 00:17:04.477
I do not have a five-year plan.

00:17:04.501 --> 00:17:05.859
I'm an engineer.

00:17:05.883 --> 00:17:07.143
And I think it's really --

00:17:07.167 --> 00:17:09.486
I mean -- I'm perfectly
happy with all the people

00:17:09.510 --> 00:17:12.261
who are walking around
and just staring at the clouds

00:17:12.285 --> 00:17:15.136
and looking at the stars
and saying, "I want to go there."

00:17:15.160 --> 00:17:16.612
But I'm looking at the ground,

00:17:16.636 --> 00:17:19.491
and I want to fix the pothole
that's right in front of me

00:17:19.515 --> 00:17:20.875
before I fall in.

00:17:20.899 --> 00:17:22.518
This is the kind of person I am.

00:17:22.542 --> 00:17:23.653
(Cheers)

00:17:23.677 --> 00:17:24.989
(Applause)

00:17:25.013 --> 00:17:28.624
CA: So you spoke to me last week
about these two guys.

00:17:29.316 --> 00:17:31.751
Who are they and how
do you relate to them?

00:17:32.197 --> 00:17:35.799
LT: Well, so this is kind
of cliché in technology,

00:17:35.823 --> 00:17:37.830
the whole Tesla versus Edison,

00:17:37.854 --> 00:17:42.795
where Tesla is seen as the visionary
scientist and crazy idea man.

00:17:42.819 --> 00:17:45.601
And people love Tesla.

00:17:45.625 --> 00:17:48.612
I mean, there are people who name
their companies after him.

00:17:48.636 --> 00:17:49.786
(Laughter)

00:17:51.323 --> 00:17:53.935
The other person there is Edison,

00:17:53.959 --> 00:17:57.466
who is actually often vilified
for being kind of pedestrian

00:17:57.490 --> 00:17:59.411
and is --

00:17:59.435 --> 00:18:02.157
I mean, his most famous quote is,

00:18:02.181 --> 00:18:06.895
"Genius is one percent inspiration
and 99 percent perspiration."

00:18:07.352 --> 00:18:08.805
And I'm in the Edison camp,

00:18:08.829 --> 00:18:11.013
even if people don't always like him.

00:18:11.037 --> 00:18:14.056
Because if you actually compare the two,

00:18:14.080 --> 00:18:18.613
Tesla has kind of this mind
grab these days,

00:18:18.637 --> 00:18:20.636
but who actually changed the world?

00:18:21.811 --> 00:18:25.193
Edison may not have been a nice person,

00:18:25.217 --> 00:18:28.349
he did a lot of things --

00:18:28.373 --> 00:18:30.802
he was maybe not so intellectual,

00:18:30.826 --> 00:18:33.053
not so visionary.

00:18:33.077 --> 00:18:36.738
But I think I'm more
of an Edison than a Tesla.

00:18:37.627 --> 00:18:40.065
CA: So our theme at TED
this week is dreams --

00:18:40.089 --> 00:18:41.436
big, bold, audacious dreams.

00:18:41.460 --> 00:18:43.262
You're really the antidote to that.

00:18:43.286 --> 00:18:45.395
LT: I'm trying to dial it down a bit, yes.

00:18:45.419 --> 00:18:46.570
CA: That's good.

00:18:46.594 --> 00:18:47.674
(Laughter)

00:18:47.698 --> 00:18:49.303
We embrace you, we embrace you.

00:18:51.004 --> 00:18:53.753
Companies like Google and many
others have made, arguably,

00:18:53.777 --> 00:18:55.983
like, billions of dollars
out of your software.

00:18:56.007 --> 00:18:57.158
Does that piss you off?

00:18:57.182 --> 00:18:58.333
LT: No.

00:18:58.357 --> 00:19:00.991
No, it doesn't piss me off
for several reasons.

00:19:01.015 --> 00:19:03.025
And one of them is, I'm doing fine.

00:19:03.049 --> 00:19:04.345
I'm really doing fine.

00:19:04.900 --> 00:19:06.484
But the other reason is --

00:19:06.508 --> 00:19:11.835
I mean, without doing the whole
open source and really letting go thing,

00:19:11.859 --> 00:19:14.085
Linux would never have been what it is.

00:19:14.109 --> 00:19:19.205
And it's brought experiences
I don't really enjoy, public talking,

00:19:19.229 --> 00:19:21.380
but at the same time,
this is an experience.

00:19:21.404 --> 00:19:22.684
Trust me.

00:19:23.196 --> 00:19:28.339
So there's a lot of things going on
that make me a very happy man

00:19:28.363 --> 00:19:30.892
and thinking I did the right choices.

00:19:30.916 --> 00:19:32.828
CA: Is the open source idea --

00:19:32.852 --> 00:19:34.488
this is, I think we'll end here --

00:19:34.512 --> 00:19:38.566
is the open source idea
fully realized now in the world,

00:19:38.590 --> 00:19:41.608
or is there more that it could go,

00:19:41.632 --> 00:19:43.647
are there more things that it could do?

00:19:44.696 --> 00:19:46.930
LT: So, I'm of two minds there.

00:19:46.954 --> 00:19:51.440
I think one reason open source
works so well in code

00:19:51.464 --> 00:19:53.873
is that at the end of the day,

00:19:53.897 --> 00:19:57.143
code tends to be somewhat black and white.

00:19:57.167 --> 00:20:01.324
There's often a fairly good way to decide,

00:20:01.348 --> 00:20:05.294
this is done correctly
and this is not done well.

00:20:05.318 --> 00:20:07.696
Code either works or it doesn't,

00:20:07.720 --> 00:20:12.328
which means that there's less
room for arguments.

00:20:12.352 --> 00:20:15.983
And we have arguments despite this, right?

00:20:16.007 --> 00:20:17.922
In many other areas --

00:20:17.946 --> 00:20:21.687
I mean, people have talked about
open politics and things like that --

00:20:21.711 --> 00:20:24.660
and it's really hard sometimes to say

00:20:24.684 --> 00:20:28.441
that, yes, you can apply the same
principles in some other areas

00:20:28.465 --> 00:20:33.904
just because the black and white
turns into not just gray,

00:20:33.928 --> 00:20:35.531
but different colors.

00:20:36.297 --> 00:20:40.663
So, obviously open source in science
is making a comeback.

00:20:40.687 --> 00:20:42.321
Science was there first.

00:20:42.345 --> 00:20:45.012
But then science ended up
being pretty closed,

00:20:45.036 --> 00:20:48.660
with very expensive journals
and some of that going on.

00:20:48.684 --> 00:20:52.520
And open source is making
a comeback in science,

00:20:52.544 --> 00:20:56.691
with things like arXiv and open journals.

00:20:59.220 --> 00:21:01.173
Wikipedia changed the world, too.

00:21:01.197 --> 00:21:02.651
So there are other examples,

00:21:02.675 --> 00:21:04.308
I'm sure there are more to come.

00:21:05.618 --> 00:21:07.185
CA: But you're not a visionary,

00:21:07.209 --> 00:21:09.162
and so it's not up to you to name them.

00:21:09.186 --> 00:21:10.345
LT: No.

00:21:10.369 --> 00:21:11.417
(Laughter)

00:21:11.441 --> 00:21:13.405
It's up to you guys to make them, right?

00:21:13.429 --> 00:21:14.692
CA: Exactly.

00:21:14.716 --> 00:21:15.874
Linus Torvalds,

00:21:15.898 --> 00:21:18.143
thank you for Linux,
thank you for the Internet,

00:21:18.167 --> 00:21:20.032
thank you for all those Android phones.

00:21:20.056 --> 00:21:23.253
Thank you for coming here to TED
and revealing so much of yourself.

00:21:23.277 --> 00:21:24.429
LT: Thank you.

00:21:24.453 --> 00:21:28.893
(Applause)

title: What does it mean to be a citizen of the world?
transcript: I want to introduce you to an amazing woman. Her name is Davinia. Davinia was born in Jamaica, emigrated to the US at the age of 18, and now lives just outside of Washington, DC. She's not a high-powered political staffer, nor a lobbyist. She'd probably tell you she's quite unremarkable, but she's having the most remarkable impact. What's incredible about Davinia is that she's willing to spend time every single week focused on people who are not her: people not her in her neighborhood, her state, nor even in her country — people she'd likely never meet.Davinia's impact started a few years ago when she reached out to all of her friends on Facebook, and asked them to donate their pennies so she could fund girls' education. She wasn't expecting a huge response, but 700,000 pennies later, she's now sent over 120 girls to school. When we spoke last week, she told me she's become a little infamous at the local bank every time she rocks up with a shopping cart full of pennies.Now — Davinia is not alone. Far from it. She's part of a growing movement. And there's a name for people like Davinia: global citizens. A global citizen is someone who self-identifies first and foremost not as a member of a state, a tribe or a nation, but as a member of the human race, and someone who is prepared to act on that belief, to tackle our world's greatest challenges. Our work is focused on finding, supporting and activating global citizens. They exist in every country and among every demographic.I want to make the case to you today that the world's future depends on global citizens. I'm convinced that if we had more global citizens active in our world, then every single one of the major challenges we face — from poverty, climate change, gender inequality — these issues become solvable. They are ultimately global issues, and they can ultimately only be solved by global citizens demanding global solutions from their leaders.Now, some people's immediate reaction to this idea is that it's either a bit utopian or even threatening. So I'd like to share with you a little of my story today, how I ended up here, how it connects with Davinia and, hopefully, with you.Growing up in Melbourne, Australia, I was one of those seriously irritating little kids that never, ever stopped asking, "Why?" You might have been one yourself. I used to ask my mum the most annoying questions. I'd ask her questions like, "Mum, why I can't I dress up and play with puppets all day?" "Why do you want fries with that?" "What is a shrimp, and why do we have to keep throwing them on the barbie?"(Laughter)"And mum — this haircut. Why?"(Laughter)The worst haircut, I think. Still terrible.As a "why" kid, I thought I could change the world, and it was impossible to convince me otherwise. And when I was 12 and in my first year of high school, I started raising money for communities in the developing world. We were a really enthusiastic group of kids, and we raised more money than any other school in Australia. And so I was awarded the chance to go to the Philippines to learn more. It was 1998. We were taken into a slum in the outskirts of Manila. It was there I became friends with Sonny Boy, who lived on what was literally a pile of steaming garbage. "Smoky Mountain" was what they called it. But don't let the romance of that name fool you, because it was nothing more than a rancid landfill that kids like Sonny Boy spent hours rummaging through every single day to find something, anything of value.That night with Sonny Boy and his family changed my life forever, because when it came time to go to sleep, we simply laid down on this concrete slab the size of half my bedroom with myself, Sonny Boy, and the rest of his family, seven of us in this long line, with the smell of rubbish all around us and cockroaches crawling all around. And I didn't sleep a wink, but I lay awake thinking to myself, "Why should anyone have to live like this when I have so much? Why should Sonny Boy's ability to live out his dreams be determined by where he's born, or what Warren Buffett called 'the ovarian lottery?'" I just didn't get it, and I needed to understand why.Now, I only later came to understand that the poverty I'd seen in the Philippines was the result of decisions made or not made, man-made, by a succession of colonial powers and corrupt governments who had anything but the interests of Sonny Boy at heart. Sure, they didn't create Smoky Mountain, but they may as well have. And if we're to try to help kids like Sonny Boy, it wouldn't work just to try to send him a few dollars or to try to clean up the garbage dump on which he lived, because the core of the problem lay elsewhere. And as I worked on community development projects over the coming years trying to help build schools, train teachers, and tackle HIV and AIDS, I came to see that community development should be driven by communities themselves, and that although charity is necessary, it's not sufficient. We need to confront these challenges on a global scale and in a systemic way. And the best thing I could do is try to mobilize a large group of citizens back home to insist that our leaders engage in that systemic change.That's why, a few years later, I joined with a group of college friends in bringing the Make Poverty History campaign to Australia. We had this dream of staging this small concert around the time of the G20 with local Aussie artists, and it suddenly exploded one day when we got a phone call from Bono, the Edge and Pearl Jam, who all agreed to headline our concert. I got a little bit excited that day, as you can see.(Laughter)But to our amazement, the Australian government heard our collective voices, and they agreed to double investment into global health and development — an additional 6.2 billion dollars. It felt like —(Applause)It felt like this incredible validation. By rallying citizens together, we helped persuade our government to do the unthinkable, and act to fix a problem miles outside of our borders.But here's the thing: it didn't last. See, there was a change in government, and six years later, all that new money disappeared. What did we learn? We learned that one-off spikes are not enough. We needed a sustainable movement, not one that is susceptible to the fluctuating moods of a politician or the hint of an economic downturn. And it needed to happen everywhere; otherwise, every individual government would have this built-in excuse mechanism that they couldn't possibly carry the burden of global action alone.And so this is what we embarked upon. And as we embarked upon this challenge, we asked ourselves, how do we gain enough pressure and build a broad enough army to win these fights for the long term? We could only think of one way. We needed to somehow turn that short-term excitement of people involved with the Make Poverty History campaign into long-term passion. It had to be part of their identity. So in 2012, we cofounded an organization that had exactly that as its goal. And there was only one name for it: Global Citizen.But this is not about any one organization. This is about citizens taking action. And research data tells us that of the total population who even care about global issues, only 18 percent have done anything about it. It's not that people don't want to act. It's often that they don't know how to take action, or that they believe that their actions will have no effect. So we had to somehow recruit and activate millions of citizens in dozens of countries to put pressure on their leaders to behave altruistically.And as we did so, we discovered something really thrilling, that when you make global citizenship your mission, you suddenly find yourself with some extraordinary allies. See, extreme poverty isn't the only issue that's fundamentally global. So, too, is climate change, human rights, gender equality, even conflict. We found ourselves shoulder to shoulder with people who are passionate about targeting all these interrelated issues.But how did we actually go about recruiting and engaging those global citizens? Well, we used the universal language: music. We launched the Global Citizen Festival in the heart of New York City in Central Park, and we persuaded some of the world's biggest artists to participate. We made sure that these festivals coincided with the UN General Assembly meeting, so that leaders who need to hear our voices couldn't possible ignore them.But there was a twist: you couldn't buy a ticket. You had to earn it. You had to take action on behalf of a global cause, and only once you'd done that could you earn enough points to qualify. Activism is the currency. I had no interest in citizenship purely as some sort of feel-good thing. For me, citizenship means you have to act, and that's what we required. And amazingly, it worked. Last year, more than 155,000 citizens in the New York area alone earned enough points to qualify. Globally, we've now signed up citizens in over 150 countries around the world. And last year, we signed up more than 100,000 new members each and every week of the whole year.See, we don't need to create global citizens from nothing. We're already everywhere. We just need to be organized and motivated to start acting. And this is where I believe we can learn a lot from Davinia, who started taking action as a global citizen back in 2012. Here's what she did. It wasn't rocket science. She started writing letters, emailing politicians' offices. She volunteered her time in her local community. That's when she got active on social media and started to collect pennies — a lot of pennies.Now, maybe that doesn't sound like a lot to you. How will that achieve anything? Well, it achieved a lot because she wasn't alone. Her actions, alongside 142,000 other global citizens', led the US government to double their investment into Global Partnership for Education. And here's Dr. Raj Shah, the head of USAID, making that announcement. See, when thousands of global citizens find inspiration from each other, it's amazing to see their collective power. Global citizens like Davinia helped persuade the World Bank to boost their investment into water and sanitation. Here's the Bank's president Jim Kim announcing 15 billion dollars onstage at Global Citizen, and Prime Minister Modi of India affirmed his commitment to put a toilet in every household and school across India by 2019. Global citizens encouraged by the late-night host Stephen Colbert launched a Twitter invasion on Norway. Erna Solberg, the country's Prime Minister, got the message, committing to double investment into girls' education. Global citizens together with Rotarians called on the Canadian, UK, and Australian governments to boost their investment into polio eradication. They got together and committed 665 million dollars.But despite all of this momentum, we face some huge challenges. See, you might be thinking to yourself, how can we possibly persuade world leaders to sustain a focus on global issues? Indeed, the powerful American politician Tip O'Neill once said, "All politics is local." That's what always got politicians elected: to seek, gain and hold onto power through the pursuit of local or at very best national interests.I experienced this for the first time when I was 21 years old. I took a meeting with a then-Australian Foreign Minister who shall remain nameless —[Alexander Downer](Laughter)And behind closed doors, I shared with him my passion to end extreme poverty. I said, "Minister — Australia has this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to help achieve the Millennium Development Goals. We can do this." And he paused, looked down on me with cold, dismissive eyes, and he said, "Hugh, no one gives a funk about foreign aid." Except he didn't use the word "funk." He went on. He said we need to look after our own backyard first.This is, I believe, outdated, even dangerous thinking. Or as my late grandfather would say, complete BS. Parochialism offers this false dichotomy because it pits the poor in one country against the poor in another. It pretends we can isolate ourselves and our nations from one another. The whole world is our backyard, and we ignore it at our peril. See, look what happened when we ignored Rwanda, when we ignore Syria, when we ignore climate change. Political leaders ought to give a "funk" because the impact of climate change and extreme poverty comes right to our shore.Now, global citizens — they understand this. We live in a time that favors the global citizen, in an age where every single voice can be heard. See, do you remember when the Millennium Development Goals were signed back in the year 2000? The most we could do in those days was fire off a letter and wait for the next election. There was no social media. Today, billions of citizens have more tools, more access to information, more capacity to influence than ever before. Both the problems and the tools to solve them are right before us. The world has changed, and those of us who look beyond our borders are on the right side of history.So where are we? So we run this amazing festival, we've scored some big policy wins, and citizens are signing up all over the world. But have we achieved our mission? No. We have such a long way to go.But this is the opportunity that I see. The concept of global citizenship, self-evident in its logic but until now impractical in many ways, has coincided with this particular moment in which we are privileged to live. We, as global citizens, now have a unique opportunity to accelerate large-scale positive change around the world. So in the months and years ahead, global citizens will hold world leaders accountable to ensure that the new Global Goals for Sustainable Development are tracked and implemented. Global citizens will partner with the world's leading NGOs to end diseases like polio and malaria. Global citizens will sign up in every corner of this globe, increasing the frequency, quality and impact of their actions. These dreams are within reach. Imagine an army of millions growing into tens of millions, connected, informed, engaged and unwilling to take no for an answer.Over all these years, I've tried to reconnect with Sonny Boy. Sadly, I've been unable to. We met long before social media, and his address has now been relocated by the authorities, as often happens with slums. I'd love to sit down with him, wherever he is, and share with him how much the time I spent on Smoky Mountain inspired me. Thanks to him and so many others, I came to understand the importance of being part of a movement of people — the kids willing to look up from their screens and out to the world, the global citizens. Global citizens who stand together, who ask the question "Why?," who reject the naysayers, and embrace the amazing possibilities of the world we share.I'm a global citizen.Are you?Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.814 --> 00:00:15.148
I want to introduce you
to an amazing woman.

00:00:15.648 --> 00:00:17.656
Her name is Davinia.

00:00:18.402 --> 00:00:22.807
Davinia was born in Jamaica,
emigrated to the US at the age of 18,

00:00:22.831 --> 00:00:25.562
and now lives just outside
of Washington, DC.

00:00:26.220 --> 00:00:29.022
She's not a high-powered
political staffer,

00:00:29.046 --> 00:00:30.219
nor a lobbyist.

00:00:30.634 --> 00:00:33.563
She'd probably tell you
she's quite unremarkable,

00:00:33.587 --> 00:00:36.112
but she's having
the most remarkable impact.

00:00:36.429 --> 00:00:37.949
What's incredible about Davinia

00:00:37.973 --> 00:00:40.836
is that she's willing to spend
time every single week

00:00:40.860 --> 00:00:43.265
focused on people who are not her:

00:00:43.289 --> 00:00:47.668
people not her in her neighborhood,
her state, nor even in her country --

00:00:47.692 --> 00:00:49.925
people she'd likely never meet.

00:00:49.949 --> 00:00:51.889
Davinia's impact started a few years ago

00:00:51.913 --> 00:00:54.657
when she reached out
to all of her friends on Facebook,

00:00:54.681 --> 00:00:56.864
and asked them to donate their pennies

00:00:56.888 --> 00:00:59.331
so she could fund girls' education.

00:00:59.355 --> 00:01:01.762
She wasn't expecting a huge response,

00:01:01.786 --> 00:01:04.569
but 700,000 pennies later,

00:01:04.593 --> 00:01:07.909
she's now sent over 120 girls to school.

00:01:07.933 --> 00:01:09.120
When we spoke last week,

00:01:09.144 --> 00:01:12.182
she told me she's become
a little infamous at the local bank

00:01:12.206 --> 00:01:16.484
every time she rocks up
with a shopping cart full of pennies.

00:01:17.000 --> 00:01:19.566
Now -- Davinia is not alone.

00:01:20.119 --> 00:01:21.272
Far from it.

00:01:21.675 --> 00:01:23.961
She's part of a growing movement.

00:01:23.985 --> 00:01:26.018
And there's a name
for people like Davinia:

00:01:26.621 --> 00:01:28.058
global citizens.

00:01:28.893 --> 00:01:33.364
A global citizen is someone
who self-identifies first and foremost

00:01:33.388 --> 00:01:37.190
not as a member of a state,
a tribe or a nation,

00:01:37.214 --> 00:01:39.401
but as a member of the human race,

00:01:39.425 --> 00:01:44.265
and someone who is prepared
to act on that belief,

00:01:44.289 --> 00:01:47.184
to tackle our world's greatest challenges.

00:01:47.208 --> 00:01:49.661
Our work is focused on finding,

00:01:49.685 --> 00:01:52.568
supporting and activating global citizens.

00:01:52.592 --> 00:01:54.490
They exist in every country

00:01:54.514 --> 00:01:56.417
and among every demographic.

00:01:56.966 --> 00:01:58.728
I want to make the case to you today

00:01:58.752 --> 00:02:01.830
that the world's future depends
on global citizens.

00:02:01.854 --> 00:02:06.156
I'm convinced that if we had
more global citizens active in our world,

00:02:06.180 --> 00:02:08.915
then every single one
of the major challenges we face --

00:02:08.939 --> 00:02:12.537
from poverty, climate change,
gender inequality --

00:02:12.561 --> 00:02:14.745
these issues become solvable.

00:02:14.769 --> 00:02:17.365
They are ultimately global issues,

00:02:17.389 --> 00:02:19.270
and they can ultimately only be solved

00:02:19.294 --> 00:02:23.689
by global citizens demanding
global solutions from their leaders.

00:02:24.689 --> 00:02:27.190
Now, some people's immediate
reaction to this idea

00:02:27.214 --> 00:02:31.082
is that it's either a bit utopian
or even threatening.

00:02:31.519 --> 00:02:34.574
So I'd like to share with you
a little of my story today,

00:02:34.598 --> 00:02:36.309
how I ended up here,

00:02:36.333 --> 00:02:38.121
how it connects with Davinia

00:02:38.145 --> 00:02:39.586
and, hopefully, with you.

00:02:40.214 --> 00:02:42.030
Growing up in Melbourne, Australia,

00:02:42.054 --> 00:02:45.393
I was one of those seriously
irritating little kids

00:02:45.417 --> 00:02:47.741
that never, ever stopped asking, "Why?"

00:02:47.765 --> 00:02:49.360
You might have been one yourself.

00:02:49.384 --> 00:02:52.756
I used to ask my mum
the most annoying questions.

00:02:52.780 --> 00:02:55.579
I'd ask her questions like,
"Mum, why I can't I dress up

00:02:55.603 --> 00:02:57.530
and play with puppets all day?"

00:02:57.554 --> 00:02:59.554
"Why do you want fries with that?"

00:02:59.894 --> 00:03:01.084
"What is a shrimp,

00:03:01.108 --> 00:03:03.780
and why do we have to keep
throwing them on the barbie?"

00:03:03.804 --> 00:03:04.805
(Laughter)

00:03:04.829 --> 00:03:06.637
"And mum -- this haircut.

00:03:06.661 --> 00:03:07.834
Why?"

00:03:07.858 --> 00:03:09.286
(Laughter)

00:03:10.084 --> 00:03:11.838
The worst haircut, I think.

00:03:13.322 --> 00:03:14.473
Still terrible.

00:03:14.497 --> 00:03:17.299
As a "why" kid, I thought
I could change the world,

00:03:17.323 --> 00:03:19.923
and it was impossible
to convince me otherwise.

00:03:19.947 --> 00:03:22.534
And when I was 12
and in my first year of high school,

00:03:22.558 --> 00:03:25.795
I started raising money
for communities in the developing world.

00:03:25.819 --> 00:03:28.014
We were a really
enthusiastic group of kids,

00:03:28.038 --> 00:03:31.299
and we raised more money
than any other school in Australia.

00:03:31.323 --> 00:03:34.911
And so I was awarded the chance
to go to the Philippines to learn more.

00:03:34.935 --> 00:03:36.849
It was 1998.

00:03:36.873 --> 00:03:40.560
We were taken into a slum
in the outskirts of Manila.

00:03:40.584 --> 00:03:44.314
It was there I became friends
with Sonny Boy,

00:03:44.338 --> 00:03:47.877
who lived on what was literally
a pile of steaming garbage.

00:03:48.575 --> 00:03:50.584
"Smoky Mountain" was what they called it.

00:03:50.608 --> 00:03:52.893
But don't let the romance
of that name fool you,

00:03:52.917 --> 00:03:55.278
because it was nothing more
than a rancid landfill

00:03:55.302 --> 00:03:59.643
that kids like Sonny Boy spent hours
rummaging through every single day

00:03:59.667 --> 00:04:02.603
to find something, anything of value.

00:04:03.262 --> 00:04:06.538
That night with Sonny Boy and his family
changed my life forever,

00:04:06.562 --> 00:04:08.585
because when it came time to go to sleep,

00:04:08.609 --> 00:04:12.356
we simply laid down on this concrete
slab the size of half my bedroom

00:04:12.380 --> 00:04:15.286
with myself, Sonny Boy,
and the rest of his family,

00:04:15.310 --> 00:04:16.921
seven of us in this long line,

00:04:16.945 --> 00:04:19.339
with the smell of rubbish all around us

00:04:19.363 --> 00:04:21.497
and cockroaches crawling all around.

00:04:21.910 --> 00:04:23.189
And I didn't sleep a wink,

00:04:23.213 --> 00:04:24.922
but I lay awake thinking to myself,

00:04:24.946 --> 00:04:27.428
"Why should anyone have to live like this

00:04:27.452 --> 00:04:28.804
when I have so much?

00:04:29.248 --> 00:04:31.994
Why should Sonny Boy's ability
to live out his dreams

00:04:32.018 --> 00:04:34.064
be determined by where he's born,

00:04:34.088 --> 00:04:36.849
or what Warren Buffett called
'the ovarian lottery?'"

00:04:37.155 --> 00:04:38.912
I just didn't get it,

00:04:38.936 --> 00:04:40.802
and I needed to understand why.

00:04:41.614 --> 00:04:43.960
Now, I only later came to understand

00:04:43.984 --> 00:04:46.412
that the poverty I'd seen
in the Philippines

00:04:46.436 --> 00:04:50.745
was the result of decisions made
or not made, man-made,

00:04:50.769 --> 00:04:54.174
by a succession of colonial powers
and corrupt governments

00:04:54.198 --> 00:04:57.363
who had anything but the interests
of Sonny Boy at heart.

00:04:57.387 --> 00:05:01.187
Sure, they didn't create Smoky Mountain,
but they may as well have.

00:05:01.211 --> 00:05:03.812
And if we're to try to help
kids like Sonny Boy,

00:05:03.836 --> 00:05:06.528
it wouldn't work just to try
to send him a few dollars

00:05:06.552 --> 00:05:09.640
or to try to clean up
the garbage dump on which he lived,

00:05:09.664 --> 00:05:12.148
because the core
of the problem lay elsewhere.

00:05:12.172 --> 00:05:15.831
And as I worked on community
development projects over the coming years

00:05:15.855 --> 00:05:17.697
trying to help build schools,

00:05:17.721 --> 00:05:20.762
train teachers, and tackle HIV and AIDS,

00:05:20.786 --> 00:05:23.223
I came to see that community development

00:05:23.247 --> 00:05:25.803
should be driven
by communities themselves,

00:05:25.827 --> 00:05:29.580
and that although charity is necessary,
it's not sufficient.

00:05:29.604 --> 00:05:31.465
We need to confront these challenges

00:05:31.489 --> 00:05:34.155
on a global scale and in a systemic way.

00:05:34.179 --> 00:05:35.624
And the best thing I could do

00:05:35.648 --> 00:05:39.155
is try to mobilize a large group
of citizens back home

00:05:39.179 --> 00:05:42.742
to insist that our leaders engage
in that systemic change.

00:05:43.273 --> 00:05:45.273
That's why, a few years later,

00:05:45.297 --> 00:05:47.566
I joined with a group of college friends

00:05:47.590 --> 00:05:50.968
in bringing the Make Poverty History
campaign to Australia.

00:05:51.405 --> 00:05:54.783
We had this dream of staging
this small concert

00:05:54.807 --> 00:05:58.680
around the time of the G20
with local Aussie artists,

00:05:58.704 --> 00:06:00.356
and it suddenly exploded one day

00:06:00.380 --> 00:06:03.982
when we got a phone call from Bono,
the Edge and Pearl Jam,

00:06:04.006 --> 00:06:07.275
who all agreed to headline our concert.

00:06:07.299 --> 00:06:09.900
I got a little bit excited
that day, as you can see.

00:06:09.924 --> 00:06:11.862
(Laughter)

00:06:11.886 --> 00:06:13.165
But to our amazement,

00:06:13.189 --> 00:06:16.281
the Australian government
heard our collective voices,

00:06:16.305 --> 00:06:19.999
and they agreed to double investment
into global health and development --

00:06:20.023 --> 00:06:22.738
an additional 6.2 billion dollars.

00:06:23.238 --> 00:06:24.413
It felt like --

00:06:24.437 --> 00:06:28.896
(Applause)

00:06:28.920 --> 00:06:31.513
It felt like this incredible validation.

00:06:31.537 --> 00:06:34.903
By rallying citizens together,
we helped persuade our government

00:06:34.927 --> 00:06:36.413
to do the unthinkable,

00:06:36.437 --> 00:06:40.082
and act to fix a problem
miles outside of our borders.

00:06:40.923 --> 00:06:42.225
But here's the thing:

00:06:43.114 --> 00:06:44.415
it didn't last.

00:06:44.957 --> 00:06:46.853
See, there was a change in government,

00:06:46.877 --> 00:06:49.565
and six years later, all that new money

00:06:49.589 --> 00:06:50.755
disappeared.

00:06:51.500 --> 00:06:52.732
What did we learn?

00:06:53.661 --> 00:06:56.738
We learned that one-off spikes
are not enough.

00:06:57.183 --> 00:06:59.643
We needed a sustainable movement,

00:06:59.667 --> 00:07:03.651
not one that is susceptible
to the fluctuating moods of a politician

00:07:03.675 --> 00:07:05.952
or the hint of an economic downturn.

00:07:05.976 --> 00:07:08.078
And it needed to happen everywhere;

00:07:08.102 --> 00:07:12.007
otherwise, every individual government
would have this built-in excuse mechanism

00:07:12.031 --> 00:07:16.140
that they couldn't possibly carry
the burden of global action alone.

00:07:17.363 --> 00:07:19.458
And so this is what we embarked upon.

00:07:20.061 --> 00:07:23.038
And as we embarked upon
this challenge, we asked ourselves,

00:07:23.062 --> 00:07:26.559
how do we gain enough pressure
and build a broad enough army

00:07:26.583 --> 00:07:28.671
to win these fights for the long term?

00:07:29.377 --> 00:07:31.344
We could only think of one way.

00:07:31.992 --> 00:07:34.703
We needed to somehow turn
that short-term excitement

00:07:34.727 --> 00:07:37.624
of people involved with
the Make Poverty History campaign

00:07:37.648 --> 00:07:39.250
into long-term passion.

00:07:39.780 --> 00:07:41.777
It had to be part of their identity.

00:07:42.277 --> 00:07:47.199
So in 2012, we cofounded an organization
that had exactly that as its goal.

00:07:47.794 --> 00:07:49.683
And there was only one name for it:

00:07:50.317 --> 00:07:51.516
Global Citizen.

00:07:52.199 --> 00:07:54.706
But this is not about
any one organization.

00:07:55.253 --> 00:07:57.576
This is about citizens taking action.

00:07:57.999 --> 00:07:59.760
And research data tells us

00:07:59.784 --> 00:08:04.015
that of the total population
who even care about global issues,

00:08:04.039 --> 00:08:07.544
only 18 percent have done
anything about it.

00:08:08.195 --> 00:08:10.529
It's not that people don't want to act.

00:08:10.553 --> 00:08:12.984
It's often that they don't
know how to take action,

00:08:13.008 --> 00:08:16.109
or that they believe that their actions
will have no effect.

00:08:16.133 --> 00:08:19.658
So we had to somehow recruit
and activate millions of citizens

00:08:19.682 --> 00:08:21.343
in dozens of countries

00:08:21.367 --> 00:08:24.666
to put pressure on their leaders
to behave altruistically.

00:08:24.690 --> 00:08:27.711
And as we did so, we discovered
something really thrilling,

00:08:28.219 --> 00:08:31.171
that when you make
global citizenship your mission,

00:08:31.195 --> 00:08:34.677
you suddenly find yourself
with some extraordinary allies.

00:08:34.701 --> 00:08:38.566
See, extreme poverty isn't the only issue
that's fundamentally global.

00:08:38.590 --> 00:08:40.454
So, too, is climate change,

00:08:40.478 --> 00:08:43.054
human rights, gender equality,

00:08:43.078 --> 00:08:44.664
even conflict.

00:08:44.688 --> 00:08:47.280
We found ourselves shoulder to shoulder

00:08:47.304 --> 00:08:50.949
with people who are passionate about
targeting all these interrelated issues.

00:08:51.274 --> 00:08:53.311
But how did we actually
go about recruiting

00:08:53.335 --> 00:08:55.261
and engaging those global citizens?

00:08:55.285 --> 00:08:58.556
Well, we used the universal language:

00:08:58.992 --> 00:09:00.221
music.

00:09:00.245 --> 00:09:02.508
We launched the Global Citizen Festival

00:09:02.532 --> 00:09:05.382
in the heart of New York City
in Central Park,

00:09:05.406 --> 00:09:09.174
and we persuaded some of the world's
biggest artists to participate.

00:09:09.198 --> 00:09:11.514
We made sure that
these festivals coincided

00:09:11.538 --> 00:09:13.679
with the UN General Assembly meeting,

00:09:13.703 --> 00:09:16.157
so that leaders who need
to hear our voices

00:09:16.181 --> 00:09:17.910
couldn't possible ignore them.

00:09:18.786 --> 00:09:20.127
But there was a twist:

00:09:20.842 --> 00:09:22.497
you couldn't buy a ticket.

00:09:22.521 --> 00:09:23.711
You had to earn it.

00:09:24.178 --> 00:09:27.155
You had to take action
on behalf of a global cause,

00:09:27.179 --> 00:09:30.771
and only once you'd done that
could you earn enough points to qualify.

00:09:31.158 --> 00:09:33.421
Activism is the currency.

00:09:34.037 --> 00:09:38.437
I had no interest in citizenship
purely as some sort of feel-good thing.

00:09:38.461 --> 00:09:42.738
For me, citizenship means you have to act,
and that's what we required.

00:09:42.762 --> 00:09:44.723
And amazingly, it worked.

00:09:44.747 --> 00:09:49.454
Last year, more than 155,000 citizens
in the New York area alone

00:09:49.478 --> 00:09:51.381
earned enough points to qualify.

00:09:51.405 --> 00:09:55.769
Globally, we've now signed up citizens
in over 150 countries around the world.

00:09:55.793 --> 00:09:59.205
And last year, we signed up
more than 100,000 new members

00:09:59.229 --> 00:10:01.182
each and every week of the whole year.

00:10:01.666 --> 00:10:05.769
See, we don't need to create
global citizens from nothing.

00:10:05.793 --> 00:10:07.722
We're already everywhere.

00:10:07.746 --> 00:10:09.925
We just need to be organized

00:10:09.949 --> 00:10:11.597
and motivated to start acting.

00:10:12.187 --> 00:10:15.282
And this is where I believe
we can learn a lot from Davinia,

00:10:15.306 --> 00:10:19.256
who started taking action
as a global citizen back in 2012.

00:10:19.883 --> 00:10:21.105
Here's what she did.

00:10:21.545 --> 00:10:23.089
It wasn't rocket science.

00:10:23.495 --> 00:10:25.771
She started writing letters,

00:10:25.795 --> 00:10:28.081
emailing politicians' offices.

00:10:28.105 --> 00:10:31.100
She volunteered her time
in her local community.

00:10:31.124 --> 00:10:33.736
That's when she got active on social media

00:10:33.760 --> 00:10:35.990
and started to collect pennies --

00:10:36.014 --> 00:10:37.315
a lot of pennies.

00:10:38.222 --> 00:10:41.500
Now, maybe that doesn't sound
like a lot to you.

00:10:42.210 --> 00:10:43.706
How will that achieve anything?

00:10:44.460 --> 00:10:47.575
Well, it achieved a lot
because she wasn't alone.

00:10:48.178 --> 00:10:52.608
Her actions, alongside 142,000
other global citizens',

00:10:52.632 --> 00:10:55.273
led the US government
to double their investment

00:10:55.297 --> 00:10:57.128
into Global Partnership for Education.

00:10:57.152 --> 00:10:58.691
And here's Dr. Raj Shah,

00:10:58.715 --> 00:11:01.217
the head of USAID,
making that announcement.

00:11:01.241 --> 00:11:05.080
See, when thousands of global citizens
find inspiration from each other,

00:11:05.104 --> 00:11:07.783
it's amazing to see
their collective power.

00:11:07.807 --> 00:11:11.219
Global citizens like Davinia
helped persuade the World Bank

00:11:11.243 --> 00:11:13.918
to boost their investment
into water and sanitation.

00:11:13.942 --> 00:11:17.982
Here's the Bank's president Jim Kim
announcing 15 billion dollars onstage

00:11:18.006 --> 00:11:19.268
at Global Citizen,

00:11:19.292 --> 00:11:22.798
and Prime Minister Modi of India
affirmed his commitment

00:11:22.822 --> 00:11:27.706
to put a toilet in every household
and school across India by 2019.

00:11:28.452 --> 00:11:32.668
Global citizens encouraged
by the late-night host Stephen Colbert

00:11:32.692 --> 00:11:35.644
launched a Twitter invasion on Norway.

00:11:35.668 --> 00:11:38.875
Erna Solberg, the country's
Prime Minister, got the message,

00:11:38.899 --> 00:11:41.907
committing to double investment
into girls' education.

00:11:42.398 --> 00:11:46.193
Global citizens together with Rotarians
called on the Canadian, UK,

00:11:46.217 --> 00:11:47.618
and Australian governments

00:11:47.642 --> 00:11:50.504
to boost their investment
into polio eradication.

00:11:50.528 --> 00:11:54.637
They got together and committed
665 million dollars.

00:11:56.267 --> 00:11:58.315
But despite all of this momentum,

00:11:59.235 --> 00:12:01.235
we face some huge challenges.

00:12:01.966 --> 00:12:03.846
See, you might be thinking to yourself,

00:12:03.870 --> 00:12:06.194
how can we possibly persuade world leaders

00:12:06.218 --> 00:12:08.575
to sustain a focus on global issues?

00:12:09.432 --> 00:12:14.515
Indeed, the powerful American
politician Tip O'Neill once said,

00:12:14.539 --> 00:12:16.538
"All politics is local."

00:12:17.720 --> 00:12:20.493
That's what always
got politicians elected:

00:12:20.517 --> 00:12:23.539
to seek, gain and hold onto power

00:12:23.563 --> 00:12:27.436
through the pursuit of local
or at very best national interests.

00:12:28.143 --> 00:12:32.455
I experienced this for the first time
when I was 21 years old.

00:12:33.071 --> 00:12:34.453
I took a meeting

00:12:34.477 --> 00:12:38.916
with a then-Australian Foreign Minister
who shall remain nameless --

00:12:39.613 --> 00:12:40.904
[Alexander Downer]

00:12:40.928 --> 00:12:42.686
(Laughter)

00:12:43.473 --> 00:12:44.695
And behind closed doors,

00:12:44.719 --> 00:12:47.195
I shared with him my passion
to end extreme poverty.

00:12:47.219 --> 00:12:51.138
I said, "Minister -- Australia
has this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity

00:12:51.162 --> 00:12:53.851
to help achieve the Millennium
Development Goals.

00:12:53.875 --> 00:12:55.121
We can do this."

00:12:55.764 --> 00:12:57.202
And he paused,

00:12:57.226 --> 00:12:59.748
looked down on me
with cold, dismissive eyes,

00:13:00.423 --> 00:13:01.891
and he said, "Hugh,

00:13:01.915 --> 00:13:04.105
no one gives a funk about foreign aid."

00:13:04.573 --> 00:13:06.383
Except he didn't use the word "funk."

00:13:07.486 --> 00:13:08.647
He went on.

00:13:08.671 --> 00:13:11.228
He said we need to look after
our own backyard first.

00:13:11.830 --> 00:13:12.993
This is, I believe,

00:13:13.017 --> 00:13:15.484
outdated, even dangerous thinking.

00:13:16.017 --> 00:13:17.890
Or as my late grandfather would say,

00:13:17.914 --> 00:13:19.259
complete BS.

00:13:19.916 --> 00:13:22.905
Parochialism offers this false dichotomy

00:13:22.929 --> 00:13:26.435
because it pits the poor in one country
against the poor in another.

00:13:26.459 --> 00:13:30.308
It pretends we can isolate ourselves
and our nations from one another.

00:13:30.657 --> 00:13:32.724
The whole world is our backyard,

00:13:32.748 --> 00:13:34.629
and we ignore it at our peril.

00:13:34.653 --> 00:13:36.851
See, look what happened
when we ignored Rwanda,

00:13:36.875 --> 00:13:38.343
when we ignore Syria,

00:13:38.367 --> 00:13:40.270
when we ignore climate change.

00:13:40.294 --> 00:13:42.477
Political leaders ought to give a "funk"

00:13:42.501 --> 00:13:45.164
because the impact of climate change
and extreme poverty

00:13:45.188 --> 00:13:46.544
comes right to our shore.

00:13:47.068 --> 00:13:49.678
Now, global citizens --
they understand this.

00:13:49.702 --> 00:13:52.952
We live in a time that favors
the global citizen,

00:13:52.976 --> 00:13:55.888
in an age where every
single voice can be heard.

00:13:55.912 --> 00:13:57.080
See, do you remember

00:13:57.104 --> 00:14:00.570
when the Millennium Development Goals
were signed back in the year 2000?

00:14:00.594 --> 00:14:03.499
The most we could do in those days
was fire off a letter

00:14:03.523 --> 00:14:05.234
and wait for the next election.

00:14:05.695 --> 00:14:07.369
There was no social media.

00:14:07.956 --> 00:14:11.171
Today, billions of citizens
have more tools,

00:14:11.195 --> 00:14:13.013
more access to information,

00:14:13.037 --> 00:14:15.488
more capacity to influence
than ever before.

00:14:16.109 --> 00:14:19.851
Both the problems and the tools
to solve them are right before us.

00:14:20.335 --> 00:14:22.401
The world has changed,

00:14:22.425 --> 00:14:24.822
and those of us who look
beyond our borders

00:14:24.846 --> 00:14:26.886
are on the right side of history.

00:14:28.021 --> 00:14:29.267
So where are we?

00:14:29.856 --> 00:14:32.223
So we run this amazing festival,

00:14:32.247 --> 00:14:34.562
we've scored some big policy wins,

00:14:34.586 --> 00:14:37.085
and citizens are signing up
all over the world.

00:14:37.775 --> 00:14:39.831
But have we achieved our mission?

00:14:40.609 --> 00:14:41.767
No.

00:14:42.243 --> 00:14:43.888
We have such a long way to go.

00:14:44.904 --> 00:14:47.086
But this is the opportunity that I see.

00:14:48.372 --> 00:14:50.499
The concept of global citizenship,

00:14:51.674 --> 00:14:57.370
self-evident in its logic but until now
impractical in many ways,

00:14:57.394 --> 00:15:01.524
has coincided with this particular moment
in which we are privileged to live.

00:15:02.002 --> 00:15:03.154
We, as global citizens,

00:15:03.178 --> 00:15:07.765
now have a unique opportunity
to accelerate large-scale positive change

00:15:07.789 --> 00:15:09.026
around the world.

00:15:09.512 --> 00:15:11.671
So in the months and years ahead,

00:15:11.695 --> 00:15:14.739
global citizens will hold
world leaders accountable

00:15:14.763 --> 00:15:17.809
to ensure that the new Global Goals
for Sustainable Development

00:15:17.833 --> 00:15:19.498
are tracked and implemented.

00:15:20.006 --> 00:15:22.884
Global citizens will partner
with the world's leading NGOs

00:15:22.908 --> 00:15:25.740
to end diseases like polio and malaria.

00:15:26.201 --> 00:15:29.368
Global citizens will sign up
in every corner of this globe,

00:15:29.392 --> 00:15:32.048
increasing the frequency, quality

00:15:32.072 --> 00:15:33.817
and impact of their actions.

00:15:34.809 --> 00:15:36.896
These dreams are within reach.

00:15:37.461 --> 00:15:40.001
Imagine an army of millions

00:15:40.025 --> 00:15:42.222
growing into tens of millions,

00:15:42.246 --> 00:15:45.993
connected, informed, engaged

00:15:46.596 --> 00:15:48.778
and unwilling to take no for an answer.

00:15:50.390 --> 00:15:51.950
Over all these years,

00:15:53.188 --> 00:15:55.363
I've tried to reconnect with Sonny Boy.

00:15:56.728 --> 00:15:58.561
Sadly, I've been unable to.

00:16:00.569 --> 00:16:02.762
We met long before social media,

00:16:03.437 --> 00:16:06.201
and his address has now
been relocated by the authorities,

00:16:06.225 --> 00:16:08.088
as often happens with slums.

00:16:09.881 --> 00:16:11.315
I'd love to sit down with him,

00:16:11.339 --> 00:16:12.532
wherever he is,

00:16:13.270 --> 00:16:17.348
and share with him how much the time
I spent on Smoky Mountain inspired me.

00:16:18.638 --> 00:16:20.387
Thanks to him and so many others,

00:16:20.411 --> 00:16:24.082
I came to understand the importance
of being part of a movement of people --

00:16:24.710 --> 00:16:28.177
the kids willing to look up
from their screens and out to the world,

00:16:28.701 --> 00:16:30.169
the global citizens.

00:16:31.062 --> 00:16:33.185
Global citizens who stand together,

00:16:33.931 --> 00:16:35.733
who ask the question "Why?,"

00:16:36.621 --> 00:16:38.373
who reject the naysayers,

00:16:38.896 --> 00:16:42.119
and embrace the amazing possibilities
of the world we share.

00:16:43.198 --> 00:16:44.563
I'm a global citizen.

00:16:45.148 --> 00:16:46.301
Are you?

00:16:46.799 --> 00:16:47.981
Thank you.

00:16:48.005 --> 00:16:55.571
(Applause)

title: Your kids might live on Mars. Here's how they'll survive
transcript: Strap yourselves in, we're going to Mars.Not just a few astronauts — thousands of people are going to colonize Mars. And I am telling you that they're going to do this soon. Some of you will end up working on projects on Mars, and I guarantee that some of your children will end up living there.That probably sounds preposterous, so I'm going to share with you how and when that will happen. But first I want to discuss the obvious question: Why the heck should we do this?12 years ago, I gave a TED talk on 10 ways the world could end suddenly. We are incredibly vulnerable to the whims of our own galaxy. A single, large asteroid could take us out forever. To survive we have to reach beyond the home planet. Think what a tragedy it would be if all that humans have accomplished were suddenly obliterated.And there's another reason we should go: exploration is in our DNA. Two million years ago humans evolved in Africa and then slowly but surely spread out across the entire planet by reaching into the wilderness that was beyond their horizons. This stuff is inside us. And they prospered doing that. Some of the greatest advances in civilization and technology came because we explored.Yes, we could do a lot of good with the money it will take to establish a thriving colony on Mars. And yes we should all be taking far better care of our own home planet. And yes, I worry we could screw up Mars the way we've screwed up Earth.But think for a moment, what we had when John F. Kennedy told us we would put a human on the moon. He excited an entire generation to dream. Think how inspired we will be to see a landing on Mars. Perhaps then we will look back at Earth and see that that is one people instead of many and perhaps then we will look back at Earth, as we struggle to survive on Mars, and realize how precious the home planet is.So let me tell you about the extraordinary adventure we're about to undertake. But first, a few fascinating facts about where we're going. This picture actually represents the true size of Mars compared to Earth. Mars is not our sister planet. It's far less than half the size of the Earth, and yet despite the fact that it's smaller, the surface area of Mars that you can stand on is equivalent to the surface area of the Earth that you can stand on, because the Earth is mostly covered by water.The atmosphere on Mars is really thin — 100 times thinner than on Earth — and it's not breathable, it's 96 percent carbon dioxide.It's really cold there. The average temperature is minus 81 degrees, although there is quite a range of temperature.A day on Mars is about as long as a day on Earth, plus about 39 minutes. Seasons and years on Mars are twice as long as they are on Earth.And for anybody who wants to strap on some wings and go flying one day, Mars has a lot less gravity than on Earth, and it's the kind of place where you can jump over your car instead of walk around it.Now, as you can see, Mars isn't exactly Earth-like, but it's by far the most livable other place in our entire solar system.Here's the problem. Mars is a long way away, a thousand times farther away from us than our own moon. The Moon is 250,000 miles away and it took Apollo astronauts three days to get there. Mars is 250 million miles away and it will take us eight months to get there — 240 days. And that's only if we launch on a very specific day, at a very specific time, once every two years, when Mars and the Earth are aligned just so, so the distance that the rocket would have to travel will be the shortest. 240 days is a long time to spend trapped with your colleagues in a tin can.And meanwhile, our track record of getting to Mars is lousy. We and the Russians, the Europeans, the Japanese, the Chinese and the Indians, have actually sent 44 rockets there, and the vast majority of them have either missed or crashed. Only about a third of the missions to Mars have been successful.And we don't at the moment have a rocket big enough to get there anyway. We once had that rocket, the Saturn V. A couple of Saturn Vs would have gotten us there. It was the most magnificent machine ever built by humans, and it was the rocket that took us to the Moon. But the last Saturn V was used in 1973 to launch the Skylab space station, and we decided to do something called the shuttle instead of continuing on to Mars after we landed on the Moon. The biggest rocket we have now is only half big enough to get us anything to Mars.So getting to Mars is not going to be easy and that brings up a really interesting question ... how soon will the first humans actually land here?Now, some pundits think if we got there by 2050, that'd be a pretty good achievement.These days, NASA seems to be saying that it can get humans to Mars by 2040. Maybe they can. I believe that they can get human beings into Mars orbit by 2035. But frankly, I don't think they're going to bother in 2035 to send a rocket to Mars, because we will already be there.We're going to land on Mars in 2027. And the reason is this man is determined to make that happen. His name is Elon Musk, he's the CEO of Tesla Motors and SpaceX. Now, he actually told me that we would land on Mars by 2025, but Elon Musk is more optimistic than I am — and that's going a ways — so I'm giving him a couple of years of slack. Still ... you've got to ask yourself, can this guy really do this by 2025 or 2027?Well, let's put a decade with Elon Musk into a little perspective. Where was this 10 years ago? That's the Tesla electric automobile. In 2005, a lot of people in the automobile industry were saying, we would not have a decent electric car for 50 years.And where was that? That is SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket, lifting six tons of supplies to the International Space Station. 10 years ago, SpaceX had not launched anything, or fired a rocket to anywhere. So I think it's a pretty good bet that the person who is revolutionizing the automobile industry in less than 10 years and the person who created an entire rocket company in less than 10 years will get us to Mars by 2027.Now, you need to know this: governments and robots no longer control this game. Private companies are leaping into space and they will be happy to take you to Mars.And that raises a really big question. Can we actually live there? Now, NASA may not be able to get us there until 2040, or we may get there a long time before NASA, but NASA has taken a huge responsibility in figuring out how we can live on Mars.Let's look at the problem this way. Here's what you need to live on Earth: food, water, shelter and clothing. And here's what you need to live on Mars: all of the above, plus oxygen.So let's look at the most important thing on this list first. Water is the basis of all life as we know it, and it's far too heavy for us to carry water from the Earth to Mars to live, so we have to find water if our life is going to succeed on Mars. And if you look at Mars, it looks really dry, it looks like the entire planet is a desert. But it turns out that it's not. The soil alone on Mars contains up to 60 percent water. And a number of orbiters that we still have flying around Mars have shown us — and by the way, that's a real photograph — that lots of craters on Mars have a sheet of water ice in them. It's not a bad place to start a colony.Now, here's a view of a little dig the Phoenix Lander did in 2008, showing that just below the surface of the soil is ice — that white stuff is ice. In the second picture, which is four days later than the first picture, you can see that some of it is evaporating.Orbiters also tell us that there are huge amounts of underground water on Mars as well as glaciers. In fact, if only the water ice at the poles on Mars melted, most of the planet would be under 30 feet of water. So there's plenty of water there, but most of it's ice, most of it's underground, it takes a lot of energy to get it and a lot of human labor.This is a device cooked up at the University of Washington back in 1998. It's basically a low-tech dehumidifier. And it turns out the Mars atmosphere is often 100 percent humid. So this device can extract all the water that humans will need simply from the atmosphere on Mars.Next we have to worry about what we will breathe. Frankly, I was really shocked to find out that NASA has this problem worked out. This is a scientist at MIT named Michael Hecht. And he's developed this machine, Moxie. I love this thing. It's a reverse fuel cell, essentially, that sucks in the Martian atmosphere and pumps out oxygen. And you have to remember that CO2 — carbon dioxide, which is 96 percent of Mars' atmosphere — CO2 is basically 78 percent oxygen.Now, the next big rover that NASA sends to Mars in 2020 is going to have one of these devices aboard, and it will be able to produce enough oxygen to keep one person alive indefinitely. But the secret to this — and that's just for testing — the secret to this is that this thing was designed from the get-go to be scalable by a factor of 100.Next, what will we eat? Well, we'll use hydroponics to grow food, but we're not going to be able to grow more than 15 to 20 percent of our food there, at least not until water is running on the surface of Mars and we actually have the probability and the capability of planting crops. In the meantime, most of our food will arrive from Earth, and it will be dried.And then we need some shelter. At first we can use inflatable, pressurized buildings as well as the landers themselves. But this really only works during the daytime. There is too much solar radiation and too much radiation from cosmic rays. So we really have to go underground.Now, it turns out that the soil on Mars, by and large, is perfect for making bricks. And NASA has figured this one out, too. They're going to throw some polymer plastic into the bricks, shove them in a microwave oven, and then you will be able to build buildings with really thick walls. Or we may choose to live underground in caves or in lava tubes, of which there are plenty.And finally there's clothing. On Earth we have miles of atmosphere piled up on us, which creates 15 pounds of pressure on our bodies at all times, and we're constantly pushing out against that. On Mars there's hardly any atmospheric pressure. So Dava Newman, a scientist at MIT, has created this sleek space suit. It will keep us together, block radiation and keep us warm.So let's think about this for a minute. Food, shelter, clothing, water, oxygen ... we can do this. We really can. But it's still a little complicated and a little difficult.So that leads to the next big — really big step — in living the good life on Mars. And that's terraforming the planet: making it more like Earth, reengineering an entire planet.That sounds like a lot of hubris, but the truth is that the technology to do everything I'm about to tell you already exists.First we've got to warm it up. Mars is incredibly cold because it has a very thin atmosphere. The answer lies here, at the south pole and at the north pole of Mars, both of which are covered with an incredible amount of frozen carbon dioxide — dry ice. If we heat it up, it sublimes directly into the atmosphere and thickens the atmosphere the same way it does on Earth.And as we know, CO2 is an incredibly potent greenhouse gas. Now, my favorite way of doing this is to erect a very, very large solar sail and focus it — it essentially serves as a mirror — and focus it on the south pole of Mars at first. As the planet spins, it will heat up all that dry ice, sublime it, and it will go into the atmosphere. It actually won't take long for the temperature on Mars to start rising, probably less than 20 years.Right now, on a perfect day at the equator, in the middle of summer on Mars, temperatures can actually reach 70 degrees, but then they go down to minus 100 at night.(Laughter)What we're shooting for is a runaway greenhouse effect: enough temperature rise to see a lot of that ice on Mars — especially the ice in the ground — melt. Then we get some real magic.As the atmosphere gets thicker, everything gets better. We get more protection from radiation, more atmosphere makes us warmer, makes the planet warmer, so we get running water and that makes crops possible. Then more water vapor goes into the air, forming yet another potent greenhouse gas. It will rain and it will snow on Mars. And a thicker atmosphere will create enough pressure so that we can throw away those space suits. We only need about five pounds of pressure to survive. Eventually, Mars will be made to feel a lot like British Columbia.We'll still be left with the complicated problem of making the atmosphere breathable, and frankly that could take 1,000 years to accomplish. But humans are amazingly smart and incredibly adaptable.There is no telling what our future technology will be able to accomplish and no telling what we can do with our own bodies. In biology right now, we are on the very verge of being able to control our own genetics, what the genes in our own bodies are doing, and certainly, eventually, our own evolution. We could end up with a species of human being on Earth that is slightly different from the species of human beings on Mars.But what would you do there? How would you live? It's going to be the same as it is on Earth. Somebody's going to start a restaurant, somebody's going to build an iron foundry. Someone will make documentary movies of Mars and sell them on Earth. Some idiot will start a reality TV show.(Laughter)There will be software companies, there will be hotels, there will be bars.This much is certain: it will be the most disruptive event in our lifetimes, and I think it will be the most inspiring.Ask any 10-year-old girl if she wants to go to Mars. Children who are now in elementary school are going to choose to live there.Remember when we landed humans on the Moon? When that happened, people looked at each other and said, "If we can do this, we can do anything." What are they going to think when we actually form a colony on Mars?Most importantly, it will make us a spacefaring species. And that means humans will survive no matter what happens on Earth. We will never be the last of our kind.Thank you.(Applause)
