00:01:22.153 --> 00:01:23.765
I came to the arts through music.

00:01:23.789 --> 00:01:25.177
I was trained as a composer,

00:01:25.201 --> 00:01:28.483
and about 15 years ago,
I started making pieces

00:01:28.507 --> 00:01:31.042
that were designed to look
at the intersection

00:01:31.066 --> 00:01:32.970
between sound and image,

00:01:32.994 --> 00:01:35.826
to use an image to unveil
a musical structure

00:01:35.850 --> 00:01:38.714
or to use a sound to show you
something interesting

00:01:38.738 --> 00:01:40.738
about something that's usually pictorial.

00:01:40.762 --> 00:01:44.229
So what you're seeing on the screen
is literally being drawn

00:01:44.253 --> 00:01:47.195
by the musical structure
of the musicians onstage,

00:01:47.219 --> 00:01:49.751
and there's no accident
that it looks like a plant,

00:01:49.775 --> 00:01:53.114
because the underlying
algorithmic biology of the plant

00:01:53.138 --> 00:01:56.449
is what informed the musical structure
in the first place.

00:01:56.473 --> 00:01:59.877
So once you know how to do this,
once you know how to code with media,

00:01:59.901 --> 00:02:01.989
you can do some pretty cool stuff.

00:02:02.013 --> 00:02:05.490
This is a project I did
for the Sundance Film Festival.

00:02:05.863 --> 00:02:09.867
Really simple idea: you take
every Academy Award Best Picture,

00:02:11.136 --> 00:02:13.497
you speed it up to one minute each

00:02:13.521 --> 00:02:15.102
and string them all together.

00:02:15.126 --> 00:02:19.037
And so in 75 minutes, I can show you
the history of Hollywood cinema.

00:02:19.550 --> 00:02:22.529
And what it really shows you
is the history of editing

00:02:22.553 --> 00:02:23.734
in Hollywood cinema.

00:02:23.758 --> 00:02:27.906
So on the left, we've got Casablanca;
on the right, we've got Chicago.

00:02:27.930 --> 00:02:30.854
And you can see that Casablanca
is a little easier to read.

00:02:30.878 --> 00:02:34.210
That's because the average length
of a cinematic shot in the 1940s

00:02:34.234 --> 00:02:35.873
was 26 seconds,

00:02:35.897 --> 00:02:37.925
and now it's around six seconds.

00:02:38.957 --> 00:02:40.701
This is a project that was inspired

00:02:40.725 --> 00:02:43.669
by some work that was funded
by the US Federal Government

00:02:43.693 --> 00:02:44.862
in the early 2000s,

00:02:44.886 --> 00:02:50.714
to look at video footage and find
a specific actor in any video.

00:02:51.563 --> 00:02:56.239
And so I repurposed this code
to train a system on one person

00:02:56.263 --> 00:03:00.110
in our culture who would never need
to be surveilled in that manner,

00:03:00.134 --> 00:03:01.661
which is Britney Spears.

00:03:01.685 --> 00:03:05.177
I downloaded 2,000 paparazzi
photos of Britney Spears

00:03:05.201 --> 00:03:07.677
and trained my computer to find her face

00:03:07.701 --> 00:03:09.082
and her face alone.

00:03:09.106 --> 00:03:13.382
I can run any footage of her through it
and will center her eyes in the frame,

00:03:13.406 --> 00:03:15.582
and this sort of is a little
double commentary

00:03:15.606 --> 00:03:17.630
about surveillance in our society.

00:03:17.654 --> 00:03:20.646
We are very fraught with anxiety
about being watched,

00:03:20.670 --> 00:03:23.269
but then we obsess over celebrity.

00:03:24.177 --> 00:03:27.907
What you're seeing on the screen here
is a collaboration I did

00:03:27.931 --> 00:03:30.487
with an artist named Lián Amaris.

00:03:30.511 --> 00:03:34.385
What she did is very simple
to explain and describe,

00:03:34.409 --> 00:03:35.641
but very hard to do.

00:03:35.665 --> 00:03:38.516
She took 72 minutes of activity,

00:03:39.166 --> 00:03:41.739
getting ready for a night out on the town,

00:03:41.763 --> 00:03:43.852
and stretched it over three days

00:03:43.876 --> 00:03:47.464
and performed it on a traffic island
in slow motion in New York City.

00:03:47.907 --> 00:03:50.126
I was there, too, with a film crew.

00:03:50.150 --> 00:03:51.402
We filmed the whole thing,

00:03:51.426 --> 00:03:54.827
and then we reversed the process,
speeding it up to 72 minutes again,

00:03:54.851 --> 00:03:56.745
so it looks like she's moving normally

00:03:56.769 --> 00:03:58.601
and the whole world is flying by.

00:03:59.049 --> 00:04:01.625
At a certain point, I figured out

00:04:01.649 --> 00:04:04.316
that what I was doing
was making portraits.

00:04:05.458 --> 00:04:09.020
When you think about portraiture,
you tend to think about stuff like this.

00:04:09.044 --> 00:04:11.107
The guy on the left
is named Gilbert Stuart.

00:04:11.131 --> 00:04:14.195
He's sort of the first real portraitist
of the United States.

00:04:14.219 --> 00:04:17.444
And on the right is his portrait
of George Washington from 1796.

00:04:17.468 --> 00:04:19.666
This is the so-called Lansdowne portrait.

00:04:19.690 --> 00:04:22.930
And if you look at this painting,
there's a lot of symbolism, right?

00:04:22.954 --> 00:04:25.614
We've got a rainbow out the window.
We've got a sword.

00:04:25.638 --> 00:04:27.093
We've got a quill on the desk.

00:04:27.117 --> 00:04:28.966
All of these things are meant to evoke

00:04:28.990 --> 00:04:31.438
George Washington
as the father of the nation.

00:04:31.790 --> 00:04:34.560
This is my portrait of George Washington.

00:04:35.734 --> 00:04:38.743
And this is an eye chart,

00:04:38.767 --> 00:04:40.941
only instead of letters, they're words.

00:04:41.671 --> 00:04:44.373
And what the words are is the 66 words

00:04:44.397 --> 00:04:46.857
in George Washington's
State of the Union addresses

00:04:46.881 --> 00:04:49.252
that he uses more
than any other president.

00:04:49.978 --> 00:04:54.180
So "gentlemen" has its own symbolism
and its own rhetoric.

00:04:54.204 --> 00:04:58.796
And it's really kind of significant
that that's the word he used the most.

00:04:58.820 --> 00:05:00.939
This is the eye chart for George W. Bush,

00:05:00.963 --> 00:05:03.943
who was president when I made this piece.

00:05:03.967 --> 00:05:05.135
And how you get there,

00:05:05.159 --> 00:05:08.611
from "gentlemen" to "terror"
in 43 easy steps,

00:05:08.635 --> 00:05:10.695
tells us a lot about American history,

00:05:10.719 --> 00:05:12.306
and gives you a different insight

00:05:12.330 --> 00:05:15.267
than you would have
looking at a series of paintings.

00:05:15.291 --> 00:05:19.225
These pieces provide a history lesson
of the United States

00:05:19.249 --> 00:05:21.505
through the political
rhetoric of its leaders.

00:05:21.529 --> 00:05:24.493
Ronald Reagan spent a lot of time
talking about deficits.

00:05:25.093 --> 00:05:26.658
Bill Clinton spent a lot of time

00:05:26.682 --> 00:05:29.966
talking about the century in which
he would no longer be president,

00:05:29.990 --> 00:05:31.601
but maybe his wife would be.

00:05:33.106 --> 00:05:35.742
Lyndon Johnson was the first President

00:05:35.766 --> 00:05:38.948
to give his State of the Union addresses
on prime-time television;

00:05:38.972 --> 00:05:41.312
he began every paragraph
with the word "tonight."

00:05:41.336 --> 00:05:44.002
And Richard Nixon,
or more accurately, his speechwriter,

00:05:44.026 --> 00:05:45.354
a guy named William Safire,

00:05:45.378 --> 00:05:47.426
spent a lot of time
thinking about language

00:05:47.450 --> 00:05:51.383
and making sure that his boss
portrayed a rhetoric of honesty.

00:05:51.407 --> 00:05:54.309
This project is shown
as a series of monolithic sculptures.

00:05:54.333 --> 00:05:56.781
It's an outdoor series of light boxes.

00:05:56.805 --> 00:05:59.235
And it's important to note
that they're to scale,

00:05:59.259 --> 00:06:02.873
so if you stand 20 feet back and you can
read between those two black lines,

00:06:02.897 --> 00:06:04.048
you have 20/20 vision.

00:06:04.072 --> 00:06:05.110
(Laughter)

00:06:05.134 --> 00:06:07.439
This is a portrait.
And there's a lot of these.

00:06:07.463 --> 00:06:10.725
There's a lot of ways
to do this with data.

00:06:10.749 --> 00:06:12.369
I started looking for a way

00:06:12.393 --> 00:06:17.098
to think about how I can do
a more democratic form of portraiture,

00:06:17.122 --> 00:06:21.353
something that's more about
my country and how it works.

00:06:21.377 --> 00:06:25.178
Every 10 years, we make a census
in the United States.

00:06:25.202 --> 00:06:26.660
We literally count people,

00:06:27.264 --> 00:06:30.408
find out who lives where,
what kind of jobs we've got,

00:06:30.432 --> 00:06:31.909
the language we speak at home.

00:06:31.933 --> 00:06:34.504
And this is important stuff --
really important stuff.

00:06:34.528 --> 00:06:36.761
But it doesn't really tell us who we are.

00:06:36.785 --> 00:06:39.456
It doesn't tell us about our dreams
and our aspirations.

00:06:39.480 --> 00:06:42.870
And so in 2010, I decided
to make my own census.

00:06:42.894 --> 00:06:46.214
And I started looking for a corpus of data

00:06:46.238 --> 00:06:49.350
that had a lot of descriptions
written by ordinary Americans.

00:06:49.374 --> 00:06:50.525
And it turns out

00:06:50.549 --> 00:06:52.291
that there is such a corpus of data

00:06:52.315 --> 00:06:54.299
that's just sitting there for the taking.

00:06:54.323 --> 00:06:55.649
It's called online dating.

00:06:56.532 --> 00:07:01.478
So in 2010, I joined 21 different
online dating services,

00:07:01.502 --> 00:07:04.602
as a gay man, a straight man,
a gay woman and a straight woman,

00:07:04.626 --> 00:07:06.243
in every zip code in America

00:07:06.267 --> 00:07:09.452
and downloaded about
19 million people's dating profiles --

00:07:09.476 --> 00:07:12.708
about 20 percent of the adult population
of the United States.

00:07:13.199 --> 00:07:15.018
I have obsessive-compulsive disorder.

00:07:15.042 --> 00:07:18.143
This is going to become
really freaking obvious. Just go with me.

00:07:18.167 --> 00:07:19.309
(Laughter)

00:07:19.333 --> 00:07:22.372
So what I did was I sorted
all this stuff by zip code.

00:07:23.880 --> 00:07:25.371
And I looked at word analysis.

00:07:25.395 --> 00:07:28.068
These are some dating profiles from 2010

00:07:28.092 --> 00:07:30.187
with the word "lonely" highlighted.

00:07:30.211 --> 00:07:33.192
If you look at these things
topographically,

00:07:33.216 --> 00:07:36.716
if you imagine dark colors to light colors
are more use of the word,

00:07:36.740 --> 00:07:41.041
you can see that Appalachia
is a pretty lonely place.

00:07:41.937 --> 00:07:46.884
You can also see
that Nebraska ain't that funny.

00:07:48.343 --> 00:07:51.998
This is the kinky map,
so what this is showing you

00:07:53.991 --> 00:07:57.094
is that the women in Alaska
need to get together

00:07:57.118 --> 00:07:58.893
with the men in southern New Mexico,

00:07:58.917 --> 00:08:00.257
and have a good time.

00:08:00.281 --> 00:08:03.147
And I have this
at a pretty granular level,

00:08:03.171 --> 00:08:06.278
so I can tell you that the men
in the eastern half of Long Island

00:08:06.302 --> 00:08:08.228
are way more interested in being spanked

00:08:08.252 --> 00:08:10.477
than men in the western half
of Long Island.

00:08:11.809 --> 00:08:14.659
This will be your one takeaway
from this whole conference.

00:08:14.683 --> 00:08:17.423
You're going to remember
that fact for, like, 30 years.

00:08:17.447 --> 00:08:20.279
(Laughter)

00:08:20.613 --> 00:08:23.036
When you bring this down
to a cartographic level,

00:08:23.060 --> 00:08:26.514
you can make maps and do the same trick
I was doing with the eye charts.

00:08:26.538 --> 00:08:29.355
You can replace the name
of every city in the United States

00:08:29.379 --> 00:08:32.371
with the word people use more
in that city than anywhere else.

00:08:32.395 --> 00:08:35.624
If you've ever dated anyone
from Seattle, this makes perfect sense.

00:08:35.648 --> 00:08:38.350
You've got "pretty."
You've got "heartbreak."

00:08:38.374 --> 00:08:40.789
You've got "gig." You've got "cigarette."

00:08:40.813 --> 00:08:42.839
They play in a band and they smoke.

00:08:43.562 --> 00:08:45.546
And right above that you can see "email."

00:08:45.570 --> 00:08:46.876
That's Redmond, Washington,

00:08:46.900 --> 00:08:49.495
which is the headquarters
of the Microsoft Corporation.

00:08:49.519 --> 00:08:52.343
Some of these you can guess --
so, Los Angeles is "acting"

00:08:52.367 --> 00:08:53.985
and San Francisco is "gay."

00:08:54.009 --> 00:08:56.001
Some are a little bit more heartbreaking.

00:08:56.025 --> 00:08:58.106
In Baton Rouge, they talk
about being curvy;

00:08:58.130 --> 00:09:01.017
downstream in New Orleans,
they still talk about the flood.

00:09:01.041 --> 00:09:03.846
Folks in the American capital
will say they're interesting.

00:09:03.870 --> 00:09:06.647
People in Baltimore, Maryland,
will say they're afraid.

00:09:06.671 --> 00:09:08.208
This is New Jersey.

00:09:08.232 --> 00:09:10.921
I grew up somewhere
between "annoying" and "cynical."

00:09:10.945 --> 00:09:15.184
(Laughter) (Applause)

00:09:15.208 --> 00:09:17.865
And New York City's
number one word is "now,"

00:09:17.889 --> 00:09:21.135
as in, "Now I'm working as a waiter,
but actually I'm an actor."

00:09:21.159 --> 00:09:22.257
(Laughter)

00:09:22.281 --> 00:09:26.576
Or, "Now I'm a professor of engineering
at NYU, but actually I'm an artist."

00:09:26.600 --> 00:09:28.525
If you go upstate, you see "dinosaur."

00:09:28.549 --> 00:09:29.700
That's Syracuse.

00:09:29.724 --> 00:09:31.797
The best place to eat
in Syracuse, New York,

00:09:31.821 --> 00:09:34.615
is a Hell's Angels barbecue joint
called Dinosaur Barbecue.

00:09:34.639 --> 00:09:36.861
That's where you would
take somebody on a date.

00:09:36.885 --> 00:09:40.691
I live somewhere between "unconditional"
and "midsummer," in Midtown Manhattan.

00:09:40.715 --> 00:09:42.762
And this is gentrified North Brooklyn,

00:09:42.786 --> 00:09:45.982
so you've got "DJ" and "glamorous"
and "hipsters" and "urbane."

00:09:46.006 --> 00:09:48.428
So that's maybe
a more democratic portrait.

00:09:48.452 --> 00:09:51.521
And the idea was, what if we made
red-state and blue-state maps

00:09:51.545 --> 00:09:53.714
based on what we want to do
on a Friday night?

00:09:53.738 --> 00:09:55.245
This is a self-portrait.

00:09:55.728 --> 00:09:56.985
This is based on my email,

00:09:57.009 --> 00:09:59.978
about 500,000 emails sent over 20 years.

00:10:00.002 --> 00:10:02.955
You can think of this
as a quantified selfie.

00:10:02.979 --> 00:10:06.073
So what I'm doing is running
a physics equation

00:10:06.097 --> 00:10:07.495
based on my personal data.

00:10:07.519 --> 00:10:10.262
You have to imagine everybody
I've ever corresponded with.

00:10:10.286 --> 00:10:13.685
It started out in the middle
and it exploded with a big bang.

00:10:13.709 --> 00:10:15.887
And everybody has gravity to one another,

00:10:15.911 --> 00:10:18.172
gravity based on how much
they've been emailing,

00:10:18.196 --> 00:10:19.704
who they've been emailing with.

00:10:19.728 --> 00:10:21.560
And it also does sentimental analysis,

00:10:21.584 --> 00:10:23.873
so if I say "I love you,"
you're heavier to me.

00:10:23.897 --> 00:10:26.393
And you attract to my email
addresses in the middle,

00:10:26.417 --> 00:10:28.512
which act like mainline stars.

00:10:28.536 --> 00:10:30.321
And all the names are handwritten.

00:10:30.875 --> 00:10:34.583
Sometimes you do this data
and this work with real-time data

00:10:34.607 --> 00:10:37.554
to illuminate a specific problem
in a specific city.

00:10:38.029 --> 00:10:40.705
This is a Walther PPK 9mm
semiautomatic handgun

00:10:40.729 --> 00:10:43.760
that was used in a shooting
in the French Quarter of New Orleans

00:10:43.784 --> 00:10:47.093
about two years ago on Valentine's Day
in an argument over parking.

00:10:47.117 --> 00:10:48.332
Those are my cigarettes.

00:10:48.356 --> 00:10:50.631
This is the house
where the shooting took place.

00:10:50.655 --> 00:10:53.029
This project involved
a little bit of engineering.

00:10:53.053 --> 00:10:55.268
I've got a bike chain
rigged up as a cam shaft,

00:10:55.292 --> 00:10:56.608
with a computer driving it.

00:10:56.632 --> 00:10:59.398
That computer and the mechanism
are buried in a box.

00:10:59.422 --> 00:11:01.636
The gun's on top welded to a steel plate.

00:11:01.660 --> 00:11:04.005
There's a wire going
through to the trigger,

00:11:04.029 --> 00:11:06.220
and the computer in the box is online.

00:11:06.244 --> 00:11:09.477
It's listening to the 911 feed
of the New Orleans Police Department,

00:11:09.501 --> 00:11:12.378
so that anytime there's a shooting
reported in New Orleans,

00:11:12.402 --> 00:11:13.403
(Gunshot sound)

00:11:13.427 --> 00:11:14.647
the gun fires.

00:11:15.258 --> 00:11:17.608
Now, there's a blank,
so there's no bullet.

00:11:17.966 --> 00:11:20.040
There's big light, big noise

00:11:20.064 --> 00:11:22.386
and most importantly, there's a casing.

00:11:22.410 --> 00:11:24.806
There's about five shootings
a day in New Orleans,

00:11:24.830 --> 00:11:27.171
so over the four months
this piece was installed,

00:11:27.195 --> 00:11:28.806
the case filled up with bullets.

00:11:29.600 --> 00:11:33.334
You guys know what this is --
you call this "data visualization."

00:11:34.517 --> 00:11:36.525
When you do it right, it's illuminating.

00:11:36.549 --> 00:11:38.985
When you do it wrong, it's anesthetizing.

00:11:39.614 --> 00:11:41.269
It reduces people to numbers.

00:11:41.293 --> 00:11:42.704
So watch out.

00:11:44.612 --> 00:11:45.968
One last piece for you.

00:11:46.424 --> 00:11:49.206
I spent the last summer
as the artist in residence

00:11:49.230 --> 00:11:50.446
for Times Square.

00:11:50.890 --> 00:11:54.533
And Times Square in New York
is literally the crossroads of the world.

00:11:54.557 --> 00:11:56.734
One of the things
people don't notice about it

00:11:56.758 --> 00:11:59.305
is it's the most Instagrammed
place on Earth.

00:11:59.861 --> 00:12:02.743
About every five seconds,
someone commits a selfie

00:12:02.767 --> 00:12:03.936
in Times Square.

00:12:04.382 --> 00:12:07.631
That's 17,000 a day, and I have them all.

00:12:07.655 --> 00:12:08.740
(Laughter)

00:12:08.764 --> 00:12:11.056
These are some of them
with their eyes centered.

00:12:11.080 --> 00:12:12.141
Every civilization,

00:12:12.141 --> 00:12:15.066
will use the maximum level
of technology available to make art.

00:12:15.090 --> 00:12:17.898
And it's the responsibility
of the artist to ask questions

00:12:17.922 --> 00:12:19.553
about what that technology means

00:12:19.577 --> 00:12:21.596
and how it reflects our culture.

00:12:21.620 --> 00:12:24.106
So I leave you with this:
we're more than numbers.

00:12:24.130 --> 00:12:26.131
We're people, and we have
dreams and ideas.

00:12:26.155 --> 00:12:28.954
And reducing us to statistics
is something that's done

00:12:28.978 --> 00:12:30.229
at our peril.

00:12:30.253 --> 00:12:31.431
Thank you very much.

00:12:31.455 --> 00:12:42.241
(Applause)

title: Why I put myself in danger to tell the stories of Gaza
transcript: Hello. This is my first trip, first time in life I'm outside of the walls of Gaza. I'm so happy to be here.(Applause)My ambition always was to be a pilot, to fly a plane, to feel free to fly the sky, to touch the sky. But that didn't happen. Simply, I live in Gaza, there is no airport. All borders are closed on every side. We live in one of the biggest prisons in the world. The only thing I can do is just to look up to the sky. On some days, we are lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make a fire on the front or on the roof of our homes. Sometimes we make food, too.My job in Gaza is to arrange everything for journalists who come to my homeland to tell the stories about what's going on in Gaza. Many mornings, I had to go to the border area to collect a journalist. If anything should happen to the journalist, or if the journalist decides to cover a story the government doesn't want us to cover, bad things could happen.Navigating through my country helping journalists, filmmakers, news crews, is my working life. I believe my success comes from building a relationship not only with journalists and the news crews, but also with the communities in the Gaza Strip. These communities who don't want their stories to be told, I never looked to them as stories or numbers. But like me, they are human beings.I have built up many relationships over 10 years. And guess what? This gives me the chance to get access to people, to stories that others can't. In some certain situations, I feel, as a woman, I have more power. Many male journalists in my society, they want to cover a story about drug addiction in my country. That problem started when the Gaza tunnel was being built. With the siege on Gaza, tunnels brought people all the basic needs like food, building material, other stuff we needed. But not anymore, because the Egyptian side flooded them up with water and they are not working anymore. Drugs were being smuggled, and many young people got addicted, too. title: A provocative way to finance the fight against climate change
transcript: Will we do whatever it takes to tackle climate change?I come at this question not as a green campaigner, in fact, I confess to be rather hopeless at recycling. I come at it as a professional observer of financial policy making and someone that wonders how history will judge us.One day, this ring that belonged to my grandfather will pass to my son, Charlie. And I wonder what his generation and perhaps the one that follows will make of the two lives this ring has worked.My grandfather was a coal miner. In his time, burning fossil fuels for energy and for allowing economies to develop was accepted. We know now that that is not the case because of the greenhouse gases that coal produces. But today, I fear it's the industry in which I work that will be judged more harshly because of its impact on the climate — more harshly than my grandfather's industry, even.I work, of course, in the banking industry, which will be remembered for its crisis in 2008 — a crisis that diverted the attention and finances of governments away from some really, really important promises, like promises made at the Copenhagen Climate Summit in 2009 to mobilize 100 billion dollars a year to help developing countries move away from burning fossil fuels and transition to using cleaner energy. That promise is already in jeopardy. And that's a real problem, because that transition to cleaner energy needs to happen sooner rather than later.Firstly, because greenhouse gases, once released, stay in the atmosphere for decades. And secondly, if a developing economy builds its power grid around fossil fuels today, it's going to be way more costly to change later on. So for the climate, history may judge that the banking crisis happened at just the wrong time. The story need not be this gloomy, though.Three years ago, I argued that governments could use the tools deployed to save the financial system to meet other global challenges. And these arguments are getting stronger, not weaker, with time. Let's take a brief reminder of what those tools looked like.When the financial crisis hit in 2008, the central banks of the US and UK began buying bonds issued by their own governments in a policy known as "quantitative easing." Depending on what happens to those bonds when they mature, this is money printing by another name. And boy, did they print. The US alone created four trillion dollars' worth of its own currency. This was not done in isolation. In a remarkable act of cooperation, the 188 countries that make up the International Monetary Fund, the IMF, agreed to issue 250 billion dollars' worth of their own currency — the Special Drawing Right — to boost reserves around the world.When the financial crisis moved to Europe, the European Central Bank President, Mario Draghi, promised "to do whatever it takes." And they did. The Bank of Japan repeated those words — that exact same commitment — to do "whatever it takes" to reflate their economy. In both cases, "whatever it takes" meant trillions of dollars more in money-printing policies that continue today. What this shows is that when faced with some global challenges, policy makers are able to act collectively, with urgency, and run the risks of unconventional policies like money printing.So, let's go back to that original question: Can we print money for climate finance? Three years ago, the idea of using money in this way was something of a taboo. Once you break down and dismantle the idea that money is a finite resource, governments can quickly get overwhelmed by demands from their people to print more and more money for other causes: education, health care, welfare — even defense.And there are some truly terrible historical examples of money printing — uncontrolled money printing — leading to hyperinflation. Think: Weimar Republic in 1930; Zimbabwe more recently, in 2008, when the prices of basic goods like bread are doubling every day. But all of this is moving the public debate forward, so much so, that money printing for the people is now discussed openly in the financial media, and even in some political manifestos.But it's important the debate doesn't stop here, with printing national currencies. Because climate change is a shared global problem, there are some really compelling reasons why we should be printing that international currency that's issued by the IMF, to fund it. The Special Drawing Right, or SDR, is the IMF's electronic unit of account that governments use to transfer funds amongst each other. Think of it as a peer-to-peer payment network, like Bitcoin, but for governments.And it's truly global. Each of the 188 members of the IMF hold SDR quotas as part of their foreign exchange reserves. These are national stores of wealth that countries keep to protect themselves against currency crises. And that global nature is why, at the height of the financial crisis in 2009, the IMF issued those extra 250 billion dollars — because it served as a collective global action that safeguarded countries large and small in one fell swoop.But here — here's the intriguing part. More than half of those extra SDRs that were printed in 2009 — 150 billion dollars' worth — went to developed market countries who, for the most part, have a modest need for these foreign exchange reserves, because they have flexible exchange rates. So those extra reserves that were printed in 2009, in the end, for developed market countries at least, weren't really needed. And they remain unused today.So here's an idea. As a first step, why don't we start spending those unused, those extra SDRs that were printed in 2009, to combat climate change?They could, for example, be used to buy bonds issued by the UN's Green Climate Fund. This was a fund created in 2009, following that climate agreement in Copenhagen. And it was designed to channel funds towards developing countries to meet their climate projects. It's been one of the most successful funds of its type, raising almost 10 billion dollars. But if we use those extra SDRs that were issued, it helps governments get back on track, to meet that promise of 100 billion dollars a year that was derailed by the financial crisis.It could also — it could also serve as a test case. If the inflationary consequences of using SDRs in this way are benign, it could be used to justify the additional, extra issuance of SDRs, say, every five years, again, with the commitment that developed-market countries would direct their share of the new reserves to the Green Climate Fund.Printing international money in this way has several advantages over printing national currencies. The first is it's really easy to argue that spending money to mitigate climate change benefits everyone. No one section of society benefits from the printing press over another. That problem of competing claims is mitigated. It's also fair to say that because it takes so many countries to agree to issue these extra SDRs, it's highly unlikely that money printing would get out of control. What you end up with is a collective, global action aimed — and it's controlled global action — aimed at a global good. And, as we've learned with the money-printing schemes, whatever concerns we have can be allayed by rules.So, for example, the issuance of these extra SDRs every five years could be capped, such that this international currency is never more than five percent of global foreign exchange reserves. That's important because it would allay well, let's say, the ridiculous concerns that the US might have that the SDR could ever challenge the dollar's dominant role in international finance. And in fact, I think the only thing that the SDR would likely steal from the dollar under this scheme is its nickname, the "greenback." Because even with that cap in place, the IMF could have followed up its issuance — its massive issuance of SDRs in 2009 — with a further 200 billion dollars of SDRs in 2014.So hypothetically, that would mean that developed countries could have contributed up to 300 billion dollars' worth of SDRs to the Green Climate Fund. That's 30 times what it has today. And you know, as spectacular as that sounds, it's only just beginning to look like "whatever it takes."And just to think what amazing things could be done with that money, consider this: in 2009, Norway promised one billion dollars of its reserves to Brazil if they followed through on their goals on deforestation. That program has since delivered a 70 percent reduction in deforestation in the past decade. That's saving 3.2 billion tons of carbon dioxide emissions, which is the equivalent of taking all American cars off the roads for three whole years. So what could we do with 300 other pay-for-performance climate projects like that, organized on a global scale? We could take cars off the roads for a generation.So, let's not quibble about whether we can afford to fund climate change. The real question is: Do we care enough about future generations to take the very same policy risks we took to save the financial system? After all, we could do it, we did do it and we are doing it today.We must, must, must do "whatever it takes."Thank you.(Applause)

the central banks of the US and UK

00:03:09.148 --> 00:03:12.583
began buying bonds issued
by their own governments

00:03:12.607 --> 00:03:14.906
in a policy known
as "quantitative easing."

00:03:15.343 --> 00:03:19.053
Depending on what happens
to those bonds when they mature,

00:03:19.077 --> 00:03:21.487
this is money printing by another name.

00:03:22.308 --> 00:03:24.212
And boy, did they print.

00:03:24.742 --> 00:03:29.310
The US alone created four trillion
dollars' worth of its own currency.

00:03:29.334 --> 00:03:31.423
This was not done in isolation.

00:03:31.447 --> 00:03:34.121
In a remarkable act of cooperation,

00:03:34.145 --> 00:03:38.718
the 188 countries that make up
the International Monetary Fund, the IMF,

00:03:38.742 --> 00:03:42.911
agreed to issue 250 billion
dollars' worth of their own currency --

00:03:42.935 --> 00:03:45.007
the Special Drawing Right --

00:03:45.031 --> 00:03:47.004
to boost reserves around the world.

00:03:47.670 --> 00:03:50.221
When the financial crisis moved to Europe,

00:03:51.584 --> 00:03:55.025
the European Central Bank
President, Mario Draghi,

00:03:55.049 --> 00:03:57.813
promised "to do whatever it takes."

00:03:59.474 --> 00:04:00.726
And they did.

00:04:01.654 --> 00:04:06.008
The Bank of Japan repeated those words --
that exact same commitment --

00:04:06.032 --> 00:04:10.143
to do "whatever it takes"
to reflate their economy.

00:04:11.442 --> 00:04:13.334
In both cases,

00:04:13.358 --> 00:04:17.597
"whatever it takes" meant
trillions of dollars more

00:04:17.621 --> 00:04:20.849
in money-printing policies
that continue today.

00:04:21.292 --> 00:04:23.080
What this shows

00:04:23.104 --> 00:04:26.870
is that when faced
with some global challenges,

00:04:28.020 --> 00:04:32.665
policy makers are able to act
collectively, with urgency,

00:04:32.689 --> 00:04:38.819
and run the risks of unconventional
policies like money printing.

00:04:39.467 --> 00:04:43.518
So, let's go back
to that original question:

00:04:45.469 --> 00:04:48.313
Can we print money for climate finance?

00:04:49.159 --> 00:04:50.889
Three years ago,

00:04:50.913 --> 00:04:54.648
the idea of using money in this way
was something of a taboo.

00:04:54.672 --> 00:04:57.848
Once you break down and dismantle the idea

00:04:57.872 --> 00:04:59.911
that money is a finite resource,

00:05:00.538 --> 00:05:05.021
governments can quickly get overwhelmed
by demands from their people

00:05:05.045 --> 00:05:08.271
to print more and more
money for other causes:

00:05:08.295 --> 00:05:10.295
education, health care, welfare --

00:05:10.319 --> 00:05:11.549
even defense.

00:05:12.342 --> 00:05:17.780
And there are some truly terrible
historical examples of money printing --

00:05:17.804 --> 00:05:20.127
uncontrolled money printing --

00:05:20.151 --> 00:05:21.896
leading to hyperinflation.

00:05:22.722 --> 00:05:26.308
Think: Weimar Republic in 1930;

00:05:26.332 --> 00:05:29.405
Zimbabwe more recently, in 2008,

00:05:29.429 --> 00:05:33.493
when the prices of basic goods
like bread are doubling every day.

00:05:34.850 --> 00:05:39.854
But all of this is moving
the public debate forward,

00:05:39.878 --> 00:05:45.206
so much so, that money printing
for the people is now discussed openly

00:05:45.230 --> 00:05:49.444
in the financial media, and even
in some political manifestos.

00:05:50.161 --> 00:05:52.700
But it's important the debate
doesn't stop here,

00:05:52.724 --> 00:05:54.907
with printing national currencies.

00:05:57.870 --> 00:06:01.809
Because climate change
is a shared global problem,

00:06:01.833 --> 00:06:04.903
there are some really compelling reasons

00:06:04.927 --> 00:06:08.356
why we should be printing
that international currency

00:06:08.380 --> 00:06:10.238
that's issued by the IMF,

00:06:10.262 --> 00:06:11.493
to fund it.

00:06:11.902 --> 00:06:15.107
The Special Drawing Right, or SDR,

00:06:15.131 --> 00:06:18.487
is the IMF's electronic unit of account

00:06:18.511 --> 00:06:23.063
that governments use to transfer
funds amongst each other.

00:06:23.891 --> 00:06:26.632
Think of it as a peer-to-peer
payment network,

00:06:26.656 --> 00:06:29.432
like Bitcoin, but for governments.

00:06:30.530 --> 00:06:32.178
And it's truly global.

00:06:32.963 --> 00:06:38.235
Each of the 188 members
of the IMF hold SDR quotas

00:06:38.259 --> 00:06:41.001
as part of their foreign
exchange reserves.

00:06:41.893 --> 00:06:44.181
These are national stores of wealth

00:06:44.205 --> 00:06:47.636
that countries keep to protect
themselves against currency crises.

00:06:48.722 --> 00:06:51.017
And that global nature is why,

00:06:51.041 --> 00:06:53.969
at the height of the financial
crisis in 2009,

00:06:55.368 --> 00:06:59.086
the IMF issued those extra
250 billion dollars --

00:06:59.110 --> 00:07:02.681
because it served
as a collective global action

00:07:02.705 --> 00:07:07.512
that safeguarded countries
large and small in one fell swoop.

00:07:09.001 --> 00:07:10.297
But here --

00:07:10.321 --> 00:07:11.987
here's the intriguing part.

00:07:13.041 --> 00:07:18.243
More than half of those extra SDRs
that were printed in 2009 --

00:07:18.267 --> 00:07:20.253
150 billion dollars' worth --

00:07:20.277 --> 00:07:24.592
went to developed market countries
who, for the most part,

00:07:24.616 --> 00:07:27.453
have a modest need
for these foreign exchange reserves,

00:07:27.477 --> 00:07:29.908
because they have flexible exchange rates.

00:07:30.385 --> 00:07:34.766
So those extra reserves
that were printed in 2009,

00:07:34.790 --> 00:07:38.261
in the end, for developed
market countries at least,

00:07:38.285 --> 00:07:39.911
weren't really needed.

00:07:40.466 --> 00:07:42.739
And they remain unused today.

00:07:43.600 --> 00:07:44.960
So here's an idea.

00:07:44.984 --> 00:07:46.356
As a first step,

00:07:47.004 --> 00:07:50.070
why don't we start
spending those unused,

00:07:50.094 --> 00:07:53.561
those extra SDRs
that were printed in 2009,

00:07:53.585 --> 00:07:55.132
to combat climate change?

00:07:55.906 --> 00:07:57.419
They could, for example,

00:07:57.443 --> 00:08:02.143
be used to buy bonds issued
by the UN's Green Climate Fund.

00:08:02.859 --> 00:08:05.755
This was a fund created in 2009,

00:08:05.779 --> 00:08:09.053
following that climate
agreement in Copenhagen.

00:08:09.864 --> 00:08:14.220
And it was designed to channel funds
towards developing countries

00:08:14.244 --> 00:08:16.311
to meet their climate projects.

00:08:16.335 --> 00:08:19.194
It's been one of the most
successful funds of its type,

00:08:19.218 --> 00:08:21.522
raising almost 10 billion dollars.

00:08:21.546 --> 00:08:24.984
But if we use those extra
SDRs that were issued,

00:08:25.008 --> 00:08:28.320
it helps governments get back on track,

00:08:28.344 --> 00:08:31.167
to meet that promise
of 100 billion dollars a year

00:08:31.191 --> 00:08:33.781
that was derailed by the financial crisis.

00:08:35.724 --> 00:08:37.632
It could also --

00:08:37.656 --> 00:08:40.302
it could also serve as a test case.

00:08:42.054 --> 00:08:47.413
If the inflationary consequences
of using SDRs in this way are benign,

00:08:48.432 --> 00:08:50.387
it could be used to justify

00:08:50.411 --> 00:08:55.145
the additional, extra issuance
of SDRs, say, every five years,

00:08:55.169 --> 00:08:57.564
again, with the commitment

00:08:57.588 --> 00:09:02.018
that developed-market countries
would direct their share

00:09:02.042 --> 00:09:03.503
of the new reserves

00:09:03.527 --> 00:09:05.320
to the Green Climate Fund.

00:09:07.034 --> 00:09:10.758
Printing international money
in this way has several advantages

00:09:10.782 --> 00:09:12.843
over printing national currencies.

00:09:13.458 --> 00:09:16.273
The first is it's really easy to argue

00:09:16.297 --> 00:09:20.714
that spending money to mitigate
climate change benefits everyone.

00:09:21.324 --> 00:09:25.183
No one section of society benefits
from the printing press over another.

00:09:25.207 --> 00:09:28.991
That problem of competing
claims is mitigated.

00:09:29.421 --> 00:09:30.761
It's also fair to say

00:09:30.785 --> 00:09:35.912
that because it takes so many countries
to agree to issue these extra SDRs,

00:09:35.936 --> 00:09:40.139
it's highly unlikely that money printing
would get out of control.

00:09:40.956 --> 00:09:45.983
What you end up with
is a collective, global action

00:09:46.839 --> 00:09:50.170
aimed -- and it's controlled
global action --

00:09:50.194 --> 00:09:52.783
aimed at a global good.

00:09:53.595 --> 00:09:54.803
And,

00:09:54.827 --> 00:09:57.394
as we've learned
with the money-printing schemes,

00:09:57.418 --> 00:10:00.250
whatever concerns we have
can be allayed by rules.

00:10:00.715 --> 00:10:02.597
So, for example,

00:10:02.621 --> 00:10:07.594
the issuance of these extra SDRs
every five years could be capped,

00:10:07.618 --> 00:10:13.213
such that this international currency
is never more than five percent

00:10:13.237 --> 00:10:15.199
of global foreign exchange reserves.

00:10:15.739 --> 00:10:17.764
That's important because it would allay

00:10:17.788 --> 00:10:21.684
well, let's say, the ridiculous
concerns that the US might have

00:10:21.708 --> 00:10:26.230
that the SDR could ever challenge
the dollar's dominant role

00:10:26.254 --> 00:10:27.850
in international finance.

00:10:28.172 --> 00:10:29.955
And in fact,

00:10:29.979 --> 00:10:33.373
I think the only thing that the SDR
would likely steal from the dollar

00:10:33.397 --> 00:10:34.866
under this scheme

00:10:34.890 --> 00:10:38.361
is its nickname, the "greenback."

00:10:38.385 --> 00:10:42.301
Because even with that cap in place,

00:10:42.325 --> 00:10:45.789
the IMF could have
followed up its issuance --

00:10:45.813 --> 00:10:48.861
its massive issuance of SDRs in 2009 --

00:10:48.885 --> 00:10:53.877
with a further 200 billion
dollars of SDRs in 2014.

00:10:54.674 --> 00:10:57.008
So hypothetically,

00:10:58.010 --> 00:11:01.128
that would mean that developed countries
could have contributed

00:11:01.152 --> 00:11:05.673
up to 300 billion dollars' worth of SDRs

00:11:05.697 --> 00:11:07.347
to the Green Climate Fund.

00:11:08.144 --> 00:11:11.604
That's 30 times what it has today.

00:11:11.628 --> 00:11:12.784
And you know,

00:11:12.808 --> 00:11:14.649
as spectacular as that sounds,

00:11:15.538 --> 00:11:19.728
it's only just beginning to look
like "whatever it takes."

00:11:21.087 --> 00:11:24.405
And just to think what amazing things
could be done with that money,

00:11:24.429 --> 00:11:25.640
consider this:

00:11:26.576 --> 00:11:28.204
in 2009,

00:11:28.228 --> 00:11:32.966
Norway promised one billion dollars
of its reserves to Brazil

00:11:32.990 --> 00:11:37.653
if they followed through
on their goals on deforestation.

00:11:38.551 --> 00:11:44.850
That program has since delivered
a 70 percent reduction in deforestation

00:11:44.874 --> 00:11:46.285
in the past decade.

00:11:46.884 --> 00:11:51.222
That's saving 3.2 billion tons
of carbon dioxide emissions,

00:11:51.246 --> 00:11:55.777
which is the equivalent of taking
all American cars off the roads

00:11:55.801 --> 00:11:58.087
for three whole years.

00:11:59.662 --> 00:12:00.964
So what could we do

00:12:00.988 --> 00:12:06.032
with 300 other pay-for-performance
climate projects like that,

00:12:06.056 --> 00:12:08.935
organized on a global scale?

00:12:09.895 --> 00:12:12.762
We could take cars off the roads
for a generation.

00:12:13.342 --> 00:12:14.492
So,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:20.241
let's not quibble about whether we can
afford to fund climate change.

00:12:20.835 --> 00:12:23.083
The real question is:

00:12:23.107 --> 00:12:26.504
Do we care enough about future generations

00:12:26.528 --> 00:12:31.569
to take the very same policy risks
we took to save the financial system?

00:12:32.181 --> 00:12:33.379
After all,

00:12:34.207 --> 00:12:35.426
we could do it,

00:12:36.242 --> 00:12:37.393
we did do it

00:12:37.417 --> 00:12:39.148
and we are doing it today.

00:12:39.766 --> 00:12:44.084
We must, must, must do
"whatever it takes."

00:12:45.384 --> 00:12:46.535
Thank you.

00:12:46.559 --> 00:12:50.925
(Applause)

title: How to read the genome and build a human being
transcript: For the next 16 minutes, I'm going to take you on a journey that is probably the biggest dream of humanity: to understand the code of life.So for me, everything started many, many years ago when I met the first 3D printer. The concept was fascinating. A 3D printer needs three elements: a bit of information, some raw material, some energy, and it can produce any object that was not there before.I was doing physics, I was coming back home and I realized that I actually always knew a 3D printer. And everyone does. It was my mom.(Laughter)My mom takes three elements: a bit of information, which is between my father and my mom in this case, raw elements and energy in the same media, that is food, and after several months, produces me. And I was not existent before.So apart from the shock of my mom discovering that she was a 3D printer, I immediately got mesmerized by that piece, the first one, the information. What amount of information does it take to build and assemble a human? Is it much? Is it little? How many thumb drives can you fill?Well, I was studying physics at the beginning and I took this approximation of a human as a gigantic Lego piece. So, imagine that the building blocks are little atoms and there is a hydrogen here, a carbon here, a nitrogen here. So in the first approximation, if I can list the number of atoms that compose a human being, I can build it. Now, you can run some numbers and that happens to be quite an astonishing number. So the number of atoms, the file that I will save in my thumb drive to assemble a little baby, will actually fill an entire Titanic of thumb drives — multiplied 2,000 times. This is the miracle of life. Every time you see from now on a pregnant lady, she's assembling the biggest amount of information that you will ever encounter. Forget big data, forget anything you heard of. This is the biggest amount of information that exists.(Applause)But nature, fortunately, is much smarter than a young physicist, and in four billion years, managed to pack this information in a small crystal we call DNA. We met it for the first time in 1950 when Rosalind Franklin, an amazing scientist, a woman, took a picture of it. But it took us more than 40 years to finally poke inside a human cell, take out this crystal, unroll it, and read it for the first time. The code comes out to be a fairly simple alphabet, four letters: A, T, C and G. And to build a human, you need three billion of them. Three billion. How many are three billion? It doesn't really make any sense as a number, right?So I was thinking how I could explain myself better about how big and enormous this code is. But there is — I mean, I'm going to have some help, and the best person to help me introduce the code is actually the first man to sequence it, Dr. Craig Venter. So welcome onstage, Dr. Craig Venter.(Applause)Not the man in the flesh, but for the first time in history, this is the genome of a specific human, printed page-by-page, letter-by-letter: 262,000 pages of information, 450 kilograms, shipped from the United States to Canada thanks to Bruno Bowden, Lulu.com, a start-up, did everything. It was an amazing feat.But this is the visual perception of what is the code of life. And now, for the first time, I can do something fun. I can actually poke inside it and read. So let me take an interesting book ... like this one. I have an annotation; it's a fairly big book. So just to let you see what is the code of life. Thousands and thousands and thousands and millions of letters. And they apparently make sense. Let's get to a specific part. Let me read it to you:(Laughter)"AAG, AAT, ATA."To you it sounds like mute letters, but this sequence gives the color of the eyes to Craig. I'll show you another part of the book. This is actually a little more complicated.Chromosome 14, book 132:(Laughter)As you might expect.(Laughter)"ATT, CTT, GATT."This human is lucky, because if you miss just two letters in this position — two letters of our three billion — he will be condemned to a terrible disease: cystic fibrosis. We have no cure for it, we don't know how to solve it, and it's just two letters of difference from what we are.A wonderful book, a mighty book, a mighty book that helped me understand and show you something quite remarkable. Every one of you — what makes me, me and you, you — is just about five million of these, half a book. For the rest, we are all absolutely identical. Five hundred pages is the miracle of life that you are. The rest, we all share it. So think about that again when we think that we are different. This is the amount that we share.So now that I have your attention, the next question is: How do I read it? How do I make sense out of it? Well, for however good you can be at assembling Swedish furniture, this instruction manual is nothing you can crack in your life.(Laughter)And so, in 2014, two famous TEDsters, Peter Diamandis and Craig Venter himself, decided to assemble a new company. Human Longevity was born, with one mission: trying everything we can try and learning everything we can learn from these books, with one target — making real the dream of personalized medicine, understanding what things should be done to have better health and what are the secrets in these books.An amazing team, 40 data scientists and many, many more people, a pleasure to work with. The concept is actually very simple. We're going to use a technology called machine learning. On one side, we have genomes — thousands of them. On the other side, we collected the biggest database of human beings: phenotypes, 3D scan, NMR — everything you can think of. Inside there, on these two opposite sides, there is the secret of translation. And in the middle, we build a machine. We build a machine and we train a machine — well, not exactly one machine, many, many machines — to try to understand and translate the genome in a phenotype. What are those letters, and what do they do? It's an approach that can be used for everything, but using it in genomics is particularly complicated. Little by little we grew and we wanted to build different challenges. We started from the beginning, from common traits. Common traits are comfortable because they are common, everyone has them.So we started to ask our questions: Can we predict height? Can we read the books and predict your height? Well, we actually can, with five centimeters of precision. BMI is fairly connected to your lifestyle, but we still can, we get in the ballpark, eight kilograms of precision. Can we predict eye color? Yeah, we can. Eighty percent accuracy. Can we predict skin color? Yeah we can, 80 percent accuracy. Can we predict age? We can, because apparently, the code changes during your life. It gets shorter, you lose pieces, it gets insertions. We read the signals, and we make a model.Now, an interesting challenge: Can we predict a human face? It's a little complicated, because a human face is scattered among millions of these letters. And a human face is not a very well-defined object. So, we had to build an entire tier of it to learn and teach a machine what a face is, and embed and compress it. And if you're comfortable with machine learning, you understand what the challenge is here.Now, after 15 years — 15 years after we read the first sequence — this October, we started to see some signals. And it was a very emotional moment. What you see here is a subject coming in our lab. This is a face for us. So we take the real face of a subject, we reduce the complexity, because not everything is in your face — lots of features and defects and asymmetries come from your life. We symmetrize the face, and we run our algorithm. The results that I show you right now, this is the prediction we have from the blood.(Applause)Wait a second. In these seconds, your eyes are watching, left and right, left and right, and your brain wants those pictures to be identical. So I ask you to do another exercise, to be honest. Please search for the differences, which are many. The biggest amount of signal comes from gender, then there is age, BMI, the ethnicity component of a human. And scaling up over that signal is much more complicated. But what you see here, even in the differences, lets you understand that we are in the right ballpark, that we are getting closer. And it's already giving you some emotions.This is another subject that comes in place, and this is a prediction. A little smaller face, we didn't get the complete cranial structure, but still, it's in the ballpark. This is a subject that comes in our lab, and this is the prediction. So these people have never been seen in the training of the machine. These are the so-called "held-out" set. But these are people that you will probably never believe. We're publishing everything in a scientific publication, you can read it.But since we are onstage, Chris challenged me. I probably exposed myself and tried to predict someone that you might recognize. So, in this vial of blood — and believe me, you have no idea what we had to do to have this blood now, here — in this vial of blood is the amount of biological information that we need to do a full genome sequence. We just need this amount. We ran this sequence, and I'm going to do it with you. And we start to layer up all the understanding we have. In the vial of blood, we predicted he's a male. And the subject is a male. We predict that he's a meter and 76 cm. The subject is a meter and 77 cm. So, we predicted that he's 76; the subject is 82. We predict his age, 38. The subject is 35. We predict his eye color. Too dark. We predict his skin color. We are almost there. That's his face.Now, the reveal moment: the subject is this person.(Laughter)And I did it intentionally. I am a very particular and peculiar ethnicity. Southern European, Italians — they never fit in models. And it's particular — that ethnicity is a complex corner case for our model. But there is another point. So, one of the things that we use a lot to recognize people will never be written in the genome. It's our free will, it's how I look. Not my haircut in this case, but my beard cut. So I'm going to show you, I'm going to, in this case, transfer it — and this is nothing more than Photoshop, no modeling — the beard on the subject. And immediately, we get much, much better in the feeling.So, why do we do this? We certainly don't do it for predicting height or taking a beautiful picture out of your blood. We do it because the same technology and the same approach, the machine learning of this code, is helping us to understand how we work, how your body works, how your body ages, how disease generates in your body, how your cancer grows and develops, how drugs work and if they work on your body.This is a huge challenge. This is a challenge that we share with thousands of other researchers around the world. It's called personalized medicine. It's the ability to move from a statistical approach where you're a dot in the ocean, to a personalized approach, where we read all these books and we get an understanding of exactly how you are. But it is a particularly complicated challenge, because of all these books, as of today, we just know probably two percent: four books of more than 175.And this is not the topic of my talk, because we will learn more. There are the best minds in the world on this topic. The prediction will get better, the model will get more precise. And the more we learn, the more we will be confronted with decisions that we never had to face before about life, about death, about parenting.So, we are touching the very inner detail on how life works. And it's a revolution that cannot be confined in the domain of science or technology. This must be a global conversation. We must start to think of the future we're building as a humanity. We need to interact with creatives, with artists, with philosophers, with politicians. Everyone is involved, because it's the future of our species. Without fear, but with the understanding that the decisions that we make in the next year will change the course of history forever.Thank you.(Applause)

00:00:40.636 --> 00:00:44.074
and I realized that I actually
always knew a 3D printer.

00:00:44.098 --> 00:00:45.434
And everyone does.

00:00:45.458 --> 00:00:46.616
It was my mom.

00:00:46.640 --> 00:00:47.641
(Laughter)

00:00:47.665 --> 00:00:50.079
My mom takes three elements:

00:00:50.103 --> 00:00:54.076
a bit of information, which is between
my father and my mom in this case,

00:00:54.100 --> 00:00:58.257
raw elements and energy
in the same media, that is food,

00:00:58.281 --> 00:01:00.789
and after several months, produces me.

00:01:00.813 --> 00:01:02.625
And I was not existent before.

00:01:02.649 --> 00:01:06.411
So apart from the shock of my mom
discovering that she was a 3D printer,

00:01:06.435 --> 00:01:11.173
I immediately got mesmerized
by that piece,

00:01:11.197 --> 00:01:12.914
the first one, the information.

00:01:12.938 --> 00:01:15.189
What amount of information does it take

00:01:15.213 --> 00:01:17.149
to build and assemble a human?

00:01:17.173 --> 00:01:18.747
Is it much? Is it little?

00:01:18.771 --> 00:01:20.951
How many thumb drives can you fill?

00:01:20.975 --> 00:01:23.599
Well, I was studying physics
at the beginning

00:01:23.623 --> 00:01:29.220
and I took this approximation of a human
as a gigantic Lego piece.

00:01:29.244 --> 00:01:33.029
So, imagine that the building
blocks are little atoms

00:01:33.053 --> 00:01:37.706
and there is a hydrogen here,
a carbon here, a nitrogen here.

00:01:37.730 --> 00:01:39.301
So in the first approximation,

00:01:39.325 --> 00:01:43.668
if I can list the number of atoms
that compose a human being,

00:01:43.692 --> 00:01:45.079
I can build it.

00:01:45.103 --> 00:01:47.132
Now, you can run some numbers

00:01:47.156 --> 00:01:50.433
and that happens to be
quite an astonishing number.

00:01:50.457 --> 00:01:53.214
So the number of atoms,

00:01:53.238 --> 00:01:57.993
the file that I will save in my thumb
drive to assemble a little baby,

00:01:58.017 --> 00:02:02.684
will actually fill an entire Titanic
of thumb drives --

00:02:02.708 --> 00:02:05.426
multiplied 2,000 times.

00:02:05.915 --> 00:02:09.316
This is the miracle of life.

00:02:09.340 --> 00:02:11.952
Every time you see from now on
a pregnant lady,

00:02:11.976 --> 00:02:14.832
she's assembling the biggest
amount of information

00:02:14.856 --> 00:02:16.412
that you will ever encounter.

00:02:16.436 --> 00:02:19.386
Forget big data, forget
anything you heard of.

00:02:19.410 --> 00:02:22.291
This is the biggest amount
of information that exists.

00:02:22.315 --> 00:02:26.148
(Applause)

00:02:26.172 --> 00:02:30.816
But nature, fortunately, is much smarter
than a young physicist,

00:02:30.840 --> 00:02:34.416
and in four billion years, managed
to pack this information

00:02:34.440 --> 00:02:37.145
in a small crystal we call DNA.

00:02:37.563 --> 00:02:41.875
We met it for the first time in 1950
when Rosalind Franklin,

00:02:41.899 --> 00:02:43.455
an amazing scientist, a woman,

00:02:43.479 --> 00:02:44.868
took a picture of it.

00:02:44.892 --> 00:02:50.080
But it took us more than 40 years
to finally poke inside a human cell,

00:02:50.104 --> 00:02:51.706
take out this crystal,

00:02:51.730 --> 00:02:54.810
unroll it, and read it for the first time.

00:02:55.573 --> 00:02:58.814
The code comes out to be
a fairly simple alphabet,

00:02:58.838 --> 00:03:02.610
four letters: A, T, C and G.

00:03:02.634 --> 00:03:06.124
And to build a human,
you need three billion of them.

00:03:06.891 --> 00:03:08.070
Three billion.

00:03:08.094 --> 00:03:09.673
How many are three billion?

00:03:09.697 --> 00:03:12.459
It doesn't really make
any sense as a number, right?

00:03:12.483 --> 00:03:16.568
So I was thinking how
I could explain myself better

00:03:16.592 --> 00:03:19.642
about how big and enormous this code is.

00:03:19.666 --> 00:03:22.720
But there is -- I mean,
I'm going to have some help,

00:03:22.744 --> 00:03:25.971
and the best person to help me
introduce the code

00:03:25.995 --> 00:03:29.517
is actually the first man
to sequence it, Dr. Craig Venter.

00:03:29.541 --> 00:03:32.931
So welcome onstage, Dr. Craig Venter.

00:03:32.955 --> 00:03:39.886
(Applause)

00:03:39.910 --> 00:03:42.166
Not the man in the flesh,

00:03:43.406 --> 00:03:45.751
but for the first time in history,

00:03:45.775 --> 00:03:49.237
this is the genome of a specific human,

00:03:49.261 --> 00:03:53.021
printed page-by-page, letter-by-letter:

00:03:53.045 --> 00:03:57.041
262,000 pages of information,

00:03:57.065 --> 00:04:01.429
450 kilograms, shipped
from the United States to Canada

00:04:01.453 --> 00:04:06.296
thanks to Bruno Bowden,
Lulu.com, a start-up, did everything.

00:04:06.320 --> 00:04:07.783
It was an amazing feat.

00:04:07.807 --> 00:04:12.104
But this is the visual perception
of what is the code of life.

00:04:12.128 --> 00:04:14.606
And now, for the first time,
I can do something fun.

00:04:14.630 --> 00:04:17.177
I can actually poke inside it and read.

00:04:17.201 --> 00:04:21.826
So let me take an interesting
book ... like this one.

00:04:25.035 --> 00:04:27.569
I have an annotation;
it's a fairly big book.

00:04:27.593 --> 00:04:31.320
So just to let you see
what is the code of life.

00:04:32.524 --> 00:04:35.915
Thousands and thousands and thousands

00:04:35.939 --> 00:04:38.609
and millions of letters.

00:04:38.633 --> 00:04:41.029
And they apparently make sense.

00:04:41.053 --> 00:04:42.810
Let's get to a specific part.

00:04:43.529 --> 00:04:44.891
Let me read it to you:

00:04:44.915 --> 00:04:45.936
(Laughter)

00:04:45.960 --> 00:04:49.966
"AAG, AAT, ATA."

00:04:50.923 --> 00:04:52.990
To you it sounds like mute letters,

00:04:53.014 --> 00:04:57.055
but this sequence gives
the color of the eyes to Craig.

00:04:57.591 --> 00:04:59.523
I'll show you another part of the book.

00:04:59.547 --> 00:05:01.641
This is actually a little
more complicated.

00:05:02.941 --> 00:05:05.588
Chromosome 14, book 132:

00:05:05.612 --> 00:05:07.702
(Laughter)

00:05:07.726 --> 00:05:09.003
As you might expect.

00:05:09.027 --> 00:05:12.493
(Laughter)

00:05:14.815 --> 00:05:19.322
"ATT, CTT, GATT."

00:05:20.287 --> 00:05:21.974
This human is lucky,

00:05:21.998 --> 00:05:26.515
because if you miss just
two letters in this position --

00:05:26.539 --> 00:05:28.416
two letters of our three billion --

00:05:28.440 --> 00:05:30.459
he will be condemned
to a terrible disease:

00:05:30.483 --> 00:05:31.923
cystic fibrosis.

00:05:31.947 --> 00:05:35.360
We have no cure for it,
we don't know how to solve it,

00:05:35.384 --> 00:05:39.139
and it's just two letters
of difference from what we are.

00:05:39.543 --> 00:05:42.248
A wonderful book, a mighty book,

00:05:43.073 --> 00:05:45.071
a mighty book that helped me understand

00:05:45.095 --> 00:05:47.848
and show you something quite remarkable.

00:05:48.438 --> 00:05:52.873
Every one of you -- what makes
me, me and you, you --

00:05:52.897 --> 00:05:55.851
is just about five million of these,

00:05:55.875 --> 00:05:57.103
half a book.

00:05:57.973 --> 00:05:59.636
For the rest,

00:05:59.660 --> 00:06:02.222
we are all absolutely identical.

00:06:02.966 --> 00:06:06.984
Five hundred pages
is the miracle of life that you are.

00:06:07.008 --> 00:06:09.539
The rest, we all share it.

00:06:09.563 --> 00:06:12.472
So think about that again
when we think that we are different.

00:06:12.496 --> 00:06:14.717
This is the amount that we share.

00:06:15.399 --> 00:06:18.828
So now that I have your attention,

00:06:18.852 --> 00:06:20.211
the next question is:

00:06:20.235 --> 00:06:21.386
How do I read it?

00:06:21.410 --> 00:06:22.919
How do I make sense out of it?

00:06:23.367 --> 00:06:27.607
Well, for however good you can be
at assembling Swedish furniture,

00:06:27.631 --> 00:06:31.194
this instruction manual
is nothing you can crack in your life.

00:06:31.218 --> 00:06:32.821
(Laughter)

00:06:32.845 --> 00:06:35.957
And so, in 2014, two famous TEDsters,

00:06:35.981 --> 00:06:38.521
Peter Diamandis and Craig Venter himself,

00:06:38.545 --> 00:06:40.472
decided to assemble a new company.

00:06:40.496 --> 00:06:41.908
Human Longevity was born,

00:06:41.932 --> 00:06:43.302
with one mission:

00:06:43.326 --> 00:06:45.187
trying everything we can try

00:06:45.211 --> 00:06:47.970
and learning everything
we can learn from these books,

00:06:47.994 --> 00:06:49.699
with one target --

00:06:50.820 --> 00:06:53.621
making real the dream
of personalized medicine,

00:06:53.645 --> 00:06:57.412
understanding what things
should be done to have better health

00:06:57.436 --> 00:06:59.719
and what are the secrets in these books.

00:07:00.287 --> 00:07:04.537
An amazing team, 40 data scientists
and many, many more people,

00:07:04.561 --> 00:07:05.911
a pleasure to work with.

00:07:05.935 --> 00:07:08.188
The concept is actually very simple.

00:07:08.212 --> 00:07:11.370
We're going to use a technology
called machine learning.

00:07:11.394 --> 00:07:15.933
On one side, we have genomes --
thousands of them.

00:07:15.957 --> 00:07:19.954
On the other side, we collected
the biggest database of human beings:

00:07:19.978 --> 00:07:24.274
phenotypes, 3D scan, NMR --
everything you can think of.

00:07:24.298 --> 00:07:27.197
Inside there, on these two opposite sides,

00:07:27.221 --> 00:07:29.663
there is the secret of translation.

00:07:29.687 --> 00:07:32.159
And in the middle, we build a machine.

00:07:32.759 --> 00:07:35.144
We build a machine
and we train a machine --

00:07:35.168 --> 00:07:38.378
well, not exactly one machine,
many, many machines --

00:07:38.402 --> 00:07:42.946
to try to understand and translate
the genome in a phenotype.

00:07:43.320 --> 00:07:46.660
What are those letters,
and what do they do?

00:07:46.684 --> 00:07:49.431
It's an approach that can
be used for everything,

00:07:49.455 --> 00:07:52.448
but using it in genomics
is particularly complicated.

00:07:52.472 --> 00:07:55.748
Little by little we grew and we wanted
to build different challenges.

00:07:55.772 --> 00:07:58.504
We started from the beginning,
from common traits.

00:07:58.528 --> 00:08:01.131
Common traits are comfortable
because they are common,

00:08:01.155 --> 00:08:02.339
everyone has them.

00:08:02.363 --> 00:08:04.857
So we started to ask our questions:

00:08:04.881 --> 00:08:06.261
Can we predict height?

00:08:06.943 --> 00:08:09.120
Can we read the books
and predict your height?

00:08:09.144 --> 00:08:10.295
Well, we actually can,

00:08:10.319 --> 00:08:12.112
with five centimeters of precision.

00:08:12.136 --> 00:08:15.271
BMI is fairly connected to your lifestyle,

00:08:15.295 --> 00:08:19.159
but we still can, we get in the ballpark,
eight kilograms of precision.

00:08:19.183 --> 00:08:20.414
Can we predict eye color?

00:08:20.438 --> 00:08:21.596
Yeah, we can.

00:08:21.620 --> 00:08:22.944
Eighty percent accuracy.

00:08:23.424 --> 00:08:25.282
Can we predict skin color?

00:08:25.306 --> 00:08:27.747
Yeah we can, 80 percent accuracy.

00:08:27.771 --> 00:08:29.111
Can we predict age?

00:08:30.079 --> 00:08:33.818
We can, because apparently,
the code changes during your life.

00:08:33.842 --> 00:08:37.124
It gets shorter, you lose pieces,
it gets insertions.

00:08:37.148 --> 00:08:39.703
We read the signals, and we make a model.

00:08:40.396 --> 00:08:41.871
Now, an interesting challenge:

00:08:41.895 --> 00:08:43.624
Can we predict a human face?

00:08:44.972 --> 00:08:46.250
It's a little complicated,

00:08:46.274 --> 00:08:49.465
because a human face is scattered
among millions of these letters.

00:08:49.489 --> 00:08:52.118
And a human face is not
a very well-defined object.

00:08:52.142 --> 00:08:54.193
So, we had to build an entire tier of it

00:08:54.217 --> 00:08:56.927
to learn and teach
a machine what a face is,

00:08:56.951 --> 00:08:58.988
and embed and compress it.

00:08:59.012 --> 00:09:01.260
And if you're comfortable
with machine learning,

00:09:01.284 --> 00:09:03.568
you understand what the challenge is here.

00:09:04.066 --> 00:09:10.057
Now, after 15 years -- 15 years after
we read the first sequence --

00:09:10.081 --> 00:09:12.983
this October, we started
to see some signals.

00:09:13.007 --> 00:09:15.462
And it was a very emotional moment.

00:09:15.486 --> 00:09:19.231
What you see here is a subject
coming in our lab.

00:09:19.577 --> 00:09:21.505
This is a face for us.

00:09:21.529 --> 00:09:25.160
So we take the real face of a subject,
we reduce the complexity,

00:09:25.184 --> 00:09:27.154
because not everything is in your face --

00:09:27.178 --> 00:09:30.964
lots of features and defects
and asymmetries come from your life.

00:09:30.988 --> 00:09:34.457
We symmetrize the face,
and we run our algorithm.

00:09:35.203 --> 00:09:37.101
The results that I show you right now,

00:09:37.125 --> 00:09:40.497
this is the prediction we have
from the blood.

00:09:41.554 --> 00:09:43.078
(Applause)

00:09:43.102 --> 00:09:44.537
Wait a second.

00:09:44.561 --> 00:09:49.253
In these seconds, your eyes are watching,
left and right, left and right,

00:09:49.277 --> 00:09:53.207
and your brain wants
those pictures to be identical.

00:09:53.231 --> 00:09:55.677
So I ask you to do
another exercise, to be honest.

00:09:55.701 --> 00:09:57.988
Please search for the differences,

00:09:58.012 --> 00:09:59.373
which are many.

00:09:59.397 --> 00:10:02.000
The biggest amount of signal
comes from gender,

00:10:02.024 --> 00:10:07.225
then there is age, BMI,
the ethnicity component of a human.

00:10:07.249 --> 00:10:10.960
And scaling up over that signal
is much more complicated.

00:10:10.984 --> 00:10:14.234
But what you see here,
even in the differences,

00:10:14.258 --> 00:10:17.853
lets you understand
that we are in the right ballpark,

00:10:17.877 --> 00:10:19.225
that we are getting closer.

00:10:19.249 --> 00:10:21.598
And it's already giving you some emotions.

00:10:21.622 --> 00:10:24.325
This is another subject
that comes in place,

00:10:24.349 --> 00:10:25.758
and this is a prediction.

00:10:25.782 --> 00:10:30.378
A little smaller face, we didn't get
the complete cranial structure,

00:10:30.402 --> 00:10:33.053
but still, it's in the ballpark.

00:10:33.592 --> 00:10:35.816
This is a subject that comes in our lab,

00:10:35.840 --> 00:10:37.283
and this is the prediction.

00:10:38.014 --> 00:10:42.690
So these people have never been seen
in the training of the machine.

00:10:42.714 --> 00:10:45.551
These are the so-called "held-out" set.

00:10:45.575 --> 00:10:49.315
But these are people that you will
probably never believe.

00:10:49.339 --> 00:10:52.015
We're publishing everything
in a scientific publication,

00:10:52.039 --> 00:10:53.190
you can read it.

00:10:53.214 --> 00:10:55.558
But since we are onstage,
Chris challenged me.

00:10:55.582 --> 00:10:59.208
I probably exposed myself
and tried to predict

00:10:59.232 --> 00:11:02.063
someone that you might recognize.

00:11:02.428 --> 00:11:06.853
So, in this vial of blood --
and believe me, you have no idea

00:11:06.877 --> 00:11:09.757
what we had to do to have
this blood now, here --

00:11:09.781 --> 00:11:13.682
in this vial of blood is the amount
of biological information

00:11:13.706 --> 00:11:15.983
that we need to do a full genome sequence.

00:11:16.007 --> 00:11:18.077
We just need this amount.

00:11:18.486 --> 00:11:21.691
We ran this sequence,
and I'm going to do it with you.

00:11:21.715 --> 00:11:25.694
And we start to layer up
all the understanding we have.

00:11:25.718 --> 00:11:29.068
In the vial of blood,
we predicted he's a male.

00:11:29.092 --> 00:11:30.456
And the subject is a male.

00:11:30.954 --> 00:11:33.392
We predict that he's a meter and 76 cm.

00:11:33.416 --> 00:11:35.808
The subject is a meter and 77 cm.

00:11:35.832 --> 00:11:39.942
So, we predicted that he's 76;
the subject is 82.

00:11:40.659 --> 00:11:43.291
We predict his age, 38.

00:11:43.315 --> 00:11:45.219
The subject is 35.

00:11:45.809 --> 00:11:47.933
We predict his eye color.

00:11:48.782 --> 00:11:49.993
Too dark.

00:11:50.017 --> 00:11:51.572
We predict his skin color.

00:11:51.984 --> 00:11:53.394
We are almost there.

00:11:53.857 --> 00:11:55.230
That's his face.

00:11:57.130 --> 00:12:00.399
Now, the reveal moment:

00:12:00.423 --> 00:12:02.193
the subject is this person.

00:12:02.217 --> 00:12:04.152
(Laughter)

00:12:04.176 --> 00:12:06.234
And I did it intentionally.

00:12:06.258 --> 00:12:09.950
I am a very particular
and peculiar ethnicity.

00:12:09.974 --> 00:12:12.924
Southern European, Italians --
they never fit in models.

00:12:12.948 --> 00:12:18.078
And it's particular -- that ethnicity
is a complex corner case for our model.

00:12:18.102 --> 00:12:19.611
But there is another point.

00:12:19.635 --> 00:12:23.112
So, one of the things that we use
a lot to recognize people

00:12:23.136 --> 00:12:24.858
will never be written in the genome.

00:12:24.882 --> 00:12:27.199
It's our free will, it's how I look.

00:12:27.223 --> 00:12:30.452
Not my haircut in this case,
but my beard cut.

00:12:30.476 --> 00:12:34.029
So I'm going to show you, I'm going to,
in this case, transfer it --

00:12:34.053 --> 00:12:36.818
and this is nothing more
than Photoshop, no modeling --

00:12:36.842 --> 00:12:38.555
the beard on the subject.

00:12:38.579 --> 00:12:42.051
And immediately, we get
much, much better in the feeling.

00:12:42.913 --> 00:12:45.622
So, why do we do this?

00:12:47.896 --> 00:12:53.036
We certainly don't do it
for predicting height

00:12:53.060 --> 00:12:55.432
or taking a beautiful picture
out of your blood.

00:12:56.348 --> 00:13:00.366
We do it because the same technology
and the same approach,

00:13:00.390 --> 00:13:02.910
the machine learning of this code,

00:13:02.934 --> 00:13:06.071
is helping us to understand how we work,

00:13:06.095 --> 00:13:07.581
how your body works,

00:13:07.605 --> 00:13:09.270
how your body ages,

00:13:09.294 --> 00:13:12.063
how disease generates in your body,

00:13:12.087 --> 00:13:15.059
how your cancer grows and develops,

00:13:15.083 --> 00:13:16.866
how drugs work

00:13:16.890 --> 00:13:19.204
and if they work on your body.

00:13:19.671 --> 00:13:21.338
This is a huge challenge.

00:13:21.852 --> 00:13:23.490
This is a challenge that we share

00:13:23.514 --> 00:13:26.093
with thousands of other
researchers around the world.

00:13:26.117 --> 00:13:28.339
It's called personalized medicine.

00:13:29.083 --> 00:13:32.543
It's the ability to move
from a statistical approach

00:13:32.567 --> 00:13:34.599
where you're a dot in the ocean,

00:13:34.623 --> 00:13:36.436
to a personalized approach,

00:13:36.460 --> 00:13:38.645
where we read all these books

00:13:38.669 --> 00:13:41.533
and we get an understanding
of exactly how you are.

00:13:42.218 --> 00:13:45.580
But it is a particularly
complicated challenge,

00:13:45.604 --> 00:13:49.602
because of all these books, as of today,

00:13:49.626 --> 00:13:52.268
we just know probably two percent:

00:13:52.985 --> 00:13:56.638
four books of more than 175.

00:13:57.979 --> 00:14:01.185
And this is not the topic of my talk,

00:14:02.103 --> 00:14:04.701
because we will learn more.

00:14:05.336 --> 00:14:08.005
There are the best minds
in the world on this topic.

00:14:09.006 --> 00:14:10.840
The prediction will get better,

00:14:10.864 --> 00:14:13.117
the model will get more precise.

00:14:13.141 --> 00:14:14.999
And the more we learn,

00:14:15.023 --> 00:14:19.853
the more we will
be confronted with decisions

00:14:19.877 --> 00:14:22.898
that we never had to face before

00:14:22.922 --> 00:14:24.357
about life,

00:14:24.381 --> 00:14:26.055
about death,

about parenting.

in the domain of science or technology.

with politicians.

Everyone is involved,
