"Say, did you hear about Jimmy?
He had a stroke."

00:03:53.570 --> 00:03:57.825
"Did you hear about Eddie?
He died last week.

00:03:57.849 --> 00:03:59.537
Massive heart attack.

00:03:59.561 --> 00:04:00.753
He was 50."

00:04:02.542 --> 00:04:06.461
More black men die from high blood
pressure than from anything else,

00:04:06.485 --> 00:04:11.380
even though decades of medical wisdom
and science have demonstrated

00:04:11.404 --> 00:04:14.548
that death from high blood pressure
can be prevented

00:04:14.572 --> 00:04:17.927
with timely diagnosis
and appropriate treatment.

00:04:19.090 --> 00:04:22.943
So why is high blood pressure
so differentially deadly for black men?

00:04:24.415 --> 00:04:28.325
Because too often, high blood pressure
is either untreated

00:04:28.349 --> 00:04:30.990
or under-treated in black men,

00:04:31.014 --> 00:04:35.152
in part because of our lower engagement
with the primary healthcare system.

00:04:36.516 --> 00:04:40.297
Black men, in particular
those with high blood pressure,

00:04:40.321 --> 00:04:42.425
are less likely to have
a primary care doctor

00:04:42.449 --> 00:04:43.599
than other groups.

00:04:44.196 --> 00:04:45.368
But why?

00:04:46.339 --> 00:04:49.439
Some of our earliest research
on black men's health

00:04:49.463 --> 00:04:54.077
revealed that for many, the doctor's
office is associated with fear,

00:04:55.048 --> 00:04:56.973
mistrust,

00:04:56.997 --> 00:04:59.018
disrespect,

00:04:59.042 --> 00:05:01.224
and unnecessary unpleasantness.

00:05:03.032 --> 00:05:07.285
The doctor's office is only a place
that you go when you don't feel well.

00:05:07.860 --> 00:05:11.150
And when you do go,
you might wait for hours

00:05:11.174 --> 00:05:13.523
only to get the run-around

00:05:13.547 --> 00:05:18.118
and to be evaluated by
a stoic figure in a white coat

00:05:18.142 --> 00:05:20.769
who only has 10 minutes to give you

00:05:20.793 --> 00:05:23.658
and who doesn't value the talk.

00:05:25.173 --> 00:05:28.641
So it's no wonder that some men
don't want to be bothered

00:05:28.665 --> 00:05:31.961
and skip going to the doctor altogether,

00:05:31.985 --> 00:05:34.117
especially if they feel fine.

00:05:35.360 --> 00:05:37.299
But herein lies the problem.

00:05:38.286 --> 00:05:40.407
You can feel just fine

00:05:40.431 --> 00:05:44.254
while high blood pressure ravages
your most vital organs.

00:05:46.792 --> 00:05:49.459
This is Denny Moe,

00:05:49.483 --> 00:05:53.141
owner of Denny Moe's
Superstar Barbershop in Harlem.

00:05:53.696 --> 00:05:57.395
I've been lucky enough to have Denny
as my barber for the last eight years.

00:05:58.498 --> 00:06:00.179
He said to me once,

00:06:00.203 --> 00:06:02.252
"Hey Doc, you know,

00:06:02.276 --> 00:06:06.672
lots of black men trust their barbers
more than they trust their doctors."

00:06:07.837 --> 00:06:09.895
This was stunning to me,

00:06:09.919 --> 00:06:11.084
at first,

00:06:11.727 --> 00:06:13.647
but not so much when you think about it.

00:06:14.829 --> 00:06:17.545
Black men have been with their
current barbers

00:06:17.569 --> 00:06:19.570
on average as long
as I've been with Denny,

00:06:19.594 --> 00:06:20.822
about eight years.

00:06:21.632 --> 00:06:25.783
And black men see their barbers
about every two weeks.

00:06:26.799 --> 00:06:31.402
Not only do you trust your barber
with your look and with your style,

00:06:31.426 --> 00:06:35.332
but you also trust him with your secrets
and sometimes your life.

00:06:37.149 --> 00:06:40.777
Denny, like many barbers,
is more than just an artist,

00:06:40.801 --> 00:06:43.007
a businessman and confidant.

00:06:43.864 --> 00:06:48.832
He's a leader and a passionate advocate
for the well-being of his community.

00:06:50.927 --> 00:06:53.905
The very first time I walked
into Denny Moe's shop,

00:06:53.929 --> 00:06:55.411
he wasn't just cutting hair.

00:06:56.403 --> 00:07:00.156
He was also orchestrating
a voter registration drive

00:07:00.180 --> 00:07:04.077
to give a voice to his customers
and his community.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.069
With this kind of activism,

00:07:09.164 --> 00:07:13.401
and community investment
that typifies the black barbershop,

00:07:13.425 --> 00:07:16.973
of course the barbershop
is a perfect place

00:07:16.997 --> 00:07:20.910
to talk about high blood pressure and
other health concerns in the community.

00:07:21.902 --> 00:07:26.052
First, the barbershop is not
a medical setting,

00:07:26.076 --> 00:07:29.321
and so it doesn't have
all the negative psychological baggage

00:07:29.345 --> 00:07:30.735
that comes along with that.

00:07:31.386 --> 00:07:33.441
When you're in a barbershop,

00:07:33.465 --> 00:07:36.894
you're in your territory,
and you're among friends

00:07:36.918 --> 00:07:39.180
who share your history,

00:07:39.204 --> 00:07:42.617
your struggle and your health risks.

00:07:43.266 --> 00:07:47.327
Second, because the barbershop
is a place of connection,

00:07:47.351 --> 00:07:49.853
loyalty and trust,

00:07:49.877 --> 00:07:53.386
it's a place where you're more open
to have a conversation about health

00:07:53.410 --> 00:07:55.433
and especially about high blood pressure.

00:07:56.123 --> 00:07:57.593
After all,

00:07:57.617 --> 00:08:01.831
conversations about high blood pressure
have all the elements of great shop talk:

00:08:02.975 --> 00:08:05.576
stress and high blood pressure,

00:08:05.600 --> 00:08:08.130
food and high blood pressure,

00:08:08.154 --> 00:08:10.791
relationships and high blood pressure,

00:08:10.815 --> 00:08:14.750
and yes, what it's like
to be a black man in America

00:08:14.774 --> 00:08:16.004
and high blood pressure.

00:08:17.804 --> 00:08:20.876
But you can do more than just talk
about high blood pressure

00:08:20.900 --> 00:08:22.139
in the barbershop.

00:08:22.633 --> 00:08:24.742
You can concretely take action.

00:08:25.873 --> 00:08:30.631
Here we have an opportunity to partner
with the Denny Moe's of the world

00:08:30.655 --> 00:08:34.933
and empower communities
to address the health inequities

00:08:34.957 --> 00:08:36.262
that uniquely affect it.

00:08:37.322 --> 00:08:40.782
When high blood pressure screening
expanded from clinics and hospitals

00:08:40.806 --> 00:08:43.933
to communities in the 1960s and '70s,

00:08:43.957 --> 00:08:47.314
black physicians like
Dr. Eli Saunders in Baltimore

00:08:47.338 --> 00:08:49.823
and Dr. Keith Ferdinand in New Orleans

00:08:49.847 --> 00:08:53.922
were at the forefront of bringing
health promotion to community hubs

00:08:53.946 --> 00:08:55.434
in urban black neighborhoods.

00:08:56.367 --> 00:09:00.507
These pioneers paved the way
for my professional journey

00:09:00.531 --> 00:09:02.514
with barbershops and health,

00:09:02.538 --> 00:09:05.823
which began in Chicago in medical school.

00:09:07.330 --> 00:09:10.812
The very first research project
that I worked on as a medical student

00:09:10.836 --> 00:09:13.336
was to help design
healthcare interventions

00:09:13.360 --> 00:09:15.633
that would appeal to black men.

00:09:16.802 --> 00:09:19.685
We conducted about a dozen focus groups

00:09:19.709 --> 00:09:22.984
with a broad cross-section of black men,

00:09:23.008 --> 00:09:25.122
and we learned that for them,

00:09:25.146 --> 00:09:29.529
being healthy was as much about
being perceived as healthy

00:09:29.553 --> 00:09:31.801
as it was about feeling healthy,

00:09:31.825 --> 00:09:36.078
and that feeling good
went hand in hand with looking good.

00:09:37.967 --> 00:09:41.816
This work led to the development
of Project Brotherhood,

00:09:41.840 --> 00:09:44.745
a community clinic founded
by Dr. Eric Whitaker

00:09:44.769 --> 00:09:47.562
that provided tailored
healthcare to black men.

00:09:48.673 --> 00:09:50.681
Part of this tailored care

00:09:50.705 --> 00:09:53.506
involved having a barber on the premises

00:09:53.530 --> 00:09:57.133
to reward the men who came
for needed healthcare

00:09:57.157 --> 00:09:59.122
with a free haircut,

00:09:59.146 --> 00:10:03.092
to let the men know that we, too,
valued how they looked

00:10:03.116 --> 00:10:04.986
as well as how they felt,

00:10:05.010 --> 00:10:09.192
and that what was important to them
was also important to us.

00:10:10.278 --> 00:10:13.506
But while there's only one
Project Brotherhood,

00:10:13.530 --> 00:10:16.851
there are thousands of black barbershops

00:10:16.875 --> 00:10:21.351
where the intersection of health
and haircuts can be cultivated.

00:10:22.740 --> 00:10:26.112
The next stop on my journey
was Dallas, Texas,

00:10:26.136 --> 00:10:29.153
where we learned that barbers
were not only willing

00:10:29.177 --> 00:10:33.216
but fully able to roll up
their sleeves and participate

00:10:33.240 --> 00:10:38.764
in delivering needed health services
to improve the health of their customers

00:10:38.788 --> 00:10:40.042
and their community.

00:10:40.874 --> 00:10:44.347
We teamed up with an amazing
cadre of black barbers

00:10:44.371 --> 00:10:46.515
and taught them how
to measure blood pressure

00:10:46.539 --> 00:10:48.320
and how to counsel their customers

00:10:48.344 --> 00:10:50.171
and refer them to doctors

00:10:50.195 --> 00:10:52.039
to help manage high blood pressure.

00:10:52.935 --> 00:10:55.197
The barbers were not only willing to do it

00:10:55.221 --> 00:10:56.689
but they were damn good at it.

00:10:57.752 --> 00:10:59.706
Over a three-year period,

00:10:59.730 --> 00:11:02.674
the barbers measured
thousands of blood pressures

00:11:02.698 --> 00:11:07.499
resulting in hundreds of black men
being referred to doctors

00:11:07.523 --> 00:11:10.603
for medical care
of their high blood pressure.

00:11:11.190 --> 00:11:14.102
These barber-doctor partnerships

00:11:14.126 --> 00:11:18.610
resulted in a 20 percent increase
in the number of men

00:11:18.634 --> 00:11:21.427
who were able to achieve
target blood pressure levels

00:11:21.451 --> 00:11:23.911
and a three-point drop, on average,

00:11:23.935 --> 00:11:25.935
in the blood pressure of each participant.

00:11:26.379 --> 00:11:29.347
If we were to extrapolate
that three point drop

00:11:29.371 --> 00:11:32.776
to every single black man
with high blood pressure in America,

00:11:32.800 --> 00:11:39.047
we would prevent 800 heart attacks,
500 strokes and 900 deaths

00:11:39.071 --> 00:11:40.929
from high blood pressure

00:11:40.953 --> 00:11:42.855
in just one year.

00:11:44.760 --> 00:11:48.982
And our experience with barbershops
has been no different in New York City,

00:11:49.006 --> 00:11:50.855
where my journey has currently led me.

00:11:51.680 --> 00:11:55.624
With an incredible team
of diverse research assistants,

00:11:55.648 --> 00:11:58.774
community health workers and volunteers,

00:11:58.798 --> 00:12:02.199
we've been able to partner
with over 200 barbershops

00:12:02.223 --> 00:12:04.707
and other trusted community venues

00:12:04.731 --> 00:12:07.992
to reach over 7,000 older black men.

00:12:08.522 --> 00:12:11.435
And we've offered high blood pressure
screening and counseling

00:12:11.459 --> 00:12:12.895
to each and every one of them.

00:12:13.768 --> 00:12:15.453
Thanks to Denny Moe

00:12:15.477 --> 00:12:19.080
and the myriad other barbers
and community leaders

00:12:19.104 --> 00:12:24.048
who shared the vision of opportunity
and empowerment

00:12:24.072 --> 00:12:26.778
to make a difference in their communities,

00:12:26.802 --> 00:12:29.557
we've been able to not only
lower blood pressure

00:12:29.581 --> 00:12:31.041
in our participants,

00:12:31.065 --> 00:12:34.777
but we've also been able to impact
other health indicators.

00:12:38.258 --> 00:12:39.580
So what do you see?

00:12:41.490 --> 00:12:43.160
What is your barbershop?

00:12:45.652 --> 00:12:48.501
Where is that place for you

00:12:49.532 --> 00:12:52.461
where people who are affected
by a unique problem

00:12:53.081 --> 00:12:54.866
can meet a unique solution?

00:12:57.525 --> 00:13:01.640
When you find that place,
see the opportunity.

00:13:02.561 --> 00:13:03.712
Thank you.

00:13:03.736 --> 00:13:07.180
(Applause)

title: My journey from Marine to actor
transcript: I was a Marine with 1/1 Weapons Company, 81's platoon, out in Camp Pendleton, California. Oorah!Audience: Oorah!(Laughter)I joined a few months after September 11, feeling like I think most people in the country did at the time, filled with a sense of patriotism and retribution and the desire to do something — that, coupled with that fact that I wasn't doing anything. I was 17, just graduated from high school that past summer, living in the back room of my parents' house paying rent, in the small town I was raised in in Northern Indiana, called Mishawaka. I can spell that later for people who are interested —(Laughter)Mishawaka is many good things but cultural hub of the world it is not, so my only exposure to theater and film was limited to the plays I did in high school and Blockbuster Video, may she rest in peace.(Laughter)I was serious enough about acting that I auditioned for Juilliard when I was a senior in high school, didn't get in, determined college wasn't for me and applied nowhere else, which was a genius move. I also did that Hail Mary LA acting odyssey that I always heard stories about, of actors moving to LA with, like, seven dollars and finding work and successful careers. I got as far as Amarillo, Texas, before my car broke down. I spent all my money repairing it, finally made it to Santa Monica — not even LA — stayed for 48 hours wandering the beach, basically, got in my car, drove home, thus ending my acting career, so —(Laughter)Seventeen, Mishawaka ... parents' house, paying rent, selling vacuums ... telemarketing, cutting grass at the local 4-H fairgrounds. This was my world going into September, 2001.So after the 11th, and feeling an overwhelming sense of duty, and just being pissed off in general — at myself, my parents, the government; not having confidence, not having a respectable job, my shitty mini-fridge that I just drove to California and back — I joined the Marine Corps and loved it. I loved being a Marine. It's one of the things I'm most proud of having done in my life. Firing weapons was cool, driving and detonating expensive things was great. But I found I loved the Marine Corps the most for the thing I was looking for the least when I joined, which was the people: these weird dudes — a motley crew of characters from a cross section of the United States — that on the surface I had nothing in common with. And over time, all the political and personal bravado that led me to the military dissolved, and for me, the Marine Corps became synonymous with my friends.And then, a few years into my service and months away from deploying to Iraq, I dislocated my sternum in a mountain-biking accident, and had to be medically separated. Those never in the military may find this hard to understand, but being told I wasn't getting deployed to Iraq or Afghanistan was very devastating for me. I have a very clear image of leaving the base hospital on a stretcher and my entire platoon is waiting outside to see if I was OK.And then, suddenly, I was a civilian again. I knew I wanted to give acting another shot, because — again, this is me — I thought all civilian problems are small compared to the military. I mean, what can you really bitch about now, you know? "It's hot. Someone should turn on the air conditioner." "This coffee line is too long." I was a Marine, I knew how to survive. I'd go to New York and become an actor. If things didn't work out, I'd live in Central Park and dumpster-dive behind Panera Bread.(Laughter)I re-auditioned for Juilliard and this time I was lucky, I got in. But I was surprised by how complex the transition was from military to civilian. And I was relatively healthy; I can't imagine going through that process on top of a mental or physical injury. But regardless, it was difficult. In part, because I was in acting school — I couldn't justify going to voice and speech class, throwing imaginary balls of energy at the back of the room, doing acting exercises where I gave birth to myself —(Laughter)while my friends were serving without me overseas. But also, because I didn't know how to apply the things I learned in the military to a civilian context. I mean that both practically and emotionally. Practically, I had to get a job. And I was an Infantry Marine, where you're shooting machine guns and firing mortars. There's not a lot of places you can put those skills in the civilian world.(Laughter)Emotionally, I struggled to find meaning. In the military, everything has meaning. Everything you do is either steeped in tradition or has a practical purpose. You can't smoke in the field because you don't want to give away your position. You don't touch your face — you have to maintain a personal level of health and hygiene. You face this way when "Colors" plays, out of respect for people who went before you. Walk this way, talk this way because of this. Your uniform is maintained to the inch. How diligently you followed those rules spoke volumes about the kind of Marine you were. Your rank said something about your history and the respect you had earned.In the civilian world there's no rank. Here you're just another body, and I felt like I constantly had to prove my worth all over again. And the respect civilians were giving me while I was in uniform didn't exist when I was out of it. There didn't seem to be a ... a sense of community, whereas in the military, I felt this sense of community. How often in the civilian world are you put in a life-or-death situation with your closest friends and they constantly demonstrate that they're not going to abandon you? And meanwhile, at acting school ...(Laughter)I was really, for the first time, discovering playwrights and characters and plays that had nothing to do with the military, but were somehow describing my military experience in a way that before to me was indescribable. And I felt myself becoming less aggressive as I was able to put words to feelings for the first time and realizing what a valuable tool that was.And when I was reflecting on my time in the military, I wasn't first thinking on the stereotypical drills and discipline and pain of it; but rather, the small, intimate human moments, moments of great feeling: friends going AWOL because they missed their families, friends getting divorced, grieving together, celebrating together, all within the backdrop of the military. I saw my friends battling these circumstances, and I watched the anxiety it produced in them and me, not being able to express our feelings about it.The military and theater communities are actually very similar. You have a group of people trying to accomplish a mission greater than themselves; it's not about you. You have a role, you have to know your role within that team. Every team has a leader or director; sometimes they're smart, sometimes they're not. You're forced to be intimate with complete strangers in a short amount of time; the self-discipline, the self-maintenance. I thought, how great would it be to create a space that combined these two seemingly dissimilar communities, that brought entertainment to a group of people that, considering their occupation, could handle something a bit more thought-provoking than the typical mandatory-fun events that I remember being "volun-told" to go to in the military —(Laughter)all well-intended but slightly offensive events, like "Win a Date with a San Diego Chargers Cheerleader," where you answer a question about pop culture, and if you get it right you win a date, which was a chaperoned walk around the parade deck with this already married, pregnant cheerleader —(Laughter)Nothing against cheerleaders, I love cheerleaders. The point is more, how great would it be to have theater presented through characters that were accessible without being condescending. So we started this nonprofit called Arts in the Armed Forces, where we tried to do that, tried to join these two seemingly dissimilar communities. We pick a play or select monologues from contemporary American plays that are diverse in age and race like a military audience is, grab a group of incredible theater-trained actors, arm them with incredible material, keep production value as minimal as possible — no sets, no costumes, no lights, just reading it — to throw all the emphasis on the language and to show that theater can be created at any setting.It's a powerful thing, getting in a room with complete strangers and reminding ourselves of our humanity, and that self-expression is just as valuable a tool as a rifle on your shoulder. And for an organization like the military, that prides itself on having acronyms for acronyms, you can get lost in the sauce when it comes to explaining a collective experience. And I can think of no better community to arm with a new means of self-expression than those protecting our country.We've gone all over the United States and the world, from Walter Reed in Bethesda, Maryland, to Camp Pendleton, to Camp Arifjan in Kuwait, to USAG Bavaria, on- and off-Broadway theaters in New York. And for the performing artists we bring, it's a window into a culture they otherwise would not have had exposure to. And for the military, it's the exact same.And in doing this for the past six years, I'm always reminded that acting is many things. It's a craft, it's a political act, it's a business, it's — whatever adjective is most applicable to you. But it's also a service. I didn't get to finish mine, so whenever I get to be of service to this ultimate service industry, the military, for me, again — there's not many things better than that.Thank you.(Applause)We're going to be doing a piece from Marco Ramirez, called "I am not Batman." An incredible actor and good friend of mine, Jesse Perez, is going to be reading, and Matt Johnson, who I just met a couple hours ago. They're doing it together for the first time, so we'll see how it goes.Jesse Perez and Matt Johnson.(Applause)Jesse Perez: It's the middle of the night and the sky is glowing like mad, radioactive red. And if you squint, you can maybe see the moon through a thick layer of cigarette smoke and airplane exhaust that covers the whole city, like a mosquito net that won't let the angels in.(Drum beat)And if you look up high enough, you can see me standing on the edge of an 87-story building. And up there, a place for gargoyles and broken clock towers that have stayed still and dead for maybe like 100 years, up there is me.(Beat)And I'm frickin' Batman.(Beat)And I gots Batmobiles and batarangs and frickin' bat caves, like, for real. And all it takes is a broom closet or a back room or a fire escape, and Danny's hand-me-down jeans are gone. And my navy blue polo shirt, the one that looks kinda good on me but has that hole on it near the butt from when it got snagged on the chain-link fence behind Arturo's but it isn't even a big deal because I tuck that part in and it's, like, all good. That blue polo shirt — it's gone, too! And I get like, like ... transformational.(Beat)And nobody pulls out a belt and whips Batman for talkin' back.(Beat)Or for not talkin' back.And nobody calls Batman simple or stupid or skinny. And nobody fires Batman's brother from the Eastern Taxi Company 'cause they was making cutbacks, neither. 'Cause they got nothing but respect. And not like afraid-respect, just, like, respect-respect.(Laughter)'Cause nobody's afraid of you. 'Cause Batman doesn't mean nobody no harm.(Beat)Ever. (Double beat)'Cause all Batman really wants to do is save people and maybe pay abuela's bills one day and die happy. And maybe get, like, mad-famous for real.(Laughter)Oh — and kill the Joker.(Drum roll)Tonight, like most nights, I'm all alone. And I'm watchin' and I'm waitin' like a eagle or like a — no, yeah, like a eagle.(Laughter)And my cape is flapping in the wind cause it's frickin' long and my pointy ears are on, and that mask that covers like half my face is on, too, and I got, like, bulletproof stuff all in my chest so no one can hurt me. And nobody — nobody! — is gonna come between Batman ... and justice.(Drums) (Laughter)From where I am, I can hear everything.(Silence)Somewhere in the city, there's a old lady picking Styrofoam leftovers up out of a trash can and she's putting a piece of sesame chicken someone spit out into her own mouth. And somewhere there's a doctor with a wack haircut in a black lab coat trying to find a cure for the diseases that are gonna make us all extinct for real one day. And somewhere there's a man, a man in a janitor's uniform, stumbling home drunk and dizzy after spending half his paycheck on 40-ounce bottles of twist-off beer, and the other half on a four-hour visit to some lady's house on a street where the lights have all been shot out by people who'd rather do what they do in this city in the dark. And half a block away from janitor man, there's a group of good-for-nothings who don't know no better, waiting for janitor man with rusted bicycle chains and imitation Louisville Sluggers, and if they don't find a cent on him, which they won't, they'll just pound at him till the muscles in their arms start burning, till there's no more teeth to crack out.But they don't count on me. They don't count on no Dark Knight, with a stomach full of grocery-store brand macaroni and cheese and cut-up Vienna sausages.(Laughter)'Cause they'd rather believe I don't exist.And from 87 stories up, I can hear one of the good-for-nothings say, "Gimme the cash!" — real fast like that, just, "Gimme me the fuckin' cash!" And I see janitor man mumble something in drunk language and turn pale, and from 87 stories up, I can hear his stomach trying to hurl its way out his Dickies.So I swoop down, like, mad-fast and I'm like darkness, I'm like, "Swoosh!" And I throw a batarang at the one naked lightbulb.(Cymbal)And they're all like, "Whoa, muthafucker! Who just turned out the lights?"(Laughter)"What's that over there?" "What?""Gimme me what you got, old man!""Did anybody hear that?" "Hear what? There ain't nothing. No, really — there ain't no bat!"But then ... one out of the three good-for-nothings gets it to the head — pow!And number two swings blindly into the dark cape before him, but before his fist hits anything, I grab a trash can lid and — right in the gut! And number one comes back with the jump kick, but I know judo karate, too, so I'm like —(Drums)Twice!(Drums)(Laughter)(Drums)But before I can do any more damage, suddenly we all hear a "click-click." And suddenly everything gets quiet. And the one good-for-nothing left standing grips a handgun and aims it straight up, like he's holding Jesus hostage, like he's threatening maybe to blow a hole in the moon. And the good-for-nothing who got it to the head, who tried to jump-kick me, and the other good-for-nothing who got it in the gut, is both scrambling back away from the dark figure before 'em. And the drunk man, the janitor man, is huddled in a corner, praying to Saint Anthony 'cause that's the only one he could remember.(Double beat) And there's me: eyes glowing white, cape blowing softly in the wind.(Beat) Bulletproof chest heaving, my heart beating right through it in a Morse code for: "Fuck with me just once come on just try."And the one good-for-nothing left standing, the one with the handgun — yeah, he laughs. And he lowers his arm. And he points it at me and gives the moon a break. And he aims it right between my pointy ears, like goal posts and he's special teams. And janitor man is still calling Saint Anthony, but he ain't pickin' up. And for a second, it seems like ... maybe I'm gonna lose.Nah!(Drums)Shoot! Shoot! Fwa-ka-ka!"Don't kill me, man!"Snap! Wrist crack! Neck! Slash!Skin meets acid: "Ahhhhhhh!"And he's on the floor and I'm standing over him and I got the gun in my hands now and I hate guns, I hate holding 'em 'cause I'm Batman. And, asterisk: Batman don't like guns 'cause his parents got iced by guns a long time ago. But for just a second, my eyes glow white, and I hold this thing for I could speak to the good-for-nothing in a language he maybe understands. Click-click!(Beat)And the good-for-nothings become good-for-disappearing into whatever toxic waste, chemical sludge shithole they crawled out of. And it's just me and janitor man. And I pick him up, and I wipe sweat and cheap perfume off his forehead. And he begs me not to hurt him and I grab him tight by his janitor-man shirt collar, and I pull him to my face and he's taller than me but the cape helps, so he listens when I look him straight in the eyes. And I say two words to him: "Go home."And he does, checking behind his shoulder every 10 feet. And I swoosh from building to building on his way there 'cause I know where he lives. And I watch his hands tremble as he pulls out his key chain and opens the door to his building. And I'm back in bed before he even walks in through the front door.And I hear him turn on the faucet and pour himself a glass of warm tap water. And he puts the glass back in the sink. And I hear his footsteps. And they get slower as they get to my room. And he creaks my door open, like, mad-slow. And he takes a step in, which he never does.(Beat) And he's staring off into nowhere, his face, the color of sidewalks in summer. And I act like I'm just waking up and I say, "Ah, what's up, Pop?" And janitor man says nothing to me. But I see in the dark, I see his arms go limp and his head turns back, like, towards me. And he lifts it for I can see his face, for I could see his eyes. And his cheeks is drippin', but not with sweat. And he just stands there breathing, like he remembers my eyes glowing white, like he remembers my bulletproof chest, like he remembers he's my pop. And for a long time I don't say nothin'. And he turns around, hand on the doorknob. And he ain't looking my way, but I hear him mumble two words to me: "I'm sorry."And I lean over, and I open my window just a crack. If you look up high enough, you could see me. And from where I am —(Cymbals)I could hear everything.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.185 --> 00:00:15.233
I was a Marine with 1/1 Weapons Company,

00:00:15.257 --> 00:00:16.408
81's platoon,

00:00:16.432 --> 00:00:18.437
out in Camp Pendleton, California.

00:00:18.461 --> 00:00:19.613
Oorah!

00:00:19.637 --> 00:00:20.789
Audience: Oorah!

00:00:20.813 --> 00:00:21.814
(Laughter)

00:00:21.838 --> 00:00:23.806
I joined a few months after September 11,

00:00:23.830 --> 00:00:26.849
feeling like I think most people
in the country did at the time,

00:00:26.873 --> 00:00:30.158
filled with a sense
of patriotism and retribution

00:00:30.182 --> 00:00:31.824
and the desire to do something --

00:00:31.848 --> 00:00:34.593
that, coupled with that fact
that I wasn't doing anything.

00:00:34.617 --> 00:00:37.863
I was 17, just graduated
from high school that past summer,

00:00:37.887 --> 00:00:40.589
living in the back room
of my parents' house paying rent,

00:00:40.613 --> 00:00:43.202
in the small town I was raised in
in Northern Indiana,

00:00:43.226 --> 00:00:44.384
called Mishawaka.

00:00:44.408 --> 00:00:46.986
I can spell that later
for people who are interested --

00:00:47.010 --> 00:00:48.014
(Laughter)

00:00:48.038 --> 00:00:51.898
Mishawaka is many good things
but cultural hub of the world it is not,

00:00:51.922 --> 00:00:53.818
so my only exposure to theater and film

00:00:53.842 --> 00:00:55.971
was limited to the plays
I did in high school

00:00:55.995 --> 00:00:58.223
and Blockbuster Video,
may she rest in peace.

00:00:58.247 --> 00:00:59.419
(Laughter)

00:00:59.443 --> 00:01:01.090
I was serious enough about acting

00:01:01.114 --> 00:01:04.422
that I auditioned for Juilliard
when I was a senior in high school,

00:01:04.446 --> 00:01:05.597
didn't get in,

00:01:05.621 --> 00:01:08.347
determined college wasn't for me
and applied nowhere else,

00:01:08.371 --> 00:01:09.664
which was a genius move.

00:01:09.688 --> 00:01:13.139
I also did that Hail Mary
LA acting odyssey

00:01:13.163 --> 00:01:14.798
that I always heard stories about,

00:01:14.822 --> 00:01:17.123
of actors moving to LA
with, like, seven dollars

00:01:17.147 --> 00:01:19.090
and finding work and successful careers.

00:01:19.114 --> 00:01:22.470
I got as far as Amarillo, Texas,
before my car broke down.

00:01:22.494 --> 00:01:24.221
I spent all my money repairing it,

00:01:24.245 --> 00:01:25.890
finally made it to Santa Monica --

00:01:25.914 --> 00:01:27.192
not even LA --

00:01:27.216 --> 00:01:29.875
stayed for 48 hours wandering
the beach, basically,

00:01:29.899 --> 00:01:31.185
got in my car, drove home,

00:01:31.209 --> 00:01:32.915
thus ending my acting career, so --

00:01:32.939 --> 00:01:34.217
(Laughter)

00:01:34.241 --> 00:01:36.129
Seventeen, Mishawaka ...

00:01:36.153 --> 00:01:39.981
parents' house, paying rent,
selling vacuums ...

00:01:40.005 --> 00:01:41.560
telemarketing,

00:01:41.584 --> 00:01:43.767
cutting grass at the local
4-H fairgrounds.

00:01:43.791 --> 00:01:46.083
This was my world
going into September, 2001.

00:01:46.107 --> 00:01:47.258
So after the 11th,

00:01:47.282 --> 00:01:49.484
and feeling an overwhelming sense of duty,

00:01:49.508 --> 00:01:51.859
and just being pissed off
in general -- at myself,

00:01:51.883 --> 00:01:53.279
my parents, the government;

00:01:53.303 --> 00:01:55.756
not having confidence,
not having a respectable job,

00:01:55.780 --> 00:01:58.882
my shitty mini-fridge that I just
drove to California and back --

00:01:58.906 --> 00:02:01.879
I joined the Marine Corps and loved it.
I loved being a Marine.

00:02:01.903 --> 00:02:04.941
It's one of the things I'm most proud
of having done in my life.

00:02:04.965 --> 00:02:06.131
Firing weapons was cool,

00:02:06.155 --> 00:02:08.590
driving and detonating
expensive things was great.

00:02:08.614 --> 00:02:10.722
But I found I loved
the Marine Corps the most

00:02:10.746 --> 00:02:13.387
for the thing I was looking
for the least when I joined,

00:02:13.411 --> 00:02:14.572
which was the people:

00:02:14.596 --> 00:02:18.176
these weird dudes --
a motley crew of characters

00:02:18.200 --> 00:02:20.582
from a cross section
of the United States --

00:02:20.606 --> 00:02:22.937
that on the surface I had
nothing in common with.

00:02:22.961 --> 00:02:24.569
And over time,

00:02:24.593 --> 00:02:26.419
all the political and personal bravado

00:02:26.443 --> 00:02:28.320
that led me to the military dissolved,

00:02:28.344 --> 00:02:31.326
and for me, the Marine Corps
became synonymous with my friends.

00:02:31.350 --> 00:02:33.638
And then, a few years into my service

00:02:33.662 --> 00:02:35.741
and months away from deploying to Iraq,

00:02:35.765 --> 00:02:38.630
I dislocated my sternum
in a mountain-biking accident,

00:02:38.654 --> 00:02:40.296
and had to be medically separated.

00:02:40.320 --> 00:02:43.253
Those never in the military
may find this hard to understand,

00:02:43.277 --> 00:02:46.340
but being told I wasn't getting deployed
to Iraq or Afghanistan

00:02:46.364 --> 00:02:47.807
was very devastating for me.

00:02:47.831 --> 00:02:51.072
I have a very clear image of leaving
the base hospital on a stretcher

00:02:51.096 --> 00:02:53.966
and my entire platoon is waiting
outside to see if I was OK.

00:02:53.990 --> 00:02:56.424
And then, suddenly,
I was a civilian again.

00:02:56.448 --> 00:02:58.653
I knew I wanted to give
acting another shot,

00:02:58.677 --> 00:03:00.481
because -- again, this is me --

00:03:00.505 --> 00:03:04.224
I thought all civilian problems
are small compared to the military.

00:03:04.248 --> 00:03:07.005
I mean, what can you really
bitch about now, you know?

00:03:07.029 --> 00:03:08.201
"It's hot.

00:03:08.630 --> 00:03:10.862
Someone should turn
on the air conditioner."

00:03:10.886 --> 00:03:12.686
"This coffee line is too long."

00:03:13.113 --> 00:03:14.265
I was a Marine,

00:03:14.289 --> 00:03:15.440
I knew how to survive.

00:03:15.464 --> 00:03:17.402
I'd go to New York and become an actor.

00:03:17.426 --> 00:03:18.687
If things didn't work out,

00:03:18.711 --> 00:03:21.695
I'd live in Central Park
and dumpster-dive behind Panera Bread.

00:03:21.719 --> 00:03:22.720
(Laughter)

00:03:22.744 --> 00:03:25.434
I re-auditioned for Juilliard
and this time I was lucky,

00:03:25.458 --> 00:03:26.609
I got in.

00:03:26.633 --> 00:03:29.174
But I was surprised
by how complex the transition was

00:03:29.198 --> 00:03:30.499
from military to civilian.

00:03:30.523 --> 00:03:33.998
And I was relatively healthy; I can't
imagine going through that process

00:03:34.022 --> 00:03:35.884
on top of a mental or physical injury.

00:03:35.908 --> 00:03:37.499
But regardless, it was difficult.

00:03:37.523 --> 00:03:39.693
In part, because I was in acting school --

00:03:39.717 --> 00:03:43.254
I couldn't justify going
to voice and speech class,

00:03:43.715 --> 00:03:46.546
throwing imaginary balls of energy
at the back of the room,

00:03:46.570 --> 00:03:49.133
doing acting exercises
where I gave birth to myself --

00:03:49.157 --> 00:03:50.158
(Laughter)

00:03:50.182 --> 00:03:52.916
while my friends were serving
without me overseas.

00:03:52.940 --> 00:03:55.549
But also, because I didn't
know how to apply the things

00:03:55.573 --> 00:03:57.926
I learned in the military
to a civilian context.

00:03:57.950 --> 00:04:00.109
I mean that both practically
and emotionally.

00:04:00.133 --> 00:04:01.702
Practically, I had to get a job.

00:04:01.726 --> 00:04:03.458
And I was an Infantry Marine,

00:04:03.482 --> 00:04:06.038
where you're shooting machine guns
and firing mortars.

00:04:06.062 --> 00:04:09.609
There's not a lot of places you can
put those skills in the civilian world.

00:04:09.633 --> 00:04:10.634
(Laughter)

00:04:10.658 --> 00:04:12.680
Emotionally, I struggled to find meaning.

00:04:13.061 --> 00:04:15.022
In the military, everything has meaning.

00:04:15.046 --> 00:04:17.299
Everything you do
is either steeped in tradition

00:04:17.323 --> 00:04:18.651
or has a practical purpose.

00:04:18.675 --> 00:04:20.028
You can't smoke in the field

00:04:20.052 --> 00:04:22.403
because you don't want
to give away your position.

00:04:22.427 --> 00:04:24.722
You don't touch your face --
you have to maintain

00:04:24.746 --> 00:04:26.628
a personal level of health and hygiene.

00:04:26.652 --> 00:04:28.478
You face this way when "Colors" plays,

00:04:28.502 --> 00:04:30.692
out of respect for people
who went before you.

00:04:30.716 --> 00:04:32.856
Walk this way, talk this way
because of this.

00:04:32.880 --> 00:04:34.760
Your uniform is maintained to the inch.

00:04:34.784 --> 00:04:37.277
How diligently you followed
those rules spoke volumes

00:04:37.301 --> 00:04:38.936
about the kind of Marine you were.

00:04:38.960 --> 00:04:40.988
Your rank said something
about your history

00:04:41.012 --> 00:04:42.496
and the respect you had earned.

00:04:42.520 --> 00:04:44.352
In the civilian world there's no rank.

00:04:44.376 --> 00:04:45.815
Here you're just another body,

00:04:45.839 --> 00:04:49.046
and I felt like I constantly had
to prove my worth all over again.

00:04:49.070 --> 00:04:52.070
And the respect civilians were giving me
while I was in uniform

00:04:52.094 --> 00:04:53.720
didn't exist when I was out of it.

00:04:53.744 --> 00:04:55.497
There didn't seem to be a ...

00:04:55.521 --> 00:04:56.721
a sense of community,

00:04:56.745 --> 00:04:59.411
whereas in the military,
I felt this sense of community.

00:04:59.435 --> 00:05:01.164
How often in the civilian world

00:05:01.706 --> 00:05:04.940
are you put in a life-or-death situation
with your closest friends

00:05:04.964 --> 00:05:08.270
and they constantly demonstrate
that they're not going to abandon you?

00:05:08.294 --> 00:05:10.347
And meanwhile, at acting school ...

00:05:10.371 --> 00:05:12.829
(Laughter)

00:05:12.853 --> 00:05:14.527
I was really, for the first time,

00:05:14.551 --> 00:05:16.836
discovering playwrights
and characters and plays

00:05:16.860 --> 00:05:18.823
that had nothing to do with the military,

00:05:18.847 --> 00:05:21.202
but were somehow describing
my military experience

00:05:21.226 --> 00:05:23.773
in a way that before
to me was indescribable.

00:05:23.797 --> 00:05:26.188
And I felt myself becoming less aggressive

00:05:26.212 --> 00:05:29.415
as I was able to put words
to feelings for the first time

00:05:29.439 --> 00:05:31.558
and realizing what
a valuable tool that was.

00:05:31.582 --> 00:05:34.062
And when I was reflecting
on my time in the military,

00:05:34.086 --> 00:05:36.497
I wasn't first thinking
on the stereotypical drills

00:05:36.521 --> 00:05:37.973
and discipline and pain of it;

00:05:37.997 --> 00:05:40.211
but rather, the small,
intimate human moments,

00:05:40.235 --> 00:05:41.568
moments of great feeling:

00:05:41.592 --> 00:05:44.217
friends going AWOL
because they missed their families,

00:05:44.241 --> 00:05:45.476
friends getting divorced,

00:05:45.500 --> 00:05:47.498
grieving together, celebrating together,

00:05:47.522 --> 00:05:49.457
all within the backdrop of the military.

00:05:49.481 --> 00:05:51.763
I saw my friends battling
these circumstances,

00:05:51.787 --> 00:05:54.818
and I watched the anxiety
it produced in them and me,

00:05:54.842 --> 00:05:57.428
not being able to express
our feelings about it.

00:05:57.984 --> 00:06:01.032
The military and theater communities
are actually very similar.

00:06:01.056 --> 00:06:03.781
You have a group of people
trying to accomplish a mission

00:06:03.805 --> 00:06:05.868
greater than themselves;
it's not about you.

00:06:05.892 --> 00:06:08.860
You have a role, you have to know
your role within that team.

00:06:08.884 --> 00:06:11.043
Every team has a leader or director;

00:06:11.067 --> 00:06:13.617
sometimes they're smart,
sometimes they're not.

00:06:13.641 --> 00:06:16.245
You're forced to be intimate
with complete strangers

00:06:16.269 --> 00:06:17.554
in a short amount of time;

00:06:17.578 --> 00:06:19.625
the self-discipline, the self-maintenance.

00:06:20.090 --> 00:06:22.573
I thought, how great would it be
to create a space

00:06:22.597 --> 00:06:25.924
that combined these two seemingly
dissimilar communities,

00:06:25.948 --> 00:06:28.183
that brought entertainment
to a group of people

00:06:28.207 --> 00:06:30.302
that, considering their occupation,

00:06:30.326 --> 00:06:32.770
could handle something
a bit more thought-provoking

00:06:32.794 --> 00:06:34.627
than the typical mandatory-fun events

00:06:34.651 --> 00:06:37.712
that I remember being
"volun-told" to go to in the military --

00:06:37.736 --> 00:06:38.738
(Laughter)

00:06:38.762 --> 00:06:41.040
all well-intended but slightly
offensive events,

00:06:41.064 --> 00:06:43.715
like "Win a Date with a San Diego
Chargers Cheerleader,"

00:06:43.739 --> 00:06:45.915
where you answer a question
about pop culture,

00:06:45.939 --> 00:06:47.832
and if you get it right you win a date,

00:06:47.856 --> 00:06:50.202
which was a chaperoned walk
around the parade deck

00:06:50.226 --> 00:06:52.617
with this already married,
pregnant cheerleader --

00:06:52.641 --> 00:06:53.808
(Laughter)

00:06:53.832 --> 00:06:56.212
Nothing against cheerleaders,
I love cheerleaders.

00:06:56.236 --> 00:06:59.348
The point is more, how great would it
be to have theater presented

00:06:59.372 --> 00:07:02.596
through characters that were accessible
without being condescending.

00:07:02.620 --> 00:07:05.525
So we started this nonprofit
called Arts in the Armed Forces,

00:07:05.549 --> 00:07:07.204
where we tried to do that,

00:07:07.228 --> 00:07:10.146
tried to join these two seemingly
dissimilar communities.

00:07:10.170 --> 00:07:13.985
We pick a play or select monologues
from contemporary American plays

00:07:14.009 --> 00:07:17.683
that are diverse in age and race
like a military audience is,

00:07:17.707 --> 00:07:20.056
grab a group of incredible
theater-trained actors,

00:07:20.080 --> 00:07:21.933
arm them with incredible material,

00:07:21.957 --> 00:07:24.177
keep production value
as minimal as possible --

00:07:24.201 --> 00:07:27.237
no sets, no costumes,
no lights, just reading it --

00:07:27.261 --> 00:07:29.740
to throw all the emphasis on the language

00:07:29.764 --> 00:07:32.479
and to show that theater can
be created at any setting.

00:07:32.503 --> 00:07:33.683
It's a powerful thing,

00:07:33.707 --> 00:07:36.593
getting in a room with complete strangers

00:07:36.617 --> 00:07:39.265
and reminding ourselves of our humanity,

00:07:39.289 --> 00:07:41.686
and that self-expression
is just as valuable a tool

00:07:41.710 --> 00:07:43.067
as a rifle on your shoulder.

00:07:43.091 --> 00:07:45.096
And for an organization like the military,

00:07:45.120 --> 00:07:48.047
that prides itself on having
acronyms for acronyms,

00:07:48.071 --> 00:07:49.494
you can get lost in the sauce

00:07:49.518 --> 00:07:52.200
when it comes to explaining
a collective experience.

00:07:52.224 --> 00:07:54.068
And I can think of no better community

00:07:54.092 --> 00:07:56.163
to arm with a new means of self-expression

00:07:56.187 --> 00:07:58.209
than those protecting our country.

00:07:58.233 --> 00:08:00.713
We've gone all over
the United States and the world,

00:08:00.737 --> 00:08:03.418
from Walter Reed in Bethesda, Maryland,

00:08:03.442 --> 00:08:05.888
to Camp Pendleton,
to Camp Arifjan in Kuwait,

00:08:05.912 --> 00:08:07.621
to USAG Bavaria,

00:08:07.645 --> 00:08:09.685
on- and off-Broadway theaters in New York.

00:08:09.709 --> 00:08:11.781
And for the performing artists we bring,

00:08:11.805 --> 00:08:13.473
it's a window into a culture

00:08:13.497 --> 00:08:15.657
they otherwise would not
have had exposure to.

00:08:15.681 --> 00:08:17.700
And for the military, it's the exact same.

00:08:17.724 --> 00:08:19.711
And in doing this for the past six years,

00:08:19.735 --> 00:08:21.966
I'm always reminded
that acting is many things.

00:08:21.990 --> 00:08:25.195
It's a craft, it's a political act,
it's a business, it's --

00:08:25.846 --> 00:08:27.971
whatever adjective
is most applicable to you.

00:08:27.995 --> 00:08:29.434
But it's also a service.

00:08:29.458 --> 00:08:30.982
I didn't get to finish mine,

00:08:31.006 --> 00:08:32.638
so whenever I get to be of service

00:08:32.662 --> 00:08:35.939
to this ultimate service industry,
the military, for me, again --

00:08:35.963 --> 00:08:38.010
there's not many things better than that.

00:08:38.034 --> 00:08:39.362
Thank you.

00:08:39.386 --> 00:08:43.974
(Applause)

00:08:43.998 --> 00:08:47.922
We're going to be doing a piece
from Marco Ramirez,

00:08:47.946 --> 00:08:49.640
called "I am not Batman."

00:08:49.664 --> 00:08:52.692
An incredible actor
and good friend of mine, Jesse Perez,

00:08:52.716 --> 00:08:53.891
is going to be reading,

00:08:53.915 --> 00:08:56.399
and Matt Johnson,
who I just met a couple hours ago.

00:08:56.423 --> 00:08:58.574
They're doing it together
for the first time,

00:08:58.598 --> 00:08:59.836
so we'll see how it goes.

00:08:59.860 --> 00:09:01.779
Jesse Perez and Matt Johnson.

00:09:01.803 --> 00:09:04.957
(Applause)

00:09:12.627 --> 00:09:14.594
Jesse Perez: It's the middle of the night

00:09:14.618 --> 00:09:16.928
and the sky is glowing
like mad, radioactive red.

00:09:16.952 --> 00:09:19.074
And if you squint,
you can maybe see the moon

00:09:19.098 --> 00:09:21.964
through a thick layer of cigarette smoke
and airplane exhaust

00:09:21.988 --> 00:09:23.279
that covers the whole city,

00:09:23.303 --> 00:09:25.601
like a mosquito net
that won't let the angels in.

00:09:25.625 --> 00:09:26.665
(Drum beat)

00:09:26.689 --> 00:09:28.175
And if you look up high enough,

00:09:28.199 --> 00:09:31.636
you can see me standing
on the edge of an 87-story building.

00:09:31.660 --> 00:09:35.087
And up there, a place for gargoyles
and broken clock towers

00:09:35.111 --> 00:09:38.087
that have stayed still and dead
for maybe like 100 years,

00:09:38.111 --> 00:09:39.622
up there is me.

00:09:39.646 --> 00:09:40.676
(Beat)

00:09:40.700 --> 00:09:42.284
And I'm frickin' Batman.

00:09:42.308 --> 00:09:43.347
(Beat)

00:09:43.371 --> 00:09:45.536
And I gots Batmobiles and batarangs

00:09:45.560 --> 00:09:47.955
and frickin' bat caves, like, for real.

00:09:47.979 --> 00:09:49.673
And all it takes is a broom closet

00:09:49.697 --> 00:09:51.641
or a back room or a fire escape,

00:09:51.665 --> 00:09:54.656
and Danny's hand-me-down jeans are gone.

00:09:54.680 --> 00:09:56.576
And my navy blue polo shirt,

00:09:56.600 --> 00:10:00.077
the one that looks kinda good on me
but has that hole on it near the butt

00:10:00.101 --> 00:10:03.125
from when it got snagged
on the chain-link fence behind Arturo's

00:10:03.149 --> 00:10:05.841
but it isn't even a big deal
because I tuck that part in

00:10:05.865 --> 00:10:07.084
and it's, like, all good.

00:10:07.108 --> 00:10:09.025
That blue polo shirt -- it's gone, too!

00:10:09.049 --> 00:10:12.056
And I get like, like ... transformational.

00:10:12.080 --> 00:10:13.080
(Beat)

00:10:13.392 --> 00:10:16.727
And nobody pulls out a belt
and whips Batman for talkin' back.

00:10:16.751 --> 00:10:17.768
(Beat)

00:10:17.792 --> 00:10:19.212
Or for not talkin' back.

00:10:19.236 --> 00:10:21.560
And nobody calls Batman simple

00:10:21.584 --> 00:10:23.133
or stupid

00:10:23.157 --> 00:10:24.354
or skinny.

00:10:24.742 --> 00:10:27.961
And nobody fires Batman's brother
from the Eastern Taxi Company

00:10:27.985 --> 00:10:30.017
'cause they was making cutbacks, neither.

00:10:30.041 --> 00:10:31.930
'Cause they got nothing but respect.

00:10:31.954 --> 00:10:34.089
And not like afraid-respect,

00:10:34.113 --> 00:10:36.492
just, like, respect-respect.

00:10:36.516 --> 00:10:37.517
(Laughter)

00:10:37.541 --> 00:10:39.048
'Cause nobody's afraid of you.

00:10:39.072 --> 00:10:41.206
'Cause Batman doesn't mean nobody no harm.

00:10:41.230 --> 00:10:42.231
(Beat)

00:10:42.255 --> 00:10:43.809
Ever.
(Double beat)

00:10:43.833 --> 00:10:46.270
'Cause all Batman really wants
to do is save people

00:10:46.294 --> 00:10:48.041
and maybe pay abuela's bills one day

00:10:48.065 --> 00:10:49.216
and die happy.

00:10:49.240 --> 00:10:51.436
And maybe get, like, mad-famous for real.

00:10:51.460 --> 00:10:52.471
(Laughter)

00:10:52.495 --> 00:10:53.832
Oh -- and kill the Joker.

00:10:53.856 --> 00:10:55.316
(Drum roll)

00:10:55.340 --> 00:10:57.998
Tonight, like most nights, I'm all alone.

00:10:58.022 --> 00:11:00.215
And I'm watchin' and I'm waitin'

00:11:00.239 --> 00:11:01.421
like a eagle

00:11:01.445 --> 00:11:02.615
or like a --

00:11:02.639 --> 00:11:04.348
no, yeah, like a eagle.

00:11:04.372 --> 00:11:05.373
(Laughter)

00:11:05.397 --> 00:11:08.215
And my cape is flapping in the wind
cause it's frickin' long

00:11:08.239 --> 00:11:09.653
and my pointy ears are on,

00:11:09.677 --> 00:11:12.507
and that mask that covers like half
my face is on, too,

00:11:12.531 --> 00:11:16.007
and I got, like, bulletproof stuff
all in my chest so no one can hurt me.

00:11:16.031 --> 00:11:17.745
And nobody -- nobody! --

00:11:17.769 --> 00:11:19.808
is gonna come between Batman ...

00:11:19.832 --> 00:11:21.011
and justice.

00:11:21.035 --> 00:11:22.837
(Drums)
(Laughter)

00:11:22.861 --> 00:11:24.369
From where I am,

00:11:24.393 --> 00:11:25.980
I can hear everything.

00:11:26.004 --> 00:11:27.170
(Silence)

00:11:27.194 --> 00:11:28.354
Somewhere in the city,

00:11:28.378 --> 00:11:31.594
there's a old lady picking
Styrofoam leftovers up out of a trash can

00:11:31.618 --> 00:11:34.468
and she's putting a piece
of sesame chicken someone spit out

00:11:34.492 --> 00:11:35.803
into her own mouth.

00:11:35.827 --> 00:11:39.136
And somewhere there's a doctor
with a wack haircut in a black lab coat

00:11:39.160 --> 00:11:41.018
trying to find a cure for the diseases

00:11:41.042 --> 00:11:44.000
that are gonna make us
all extinct for real one day.

00:11:44.024 --> 00:11:45.384
And somewhere there's a man,

00:11:45.408 --> 00:11:46.805
a man in a janitor's uniform,

00:11:46.829 --> 00:11:48.762
stumbling home drunk and dizzy

00:11:48.786 --> 00:11:52.538
after spending half his paycheck
on 40-ounce bottles of twist-off beer,

00:11:52.562 --> 00:11:55.506
and the other half on a four-hour visit
to some lady's house

00:11:55.530 --> 00:11:57.955
on a street where the lights
have all been shot out

00:11:57.979 --> 00:12:01.012
by people who'd rather do
what they do in this city in the dark.

00:12:01.036 --> 00:12:02.962
And half a block away from janitor man,

00:12:02.986 --> 00:12:05.900
there's a group of good-for-nothings
who don't know no better,

00:12:05.924 --> 00:12:08.448
waiting for janitor man
with rusted bicycle chains

00:12:08.472 --> 00:12:10.141
and imitation Louisville Sluggers,

00:12:10.165 --> 00:12:11.947
and if they don't find a cent on him,

00:12:11.971 --> 00:12:13.122
which they won't,

00:12:13.146 --> 00:12:16.504
they'll just pound at him till the muscles
in their arms start burning,

00:12:16.528 --> 00:12:18.601
till there's no more teeth to crack out.

00:12:18.625 --> 00:12:20.124
But they don't count on me.

00:12:20.622 --> 00:12:22.869
They don't count on no Dark Knight,

00:12:22.893 --> 00:12:25.887
with a stomach full of grocery-store
brand macaroni and cheese

00:12:25.911 --> 00:12:27.500
and cut-up Vienna sausages.

00:12:27.524 --> 00:12:28.525
(Laughter)

00:12:28.549 --> 00:12:31.105
'Cause they'd rather believe
I don't exist.

00:12:31.851 --> 00:12:35.464
And from 87 stories up, I can hear
one of the good-for-nothings say,

00:12:35.488 --> 00:12:37.789
"Gimme the cash!" -- real fast like that,

00:12:37.813 --> 00:12:39.556
just, "Gimme me the fuckin' cash!"

00:12:39.580 --> 00:12:43.133
And I see janitor man mumble something
in drunk language and turn pale,

00:12:43.157 --> 00:12:44.334
and from 87 stories up,

00:12:44.358 --> 00:12:47.466
I can hear his stomach trying
to hurl its way out his Dickies.

00:12:47.490 --> 00:12:49.371
So I swoop down, like, mad-fast

00:12:49.395 --> 00:12:52.410
and I'm like darkness, I'm like, "Swoosh!"

00:12:52.434 --> 00:12:54.889
And I throw a batarang
at the one naked lightbulb.

00:12:54.913 --> 00:12:55.952
(Cymbal)

00:12:55.976 --> 00:12:58.104
And they're all like, "Whoa, muthafucker!

00:12:58.128 --> 00:12:59.719
Who just turned out the lights?"

00:12:59.743 --> 00:13:00.744
(Laughter)

00:13:00.768 --> 00:13:02.437
"What's that over there?"
"What?"

00:13:02.461 --> 00:13:04.054
"Gimme me what you got, old man!"

00:13:04.078 --> 00:13:05.244
"Did anybody hear that?"

00:13:05.268 --> 00:13:09.108
"Hear what? There ain't nothing.
No, really -- there ain't no bat!"

00:13:09.132 --> 00:13:10.359
But then ...

00:13:10.383 --> 00:13:13.862
one out of the three good-for-nothings
gets it to the head -- pow!

00:13:13.886 --> 00:13:16.743
And number two swings blindly
into the dark cape before him,

00:13:16.767 --> 00:13:18.576
but before his fist hits anything,

00:13:18.600 --> 00:13:20.504
I grab a trash can lid and --

00:13:20.528 --> 00:13:21.715
right in the gut!

00:13:21.739 --> 00:13:23.854
And number one comes
back with the jump kick,

00:13:23.878 --> 00:13:26.509
but I know judo karate, too,
so I'm like --

00:13:26.533 --> 00:13:30.314
(Drums)

00:13:30.338 --> 00:13:31.489
Twice!

00:13:31.513 --> 00:13:32.514
(Drums)

00:13:32.538 --> 00:13:33.763
(Laughter)

00:13:33.787 --> 00:13:35.239
(Drums)

00:13:35.263 --> 00:13:37.023
But before I can do any more damage,

00:13:37.047 --> 00:13:39.246
suddenly we all hear a "click-click."

00:13:40.175 --> 00:13:42.411
And suddenly everything gets quiet.

00:13:43.007 --> 00:13:45.023
And the one good-for-nothing left standing

00:13:45.047 --> 00:13:46.984
grips a handgun and aims it straight up,

00:13:47.008 --> 00:13:48.589
like he's holding Jesus hostage,

00:13:48.613 --> 00:13:51.498
like he's threatening maybe
to blow a hole in the moon.

00:13:51.522 --> 00:13:53.794
And the good-for-nothing
who got it to the head,

00:13:53.818 --> 00:13:55.086
who tried to jump-kick me,

00:13:55.110 --> 00:13:57.603
and the other good-for-nothing
who got it in the gut,

00:13:57.627 --> 00:14:00.508
is both scrambling back away
from the dark figure before 'em.

00:14:00.532 --> 00:14:02.215
And the drunk man, the janitor man,

00:14:02.239 --> 00:14:04.502
is huddled in a corner,
praying to Saint Anthony

00:14:04.526 --> 00:14:06.642
'cause that's the only one
he could remember.

00:14:06.666 --> 00:14:07.667
(Double beat)

00:14:07.691 --> 00:14:08.843
And there's me:

00:14:09.268 --> 00:14:10.638
eyes glowing white,

00:14:10.662 --> 00:14:12.669
cape blowing softly in the wind.

00:14:12.693 --> 00:14:13.694
(Beat)

00:14:13.718 --> 00:14:15.215
Bulletproof chest heaving,

00:14:15.239 --> 00:14:17.779
my heart beating right through it
in a Morse code for:

00:14:17.803 --> 00:14:18.954
"Fuck with me

00:14:18.978 --> 00:14:20.129
just once

00:14:20.153 --> 00:14:21.304
come on

00:14:21.328 --> 00:14:22.478
just try."

00:14:22.788 --> 00:14:24.868
And the one good-for-nothing
left standing,

00:14:24.892 --> 00:14:26.207
the one with the handgun --

00:14:26.231 --> 00:14:27.382
yeah, he laughs.

00:14:27.406 --> 00:14:28.588
And he lowers his arm.

00:14:28.612 --> 00:14:29.922
And he points it at me

00:14:29.946 --> 00:14:31.397
and gives the moon a break.

00:14:31.421 --> 00:14:33.594
And he aims it right
between my pointy ears,

00:14:33.618 --> 00:14:36.567
like goal posts and he's special teams.

00:14:37.402 --> 00:14:40.071
And janitor man is still
calling Saint Anthony,

00:14:40.095 --> 00:14:41.451
but he ain't pickin' up.

00:14:42.235 --> 00:14:43.913
And for a second,

00:14:43.937 --> 00:14:45.191
it seems like ...

00:14:46.998 --> 00:14:48.723
maybe I'm gonna lose.

00:14:50.857 --> 00:14:52.015
Nah!

00:14:52.039 --> 00:14:53.055
(Drums)

00:14:53.079 --> 00:14:54.264
Shoot! Shoot! Fwa-ka-ka!

00:14:54.288 --> 00:14:55.439
"Don't kill me, man!"

00:14:55.463 --> 00:14:57.421
Snap! Wrist crack! Neck! Slash!

00:14:57.445 --> 00:15:01.428
Skin meets acid:
"Ahhhhhhh!"

00:15:01.452 --> 00:15:02.690
And he's on the floor

00:15:02.714 --> 00:15:03.912
and I'm standing over him

00:15:03.936 --> 00:15:05.845
and I got the gun in my hands now

00:15:05.869 --> 00:15:08.533
and I hate guns, I hate holding 'em
'cause I'm Batman.

00:15:08.557 --> 00:15:09.735
And, asterisk:

00:15:09.759 --> 00:15:13.317
Batman don't like guns 'cause his parents
got iced by guns a long time ago.

00:15:13.341 --> 00:15:14.556
But for just a second,

00:15:14.580 --> 00:15:15.898
my eyes glow white,

00:15:15.922 --> 00:15:17.081
and I hold this thing

00:15:17.105 --> 00:15:19.088
for I could speak to the good-for-nothing

00:15:19.112 --> 00:15:20.858
in a language he maybe understands.

00:15:20.882 --> 00:15:22.429
Click-click!

00:15:22.453 --> 00:15:23.466
(Beat)

00:15:23.490 --> 00:15:26.055
And the good-for-nothings
become good-for-disappearing

00:15:26.079 --> 00:15:29.774
into whatever toxic waste, chemical
sludge shithole they crawled out of.

00:15:30.742 --> 00:15:32.718
And it's just me and janitor man.

00:15:33.513 --> 00:15:34.983
And I pick him up,

00:15:35.007 --> 00:15:38.140
and I wipe sweat and cheap perfume
off his forehead.

00:15:38.164 --> 00:15:39.600
And he begs me not to hurt him

00:15:39.624 --> 00:15:42.154
and I grab him tight
by his janitor-man shirt collar,

00:15:42.178 --> 00:15:43.465
and I pull him to my face

00:15:43.489 --> 00:15:45.569
and he's taller than me
but the cape helps,

00:15:45.593 --> 00:15:47.986
so he listens when I look him
straight in the eyes.

00:15:48.010 --> 00:15:49.731
And I say two words to him:

00:15:50.425 --> 00:15:52.033
"Go home."

00:15:53.240 --> 00:15:54.486
And he does,

00:15:54.510 --> 00:15:56.978
checking behind his shoulder
every 10 feet.

00:15:57.002 --> 00:15:59.591
And I swoosh from building
to building on his way there

00:15:59.615 --> 00:16:01.019
'cause I know where he lives.

00:16:01.043 --> 00:16:03.847
And I watch his hands tremble
as he pulls out his key chain

00:16:03.871 --> 00:16:05.580
and opens the door to his building.

00:16:05.604 --> 00:16:06.875
And I'm back in bed

00:16:06.899 --> 00:16:09.171
before he even walks in
through the front door.

00:16:09.506 --> 00:16:11.125
And I hear him turn on the faucet

00:16:11.149 --> 00:16:13.405
and pour himself a glass
of warm tap water.

00:16:13.754 --> 00:16:15.650
And he puts the glass back in the sink.

00:16:16.357 --> 00:16:17.758
And I hear his footsteps.

00:16:18.588 --> 00:16:20.643
And they get slower
as they get to my room.

00:16:21.716 --> 00:16:24.841
And he creaks my door open,
like, mad-slow.

00:16:25.911 --> 00:16:27.739
And he takes a step in,

00:16:27.763 --> 00:16:29.119
which he never does.

00:16:29.635 --> 00:16:30.635
(Beat)

00:16:31.125 --> 00:16:32.755
And he's staring off into nowhere,

00:16:32.779 --> 00:16:35.444
his face, the color
of sidewalks in summer.

00:16:35.468 --> 00:16:37.049
And I act like I'm just waking up

00:16:37.073 --> 00:16:39.482
and I say, "Ah, what's up, Pop?"

00:16:40.410 --> 00:16:42.681
And janitor man says nothing to me.

00:16:43.711 --> 00:16:44.872
But I see in the dark,

00:16:44.896 --> 00:16:46.269
I see his arms go limp

00:16:46.293 --> 00:16:48.407
and his head turns back, like, towards me.

00:16:48.431 --> 00:16:50.807
And he lifts it for I can see his face,

00:16:50.831 --> 00:16:52.697
for I could see his eyes.

00:16:52.721 --> 00:16:55.093
And his cheeks is drippin',
but not with sweat.

00:16:55.662 --> 00:16:57.443
And he just stands there breathing,

00:16:57.467 --> 00:16:59.899
like he remembers my eyes glowing white,

00:16:59.923 --> 00:17:02.613
like he remembers my bulletproof chest,

00:17:03.471 --> 00:17:05.414
like he remembers he's my pop.

00:17:09.533 --> 00:17:12.489
And for a long time I don't say nothin'.

00:17:14.541 --> 00:17:16.567
And he turns around, hand on the doorknob.

00:17:16.591 --> 00:17:18.019
And he ain't looking my way,

00:17:18.043 --> 00:17:20.585
but I hear him mumble two words to me:

00:17:22.211 --> 00:17:23.625
"I'm sorry."

00:17:26.275 --> 00:17:29.554
And I lean over, and I open
my window just a crack.

00:17:30.655 --> 00:17:32.340
If you look up high enough,

00:17:32.994 --> 00:17:34.570
you could see me.

00:17:35.477 --> 00:17:36.894
And from where I am --

00:17:37.599 --> 00:17:38.870
(Cymbals)

00:17:39.650 --> 00:17:41.400
I could hear everything.

00:17:44.034 --> 00:17:52.458
(Applause)

00:17:52.502 --> 00:17:53.719
Thank you.

00:17:53.759 --> 00:18:01.098
(Applause)

title: A smarter, more precise way to think about public health
transcript: OK, first, some introductions. My mom, Jennie, took this picture. That's my dad, Frank, in the middle. And on his left, my sisters: Mary Catherine, Judith Ann, Theresa Marie. John Patrick's sitting on his lap and Kevin Michael's on his right. And in the pale-blue windbreaker, Susan Diane. Me. I loved growing up in a big family. And one of my favorite things was picking names. But by the time child number seven came along, we had nearly run out of middle names. It was a long deliberation before we finally settled on Jennifer Bridget. Every parent in this audience knows the joy and excitement of picking a new baby's name. And I was excited and thrilled to help my mom in that special ceremonial moment.But it's not like that everywhere. I travel a lot and I see a lot. But it took me by surprise to learn in an area of Ethiopia, parents delay picking the names for their new babies by a month or more. Why delay? Why not take advantage of this special ceremonial time? Well, they delay because they're afraid. They're afraid their baby will die. And this loss might be a little more bearable without a name. A face without a name might help them feel just a little less attached.So here we are in one part of the world — a time of joy, excitement, dreaming of the future of that child — while in another world, parents are filled with dread, not daring to dream of a future for their child beyond a few precious weeks. How can that be? How can it be that 2.6 million babies die around the world before they're even one month old? 2.6 million. That's the population of Vancouver. And the shocking thing is: Why? In too many cases, we simply don't know.Now, I remember recently seeing an updated pie chart. And the pie chart was labeled, "Causes of death in children under five worldwide." And there was a pretty big section of that pie chart, about 40 percent — 40 percent was labeled "neonatal." Now, "neonatal" is not a cause of death. Neonatal is simply an adjective, an adjective that means that the child is less than one month old. For me, "neonatal" said: "We have no idea."Now, I'm a scientist. I'm a doctor. I want to fix things. But you can't fix what you can't define. So our first step in restoring the dreams of those parents is to answer the question: Why are babies dying?So today, I want to talk about a new approach, an approach that I feel will not only help us know why babies are dying, but is beginning to completely transform the whole field of global health. It's called "Precision Public Health."For me, precision medicine comes from a very special place. I trained as a cancer doctor, an oncologist. I got into it because I wanted to help people feel better. But too often my treatments made them feel worse. I still remember young women being driven to my clinic by their moms — adults, who had to be helped into my exam room by their mothers. They were so weak from the treatment I had given them. But at the time, in those front lines in the war on cancer, we had few tools. And the tools we did have couldn't differentiate between the cancer cells that we wanted to hit hard and those healthy cells that we wanted to preserve. And so the side effects that you're all very familiar with — hair loss, being sick to your stomach, having a suppressed immune system, so infection was a constant threat — were always surrounding us.And then I moved to the biotechnology industry. And I got to work on a new approach for breast cancer patients that could do a better job of telling the healthy cells from the unhealthy or cancer cells. It's a drug called Herceptin. And what Herceptin allowed us to do is to precisely target HER2-positive breast cancer, at the time, the scariest form of breast cancer. And that precision let us hit hard the cancer cells, while sparing and being more gentle on the normal cells. A huge breakthrough. It felt like a miracle, so much so that today, we're harnessing all those tools — big data, consumer monitoring, gene sequencing and more — to tackle a broad variety of diseases. WEBVTT

00:00:14.180 --> 00:00:16.846
OK, first, some introductions.

00:00:17.877 --> 00:00:20.100
My mom, Jennie, took this picture.

00:00:21.116 --> 00:00:23.455
That's my dad, Frank, in the middle.

00:00:24.097 --> 00:00:26.241
And on his left, my sisters:

00:00:26.724 --> 00:00:30.749
Mary Catherine, Judith Ann,
Theresa Marie.

00:00:30.773 --> 00:00:34.697
John Patrick's sitting on his lap
and Kevin Michael's on his right.

00:00:35.697 --> 00:00:38.170
And in the pale-blue windbreaker,

00:00:38.194 --> 00:00:40.339
Susan Diane. Me.

00:00:41.449 --> 00:00:44.577
I loved growing up in a big family.

00:00:45.117 --> 00:00:48.790
And one of my favorite things
was picking names.

00:00:49.882 --> 00:00:53.327
But by the time child
number seven came along,

00:00:53.351 --> 00:00:55.668
we had nearly run out of middle names.

00:00:57.033 --> 00:00:58.875
It was a long deliberation

00:00:58.899 --> 00:01:02.906
before we finally settled
on Jennifer Bridget.

00:01:04.311 --> 00:01:07.042
Every parent in this audience

00:01:07.066 --> 00:01:09.690
knows the joy and excitement

00:01:09.714 --> 00:01:12.152
of picking a new baby's name.

00:01:12.871 --> 00:01:14.793
And I was excited and thrilled

00:01:14.817 --> 00:01:18.520
to help my mom in that special
ceremonial moment.

00:01:19.782 --> 00:01:21.821
But it's not like that everywhere.

00:01:23.121 --> 00:01:25.804
I travel a lot and I see a lot.

00:01:26.231 --> 00:01:29.324
But it took me by surprise to learn

00:01:29.348 --> 00:01:31.527
in an area of Ethiopia,

00:01:31.551 --> 00:01:35.232
parents delay picking the names
for their new babies

00:01:35.256 --> 00:01:36.807
by a month or more.

00:01:37.866 --> 00:01:39.283
Why delay?

00:01:40.236 --> 00:01:43.603
Why not take advantage
of this special ceremonial time?

00:01:44.381 --> 00:01:46.778
Well, they delay because they're afraid.

00:01:47.965 --> 00:01:50.182
They're afraid their baby will die.

00:01:51.038 --> 00:01:56.188
And this loss might be a little more
bearable without a name.

00:01:57.206 --> 00:02:01.111
A face without a name might help them feel

00:02:01.135 --> 00:02:03.904
just a little less attached.

00:02:04.977 --> 00:02:07.454
So here we are in one part of the world --

00:02:07.478 --> 00:02:12.219
a time of joy, excitement,
dreaming of the future of that child --

00:02:12.851 --> 00:02:15.113
while in another world,

00:02:15.137 --> 00:02:18.057
parents are filled with dread,

00:02:18.081 --> 00:02:21.656
not daring to dream
of a future for their child

00:02:21.680 --> 00:02:23.546
beyond a few precious weeks.

00:02:24.747 --> 00:02:26.143
How can that be?

00:02:27.147 --> 00:02:32.632
How can it be that 2.6 million babies

00:02:32.656 --> 00:02:34.450
die around the world

00:02:34.474 --> 00:02:36.894
before they're even one month old?

00:02:37.884 --> 00:02:39.859
2.6 million.

00:02:40.992 --> 00:02:43.311
That's the population of Vancouver.

00:02:44.470 --> 00:02:46.589
And the shocking thing is:

00:02:47.001 --> 00:02:48.299
Why?

00:02:48.323 --> 00:02:52.093
In too many cases, we simply don't know.

00:02:53.103 --> 00:02:57.229
Now, I remember recently seeing
an updated pie chart.

00:02:57.253 --> 00:02:59.421
And the pie chart was labeled,

00:02:59.445 --> 00:03:02.957
"Causes of death in children
under five worldwide."

00:03:03.796 --> 00:03:07.841
And there was a pretty big section
of that pie chart, about 40 percent --

00:03:07.865 --> 00:03:11.227
40 percent was labeled "neonatal."

00:03:12.035 --> 00:03:14.412
Now, "neonatal" is not a cause of death.

00:03:14.878 --> 00:03:17.645
Neonatal is simply an adjective,

00:03:17.669 --> 00:03:22.537
an adjective that means that the child
is less than one month old.

00:03:23.614 --> 00:03:27.971
For me, "neonatal" said:
"We have no idea."

00:03:29.058 --> 00:03:31.228
Now, I'm a scientist. I'm a doctor.

00:03:31.252 --> 00:03:32.745
I want to fix things.

00:03:33.538 --> 00:03:37.403
But you can't fix
what you can't define.

00:03:38.185 --> 00:03:42.953
So our first step in restoring
the dreams of those parents

00:03:42.977 --> 00:03:45.154
is to answer the question:

00:03:45.178 --> 00:03:47.127
Why are babies dying?

00:03:48.317 --> 00:03:52.052
So today, I want to talk
about a new approach,

00:03:52.076 --> 00:03:54.013
an approach that I feel

00:03:54.037 --> 00:03:58.721
will not only help us
know why babies are dying,

00:03:59.325 --> 00:04:02.702
but is beginning to completely transform

00:04:02.726 --> 00:04:04.510
the whole field of global health.

00:04:06.193 --> 00:04:09.319
It's called "Precision Public Health."

00:04:10.573 --> 00:04:15.573
For me, precision medicine comes
from a very special place.

00:04:16.852 --> 00:04:19.659
I trained as a cancer doctor,
an oncologist.

00:04:20.037 --> 00:04:23.655
I got into it because I wanted
to help people feel better.

00:04:24.449 --> 00:04:28.254
But too often my treatments
made them feel worse.

00:04:29.235 --> 00:04:33.971
I still remember young women
being driven to my clinic

00:04:34.508 --> 00:04:35.702
by their moms --

00:04:36.569 --> 00:04:41.368
adults, who had to be helped
into my exam room by their mothers.

00:04:42.749 --> 00:04:43.909
They were so weak

00:04:43.933 --> 00:04:46.162
from the treatment I had given them.

00:04:47.241 --> 00:04:51.441
But at the time, in those front lines
in the war on cancer,

00:04:51.465 --> 00:04:53.099
we had few tools.

00:04:53.988 --> 00:04:57.680
And the tools we did have
couldn't differentiate

00:04:57.704 --> 00:05:00.978
between the cancer cells
that we wanted to hit hard

00:05:01.628 --> 00:05:05.067
and those healthy cells
that we wanted to preserve.

00:05:06.621 --> 00:05:09.576

all very familiar with --

00:05:09.600 --> 00:05:12.434

00:05:12.458 --> 00:05:16.572

so infection was a constant threat --

00:05:17.137 --> 00:05:19.922
were always surrounding us.

00:05:20.943 --> 00:05:23.652
And then I moved
to the biotechnology industry.

00:05:24.227 --> 00:05:28.307
And I got to work on a new approach
for breast cancer patients

00:05:28.331 --> 00:05:33.332

of telling the healthy cells

00:05:33.356 --> 00:05:35.698

00:05:36.524 --> 00:05:38.547
It's a drug called Herceptin.

00:05:39.301 --> 00:05:42.537
And what Herceptin allowed us to do

00:05:42.561 --> 00:05:47.772

HER2-positive breast cancer,

00:05:48.994 --> 00:05:51.676
at the time, the scariest
form of breast cancer.

00:05:52.049 --> 00:05:55.884
And that precision let us
hit hard the cancer cells,

00:05:56.685 --> 00:06:00.775

gentle on the normal cells.

00:06:02.399 --> 00:06:04.115
A huge breakthrough.

00:06:04.139 --> 00:06:06.219
It felt like a miracle,

00:06:07.049 --> 00:06:09.998

00:06:10.022 --> 00:06:12.553

00:06:13.114 --> 00:06:18.638

00:06:18.662 --> 00:06:21.983

00:06:23.002 --> 00:06:28.071

00:06:28.095 --> 00:06:31.379

00:06:32.689 --> 00:06:37.149
Precision medicine
revolutionized cancer therapy.

00:06:37.613 --> 00:06:39.215
Everything changed.

00:06:40.145 --> 00:06:43.266

00:06:44.172 --> 00:06:46.424

00:06:46.448 --> 00:06:48.266

00:06:48.290 --> 00:06:53.099

better way to tackle diseases

00:06:53.123 --> 00:06:54.286
to the rich world?

00:06:56.063 --> 00:06:57.575

00:06:57.599 --> 00:07:00.925

expensive medicines like Herceptin

00:07:00.949 --> 00:07:02.834

00:07:07.654 --> 00:07:12.022

00:07:12.046 --> 00:07:14.689

00:08:40.252 --> 00:08:43.432

00:08:43.910 --> 00:08:45.291

00:09:25.989 --> 00:09:29.093

00:09:29.117 --> 00:09:34.632

00:09:36.410 --> 00:09:37.561

00:09:38.171 --> 00:09:39.348

00:09:39.372 --> 00:09:41.537

00:09:41.854 --> 00:09:44.172

00:09:57.772 --> 00:10:01.673

00:10:01.697 --> 00:10:03.714

00:10:14.086 --> 00:10:17.097

00:11:36.007 --> 00:11:40.090

and safe as penicillin.

00:11:46.548 --> 00:11:49.984

00:11:50.008 --> 00:11:53.547

00:11:53.571 --> 00:11:54.994

00:12:00.707 --> 00:12:02.732

00:12:02.756 --> 00:12:04.467

00:12:04.491 --> 00:12:07.038

00:12:07.062 --> 00:12:10.548

our 15-year goal.

00:12:11.381 --> 00:12:15.710

00:12:15.734 --> 00:12:17.371
every single year.

00:12:18.211 --> 00:12:22.521
One million babies every single year.

00:12:23.664 --> 00:12:25.506

to public health --

00:12:29.598 --> 00:12:32.363

00:12:32.870 --> 00:12:36.259

00:12:37.601 --> 00:12:41.878

cervical cancer in women?

00:12:42.790 --> 00:12:45.608

00:12:45.632 --> 00:12:46.633
(Applause)

00:12:47.894 --> 00:12:51.822

00:12:51.846 --> 00:12:54.689
So, you know, I live
in two different worlds,

00:12:54.713 --> 00:12:57.921

00:13:03.277 --> 00:13:05.705

00:13:05.729 --> 00:13:08.053

00:13:21.592 --> 00:13:24.051

00:13:25.009 --> 00:13:28.029

00:13:28.053 --> 00:13:31.308

talent and tools --

00:13:31.332 --> 00:13:33.291

00:13:33.315 --> 00:13:38.228

00:13:38.252 --> 00:13:40.086

00:13:40.110 --> 00:13:45.126

00:13:45.150 --> 00:13:47.588

00:13:51.232 --> 00:13:55.289

00:13:55.313 --> 00:13:59.641
