graduating with debt.

00:00:59.257 --> 00:01:04.543
My friend Paul's father
graduated from Colorado State University

00:01:04.567 --> 00:01:05.717
on the GI Bill.

00:01:07.504 --> 00:01:09.092
For his generation,

00:01:09.116 --> 00:01:11.964
higher education was free or almost free,

00:01:11.988 --> 00:01:14.385
because it was thought of
as a public good.

00:01:15.634 --> 00:01:16.830
Not anymore.

00:01:18.129 --> 00:01:22.225
When Paul also graduated
from Colorado State University,

00:01:22.249 --> 00:01:25.622
he paid for his English degree
by working part-time.

00:01:26.122 --> 00:01:27.273
30 years ago,

00:01:27.297 --> 00:01:29.964
higher education tuition
was affordable, reasonable,

00:01:29.988 --> 00:01:33.384
and what debts you accumulated,
you paid off by graduation date.

00:01:33.910 --> 00:01:35.060
Not anymore.

00:01:35.787 --> 00:01:39.161
Paul's daughter followed in his footsteps,

00:01:39.185 --> 00:01:40.486
but with one difference:

00:01:40.510 --> 00:01:43.002
when she graduated five years ago,

00:01:43.026 --> 00:01:44.375
it was with a whopping debt.

00:01:45.137 --> 00:01:48.479
Students like Kate have to take on a loan

00:01:48.503 --> 00:01:51.702
because the cost of higher education
has become unaffordable

00:01:51.726 --> 00:01:55.415
for many if not most American families.

00:01:56.385 --> 00:01:57.535
But so what?

00:01:58.075 --> 00:02:00.623
Getting into debt to buy
an expensive education

00:02:00.647 --> 00:02:03.409
is not all bad if you could pay it off

00:02:03.433 --> 00:02:06.567
with the increased income
that you earned from it.

00:02:07.224 --> 00:02:09.337
But that's where the rubber
meets the road.

00:02:11.610 --> 00:02:17.206
Even a college grad
earned 10 percent more in 2001

00:02:17.230 --> 00:02:19.205
than she did in 2013.

00:02:19.942 --> 00:02:21.092
So ...

00:02:21.737 --> 00:02:23.396
tuition costs up,

00:02:23.420 --> 00:02:24.943
public funding down,

00:02:24.967 --> 00:02:27.404
family incomes diminished,

00:02:27.428 --> 00:02:29.840
personal incomes weak.

00:02:30.199 --> 00:02:34.604
Is it any wonder that more
than a quarter of those who must

00:02:34.628 --> 00:02:36.635
cannot make their student loan payments?

00:02:38.810 --> 00:02:41.787
The worst of times
can be the best of times,

00:02:41.811 --> 00:02:45.689
because certain truths flash up
in ways that you can't ignore.

00:02:46.404 --> 00:02:48.350
I want to speak of three of them today.

00:02:49.529 --> 00:02:53.403
1.2 trillion dollars of debts for diplomas

00:02:53.427 --> 00:02:55.892
make it abundantly obvious

00:02:55.916 --> 00:02:59.654
that higher education
is a consumer product you can buy.

00:03:00.241 --> 00:03:05.059
All of us talk about education
just as the economists do now,

00:03:05.083 --> 00:03:09.564
as an investment that you make
to improve the human stock

00:03:09.588 --> 00:03:11.329
by training them for work.

00:03:11.770 --> 00:03:16.493
As an investment you make
to sort and classify people

00:03:16.517 --> 00:03:19.285
so that employers
can hire them more easily.

00:03:20.354 --> 00:03:23.752
The U.S. News & World Report
ranks colleges

00:03:23.776 --> 00:03:27.029
just as the consumer report
rates washing machines.

00:03:27.053 --> 00:03:30.816
The language is peppered with barbarisms.

00:03:30.840 --> 00:03:34.221
Teachers are called "service providers,"

00:03:34.245 --> 00:03:35.998
students are called "consumers."

00:03:37.467 --> 00:03:41.348
Sociology and Shakespeare
and soccer and science,

00:03:41.372 --> 00:03:42.967
all of these are "content."

00:03:45.276 --> 00:03:46.657
Student debt is profitable.

00:03:46.681 --> 00:03:47.831
Only not on you.

00:03:49.919 --> 00:03:53.522
Your debt fattens the profit
of the student loan industry.

00:03:53.998 --> 00:03:56.435
The two 800-pound gorillas of which --

00:03:56.459 --> 00:03:58.522
Sallie Mae and Navient --

00:03:58.546 --> 00:04:03.752
posted last year a combined profit
of 1.2 billion dollars.

00:04:04.526 --> 00:04:07.098
And just like home mortgages,

00:04:07.122 --> 00:04:10.308
student loans can be bundled
and packaged and sliced and diced,

00:04:10.332 --> 00:04:11.582
and sold on Wall Street.

00:04:12.327 --> 00:04:13.923
And colleges and universities

00:04:13.947 --> 00:04:17.247
that invest in these securitized loans

00:04:18.128 --> 00:04:19.279
profit twice.

00:04:19.693 --> 00:04:21.114
Once from your tuition,

00:04:21.138 --> 00:04:23.518
and then again from the interest on debt.

00:04:25.066 --> 00:04:27.432
With all that money to be made,

00:04:27.456 --> 00:04:33.043
are we surprised that some
in the higher education business

00:04:33.067 --> 00:04:35.139
have begun to engage in false advertising,

00:04:35.163 --> 00:04:36.320
in bait and switch ...

00:04:38.543 --> 00:04:42.638
in exploiting the very ignorance
that they pretend to educate?

00:04:44.102 --> 00:04:45.252
Third:

00:04:45.636 --> 00:04:47.025
diplomas are a brand.

00:04:47.699 --> 00:04:50.050
Many years ago my teacher wrote,

00:04:50.074 --> 00:04:52.615
"When students are treated as consumers,

00:04:52.639 --> 00:04:55.764
they're made prisoners
of addiction and envy."

00:04:59.752 --> 00:05:04.293
Just as consumers can be sold and resold
upgraded versions of an iPhone,

00:05:04.317 --> 00:05:07.259
so also people can be sold
more and more education.

00:05:08.765 --> 00:05:10.631
College is the new high school,

00:05:10.655 --> 00:05:11.979
we already say that.

00:05:13.366 --> 00:05:14.765
But why stop there?

00:05:14.789 --> 00:05:18.266
People can be upsold
on certifications and recertifications,

00:05:18.290 --> 00:05:20.646
master's degrees, doctoral degrees.

00:05:23.394 --> 00:05:27.107
Higher education is also marketed
as a status object.

00:05:28.592 --> 00:05:29.743
Buy a degree,

00:05:29.767 --> 00:05:32.954
much like you do a Lexus
of a Louis Vuitton bag,

00:05:32.978 --> 00:05:34.772
to distinguish yourself from others.

00:05:34.796 --> 00:05:37.247
So you can be the object
of envy of others.

00:05:38.627 --> 00:05:40.358
Diplomas are a brand.

00:05:40.992 --> 00:05:47.587
But these truths are often times
hidden by a very noisy sales pitch.

00:05:48.493 --> 00:05:50.129
There is not a day that goes by

00:05:50.153 --> 00:05:55.190
without some policy guy
on television telling us,

00:05:55.214 --> 00:05:57.238
"A college degree is absolutely essential

00:05:57.262 --> 00:05:59.979
to get on that up escalator
to a middle-class life."

00:06:00.848 --> 00:06:04.526
And the usual evidence offered
is the college premium:

00:06:04.550 --> 00:06:09.797
a college grad who makes on average
56 percent more than a high school grad.

00:06:10.383 --> 00:06:12.431
Let's look at that number more carefully,

00:06:12.455 --> 00:06:13.781
because on the face of it,

00:06:13.805 --> 00:06:17.149
it seems to belie the stories we all hear

00:06:17.173 --> 00:06:21.561
about college grads
working as baristas and cashiers.

00:06:22.503 --> 00:06:27.654
Of 100 people who enroll
in any form of post-secondary education,

00:06:27.678 --> 00:06:30.726
45 do not complete it in a timely fashion,

00:06:30.750 --> 00:06:33.816
for a number of reasons,
including financial.

00:06:34.233 --> 00:06:36.146
Of the 55 that do graduate,

00:06:36.170 --> 00:06:38.218
two will remain unemployed,

00:06:38.242 --> 00:06:40.972
and another 18 are underemployed.

00:06:42.016 --> 00:06:45.691
So, college grads earn more
than high school grads,

00:06:45.715 --> 00:06:48.708
but does it pay for the exorbitant tuition

00:06:48.732 --> 00:06:51.123
and the lost wages while at college?

00:06:51.619 --> 00:06:54.215
Now even economists admit

00:06:54.239 --> 00:06:59.469
going to college pays off
for only those who complete it.

00:07:00.053 --> 00:07:04.085
But that's only because high school wages
have been cut to the bone,

00:07:04.109 --> 00:07:05.549
for decades now.

00:07:07.327 --> 00:07:09.216
For decades,

00:07:09.240 --> 00:07:11.597
workers with a high school degree

00:07:11.621 --> 00:07:15.724
have been denied a fair share
of what they have produced.

00:07:16.438 --> 00:07:19.343
And had they received as they should have,

00:07:19.367 --> 00:07:23.320
then going to college would have been
a bad investment for many.

00:07:23.344 --> 00:07:25.470
College premium?

00:07:25.899 --> 00:07:27.653
I think it's a high school discount.

00:07:28.646 --> 00:07:33.050
Two out of three people who enroll
are not going to find an adequate job.

00:07:33.714 --> 00:07:36.825
And the future, for them,
doesn't look particularly promising --

00:07:36.849 --> 00:07:38.571
in fact, it's downright bleak.

00:07:38.595 --> 00:07:40.999
And it is they who are going to suffer

00:07:42.499 --> 00:07:45.182
the most punishing forms of student debt.

00:07:45.960 --> 00:07:47.111
And it is they,

00:07:47.135 --> 00:07:48.516
curiously and sadly,

00:07:48.540 --> 00:07:52.349
who are marketed most loudly
about this college premium thing.

00:07:53.944 --> 00:07:56.341
That's not just cynical marketing,

00:07:56.365 --> 00:07:57.515
that's cruel.

00:07:59.235 --> 00:08:00.385
So what do we do?

00:08:01.237 --> 00:08:06.846
What if students and parents treated
higher education as a consumer product?

00:08:08.157 --> 00:08:09.696
Everybody else seems to.

00:08:10.644 --> 00:08:12.906
Then, like any other consumer product,

00:08:12.930 --> 00:08:15.429
you would demand to know
what you're paying for.

00:08:15.453 --> 00:08:16.668
When you buy medicines,

00:08:16.692 --> 00:08:18.607
you get a list of side effects.

00:08:18.631 --> 00:08:20.743
When you buy a higher educational product,

00:08:20.767 --> 00:08:22.401
you should have a warning label

00:08:22.425 --> 00:08:24.617
that allows consumers to choose,

00:08:24.641 --> 00:08:26.020
make informed choices.

00:08:26.796 --> 00:08:27.988
When you buy a car,

00:08:28.012 --> 00:08:30.623
it tells you how many
miles per gallon to expect.

00:08:31.146 --> 00:08:32.592
Who knows what to expect

00:08:32.616 --> 00:08:36.330
from a degree say, in Canadian Studies.

00:08:36.764 --> 00:08:38.423
There is such a thing, by the way.

00:08:40.947 --> 00:08:43.002
What if there was an app for that?

00:08:46.360 --> 00:08:51.228
One that linked up the cost of a major
to the expected income.

00:08:52.166 --> 00:08:54.532
Let's call it Income-Based Tuition or IBT.

00:08:54.556 --> 00:08:56.078
One of you make this.

00:08:56.102 --> 00:08:57.641
(Laughter)

00:08:57.665 --> 00:08:59.397
Discover your reality.

00:08:59.421 --> 00:09:01.730
(Laughter)

00:09:01.754 --> 00:09:03.183
There are three advantages,

00:09:03.207 --> 00:09:05.888
three benefits to Income-Based Tuition.

00:09:07.190 --> 00:09:09.079
Any user can figure out

00:09:09.103 --> 00:09:12.307
how much money he or she will make
from a given college and major.

00:09:13.063 --> 00:09:14.405
Such informed users

00:09:14.429 --> 00:09:18.374
are unlikely to fall victim
to the huckster's ploy,

00:09:18.398 --> 00:09:19.808
to the sales pitch.

00:09:19.832 --> 00:09:21.538
But also to choose wisely.

00:09:21.562 --> 00:09:23.964
Why would anybody pay more for college

00:09:23.988 --> 00:09:27.014
than let's say, 15 percent
of the additional income they earn?

00:09:28.998 --> 00:09:31.714
There's a second benefit
to Income-Based Tuition.

00:09:31.738 --> 00:09:34.698
By tying the cost to the income,

00:09:34.722 --> 00:09:39.143
college administrators would be forced
to manage costs better,

00:09:39.167 --> 00:09:41.507
to find innovative ways to do so.

00:09:41.531 --> 00:09:42.685
For instance,

00:09:42.709 --> 00:09:46.769
all of you students here pay roughly
the same tuition for every major.

00:09:47.436 --> 00:09:51.483
That is manifestly unfair,
and should change.

00:09:52.253 --> 00:09:56.174
An engineering student uses more resources

00:09:56.198 --> 00:09:58.607
and facilities and labs and faculty

00:09:58.631 --> 00:10:00.309
than a philosophy student.

00:10:01.539 --> 00:10:03.643
But the philosophy student,
as a consequence,

00:10:03.667 --> 00:10:05.857
is subsidizing the engineering student.

00:10:06.258 --> 00:10:08.949
Who then, by the way,
goes on and earns more money.

00:10:08.973 --> 00:10:12.680
Why should two people
buy the same product,

00:10:12.704 --> 00:10:13.879
pay the same,

00:10:13.903 --> 00:10:16.680
but one person receive
half or a third of the service.

00:10:18.406 --> 00:10:22.477
In fact, college grads, some majors,

00:10:22.501 --> 00:10:26.121
pay 25 percent of their income
servicing their student debt,

00:10:26.145 --> 00:10:27.818
while others pay five percent.

00:10:29.468 --> 00:10:33.984
That kind if inequity would end
when majors are priced more correctly.

00:10:35.000 --> 00:10:37.159
Now of course, all this data --

00:10:37.183 --> 00:10:39.257
and one of you is going to do this, right?

00:10:39.281 --> 00:10:41.128
All this data has to be well designed,

00:10:41.152 --> 00:10:43.250
maybe audited by public accounting firms

00:10:43.274 --> 00:10:45.226
to avoid statistical lies.

00:10:45.250 --> 00:10:47.095
We know about statistics, right?

00:10:48.724 --> 00:10:49.947
But be that as it may,

00:10:49.971 --> 00:10:54.352
the third and biggest benefit
of Income-Based Tuition,

00:10:54.376 --> 00:10:59.805
is it would free Americans from the fear
and the fact of financial ruin

00:10:59.829 --> 00:11:01.995
because they bought a defective product.

00:11:02.771 --> 00:11:05.090
Perhaps, in time,

00:11:05.114 --> 00:11:07.362
young and old Americans may rediscover,

00:11:07.386 --> 00:11:09.583
as the gentleman said earlier,

00:11:09.607 --> 00:11:11.646
their curiosity, their love of learning --

00:11:11.670 --> 00:11:13.107
begin to study what they love,

00:11:13.131 --> 00:11:14.310
love what they study,

00:11:14.334 --> 00:11:15.717
follow their passion ...

00:11:16.535 --> 00:11:19.004
getting stimulated by their intelligence,

00:11:19.028 --> 00:11:22.465
follow paths of inquiry
that they really want to.

00:11:22.806 --> 00:11:27.256
After all, it was Eric and Kevin,

00:11:27.280 --> 00:11:28.448
two years ago,

00:11:29.456 --> 00:11:32.888
just exactly these kinds of young men,

00:11:32.912 --> 00:11:34.934
who prompted me and worked with me,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.519
and still do,

00:11:36.543 --> 00:11:40.229
in the study of indebted
students in America.

00:11:41.230 --> 00:11:42.761
Thank you for your attention.

00:11:42.785 --> 00:11:47.349
(Applause)

title: A highly scientific taxonomy of haters
transcript: I'm an Iranian-American Muslim female, like all of you. And I'm also a social justice comedian, something that I insist is an actual job.To explain what that is, let me tell you how I got here. I've performed all over the country. And let me tell you, America is majestic, right? It's got breathtaking nature, waffle houses and diabetes as far as the eye can see. It is really something.Now, the American population can be broken up into three main categories: there's mostly wonderful people, haters and Florida.(Laughter)Besides Florida, the most troubling category here are the Haters. They are a minority, but they overcompensate by being extra loud. They have the Napoleon complex of demographics, and yes, some of the men do wear heels.As a social justice comedian, it's my goal to convert these haters, because they hate a lot of things, which leads to negative outcomes, like racism, violence and Ted Nugent. This is not an exhaustive list; I'm probably missing 3-7 items.But the point is, we have to reckon with the haters. But there's variance within this group and it's not efficient to go after all of them, right? So what I've done is created a highly scientific Taxonomy of Haters. I basically took all of the haters, I put them in a petri dish, like a scientist, and this is what I found.(Laughter)First off, we have the trolls. These are your garden-variety digital haters. They're the people who quit their jobs so they can post on YouTube videos all day long. There's also the drive-by haters. Now, these people will be at a stoplight, they'll wait for the light to turn green and when it does, they yell, "Go back to your own country!" Now back in the day, they would've actually gotten out of their cars and hated you to your face. But they just don't make them like they used to — which is another sign of the decline in America.(Laughter)The next category is the mission-oriented-bigot- whose-group-affiliation- gives-them-cover-for-hating hater. These guys like to hate via a seemingly nice organization, like a church or a nonprofit, and they oftentimes like to speak in an old-timey voice.But the group I'm most interested in is the swing hater. The swing hater is sister to the swing voter — they just can't decide! They're like ideological sluts who move from hating to not hating. And they do it because they don't have enough information. This is the group I like to target with social justice comedy. Why comedy? Because on a scale of comedy to brochure, the average American prefers comedy, as you can see from this graph.(Laughter)Comedy is very popular. And by the way, this is a mathematically accurate graph, generated from fake numbers.(Laughter)Now, the question is: Why does social justice comedy work? Because, first off, it makes you laugh. And when you're laughing, you enter into a state of openness. And in that moment of openness, a good social justice comedian can stick in a whole bunch of information, and if they're really skilled, a rectal exam.(Laughter)Here are some ground rules for social justice comedy: first off, it's not partisan. This isn't political comedy, this is about justice, and no one is against justice. Two, it's inviting and warm, it makes you feel like you're sitting inside of a burrito. Three, it's funny but sneaky, like you could be hearing an interesting treatise on income inequality, that's encased in a really sophisticated poop joke.(Laughter)Here's how I see social justice comedy working. A few years ago, I rounded up a bunch of Muslim-American comedians — in a non-violent way —(Laughter)And we went around the country to places like Alabama, Arizona, Tennessee, Georgia — places where they love the Muzzies — and we did stand-up shows. We called the tour "The Muslims Are Coming!"(Laughter)We turned this into a movie, and then after the movie came out, a known hate group spent 300,000 dollars on an anti-Muslim poster campaign with the MTA — that's the New York City subway system. Now, the posters were truly offensive, not to mentioned poorly designed — I mean, if you're going to be bigoted, you might as well use a better font.(Laughter)But we decided, why not launch our own poster campaign that says nice things about Muslims, while promoting the movie. So myself and fellow comedian Dean Obeidallah decided to launch the fighting-bigotry- with-delightful-posters campaign. We raised the money, worked with the MTA for over 5 months, got the posters approved, and two days after they were supposed to go up, the MTA decided to ban the posters, citing political content.Let's take a look at a couple of those posters. Here's one. Facts about Muslims: Muslims invented the concept of a hospital. OK. Fact: Grown-up Muslims can do more push-ups than baby Muslims.(Laughter)Fact: Muslims invented Justin Timberlake.(Laughter)Let's take a look at another one. The ugly truth about Muslims: they have great frittata recipes.Now clearly, frittatas are considered political by the MTA. Either that, or the mere mention of Muslims in a positive light was considered political — but it isn't. It's about justice. So we decided to change our fighting-bigortry- with-delightful-posters campaign and turn it into the fighting-bigotry- with-a-delightful-lawsuit campaign.(Laughter)So basically, what I'm saying is a couple of dirt-bag comedians took on a major New York City agency and the comedians won.(Applause and cheers)Thank you. Victory was a very weird feeling. I was like, "Is this what blonde girls feel like all the time? 'Cause this is amazing!"(Laughter)Here's another example. I'm asked everywhere I go: "Why don't Muslims denounce terrorism?" We do. But OK, I'll take the bait. So I decided to launch thedailydenouncer.com. It's a website that denounces terrorism every day of the week, while taking the weekends off. Let's take a look at an example. They generally appear as single-panel cartoons, "I denounce terrorism! I also denounce people who never fill the paper tray!" The point of the website is that it denounces terrorism while recognizing that it's ridiculous that we have to constantly denounce terrorism.But if bigotry isn't your thing, social justice comedy is useful for all sorts of issues. For example, myself and fellow comedian Lee Camp went to the Cayman Islands to investigate offshore banking. Now, the United States loses something like 300 billion dollars a year in these offshore tax havens. Not to brag, but at the end of every month, I have something like 5-15 dollars in disposable income. So we walked into these banks in the Cayman Islands and asked if we could open up a bank account with eight dollars and 27 cents.(Laughter)The bank managers would indulge us for 30-45 seconds before calling security. Security would come out, brandish their weapons, and then we would squeal with fear and run away, because — and this is the last rule of social justice comedy — sometimes it makes you want to take a dump in your pants.Most of my work is meant to be fun. It's meant to generate a connection and laughter. But yes, sometimes I get run off the grounds by security. Sometimes I get mean tweets and hate mail. Sometimes I get voice mails saying that if I continue telling my jokes, they'll kill me and they'll kill my family. And those death threats are definitely not funny.But despite the occasional danger, I still think that social justice comedy is one of our best weapons. I mean, we've tried a lot of approaches to social justice, like war and competitive ice dancing. But still, a lot of things are still kind of awful. So I think it's time we try and tell a really good poop joke.Thank you.(Applause)

Now, the American population
can be broken up

00:00:40.005 --> 00:00:41.546
into three main categories:

00:00:41.570 --> 00:00:43.308
there's mostly wonderful people,

00:00:43.332 --> 00:00:44.483
haters

00:00:44.507 --> 00:00:45.658
and Florida.

00:00:45.682 --> 00:00:47.265
(Laughter)

00:00:47.289 --> 00:00:50.603
Besides Florida, the most troubling
category here are the Haters.

00:00:50.627 --> 00:00:52.816
They are a minority,

00:00:52.840 --> 00:00:55.343
but they overcompensate
by being extra loud.

00:00:55.367 --> 00:00:57.676
They have the Napoleon complex
of demographics,

00:00:57.700 --> 00:00:59.768
and yes, some of the men do wear heels.

00:00:59.792 --> 00:01:01.895
As a social justice comedian,

00:01:01.919 --> 00:01:03.787
it's my goal to convert these haters,

00:01:03.811 --> 00:01:07.017
because they hate a lot of things,
which leads to negative outcomes,

00:01:07.041 --> 00:01:10.652
like racism, violence and Ted Nugent.

00:01:11.358 --> 00:01:13.240
This is not an exhaustive list;

00:01:13.264 --> 00:01:14.938
I'm probably missing 3-7 items.

00:01:14.962 --> 00:01:16.184
But the point is,

00:01:16.208 --> 00:01:17.937
we have to reckon with the haters.

00:01:17.961 --> 00:01:19.772
But there's variance within this group

00:01:19.796 --> 00:01:22.817
and it's not efficient to go
after all of them, right?

00:01:22.841 --> 00:01:26.354
So what I've done is created
a highly scientific Taxonomy of Haters.

00:01:26.378 --> 00:01:28.101
I basically took all of the haters,

00:01:28.125 --> 00:01:30.971
I put them in a petri dish,
like a scientist,

00:01:30.995 --> 00:01:32.454
and this is what I found.

00:01:32.478 --> 00:01:33.629
(Laughter)

00:01:33.653 --> 00:01:35.947
First off, we have the trolls.

00:01:35.971 --> 00:01:38.354
These are your garden-variety
digital haters.

00:01:38.378 --> 00:01:40.244
They're the people who quit their jobs

00:01:40.268 --> 00:01:43.382
so they can post on YouTube
videos all day long.

00:01:43.406 --> 00:01:46.067
There's also the drive-by haters.

00:01:46.091 --> 00:01:48.383
Now, these people will be at a stoplight,

00:01:48.407 --> 00:01:50.376
they'll wait for the light to turn green

00:01:50.400 --> 00:01:53.222
and when it does, they yell,
"Go back to your own country!"

00:01:53.246 --> 00:01:56.463
Now back in the day, they would've
actually gotten out of their cars

00:01:56.487 --> 00:01:57.779
and hated you to your face.

00:01:57.803 --> 00:02:00.181
But they just don't make them
like they used to --

00:02:00.205 --> 00:02:02.490
which is another sign
of the decline in America.

00:02:02.514 --> 00:02:03.688
(Laughter)

00:02:04.251 --> 00:02:05.402
The next category

00:02:05.426 --> 00:02:08.069
is the mission-oriented-bigot-
whose-group-affiliation-

00:02:08.093 --> 00:02:09.761
gives-them-cover-for-hating hater.

00:02:09.785 --> 00:02:13.323
These guys like to hate
via a seemingly nice organization,

00:02:13.347 --> 00:02:15.520
like a church or a nonprofit,

00:02:15.544 --> 00:02:18.258
and they oftentimes like to speak
in an old-timey voice.

00:02:18.282 --> 00:02:22.822
But the group I'm most
interested in is the swing hater.

00:02:22.846 --> 00:02:26.433
The swing hater is sister
to the swing voter --

00:02:26.457 --> 00:02:28.186
they just can't decide!

00:02:28.210 --> 00:02:30.088
They're like ideological sluts

00:02:30.112 --> 00:02:32.102
who move from hating to not hating.

00:02:32.126 --> 00:02:34.881
And they do it because they don't have
enough information.

00:02:34.905 --> 00:02:37.883
This is the group I like to target
with social justice comedy.

00:02:37.907 --> 00:02:39.217
Why comedy?

00:02:39.241 --> 00:02:41.770
Because on a scale of comedy to brochure,

00:02:41.794 --> 00:02:45.492
the average American prefers comedy,
as you can see from this graph.

00:02:45.516 --> 00:02:46.667
(Laughter)

00:02:46.691 --> 00:02:48.051
Comedy is very popular.

00:02:48.075 --> 00:02:49.226
And by the way,

00:02:49.250 --> 00:02:51.196
this is a mathematically accurate graph,

00:02:51.220 --> 00:02:52.744
generated from fake numbers.

00:02:52.768 --> 00:02:54.245
(Laughter)

00:02:54.269 --> 00:02:55.454
Now, the question is:

00:02:55.478 --> 00:02:58.263
Why does social justice comedy work?

00:02:58.287 --> 00:03:00.986
Because, first off, it makes you laugh.

00:03:01.010 --> 00:03:04.172
And when you're laughing,
you enter into a state of openness.

00:03:04.196 --> 00:03:05.754
And in that moment of openness,

00:03:05.778 --> 00:03:09.442
a good social justice comedian
can stick in a whole bunch of information,

00:03:09.466 --> 00:03:10.996
and if they're really skilled,

00:03:11.020 --> 00:03:12.171
a rectal exam.

00:03:12.195 --> 00:03:14.728
(Laughter)

00:03:14.752 --> 00:03:17.953
Here are some ground rules
for social justice comedy:

00:03:17.977 --> 00:03:19.936
first off, it's not partisan.

00:03:19.960 --> 00:03:22.501
This isn't political comedy,
this is about justice,

00:03:22.525 --> 00:03:24.222
and no one is against justice.

00:03:24.246 --> 00:03:26.239
Two, it's inviting and warm,

00:03:26.263 --> 00:03:29.024
it makes you feel like you're sitting
inside of a burrito.

00:03:29.048 --> 00:03:31.453
Three, it's funny but sneaky,

00:03:31.477 --> 00:03:34.273
like you could be hearing
an interesting treatise

00:03:34.297 --> 00:03:35.511
on income inequality,

00:03:35.535 --> 00:03:38.449
that's encased in a really
sophisticated poop joke.

00:03:38.473 --> 00:03:40.092
(Laughter)

00:03:40.116 --> 00:03:43.139
Here's how I see
social justice comedy working.

00:03:43.163 --> 00:03:46.461
A few years ago, I rounded up a bunch
of Muslim-American comedians --

00:03:46.485 --> 00:03:47.651
in a non-violent way --

00:03:47.675 --> 00:03:49.199
(Laughter)

00:03:49.223 --> 00:03:50.695
And we went around the country

00:03:50.719 --> 00:03:53.656
to places like Alabama, Arizona,
Tennessee, Georgia --

00:03:53.680 --> 00:03:55.879
places where they love the Muzzies --

00:03:55.903 --> 00:03:58.591
and we did stand-up shows.

00:03:58.615 --> 00:04:00.929
We called the tour
"The Muslims Are Coming!"

00:04:00.953 --> 00:04:03.218
(Laughter)

00:04:03.242 --> 00:04:04.948
We turned this into a movie,

00:04:04.972 --> 00:04:07.196
and then after the movie came out,

00:04:07.220 --> 00:04:10.623
a known hate group spent 300,000 dollars

00:04:10.647 --> 00:04:12.768
on an anti-Muslim poster campaign

00:04:12.792 --> 00:04:15.663
with the MTA -- that's
the New York City subway system.

00:04:15.687 --> 00:04:17.533
Now, the posters were truly offensive,

00:04:17.557 --> 00:04:19.318
not to mentioned poorly designed --

00:04:19.342 --> 00:04:21.176
I mean, if you're going to be bigoted,

00:04:21.200 --> 00:04:22.952
you might as well use a better font.

00:04:22.976 --> 00:04:23.977
(Laughter)

00:04:24.001 --> 00:04:27.953
But we decided, why not launch
our own poster campaign

00:04:27.977 --> 00:04:29.851
that says nice things about Muslims,

00:04:29.875 --> 00:04:31.122
while promoting the movie.

00:04:31.146 --> 00:04:33.271
So myself and fellow comedian
Dean Obeidallah

00:04:33.295 --> 00:04:36.791
decided to launch the fighting-bigotry-
with-delightful-posters campaign.

00:04:36.815 --> 00:04:40.565
We raised the money, worked
with the MTA for over 5 months,

00:04:40.589 --> 00:04:41.900
got the posters approved,

00:04:41.924 --> 00:04:44.803
and two days after they
were supposed to go up,

00:04:44.827 --> 00:04:47.974
the MTA decided to ban the posters,

00:04:47.998 --> 00:04:49.834
citing political content.

00:04:49.858 --> 00:04:52.091
Let's take a look
at a couple of those posters.

00:04:52.115 --> 00:04:53.409
Here's one.

00:04:53.433 --> 00:04:54.647
Facts about Muslims:

00:04:54.671 --> 00:04:56.768
Muslims invented
the concept of a hospital.

00:04:56.792 --> 00:04:57.943
OK.

00:04:57.967 --> 00:05:01.974
Fact: Grown-up Muslims can do
more push-ups than baby Muslims.

00:05:01.998 --> 00:05:03.537
(Laughter)

00:05:03.561 --> 00:05:06.409
Fact: Muslims invented Justin Timberlake.

00:05:06.433 --> 00:05:07.512
(Laughter)

00:05:07.536 --> 00:05:09.418
Let's take a look at another one.

00:05:09.442 --> 00:05:10.871
The ugly truth about Muslims:

00:05:10.895 --> 00:05:13.483
they have great frittata recipes.

00:05:13.507 --> 00:05:18.014
Now clearly, frittatas are considered
political by the MTA.

00:05:18.038 --> 00:05:21.495
Either that, or the mere mention
of Muslims in a positive light

00:05:21.519 --> 00:05:23.543
was considered political -- but it isn't.

00:05:23.567 --> 00:05:24.820
It's about justice.

00:05:24.844 --> 00:05:26.003
So we decided to change

00:05:26.027 --> 00:05:28.635
our fighting-bigortry-
with-delightful-posters campaign

00:05:28.659 --> 00:05:32.138
and turn it into the fighting-bigotry-
with-a-delightful-lawsuit campaign.

00:05:32.182 --> 00:05:33.797
(Laughter)

00:05:33.821 --> 00:05:36.785
So basically, what I'm saying
is a couple of dirt-bag comedians

00:05:36.809 --> 00:05:39.340
took on a major New York City agency

00:05:39.364 --> 00:05:40.904
and the comedians won.

00:05:40.928 --> 00:05:43.504
(Applause and cheers)

00:05:43.528 --> 00:05:44.679
Thank you.

00:05:44.703 --> 00:05:46.426
Victory was a very weird feeling.

00:05:46.450 --> 00:05:49.386
I was like, "Is this what
blonde girls feel like all the time?

00:05:49.410 --> 00:05:50.729
'Cause this is amazing!"

00:05:50.753 --> 00:05:52.753
(Laughter)

00:05:53.660 --> 00:05:55.151
Here's another example.

00:05:55.957 --> 00:05:59.186
I'm asked everywhere I go:
"Why don't Muslims denounce terrorism?"

00:05:59.210 --> 00:06:01.401
We do. But OK, I'll take the bait.

00:06:01.425 --> 00:06:04.071
So I decided to launch
thedailydenouncer.com.

00:06:04.095 --> 00:06:07.055
It's a website that denounces
terrorism every day of the week,

00:06:07.079 --> 00:06:08.560
while taking the weekends off.

00:06:08.584 --> 00:06:10.942
Let's take a look at an example.

00:06:10.966 --> 00:06:13.363
They generally appear
as single-panel cartoons,

00:06:13.387 --> 00:06:17.806
"I denounce terrorism! I also denounce
people who never fill the paper tray!"

00:06:17.830 --> 00:06:20.645
The point of the website
is that it denounces terrorism

00:06:20.669 --> 00:06:22.805
while recognizing that it's ridiculous

00:06:22.829 --> 00:06:25.590
that we have to constantly
denounce terrorism.

00:06:25.614 --> 00:06:27.865
But if bigotry isn't your thing,

00:06:27.889 --> 00:06:31.280
social justice comedy is useful
for all sorts of issues.

00:06:31.304 --> 00:06:34.195
For example, myself and fellow
comedian Lee Camp

00:06:34.219 --> 00:06:37.684
went to the Cayman Islands
to investigate offshore banking.

00:06:37.708 --> 00:06:42.613
Now, the United States loses
something like 300 billion dollars a year

00:06:42.637 --> 00:06:44.462
in these offshore tax havens.

00:06:44.486 --> 00:06:45.740
Not to brag,

00:06:45.764 --> 00:06:47.232
but at the end of every month,

00:06:47.256 --> 00:06:49.900
I have something like 5-15 dollars
in disposable income.

00:06:49.924 --> 00:06:52.396
So we walked into these banks
in the Cayman Islands

00:06:52.420 --> 00:06:54.576
and asked if we could
open up a bank account

00:06:54.600 --> 00:06:56.646
with eight dollars and 27 cents.

00:06:56.670 --> 00:06:58.473
(Laughter)

00:06:58.497 --> 00:07:03.928
The bank managers would indulge us
for 30-45 seconds before calling security.

00:07:03.952 --> 00:07:06.524
Security would come out,
brandish their weapons,

00:07:06.548 --> 00:07:09.318
and then we would squeal
with fear and run away,

00:07:09.342 --> 00:07:12.371
because -- and this is the last
rule of social justice comedy --

00:07:12.395 --> 00:07:15.109
sometimes it makes you want
to take a dump in your pants.

00:07:15.133 --> 00:07:17.980
Most of my work is meant to be fun.

00:07:18.004 --> 00:07:21.091
It's meant to generate
a connection and laughter.

00:07:21.115 --> 00:07:24.447
But yes, sometimes I get
run off the grounds by security.

00:07:24.471 --> 00:07:27.438
Sometimes I get mean tweets and hate mail.

00:07:27.462 --> 00:07:32.337
Sometimes I get voice mails saying
that if I continue telling my jokes,

00:07:32.361 --> 00:07:35.423
they'll kill me
and they'll kill my family.

00:07:35.447 --> 00:07:39.221
And those death threats
are definitely not funny.

00:07:39.245 --> 00:07:41.379
But despite the occasional danger,

00:07:41.403 --> 00:07:45.303
I still think that social justice comedy
is one of our best weapons.

00:07:45.327 --> 00:07:48.382
I mean, we've tried
a lot of approaches to social justice,

00:07:48.406 --> 00:07:50.928
like war and competitive ice dancing.

00:07:50.952 --> 00:07:54.802
But still, a lot of things
are still kind of awful.

00:07:55.223 --> 00:07:58.465
So I think it's time we try and tell
a really good poop joke.

00:07:58.991 --> 00:08:00.142
Thank you.

00:08:00.166 --> 00:08:04.458
(Applause)

title: 3 reasons why we can win the fight against poverty
transcript: I've been living in rural East Africa for about 10 years, and I want to share a field perspective with you on global poverty. I believe that the greatest failure of the human race is the fact that we've left more than one billion of our members behind. Hungry, extreme poverty: these often seem like gigantic, insurmountable problems, too big to solve. But as a field practitioner, I believe these are actually very solvable problems if we just take the right strategies.Archimedes was an ancient Greek thinker, and he taught us that if we lean on the right levers, we can move the world. In the fight against extreme poverty, I believe there are three powerful levers that we can lean on. This talk is all about those levers, and why they make poverty a winnable fight in our lifetimes.What is extreme poverty? When I first moved to rural East Africa, I stayed overnight with a farm family. They were wonderful people. They invited me into their home. We sang songs together and ate a simple dinner. They gave me a blanket to sleep on the floor. In the morning, however, there was nothing to eat. And then at lunchtime, I watched with an increasingly sick feeling as the eldest girl in the family cooked porridge as a substitute for lunch. For that meal, every child drank one cup to survive. And I cannot tell you how ashamed I felt when they handed one of those cups to me, and I knew I had to accept their hospitality.Children need food not only to survive but also to grow physically and mentally. Every day they fail to eat, they lose a little bit of their future. Amongst the extreme poor, one in three children are permanently stunted from a lifetime of not eating enough. When that's combined with poor access to health care, one in 10 extremely poor children die before they reach age five. And only one quarter of children complete high school because they lack school fees. Hunger and extreme poverty curb human potential in every possible way. We see ourselves as a thinking, feeling and moral human race, but until we solve these problems for all of our members, we fail that standard, because every person on this planet matters. This child matters. These children matter. This girl matters.You know, we see things like this, and we're upset by them, but they seem like such big problems. We don't know how to take effective action. But remember our friend Archimedes. Global poverty has powerful levers. It's a problem like any other. I live and work in the field, and as a practitioner, I believe these are very solvable problems. So for the next 10 minutes, let's not be sad about the state of the world. Let's engage our brains. Let's engage our collective passion for problem-solving and figure out what those levers are.Lever number one: most of the world's poor are farmers. Think about how extraordinary this is. If this picture represents the world's poor, then more than half engage in farming as a major source of income. This gets me really excited. All of these people, one profession. Think how powerful this is. When farmers become more productive, then more than half the world's poor earn more money and climb out of poverty. And it gets better. The product of farming is, of course, food. So when farmers become more productive, they earn more food, and they don't just help themselves, but they help to feed healthy communities and thriving economies. And when farmers become more productive, they reduce environmental pressure. We only have two ways we can feed the world: we can either make our existing farmland a lot more productive, or we can clear cut forest and savannah to make more farmland, which would be environmentally disastrous. Farmers are basically a really important leverage point. When farmers become more productive, they earn more income, they climb out of poverty, they feed their communities and they reduce environmental land pressure. Farmers stand at the center of the world.And not a farmer like this one, but rather this lady. Most of the farmers I know are actually women. Look at the strength and the will radiating from this woman. She is physically strong, mentally tough, and she will do whatever it takes to earn a better life for her children. If we're going to put the future of humanity in one person's hands, then I'm really glad it's her.(Applause)There's just one problem: many smallholder farmers lack access to basic tools and knowledge. Currently, they take a little bit of saved food grain from the prior year, they plant it in the ground and they till it with a manual hand hoe. These are tools and techniques that date to the Bronze Age, and it's why many farmers are still very poor.But good news, again. Lever number two: humanity actually solved the problem of agricultural poverty a century ago. Let me walk you through the three most basic factors in farming. First, hybrid seed is created when you cross two seeds together. If you naturally pollinate a high-yielding variety together with a drought-resistant variety, you get a hybrid that inherits positive traits from both of its parents. Next, conventional fertilizer, if used responsibly, is environmentally sustainable. If you micro-dose just a pinch of fertilizer to a plant that's taller than I am, you unlock enormous yield gain. These are known as farm inputs. Farm inputs need to be combined with good practice. When you space your seeds and plant with massive amounts of compost, farmers multiply their harvests. These proven tools and practices have more than tripled agricultural productivity in every major region of the world, moving mass numbers of people out of poverty. We just haven't finished delivering these things to everybody just yet, particularly in Sub-Saharan Africa.So overall, this is amazing news. Humanity actually solved agricultural poverty a century ago, in theory. We just haven't delivered these things to everybody just yet. In this century, the reason that people remain poor is because maybe they live in remote places. They lack access to these things. Therefore, ending poverty is simply a matter of delivering proven goods and services to people. We don't need more genius types right now. The humble delivery guy is going to end global poverty in our lifetime.So these are the three levers, and the most powerful lever is simply delivery. Wherever the world's companies, governments and nonprofits set up delivery networks for life-improving goods, we eliminate poverty.OK, so that sounds really nice in theory, but what about in practice? What do these delivery networks look like? I want to share the concrete example that I know best, my organization, One Acre Fund. We only serve the farmer, and our job is to provide her with the tools that she needs to succeed. We start off by delivering farm inputs to really rural places. Now, this may appear initially very challenging, but it's pretty possible. Let me show you. We buy farm inputs with the combined power of our farmer network, and store it in 20 warehouses like this. Then, during input delivery, we rent hundreds of 10-ton trucks and send them out to where farmers are waiting in the field. They then get their individual orders and walk it home to their farms. It's kind of like Amazon for rural farmers. Importantly, realistic delivery also includes finance, a way to pay. Farmers pay us little by little over time, covering most of our expenses. And then we surround all that with training. Our rural field officers deliver practical, hands-on training to farmers in the field every two weeks.Wherever we deliver our services, farmers use these tools to climb out of poverty. This is a farmer in our program, Consolata. Look at the pride on her face. She has achieved a modest prosperity that I believe is the human right of every hardworking person on the planet. Today, I'm proud to say that we're serving about 400,000 farmers like Consolata.(Applause)The key to doing this is scalable delivery. In any given area, we hire a rural field officer who delivers our services to 200 farmers, on average, with more than 1,000 people living in those families. Today, we have 2,000 of these rural field officers growing very quickly. This is our delivery army, and we're just one organization. There are many companies, governments and nonprofits that have delivery armies just like this. And I believe we stand at a moment in time where collectively, we are capable of delivering farm services to all farmers.Let me show you how possible this is. This is a map of Sub-Saharan Africa, with a map of the United States for scale. I chose Sub-Saharan Africa because this is a huge delivery territory. It's very challenging. But we analyzed every 50-mile by 50-mile block on the continent, and we found that half of farmers live in just these shaded regions. That's a remarkably small area overall. If you were to lay these boxes next to each other within a map of the United States, they would only cover the Eastern United States. You can order pizza anywhere in this territory and it'll arrive to your house hot, fresh and delicious. If America can deliver pizza to an area of this size, then Africa's companies, governments and non-profits can deliver farm services to all of her farmers. This is possible.I'm going to wrap up by generalizing beyond just farming. In every field of human development, humanity has already invented effective tools to end poverty. We just need to deliver them. So again, in every area of human development, super-smart people a long time ago invented inexpensive, highly effective tools. Humanity is armed to the teeth with simple, effective solutions to poverty. We just need to deliver these to a pretty small area. Again using the map of Sub-Saharan Africa as an example, remember that rural poverty is concentrated in these blue shaded areas. Urban poverty is even more concentrated, in these green little dots. Again, using a map of the United States for scale, this is what I would call a highly achievable delivery zone. In fact, for the first time in human history, we have a vast amount of delivery infrastructure available to us. The world's companies, governments and non-profits have delivery armies that are fully capable of covering this relatively small area. We just lack the will.If we are willing, every one of us has a role to play. We first need more people to pursue careers in human development, especially if you live in a developing nation. We need more front line health workers, teachers, farmer trainers, sales agents for life-improving goods. These are the delivery people that dedicate their careers to improving the lives of others. But we also need a lot of support roles. These are roles available at just my organization alone, and we're just one out of many. This may surprise you, but no matter what your technical specialty, there is a role for you in this fight. And no matter how logistically possible it is to end poverty, we need a lot more resources. This is our number one constraint. For private investors, we need a big expansion of venture capital, private equity, working capital, available in emerging markets. But there are also limits to what private business can accomplish. Private businesses often struggle to profitably serve the extreme poor, so philanthropy still has a major role to play. Anybody can give, but we need more leadership. We need more visionary philanthropists and global leaders who will take problems in human development and lead humanity to wipe them off the face of the planet. If you're interested in these ideas, check out this website.We need more leaders. Humanity has put people on the moon. We've invented supercomputers that fit into our pockets and connect us with anybody on the planet. We've run marathons at a five-minute mile pace. We are an exceptional people. But we've left more than one billion of our members behind. Until every girl like this one has an opportunity to earn her full human potential, we have failed to become a truly moral and just human race. Logistically speaking, it's incredibly possible to end extreme poverty. We just need to deliver proven goods and services to everybody. If we have the will, every one of us has a role to play. Let's deploy our time, our careers, our collective wealth. Let us deliver an end to extreme poverty in this lifetime.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.124 --> 00:00:16.194
I've been living in rural East Africa
for about 10 years,

00:00:16.218 --> 00:00:19.398
and I want to share a field perspective
with you on global poverty.

00:00:19.892 --> 00:00:22.466
I believe that the greatest failure
of the human race

00:00:22.490 --> 00:00:25.896
is the fact that we've left more than
one billion of our members behind.

00:00:26.293 --> 00:00:28.635
Hungry, extreme poverty:

00:00:28.659 --> 00:00:31.947
these often seem like gigantic,
insurmountable problems,

00:00:31.971 --> 00:00:33.404
too big to solve.

00:00:33.964 --> 00:00:35.673
But as a field practitioner,

00:00:35.697 --> 00:00:38.501
I believe these are actually
very solvable problems

00:00:38.525 --> 00:00:40.966
if we just take the right strategies.

00:00:42.348 --> 00:00:44.463
Archimedes was an ancient Greek thinker,

00:00:44.487 --> 00:00:46.971
and he taught us that if we lean
on the right levers,

00:00:46.995 --> 00:00:48.405
we can move the world.

00:00:48.917 --> 00:00:52.633
In the fight against extreme poverty,
I believe there are three powerful levers

00:00:52.657 --> 00:00:54.030
that we can lean on.

00:00:54.054 --> 00:00:57.056
This talk is all about those levers,
and why they make poverty

00:00:57.080 --> 00:00:59.165
a winnable fight in our lifetimes.

00:00:59.952 --> 00:01:01.354
What is extreme poverty?

00:01:02.245 --> 00:01:04.190
When I first moved to rural East Africa,

00:01:04.214 --> 00:01:06.114
I stayed overnight with a farm family.

00:01:06.587 --> 00:01:08.687
They were wonderful people.

00:01:08.711 --> 00:01:11.583
They invited me into their home.
We sang songs together

00:01:11.607 --> 00:01:12.758
and ate a simple dinner.

00:01:12.782 --> 00:01:14.886
They gave me a blanket
to sleep on the floor.

00:01:15.317 --> 00:01:17.696
In the morning, however,
there was nothing to eat.

00:01:18.223 --> 00:01:21.660
And then at lunchtime, I watched
with an increasingly sick feeling

00:01:21.999 --> 00:01:26.091
as the eldest girl in the family
cooked porridge as a substitute for lunch.

00:01:26.661 --> 00:01:30.865
For that meal, every child
drank one cup to survive.

00:01:31.533 --> 00:01:33.523
And I cannot tell you how ashamed I felt

00:01:33.547 --> 00:01:35.510
when they handed one of those cups to me,

00:01:35.534 --> 00:01:38.006
and I knew I had to accept
their hospitality.

00:01:38.739 --> 00:01:42.719
Children need food not only to survive
but also to grow physically and mentally.

00:01:43.223 --> 00:01:46.389
Every day they fail to eat,
they lose a little bit of their future.

00:01:47.072 --> 00:01:49.954
Amongst the extreme poor,
one in three children

00:01:49.978 --> 00:01:53.578
are permanently stunted
from a lifetime of not eating enough.

00:01:54.284 --> 00:01:56.796
When that's combined
with poor access to health care,

00:01:56.820 --> 00:02:01.280
one in 10 extremely poor children
die before they reach age five.

00:02:01.777 --> 00:02:04.314
And only one quarter of children
complete high school

00:02:04.338 --> 00:02:05.842
because they lack school fees.

00:02:05.866 --> 00:02:11.638
Hunger and extreme poverty curb
human potential in every possible way.

00:02:12.729 --> 00:02:17.019
We see ourselves as a thinking,
feeling and moral human race,

00:02:17.043 --> 00:02:20.078
but until we solve these problems
for all of our members,

00:02:20.102 --> 00:02:21.787
we fail that standard,

00:02:22.290 --> 00:02:24.632
because every person
on this planet matters.

00:02:24.656 --> 00:02:26.448
This child matters.

00:02:27.083 --> 00:02:28.842
These children matter.

00:02:29.596 --> 00:02:31.400
This girl matters.

00:02:32.167 --> 00:02:33.856
You know, we see things like this,

00:02:33.880 --> 00:02:35.457
and we're upset by them,

00:02:35.481 --> 00:02:37.283
but they seem like such big problems.

00:02:37.307 --> 00:02:40.142
We don't know how
to take effective action.

00:02:40.851 --> 00:02:42.748
But remember our friend Archimedes.

00:02:43.530 --> 00:02:45.858
Global poverty has powerful levers.

00:02:45.882 --> 00:02:47.471
It's a problem like any other.

00:02:47.981 --> 00:02:50.427
I live and work in the field,
and as a practitioner,

00:02:50.451 --> 00:02:53.254
I believe these are very
solvable problems.

00:02:53.278 --> 00:02:54.759
So for the next 10 minutes,

00:02:54.783 --> 00:02:56.937
let's not be sad
about the state of the world.

00:02:56.961 --> 00:02:58.461
Let's engage our brains.

00:02:58.816 --> 00:03:01.561
Let's engage our collective passion
for problem-solving

00:03:01.585 --> 00:03:03.774
and figure out what those levers are.

00:03:04.374 --> 00:03:07.527
Lever number one: most
of the world's poor are farmers.

00:03:08.115 --> 00:03:10.178
Think about how extraordinary this is.

00:03:10.202 --> 00:03:12.663
If this picture represents
the world's poor,

00:03:12.687 --> 00:03:15.992
then more than half engage in farming
as a major source of income.

00:03:16.326 --> 00:03:18.253
This gets me really excited.

00:03:18.277 --> 00:03:20.629
All of these people, one profession.

00:03:21.205 --> 00:03:22.661
Think how powerful this is.

00:03:22.685 --> 00:03:26.203
When farmers become more productive,
then more than half the world's poor

00:03:26.227 --> 00:03:28.631
earn more money and climb out of poverty.

00:03:28.655 --> 00:03:29.875
And it gets better.

00:03:29.899 --> 00:03:32.154
The product of farming
is, of course, food.

00:03:32.178 --> 00:03:35.783
So when farmers become more productive,
they earn more food,

00:03:35.807 --> 00:03:37.528
and they don't just help themselves,

00:03:37.552 --> 00:03:40.778
but they help to feed healthy communities
and thriving economies.

00:03:41.186 --> 00:03:44.759
And when farmers become more productive,
they reduce environmental pressure.

00:03:45.401 --> 00:03:47.683
We only have two ways
we can feed the world:

00:03:47.707 --> 00:03:51.030
we can either make our existing farmland
a lot more productive,

00:03:51.054 --> 00:03:54.334
or we can clear cut forest and savannah
to make more farmland,

00:03:54.358 --> 00:03:56.608
which would be environmentally disastrous.

00:03:57.646 --> 00:04:00.958
Farmers are basically
a really important leverage point.

00:04:01.454 --> 00:04:03.387
When farmers become more productive,

00:04:03.411 --> 00:04:06.022
they earn more income,
they climb out of poverty,

00:04:06.046 --> 00:04:10.121
they feed their communities and they
reduce environmental land pressure.

00:04:10.145 --> 00:04:12.790
Farmers stand at the center of the world.

00:04:14.264 --> 00:04:15.964
And not a farmer like this one,

00:04:15.988 --> 00:04:17.583
but rather this lady.

00:04:18.013 --> 00:04:20.169
Most of the farmers I know
are actually women.

00:04:20.657 --> 00:04:23.929
Look at the strength and the will
radiating from this woman.

00:04:23.953 --> 00:04:26.165
She is physically strong, mentally tough,

00:04:26.189 --> 00:04:29.620
and she will do whatever it takes
to earn a better life for her children.

00:04:29.644 --> 00:04:32.788
If we're going to put the future
of humanity in one person's hands,

00:04:32.812 --> 00:04:34.625
then I'm really glad it's her.

00:04:34.649 --> 00:04:40.059
(Applause)

00:04:40.083 --> 00:04:41.339
There's just one problem:

00:04:41.363 --> 00:04:46.106
many smallholder farmers
lack access to basic tools and knowledge.

00:04:46.706 --> 00:04:50.394
Currently, they take a little bit
of saved food grain from the prior year,

00:04:50.418 --> 00:04:53.798
they plant it in the ground
and they till it with a manual hand hoe.

00:04:53.822 --> 00:04:56.587
These are tools and techniques
that date to the Bronze Age,

00:04:56.611 --> 00:04:59.549
and it's why many farmers
are still very poor.

00:05:00.713 --> 00:05:02.095
But good news, again.

00:05:02.119 --> 00:05:03.270
Lever number two:

00:05:03.294 --> 00:05:07.660
humanity actually solved the problem
of agricultural poverty a century ago.

00:05:08.407 --> 00:05:11.430
Let me walk you through the three
most basic factors in farming.

00:05:11.902 --> 00:05:16.299
First, hybrid seed is created
when you cross two seeds together.

00:05:16.323 --> 00:05:19.127
If you naturally pollinate
a high-yielding variety

00:05:19.151 --> 00:05:21.462
together with a drought-resistant variety,

00:05:21.486 --> 00:05:25.324
you get a hybrid that inherits
positive traits from both of its parents.

00:05:25.348 --> 00:05:29.045
Next, conventional fertilizer,
if used responsibly,

00:05:29.069 --> 00:05:30.868
is environmentally sustainable.

00:05:31.391 --> 00:05:34.385
If you micro-dose
just a pinch of fertilizer

00:05:34.409 --> 00:05:36.493
to a plant that's taller than I am,

00:05:36.517 --> 00:05:38.691
you unlock enormous yield gain.

00:05:39.076 --> 00:05:40.780
These are known as farm inputs.

00:05:41.199 --> 00:05:43.799
Farm inputs need to be combined
with good practice.

00:05:43.823 --> 00:05:47.917
When you space your seeds
and plant with massive amounts of compost,

00:05:47.941 --> 00:05:50.494
farmers multiply their harvests.

00:05:50.904 --> 00:05:53.480
These proven tools and practices
have more than tripled

00:05:53.504 --> 00:05:56.552
agricultural productivity
in every major region of the world,

00:05:56.576 --> 00:05:59.349
moving mass numbers of people
out of poverty.

00:05:59.886 --> 00:06:03.225
We just haven't finished delivering
these things to everybody just yet,

00:06:03.249 --> 00:06:04.990
particularly in Sub-Saharan Africa.

00:06:05.883 --> 00:06:07.605
So overall, this is amazing news.

00:06:07.629 --> 00:06:11.185
Humanity actually solved
agricultural poverty a century ago,

00:06:11.635 --> 00:06:12.842
in theory.

00:06:12.866 --> 00:06:15.790
We just haven't delivered these things
to everybody just yet.

00:06:16.312 --> 00:06:18.699
In this century, the reason
that people remain poor

00:06:18.723 --> 00:06:20.929
is because maybe they live
in remote places.

00:06:20.953 --> 00:06:23.048
They lack access to these things.

00:06:24.112 --> 00:06:26.673
Therefore, ending poverty
is simply a matter

00:06:26.697 --> 00:06:30.119
of delivering proven goods
and services to people.

00:06:30.143 --> 00:06:32.441
We don't need more genius types right now.

00:06:32.465 --> 00:06:36.914
The humble delivery guy is going
to end global poverty in our lifetime.

00:06:38.046 --> 00:06:39.534
So these are the three levers,

00:06:39.558 --> 00:06:42.211
and the most powerful lever
is simply delivery.

00:06:42.991 --> 00:06:46.278
Wherever the world's companies,
governments and nonprofits

00:06:46.302 --> 00:06:49.001
set up delivery networks
for life-improving goods,

00:06:49.358 --> 00:06:51.499
we eliminate poverty.

00:06:51.981 --> 00:06:53.974
OK, so that sounds really nice in theory,

00:06:53.998 --> 00:06:55.288
but what about in practice?

00:06:55.312 --> 00:06:57.314
What do these delivery networks look like?

00:06:57.964 --> 00:07:00.499
I want to share the concrete example
that I know best,

00:07:00.523 --> 00:07:02.434
my organization, One Acre Fund.

00:07:03.123 --> 00:07:04.518
We only serve the farmer,

00:07:04.542 --> 00:07:07.907
and our job is to provide her
with the tools that she needs to succeed.

00:07:08.242 --> 00:07:11.196
We start off by delivering farm inputs
to really rural places.

00:07:11.220 --> 00:07:13.486
Now, this may appear
initially very challenging,

00:07:13.510 --> 00:07:15.721
but it's pretty possible. Let me show you.

00:07:15.745 --> 00:07:18.805
We buy farm inputs with the combined power
of our farmer network,

00:07:18.829 --> 00:07:21.148
and store it in 20 warehouses like this.

00:07:21.596 --> 00:07:25.572
Then, during input delivery,
we rent hundreds of 10-ton trucks

00:07:25.596 --> 00:07:28.434
and send them out to where farmers
are waiting in the field.

00:07:28.911 --> 00:07:32.349
They then get their individual orders
and walk it home to their farms.

00:07:32.373 --> 00:07:34.840
It's kind of like Amazon
for rural farmers.

00:07:35.652 --> 00:07:40.470
Importantly, realistic delivery
also includes finance, a way to pay.

00:07:40.494 --> 00:07:44.947
Farmers pay us little by little over time,
covering most of our expenses.

00:07:45.545 --> 00:07:47.682
And then we surround
all that with training.

00:07:48.109 --> 00:07:51.760
Our rural field officers
deliver practical, hands-on training

00:07:51.784 --> 00:07:53.189
to farmers in the field

00:07:53.213 --> 00:07:54.758
every two weeks.

00:07:55.454 --> 00:07:59.038
Wherever we deliver our services,
farmers use these tools

00:07:59.062 --> 00:08:00.632
to climb out of poverty.

00:08:01.151 --> 00:08:03.575
This is a farmer
in our program, Consolata.

00:08:03.991 --> 00:08:05.834
Look at the pride on her face.

00:08:06.170 --> 00:08:09.828
She has achieved a modest prosperity
that I believe is the human right

00:08:09.852 --> 00:08:12.465
of every hardworking person on the planet.

00:08:13.222 --> 00:08:18.124
Today, I'm proud to say that we're serving
about 400,000 farmers like Consolata.

00:08:18.148 --> 00:08:23.815
(Applause)

00:08:23.839 --> 00:08:26.117
The key to doing this
is scalable delivery.

00:08:26.440 --> 00:08:29.329
In any given area, we hire
a rural field officer

00:08:29.353 --> 00:08:32.509
who delivers our services
to 200 farmers, on average,

00:08:32.533 --> 00:08:35.384
with more than 1,000 people
living in those families.

00:08:35.763 --> 00:08:39.194
Today, we have 2,000
of these rural field officers

00:08:39.218 --> 00:08:40.599
growing very quickly.

00:08:40.623 --> 00:08:42.430
This is our delivery army,

00:08:42.949 --> 00:08:44.616
and we're just one organization.

00:08:44.640 --> 00:08:47.804
There are many companies,
governments and nonprofits

00:08:47.828 --> 00:08:50.039
that have delivery armies just like this.

00:08:50.063 --> 00:08:52.109
And I believe we stand at a moment in time

00:08:52.133 --> 00:08:57.036
where collectively, we are capable of
delivering farm services to all farmers.

00:08:57.713 --> 00:08:59.490
Let me show you how possible this is.

00:08:59.918 --> 00:09:01.787
This is a map of Sub-Saharan Africa,

00:09:01.811 --> 00:09:03.916
with a map of the United States for scale.

00:09:03.940 --> 00:09:07.328
I chose Sub-Saharan Africa because
this is a huge delivery territory.

00:09:07.352 --> 00:09:08.525
It's very challenging.

00:09:09.206 --> 00:09:12.859
But we analyzed every 50-mile
by 50-mile block on the continent,

00:09:13.250 --> 00:09:17.855
and we found that half of farmers
live in just these shaded regions.

00:09:19.223 --> 00:09:21.555
That's a remarkably small area overall.

00:09:22.153 --> 00:09:24.462
If you were to lay these boxes
next to each other

00:09:24.486 --> 00:09:26.122
within a map of the United States,

00:09:26.146 --> 00:09:28.411
they would only cover
the Eastern United States.

00:09:29.242 --> 00:09:32.484
You can order pizza
anywhere in this territory

00:09:32.790 --> 00:09:35.941
and it'll arrive to your house
hot, fresh and delicious.

00:09:36.539 --> 00:09:39.806
If America can deliver pizza
to an area of this size,

00:09:39.830 --> 00:09:42.853
then Africa's companies,
governments and non-profits

00:09:42.877 --> 00:09:45.900
can deliver farm services
to all of her farmers.

00:09:45.924 --> 00:09:47.207
This is possible.

00:09:48.953 --> 00:09:51.706
I'm going to wrap up by generalizing
beyond just farming.

00:09:52.250 --> 00:09:54.357
In every field of human development,

00:09:54.381 --> 00:09:58.210
humanity has already invented
effective tools to end poverty.

00:09:58.234 --> 00:09:59.645
We just need to deliver them.

00:10:00.280 --> 00:10:02.521
So again, in every area
of human development,

00:10:02.545 --> 00:10:05.947
super-smart people a long time ago
invented inexpensive,

00:10:05.971 --> 00:10:07.803
highly effective tools.

00:10:07.827 --> 00:10:09.759
Humanity is armed to the teeth

00:10:09.783 --> 00:10:13.121
with simple, effective
solutions to poverty.

00:10:13.554 --> 00:10:16.326
We just need to deliver these
to a pretty small area.

00:10:17.224 --> 00:10:20.326
Again using the map
of Sub-Saharan Africa as an example,

00:10:20.350 --> 00:10:23.824
remember that rural poverty is
concentrated in these blue shaded areas.

00:10:24.398 --> 00:10:28.282
Urban poverty is even more concentrated,
in these green little dots.

00:10:29.240 --> 00:10:31.756
Again, using a map
of the United States for scale,

00:10:32.275 --> 00:10:35.834
this is what I would call
a highly achievable delivery zone.

00:10:36.304 --> 00:10:38.466
In fact, for the first time
in human history,

00:10:38.490 --> 00:10:41.989
we have a vast amount of delivery
infrastructure available to us.

00:10:42.013 --> 00:10:44.737
The world's companies,
governments and non-profits

00:10:44.761 --> 00:10:46.984
have delivery armies
that are fully capable

00:10:47.008 --> 00:10:49.391
of covering this relatively small area.

00:10:49.885 --> 00:10:52.010
We just lack the will.

00:10:52.871 --> 00:10:54.282
If we are willing,

00:10:54.306 --> 00:10:56.114
every one of us has a role to play.

00:10:57.878 --> 00:11:01.249
We first need more people to pursue
careers in human development,

00:11:01.273 --> 00:11:03.421
especially if you live
in a developing nation.

00:11:03.445 --> 00:11:06.931
We need more front line health workers,
teachers, farmer trainers,

00:11:06.955 --> 00:11:09.067
sales agents for life-improving goods.

00:11:09.397 --> 00:11:12.067
These are the delivery people
that dedicate their careers

00:11:12.091 --> 00:11:13.757
to improving the lives of others.

00:11:14.490 --> 00:11:16.443
But we also need a lot of support roles.

00:11:17.689 --> 00:11:20.540
These are roles available
at just my organization alone,

00:11:20.564 --> 00:11:22.054
and we're just one out of many.

00:11:22.357 --> 00:11:26.131
This may surprise you, but no matter
what your technical specialty,

00:11:26.155 --> 00:11:28.365
there is a role for you in this fight.

00:11:29.116 --> 00:11:32.463
And no matter how logistically possible
it is to end poverty,

00:11:32.487 --> 00:11:34.382
we need a lot more resources.

00:11:34.406 --> 00:11:36.250
This is our number one constraint.

00:11:36.769 --> 00:11:40.145
For private investors, we need
a big expansion of venture capital,

00:11:40.169 --> 00:11:43.893
private equity, working capital,
available in emerging markets.

00:11:44.435 --> 00:11:47.544
But there are also limits
to what private business can accomplish.

00:11:47.886 --> 00:11:51.537
Private businesses often struggle
to profitably serve the extreme poor,

00:11:51.855 --> 00:11:54.187
so philanthropy still has
a major role to play.

00:11:54.956 --> 00:11:57.509
Anybody can give,
but we need more leadership.

00:11:58.070 --> 00:12:00.017
We need more visionary philanthropists

00:12:00.041 --> 00:12:03.953
and global leaders who will take
problems in human development

00:12:03.977 --> 00:12:07.007
and lead humanity to wipe them
off the face of the planet.

00:12:08.234 --> 00:12:11.056
If you're interested in these ideas,
check out this website.

00:12:11.080 --> 00:12:12.788
We need more leaders.

00:12:14.132 --> 00:12:16.154
Humanity has put people on the moon.

00:12:16.178 --> 00:12:18.755
We've invented supercomputers
that fit into our pockets

00:12:18.779 --> 00:12:20.835
and connect us with anybody on the planet.

00:12:20.859 --> 00:12:24.141
We've run marathons
at a five-minute mile pace.

00:12:24.165 --> 00:12:26.608
We are an exceptional people.

00:12:27.780 --> 00:12:30.906
But we've left more than one billion
of our members behind.

00:12:31.443 --> 00:12:33.741
Until every girl like this one
has an opportunity

00:12:33.765 --> 00:12:35.663
to earn her full human potential,

00:12:36.005 --> 00:12:39.876
we have failed to become
a truly moral and just human race.

00:12:40.474 --> 00:12:43.230
Logistically speaking,
it's incredibly possible

00:12:43.254 --> 00:12:44.854
to end extreme poverty.

00:12:45.178 --> 00:12:48.060
We just need to deliver
proven goods and services

00:12:48.084 --> 00:12:49.281
to everybody.

00:12:49.623 --> 00:12:53.347
If we have the will, every one of us
has a role to play.

00:12:53.982 --> 00:12:56.871
Let's deploy our time, our careers,

00:12:56.895 --> 00:12:58.146
our collective wealth.

00:12:58.739 --> 00:13:01.475
Let us deliver an end to extreme poverty

00:13:01.499 --> 00:13:03.166
in this lifetime.

00:13:03.929 --> 00:13:05.080
Thank you.

00:13:05.104 --> 00:13:12.104
(Applause)

title: The secret to effective nonviolent resistance
transcript: War has been a part of my life since I can remember. I was born in Afghanistan, just six months after the Soviets invaded, and even though I was too young to understand what was happening, I had a deep sense of the suffering and the fear around me.Those early experiences had a major impact on how I now think about war and conflict. I learned that when people have a fundamental issue at stake, for most of them, giving in is not an option. For these types conflicts — when people's rights are violated, when their countries are occupied, when they're oppressed and humiliated — they need a powerful way to resist and to fight back. Which means that no matter how destructive and terrible violence is, if people see it as their only choice, they will use it. Most of us are concerned with the level of violence in the world. But we're not going to end war by telling people that violence is morally wrong. Instead, we must offer them a tool that's at least as powerful and as effective as violence.This is the work I do. For the past 13 years, I've been teaching people in some of the most difficult situations around the world how they can use nonviolent struggle to conduct conflict. Most people associate this type of action with Gandhi and Martin Luther King. But people have been using nonviolent action for thousands of years. In fact, most of the rights that we have today in this country — as women, as minorities, as workers, as people of different sexual orientations and citizens concerned with the environment — these rights weren't handed to us. They were won by people who fought for them and who sacrificed for them. But because we haven't learned from this history, nonviolent struggle as a technique is widely misunderstood.I met recently with a group of Ethiopian activists, and they told me something that I hear a lot. They said they'd already tried nonviolent action, and it hadn't worked. Years ago they held a protest. The government arrested everyone, and that was the end of that. The idea that nonviolent struggle is equivalent to street protests is a real problem. Because although protests can be a great way to show that people want change, on their own, they don't actually create change — at least change that is fundamental.(Laughter)Powerful opponents are not going to give people what they want just because they asked nicely ... or even not so nicely.(Laughter)Nonviolent struggle works by destroying an opponent, not physically, but by identifying the institutions that an opponent needs to survive, and then denying them those sources of power. Nonviolent activists can neutralize the military by causing soldiers to defect. They can disrupt the economy through strikes and boycotts. And they can challenge government propaganda by creating alternative media.There are a variety of methods that can be used to do this. My colleague and mentor, Gene Sharp, has identified 198 methods of nonviolent action. And protest is only one. Let me give you a recent example.Until a few months ago, Guatemala was ruled by corrupt former military officials with ties to organized crime. People were generally aware of this, but most of them felt powerless to do anything about it — until one group of citizens, just 12 regular people, put out a call on Facebook to their friends to meet in the central plaza, holding signs with a message: "Renuncia YA" — resign already. To their surprise, 30,000 people showed up. They stayed there for months as protests spread throughout the country. At one point, the organizers delivered hundreds of eggs to various government buildings with a message: "If you don't have the huevos" — the balls — "to stop corrupt candidates from running for office, you can borrow ours."(Laughter)(Applause)President Molina responded by vowing that he would never step down. And the activists realized that they couldn't just keep protesting and ask the president to resign. They needed to leave him no choice. So they organized a general strike, in which people throughout the country refused to work. In Guatemala City alone, over 400 businesses and schools shut their doors. Meanwhile, farmers throughout the country blocked major roads. Within five days, the president, along with dozens of other government officials, resigned already.(Applause)I've been greatly inspired by the creativity and bravery of people using nonviolent action in nearly every country in the world. For example, recently a group of activists in Uganda released a crate of pigs in the streets. You can see here that the police are confused about what to do with them.(Laughter)The pigs were painted the color of the ruling party. One pig was even wearing a hat, a hat that people recognized.(Laughter)Activists around the world are getting better at grabbing headlines, but these isolated actions do very little if they're not part of a larger strategy. A general wouldn't march his troops into battle unless he had a plan to win the war. Yet this is how most of the world's nonviolent movements operate. Nonviolent struggle is just as complex as military warfare, if not more. Its participants must be well-trained and have clear objectives, and its leaders must have a strategy of how to achieve those objectives.The technique of war has been developed over thousands of years with massive resources and some of our best minds dedicated to understanding and improving how it works. Meanwhile, nonviolent struggle is rarely systematically studied, and even though the number is growing, there are still only a few dozen people in the world who are teaching it. This is dangerous, because we now know that our old approaches of dealing with conflict are not adequate for the new challenges that we're facing.The US government recently admitted that it's in a stalemate in its war against ISIS. But what most people don't know is that people have stood up to ISIS using nonviolent action. When ISIS captured Mosul in June 2014, they announced that they were putting in place a new public school curriculum, based on their own extremist ideology. But on the first day of school, not a single child showed up. Parents simply refused to send them. They told journalists they would rather homeschool their children than to have them brainwashed.This is an example of just one act of defiance in just one city. But what if it was coordinated with the dozens of other acts of nonviolent resistance that have taken place against ISIS? What if the parents' boycott was part of a larger strategy to identify and cut off the resources that ISIS needs to function; the skilled labor needed to produce food; the engineers needed to extract and refine oil; the media infrastructure and communications networks and transportation systems, and the local businesses that ISIS relies on? It may be difficult to imagine defeating ISIS with action that is nonviolent. But it's time we challenge the way we think about conflict and the choices we have in facing it.Here's an idea worth spreading: let's learn more about where nonviolent action has worked and how we can make it more powerful, just like we do with other systems and technologies that are constantly being refined to better meet human needs. It may be that we can improve nonviolent action to a point where it is increasingly used in place of war. Violence as a tool of conflict could then be abandoned in the same way that bows and arrows were, because we have replaced them with weapons that are more effective. With human innovation, we can make nonviolent struggle more powerful than the newest and latest technologies of war. The greatest hope for humanity lies not in condemning violence but in making violence obsolete.Thank you.(Applause)
